tgt_text.2594: And the cup that was carried round did not hold more than a cotyla.
tgt_text.2595: And the second course consisted of lupins or beans, and sometimes fruits, such as pears, pomegranates, pulse, and sometimes, by Jove, dried figs.
tgt_text.2596: And all these circum- stances are detailed by Lycophron, in his satiric dramas, which he inscribed with the name of Menedemus, making his play a panegyric on the philosopher.

tgt_text.2599: After a temperate feast, a small-sized cup
tgt_text.2600: Is handed round with moderation due ;
tgt_text.2601: And conversation wise makes the dessert.
tgt_text.2603: At first, now, he was not thought much of, being called cynic and trifler by the Eretrians ;
tgt_text.2604: but subsequently, he was so much admired by his countrymen, that they entrusted him with the chief government of the state.
tgt_text.2605: And he was sent on embassies to Ptolemy and Lysimachus, and was greatly honoured everywhere.
tgt_text.2606: He was sent as envoy to Demetrius ;
tgt_text.2607: and, as the city used to pay him two hundred talents a year, lie persuaded him to remit fifty.
tgt_text.2608: And having been falsely accused to him, as having betrayed the city to Ptolemy, he defended himself from the charge, in a letter which begins thus :
tgt_text.2611: I hear that information has been laid before you concerning us.”
tgt_text.2612: And the tradition is, that a man of the name of Æschylus, who was one of the opposite party in the state, was in the habit of making these false charges.
tgt_text.2613: It is well known too that he was sent on a most important embassy to Demetrius, on the subject of Oropus, as Euphantus relates in his History.
tgt_text.2615: Antigonus was greatly attached to him, and professed himself his pupil;
tgt_text.2616: and when he defeated the barbarians, near Lysimachia, Menedemus drew up a decree for him, in simple terms, free from all flattery, which begins thus :
tgt_text.2618: The generals and councillors have determined, since king Antigonus has defeated the barbarians in battle, and has re- turned to his own kingdom, and since he has succeeded in all his measures according to his wishes, it has seemed good to the council and to the people."
tgt_text.2620: And from these circum- stances, and because of his friendship for him, as shown in other matters, he was suspected of betraying the city to him ;
tgt_text.2621: and being impeached by Aristodemus, he left the city, and re- turned to Oropus, and there took up his abode in the temple of Amphiaraus;
tgt_text.2622: and as some golden goblets which were there were lost, he was ordered to depart by a general vote of the Boeotians.
tgt_text.2623: Leaving Oropus, and being in a state of great despondency, he entered his country secretly;
tgt_text.2624: and taking with him his wife and daughters, be went to the court of Antigonus, and there died of a broken heart.
tgt_text.2625: But Heraclides gives an entirely different account of him ;
tgt_text.2626: saying, that while he was the chief councillor of the Eretrians, he more than once preserved the liberties of the city from those who would have brought in Demetrius the tyrant;
tgt_text.2627: so that he never could have betrayed the city to Antigonus, and the accusation must have been false ;
tgt_text.2628: and that he went to the court of Antigonus, and endeavoured to effect the deliverance of his country;
tgt_text.2629: and as he could make no impression on him, he fell into despondency, and starved himself for seven days, and so he died.
tgt_text.2630: And Antigonus of Carystus gives a similar account:
tgt_text.2631: and Persæus was the only man with whom he had an implacable quarrel ;
tgt_text.2632: for he thought that when Antigonus himself was willing to re-establish the democracy among the Eretrians for his sake, Persæus prevented him.
tgt_text.2633: And on this account Menedemus once attacked him at a banquet, saying many other things, and among them, " He may, indeed, be a philosopher, but be is the worst man that lives or that ever will live."

tgt_text.2642: I. PLATO was the son of Ariston and Perictione ;
tgt_text.2643: or Petone, and a citizen of Athens ;
tgt_text.2644: and his mother traced her family back to Solon;
tgt_text.2645: for Solon had a brother named Diopidas, who had a son named Critias, who was the father of Callœschrus, who was the father of that Critias who was one of the thirty tyrants, and also of Glaucon, who was the father of Charmides and Perictione.
tgt_text.2646: And she became the mother of Plato by her husband Ariston, Plato being the sixth in descent from Solon.
tgt_text.2647: And Solon traced his pedigree up to Neleus and Neptune.
tgt_text.2648: They say too that on the father's side, he was descended from Codrus, the son of Melanthus, and they too are said by Thra- sylus to derive their origin from Neptune.
tgt_text.2649: And Speusippus, in his book which is entitled the Funeral Banquet of Plato, and Clearchus in his Panegyric on Plato, and Anaxilides in the second book of his History of Philosophers, say that the report at Athens was that Perictione was very beautiful, and that Ariston endeavoured to violate her and did not succeed;
tgt_text.2650: and that he, after he had desisted from his violence saw a vision of Apollo in a dream, in consequence of which he ab- stained from approaching his wife till after her confinement.
tgt_text.2652: And Plato was born, as Apollodorus says in his Chronicles, in the eighty-eighth Olympiad, on the seventh day of the month Thargelion, on which day the people of Delos say that Apollo also was born.
tgt_text.2653: And he died, as Hermippus says, at a marriage feast, in the first year of the hundred and eighth Olympiad, having lived eighty-one years.

tgt_text.2655: He is then younger than Isocrates by six years;
tgt_text.2656: for Isocrates was born in the archonship of Lysimacbus, and Plato in that of Aminias, in which year Pericles died.
tgt_text.2658: And he was of the borough of Colytus, as Antileon tells us in his second book on Dates.
tgt_text.2659: And he was born, ao- cording to some writers, in Ægina, in the house of Phidiades the son of Thales, as Pharorinus affirms in his Universal History, as his father had been sent thither with several others as a settler, and returned again to Athens when the settlers were driven out by the Lacedaemonians, who came to the as- sistance of the Æginetans.
tgt_text.2660: And he served the office of choregus at Athens, when Dion was at the expense of the spectacle exhibited, as Theodorus relates in the eighth book of his Philosophical Conservations.

tgt_text.2702: He combined the principles of the schools of Hera- clitus, and Pythagoras and Socrates ;

tgt_text.2705: and on politics, according to that of Socrates.

tgt_text.2749: On account of which Plato used to say, that those who wished to become acquainted with the principles of everything, ought first of all to divide the ideas as he calls them, separately, such as similarity, and unity, and multitude, and magnitude, and stationariness, and motion.
tgt_text.2750: And secondly, that they ought to form a notion of the honourable and the good, and the just, and things of that sort, by themselves, apart from other considerations.
tgt_text.2751: And thirdly, that they ought to ascertain the character of such ideas as are relative to one another, such as knowledge, or magnitude, or au- thority;
tgt_text.2752: considering that the things which come under our notice from partaking of their nature, have the same names that they have.
tgt_text.2753: I mean that one calls that just which partakes of the just;
tgt_text.2754: and that beautiful which partakes of the beautiful.
tgt_text.2755: And each of these primary species is eternal, and is to be understood by the intellect, and is not subject to the influence of external circumstances.
tgt_text.2756: On which account he says, that ideas exist in nature as models;
tgt_text.2757: and that all other things are like them, and, as it were, copies of them.

tgt_text.2807: And Plato made three voyages to Sicily, first of all for the purpose of seeing the island and the craters of volcanoes, when Dionysius, the son of Hermocrates, being the tyrant of Sicily, pressed him earnestly to come and see him;
tgt_text.2808: and he, conversing about tyranny, and saying that that is not the best government which is advantageous for one individual alone, unless that individual is pre-eminent in virtue, had a quarrel with Dionysius, who got angry, and said, " Your words are those of an old dotard."
tgt_text.2809: And Plato replied, " And your language is that of a tyrant."
tgt_text.2810: And on this the tyrant became very indignant, and at first was inclined to put him to death;
tgt_text.2811: but afterwards, being appeased by Deni and Aristimenes, he forebore to do that, but gave him to Pollis, the Lacedaemonian, who happened to have come to him on an embassy just at that time, to sell as a slave.
tgt_text.2812: And he took him to Ægina and sold him;
tgt_text.2813: and Charmander, the son of Charmandrides, instituted a capital prosecution against him, in accordance with the law which was in force, in the island of Ægina, that the first Athenian who landed on the island should be put to death without a trial;
tgt_text.2814: and he himself was the person who had originally proposed that law, as Pharorinus says, in his Universal History.
tgt_text.2815: But when some one said, though he said it only in joke, that it was a phi- losopher who had landed, the people released him.
tgt_text.2816: But some say that he was brought into the assembly and watched ;
tgt_text.2817: and that he did not say a word, but stood prepared to submit to whatever might befall him ;
tgt_text.2818: and that they determined not to put him to death, but to sell him after the fashion of prisoners of war.
tgt_text.2819: And it happened by chance that Anniceris, the Cyrenean, was present, who ransomed him for twenty minæ, or, as others say, for thirty, and sent him to Athens, to his companions, and they immediately sent Anniceris his money:
tgt_text.2820: but he refused to receive it, saying that they were not the only people in the world who were entitled to have a regard for Plato.
tgt_text.2821: Some writers again say, that it was Deni who sent the money, and that he did not refuse it, but bought him the garden in the Academy.
tgt_text.2822: And with respect to Pollis it is said that he was defeated by Chabrias, and that he was afterwards drowned in Helia, in consequence of the anger of the deity at his treatment of this philosopher.
tgt_text.2823: And this is the story told by Pharorinus in the first book of his Commentaries.
tgt_text.2824: Dionysius, however, did not remain quiet;
tgt_text.2825: but when he had heard what had happened he wrote to Plato not to speak ill of him, and he wrote back in reply that he had not leisure enough to think at all of Dionysius.
tgt_text.2827: But he went a second time to Sicily to the younger Dionysius, and asked him for some land and for some men whom he might make live according to his own theory of a constitution.
tgt_text.2828: And Dionysius promised to give him some, but never did it.
tgt_text.2829: And some say that he was in danger.

tgt_text.2831: but that Archytas, the Pythagorean, wrote a letter to Dionvsius, and begged Plato off and sent him back safe to Athens.
tgt_text.2832: And the letter is as follows :
tgt_text.2834: All of us who are the friends of Plato, have sent to you Lamiscus and Photidas, to claim of you this philosopher in accordance with the agreement which you made with us.
tgt_text.2835: And it is right that you should recollect the eagerness which you had to see him, when you pressed us all to secure Plato's visit to you, promising to provide for him, and to treat him hospitably in every respect, and to ensure his safety both while he remained with you, and when he departed.
tgt_text.2836: Remember this too that you were very delighted indeed at his arrival, and that you expressed great pleasure at the time, such as you never did on anyother occasion.
tgt_text.2837: And if any unpleasantness has arisen between you, you ought to behave with humanity, and restore the man unhurt;
tgt_text.2838: for by so doing you will act justly, and do us a favour."
tgt_text.2840: The third time that he went to Sicily was for the purpose of reconciling Dion to Dionysius.
tgt_text.2841: And as he could not succeed he returned back to his own country, having lost his labour.
tgt_text.2843: And in his own country he did not meddle with state affairs, although he was a politician as far as his writings went.
tgt_text.2844: And the reason was, that the people were accustomed to a form of government and constitution different from what he approved of.

tgt_text.2846: but that he, when he had ascertained that they would not con- sent to an equality of rights, refused to go thither.

tgt_text.2854: He was the first author who wrote treatises in the form of dialogues, as Pharorinus tells us in the eighth book of his Universal History.
tgt_text.2855: And he was also the first person who introduced the analytical method of investigation, which he taught to Leodamus of Thasos.
tgt_text.2856: He was also the first person in philosophy who spoke of antipodes, and elements, and dia- lectics, and actions (ποιήματα), and oblong numbers, and plane surfaces, and the providence of God.
tgt_text.2857: He was likewise the first of the philosophers who contradicted the assertion of Ly- sias, the son of Cephalus, setting it out word for word in his Phædrus.
tgt_text.2858: And he was also the first person who examined the subject of grammatical knowledge scientifically.
tgt_text.2859: And as he argued against almost every one who had lived before his time, it is often asked why he has never mentioned Democritus.

tgt_text.2908: and also to Dion, whom we have already men- tioned.
tgt_text.2909: And some say that he was also attached to Phædrus, and that the following epigrams which ho wrote upon them are evidences of the love he felt for them :
tgt_text.2911: My Aster, you're gazing on the stars (ἀστέρες),
tgt_text.2912: Would that I were the heavens, that so I might Gaze in return with many eyes on thee.
tgt_text.2915: Aster, you while among the living shone, The morning star.
tgt_text.2916: But now that you are dead, You beam like Hesperus in the shades below.

tgt_text.2919: Once, at their birth, the fates did destine tears
tgt_text.2920: To be the lot of all the Trojan women, And Hecuba, their Queen-to you, 0 Dion, As the deserved reward for glorious deeds, They gave extensive and illustrious hopes.
tgt_text.2921: And now you lie beneath your native soil;
tgt_text.2922: Honoured by all your countrymen, 0 Dion, And loved by me with ardent, lasting love.

tgt_text.2926: Now when Alexis is no longer aught, Say only how beloved, how fair he was, And every one does turn his eyes at once.

tgt_text.2931: — I have a mistress fair from Colophon, Archianassa, on whose very wrinkles Sits genial love :
tgt_text.2932: hard must have been the fate, Of him who met her earliest blaze of beauty, Surely he must have been completely scorched.

tgt_text.2975: Plato also was a great enemy of Aristippus ;
tgt_text.2976: accordingly, he speaks ill of him in his book on the Soul, and says that he was not with Socrates when he died, though he was in Ægina, at no great distance.
tgt_text.2977: He also had a great rivalry with Æschi- nes, for that he had been held in great esteem by Dionysius, and afterwards came to want, and was despised by Plato, but supported by Aristippus.
tgt_text.2978: And Idomeneus says, that the speech which Plato attributes to Crito in the prison, when he coun- selled Socrates to make his escape, was really delivered by Æschines, but that Plato attributed it to Crito because of his dislike to the other.

tgt_text.2990: A story is told, that Plato, having seen a man play- ing at dice, reproached him for it, and that he said he was playing for a trifle ;
tgt_text.2992: But the habit," rejoined Plato, " is not a trifle."
tgt_text.2993: On one occasion he was asked whether there would be any monument of him, as of his predecessors in philosophy ?
tgt_text.2994: and he answered, " A man must first make a name, and the monu- ment will follow."
tgt_text.2995: Once, when Xenocrates came into his house, he desired him to scourge one of his slaves for him, for that he himself could not do it because he was in a passion ;
tgt_text.2996: and that at another time he said to one of his slaves, " I should beat you if I were not in a passion."
tgt_text.2997: Having got on horseback he dismounted again immediately, saying that he was afraid that he should be infected with horse-pride.
tgt_text.2998: He used to advise people who got drunk to look in the glass, and then they would abandon their unseemly habit;
tgt_text.2999: and he said that it was never decorous to drink to the degree of drunkenness, except at the festivals of the God who had given men wine.
tgt_text.3000: He also dis- approved of much sleeping :
tgt_text.3001: accordingly in his Laws he says, “ No one while sleeping is good for anything."
tgt_text.3002: Another say- ing of his was, " That the pleasantest of all things to hear was the truth;
tgt_text.3003: but others report this saying thus, " That the sweetest of all things was to speak truth."
tgt_text.3004: And of truth he speaks thus in his Laws, " Truth, my friend, is a beautiful and a durable thing;
tgt_text.3005: but it is not easy to persuade men of this fact.
tgt_text.3007: He used also to wish to leave a memorial of himself behind, either in the hearts of his friends, or in his books.

tgt_text.3011: And he died in the manner we have already mentioned, in the thirteenth year of the reign of Philip of Macedon, as Pharorinus mentions in the third book of his Commentaries;

tgt_text.3014: implying that he had died of that disease.
tgt_text.3016: He was buried in the Academy, where he spent the greater part of his time in the practice of philosophy, from which his was called the Academic school;
tgt_text.3017: and his funeral was attended by all the pupils of that sect.
tgt_text.3018: And he made his will in the following terms :
tgt_text.3020: Plato left these things, and has bequeathed them as follows :
tgt_text.3022: The farm in the district of the Hephæstiades, bounded on the north by the road from the temple of the Cephiciades, and on the south by the temple of Hercules, which is in the district of the Hephæstiades;
tgt_text.3023: and on the east by the estate of Archestratus the Phreanian, and on the west by the farm of Philip the Challidian, shall be incapable of being sold or alienated, but shall belong to my son Ademantus as far as possible.
tgt_text.3024: And so likewise shall my farm in the district of the Eiresides, which I bought of Calli- machus, which is bounded on the north by the property of Eurymedon the Myrrhinusian, on the south by that of Demostratus of Xypeta, on the east by that of Eurymedcn the Myrrhinusian, and on the west by the Cephisus ;
tgt_text.3025: — I also leave him three mince of silver, a silver goblet weighing a hundred and sixty-five drachms, a cup weighing forty-five drachms, a golden ring, and a golden ear-ring, weighing together four drachms and three obols.

tgt_text.3028: My slaves Sychon, Bictas, Apolloniades, and Dionysius, I bequeath to my son ;
tgt_text.3029: and I also give him all my furniture, of which Demetrius has a catalogue.

tgt_text.3060: His disciples were, Speusippus the Athenian, Zenocrates of Chalcedon, Aristotle the Stagirite, Philip of Opus, Histiæus of Perinthus, Dion of Syracuse, Amyclus of Heraclea, Erastus and Coriscus of Sceptos, Timolaus of Cyzicus, Eudon of Lampsacus, Pithon and Heraclides of Æmus, Hippothales and Callippus, Athenians, Demetrius of Amphipolis, Heraclides of Pontus, and numbers of others, among whom there were also two women, Lasthenea of Mantinea, and Axiothea of Phlius, who used even to wear man's clothes, as we are told by Dicsearchus.
