tgt_text.3067: But as you, 0 lady, are rightly very much attached to Plato, and as you are very fond of hunting out in every quarter all the doctrines of the philosopher with great eager- ness, I have thought it necessary to subjoin an account of the general character of his lectures, and of the arrangement of his dialogues, and of the method of his inductive argument;
tgt_text.3068: going back to their elements and first principles as far as I could, so that the collection of anecdotes concerning his life which I have been able to make, may not be curtailed by the omission of any statement as to his doctrines.
tgt_text.3069: For it would be like sending owls to Athens, as the proverb is, if I were to descend to particular details.
tgt_text.3070: They say now, that Zeno, the Eleatic, was the first person who composed essays in the form of dialogue.
tgt_text.3071: But Aristotle, in the first book of his treatise on Poets, says that Alexander, a native of Styra, or Teos, did so before him, as Phavorinus also says in his Commentaries.
tgt_text.3072: But it seems to me that Plato gave this kind of writing the last polish, and that he has therefore, a just right to the first honour, not only as the improver, but also as inventor of that kind of writing, Now, the dialogue is a discourse carried on by way of question and answer, on some one of the subjects with which philosophy is conversant, or with which statesmanship is concerned, with a becoming attention to the characters of the persons who are introduced as speakers, and with a careful selection of language governed by the same consideration.
tgt_text.3073: And dialectics is the art of conversing, by means of which we either overturn or establish the proposition contended for, by means of the ques- tions and answers which are put in the mouths of the parties conversing.
tgt_text.3074: Now, of the Platonic discourse there are two characteristics discernible on the very surface;
tgt_text.3075: one fitted for guiding, the other for investigating.
tgt_text.3076: The first of these has two subordinate species, one specula- tive, the other practical;
tgt_text.3077: and of these two again, the speculative is divided into the natural and the logical, and the practical into the ethical and the political.
tgt_text.3078: Again, the kind fitted for investigating has also two primary divisions with their separate characteristics, one object of which is simply practice, the other being also disputatious :
tgt_text.3079: and the first of these two is again subdivided into two;
tgt_text.3080: one of which may be compared to the art of the midwife, and the other is at it were tentative ;
tgt_text.3081: the disputatious one is also divided into the demonstrative and the distinctive.
tgt_text.3082: But we are not unaware that some writers distinguish the various dialogues in a different manner from what we do.
tgt_text.3083: For they say that some of them are dramatic, and others narrative, and others of a mixed nature.
tgt_text.3084: But they, in this division, are classifying the dialogues in a theatrical rather than in a philo- sophical manner.
tgt_text.3085: Some of the dialogues also refer to subjects of natural philosophy, such as the Timæus.
tgt_text.3086: Of the logical class, there are the Politics, the Cratylus, the Parmenides, and the Sophist.
tgt_text.3087: Of the ethical kind there is the defence of Socrates, the Crito, the Phædo, the Phsedrus, the Banquet, the Menexenus, the Clitiphon, the Epistles, the Philebus, the Hipparchus.
tgt_text.3089: Of the political class there is the Republic, the Laws, the Minos, the Epinomis, and the Atlanticus.
tgt_text.3090: Of the midwife description we have the two Alcibiades's, the Theages, the Lysis, the Laches.
tgt_text.3091: Of the tentative kind, there is the Euthyphro, the Meno, the Ion, the Charmides, and the Theætetus.
tgt_text.3092: Of the demonstrative description, we have the Protagoras, and of the distinctive class the Euthydemus, the two Hippias's, and the Gorgias.
tgt_text.3093: And this is enough to say about the dialogues as to what they are, and what their different kinds are.
tgt_text.3095: But since there is also a great division of opinion respecting them, from some people asserting that in them Plato dogmatizes in a positive manner, while others deny this, we had better also touch upon this part of the question.
tgt_text.3096: Now, dogmatizing is laying down dogmas, just as legislating is making laws.
tgt_text.3097: But the word dogma is used in two senses;
tgt_text.3098: to mean both that which we think, and opinion itself.
tgt_text.3099: Now of these, that which we think is the proposition, and opinion is the conception by which we entertain it in our minds.
tgt_text.3100: Plato then explains the opinions which he entertains himself, and refutes false ones;
tgt_text.3101: and about doubtful matters he suspends his judgment.
tgt_text.3102: His opinions of matters as they appear to him he puts into the mouth of four persons, Socrates, Timæus, an Athenian poet, and an Eleatic stranger.
tgt_text.3103: But the strangers are not, as some people have supposed, Plato and Parmenides, but certain nameless imaginary characters.
tgt_text.3104: Since Plato asserts as undeniable axioms all the opinions which he puts into the mouth of Socrates or Timseus.
tgt_text.3105: But when he is refuting false propositions, he introduces such characters as Thrasymachus, and Callicles, and Polus, and Gorgias, and Protagoras, Hippi- astro, and Euthydemus, and men of that stamp.
tgt_text.3106: But when he is demonstrating anything, then he chiefly uses the indue- tive form of argument, and that too not of one kind only, but of two.
tgt_text.3107: For induction is an argument, which by means of some admitted truths establishes naturally other truths which resemble them.
tgt_text.3108: But there are two kinds of induction ;
tgt_text.3109: the one proceeding from contraries, the other from consequents.
tgt_text.3110: Now, the one which proceeds from contraries, is one in which from the answer given, whatever that answer may be, the con- trary of the principle indicated in the question must follow.
tgt_text.3112: My father is either a different person from your father, or he is the same person.
tgt_text.3113: If now your father is a different person from my father, then as he is a different person from a father, he cannot be a father.
tgt_text.3114: If, on the other hand, he is the same person as my father, then, since he is the same person as my father, he must be my father.
tgt_text.3115: And again, if man be not an animal, he must be either a stone or a piece of wood ;
tgt_text.3116: but he is not a stone or a piece of wood, for he is a living animal, and capable of independent motion.
tgt_text.3118: But, if he is an animal, and a dog or an ox is likewise an animal, then man must be an animal, and a dog, and an ox. —
tgt_text.3119: This then is the method of induction in contradiction and contention, which Plato was accustomed to employ, not for the purpose of establishing principles of his own, but with the object of refuting the arguments of others.
tgt_text.3120: Now, the inductive kind of argument drawn from conse- quents is of a twofold character.
tgt_text.3121: The one proving a particular opinion by an admitted fact of an equally particular nature;
tgt_text.3122: or else going from particulars to generals.
tgt_text.3123: And the first of these two divisions is the oratorical one, the second the dialectic one.
tgt_text.3124: As for instance, in the former kind the ques- tion is whether this person has committed a murder;
tgt_text.3125: the proof is that he was found at the time covered with blood.
tgt_text.3126: But this is the oratorical method of employing the induction ;
tgt_text.3127: since oratory is conversant about particulars, and does not concern itself about generals.
tgt_text.3128: For its object is not to ascer- tain abstract justice, but only particular justice.
tgt_text.3129: The other is the dialectic kind, the general proposition having been established by particular ones.
tgt_text.3130: As for instance, the question is whether the soul is immortal, and whether the living con- sist of those who have once been dead;
tgt_text.3131: and this proposition Plato establishes in his book on the Soul, by a certain general proposition, that contraries arise out of contraries ;
tgt_text.3132: and this identical general proposition is established by certain particular ones.
tgt_text.3133: As, for instance, that sleep follows on waking, and waking from sleeping, and the greater from the less, and reversely the less from the greater.
tgt_text.3134: And this kind of induction he used to employ for the establishment of his own opinions.
tgt_text.3136: Anciently, in tragedy, it was only the chorus who did the whole work of the play;
tgt_text.3137: but subsequently, Thespis introduced one actor for the sake of giving the chorus some rest, and Æschylus added a second, and Sophocles a third, and so they made tragedy complete.
tgt_text.3138: So in the same manner, philosophical discourse was originally uniform, con- cerning itself solely about natural philosophy;
tgt_text.3139: then Socrates added to it a second character, the ethical:
tgt_text.3140: and Plato a third, the dialectic:
tgt_text.3141: and so he brought philosophy to perfection.
tgt_text.3143: But Thrasybulus says that he published his dia- logues as the dramatic poets published their tetralogies.
tgt_text.3144: For, they contended with four plays, (and at four festivals, the Dionysiac, the Lenæau, the Panathenæan, and the Chytri), one of which was a satiric drama, and the whole four plays were called a tetralogy.
tgt_text.3145: Now, people say, the whole of his genuine dialogues amount to fifty-six;
tgt_text.3146: the treatise on the Republic being divided into ten books, (which Phavorinus, in the second book of his Universal History, says may be found almost entire in the Contradictions of Protagoras), and that on Laws into twelve.
tgt_text.3147: And there are nine tetralogies, if we consider the Republic as occupying the place of one book, and the Laws of another.
tgt_text.3148: He arranges, therefore, the first tetra- logy of these dialogues which have a common subject, wishing to show what sort of life that of the philosopher may have been.
tgt_text.3149: And he uses two titles for each separate book, taking one from the name of the principal speaker, and the other from the subject.
tgt_text.3150: This tetralogy then, which is the first, is commenced by the Euthyphron, or what is Holy;
tgt_text.3151: and that dialogue is a tentative one.
tgt_text.3152: The second is the Defence of Socrates, a moral one.
tgt_text.3153: The third is the Criton, or What is to be done, a moral one.
tgt_text.3154: The fourth is the Phædo, or the Dialogue on the Soul, a moral one.
tgt_text.3155: The second tetralogy is that of which the first piece is the Cratylus, or the correctness of names, a logical one.
tgt_text.3156: The Mesetetus, or Knowledge, a tentative one.
tgt_text.3157: The Sophist, or a dialogue on the Existent, a logical one.
tgt_text.3158: The Statesman, or a dialogue of Monarchy, a logical one.
tgt_text.3159: The first dialogue in the third tetralogy is the Parmenides, or a dialogue of Ideas, a logical one.
tgt_text.3160: The second is the Philelus, or on Pleasure, a moral one.
tgt_text.3161: The Banquet, or on the Good, a moral one.
tgt_text.3162: The Phædrus, or on Love, a moral one.
tgt_text.3163: The fourth tetralogy opens with the Alcibiades, or a treatise on the Nature of Man, a midwife-like work.
tgt_text.3164: The second Alcibiades, or on Prayer, a piece of the same charac- ter.
tgt_text.3165: The Hipparchus, or on the Love of Gain, a moral one.
tgt_text.3166: The Rival Lovers, or a treatise on Philosophy, a moral one.
tgt_text.3167: The first dialogue in the fifth is the Theages, or another treatise on Philosophy, another midwife-like work.
tgt_text.3168: The Charmides, or on Temperance, a tentative esssay.
tgt_text.3169: The Laches, or on Manly Courage, midwife-like.
tgt_text.3170: The Lysis, or a dissertation on Friendship, also midwife-like.
tgt_text.3171: The sixth tetralogy commences with the Euthydemus, or the Disputatious Man, a distinctive dialogue.
tgt_text.3172: Then comes the Protagoras, or the Sophists, a demonstrative one.
tgt_text.3173: The Gorgias, or a dissertation on Rhetoric, another distinctive one.
tgt_text.3174: And the Mono, or on Virtue, a tentative dialogue.
tgt_text.3175: The seventh begins with the two Hippias's.
tgt_text.3176: The first being a dissertation on the Beautiful, the second one on Falsehood, both distinctive.
tgt_text.3177: The third is the Ion, or a dissertation on the Iliad, a tentative one.
tgt_text.3178: The fourth is the Menexenus, or the Funeral Oration, a moral one.
tgt_text.3179: The first dialogue in the eighth is the Clitophon, or the Exhortation, a moral piece.
tgt_text.3180: Then comes the Republic, or the treatise on Justice, a political one.
tgt_text.3181: The Timæus, or a dis- sertation on Nature, a dialogue on Natural Philosophy.
tgt_text.3182: And the Critias, or Atlanticus, a moral oneThe ninth begins with the Minos, or a treatise on Law, a political work.
tgt_text.3183: The Laws, or a dissertation on Legislation, another political work.
tgt_text.3184: The Epinomis, or the Nocturnal Conversation, or the Philosopher, a third political one.
tgt_text.3186: And this last tetralogy is completed by thirteen epistles, all moral;
tgt_text.3187: to which is prefixed as a motto, εὖ πϱάττειν, just as Epicurus inscribed on his εὖ διάγειν, and Cleon on his χαιϱειν.
tgt_text.3188: They are, one letter to Aristodemns, two to Archytas, four to Dionysius, one to Hermeias, Erastus, and Coriscus, one to Leodamas, one to Dion, one to Perdiccas, and two to the friends of Dion.
tgt_text.3190: And this is the way in which some people divide his works.
tgt_text.3191: But others, among whom is Aristophanes, the grammarian, arrange his dialogues in trilogies ;
tgt_text.3192: and they make the first to consist of the Republic, the Timæus and the Critias.
tgt_text.3193: The second of the Sophist, the Statesman, the Cratylus.
tgt_text.3194: The third of the Laws, the Minos, the Epinomis.
tgt_text.3195: The fourth of the Theætetus, the Euthypbro, the Defence of Socrates.
tgt_text.3196: The fifth of the Crito, the Phædo, the Epistles.
tgt_text.3197: And the rest they arrange singly and independently, without any regular order.
tgt_text.3198: And some authors, as has been said already, place the Republic at the head of his works :
tgt_text.3199: others begin with the Greater Alcibiades :
tgt_text.3201: some with the Euthyphro, others with the Clitophon ;
tgt_text.3202: some with the Timæus, some with the Phædrus, others again with the Theætetus.
tgt_text.3203: Many make the Defence of Socrates the first piece.
tgt_text.3204: There are some dialogues attributed to him which are confessedly spurious.
tgt_text.3215: Of which the Alcyon is believed to be the work of a man named Leon ;
tgt_text.3216: as Phavorinus tells us in the seventh book of his Commentaries.
tgt_text.3218: But he employs a great variety of terms in order to render his philosophical system unintelligible to the ignorant.
tgt_text.3219: In his phraseology he considers wisdom as the knowledge of things which can be understood by the intellect, and which have a real existence :
tgt_text.3220: which has the Gods for its object, and the soul as unconnected with the body.
tgt_text.3221: He also, with a peculiarity of expression, calls wisdom also philosophy, which he explains as a desire for divine wisdom.
tgt_text.3222: But wisdom and experience are also used by him in their common accepta- tion ;
tgt_text.3223: as, for instance, when he calls an artisan wise (σοϕὸς).
tgt_text.3224: He also uses the same words in different senses at different times.
tgt_text.3225: Accordingly he uses ϕαυ̃λος in the sense of ἁπλου̃ς, simple, in which meaning also the word occurs in Euripides, in the Licymonius, where the poet speaks of Hercules in the following terms :
tgt_text.3226: - Mean looking (φαυ̃λος), rude, virtuous in great affairs, Measuring all wisdom by its last results, A hero unrefined in speech.
tgt_text.3227: But Plato uses the word sometimes even for what is beautiful;
tgt_text.3228: and sometimes for small and insignificant;
tgt_text.3229: and very often he uses different words to express the same idea.
tgt_text.3230: Accordingly, besides the word ἰδέα, for a class, he uses also εἶδος, and γένος, and and ἀϱχὴ, and αἴτιον.
tgt_text.3231: Sometimes he uses opposite expressions for the same thing;
tgt_text.3232: accordingly, he says that it is an object of sensation that exists, while at other times he says it is that which does not exist;
tgt_text.3233: speaking of it as existing because of its origin, and as non-existent with reference to its continual changes.
tgt_text.3234: Then again, he defines his ἰδέα, as something which is neither moving nor stationary, at one time calling the same thing, at another time one thing, at a third time many things,
tgt_text.3235: And he is in the habit of doing this in many instances.
tgt_text.3236: And the explanation of his arguments is three-fold.
tgt_text.3237: For first of all, it is necessary to explain what each thing that is said is;
tgt_text.3238: secondly, on what account it is said, whether because of its bearing on the principal point, or figuratively, and whether it is said for the purpose of establishing an opinion of his own, or of refuting the arguments brought forward by the other party to the conversation ;
tgt_text.3239: and thirdly, whether it has been said truly.
tgt_text.3241: But since there are some particular marks put in his books, we must also say something about them.
tgt_text.3242: x indicates peculiar expressions and figures of speech, and generally any peculiarities of Plato's style.
tgt_text.3243: When doubled it points to the doctrines and peculiar opinions of Plato;
tgt_text.3244: ※ when dotted all round, points to some select bits of beautiful writing.
tgt_text.3245: When doubled and dotted it indicates corrections of some passages.
tgt_text.3246: A dotted obelus indicates hasty disapprovals.
tgt_text.3247: An inverted sigma dotted all round points out passages which may be taken in a double sense, and transpositions of words.
tgt_text.3248: The Ceraunium* indicates a connection of philosophical ideas.
tgt_text.3249: An asterisk points out an agreement in doctrine.
tgt_text.3250: And an obelus marks the rejection of the expression or of the passage.
tgt_text.3251: These then are the marginal marks which occur, and the writings of which Plato was the author :
tgt_text.3252: -which, as Antigonus the Carystian says, in his treatise on Zeno, when they had been but lately published, brought in some gain to the posses- sors, if any one else was desirous of reading them.
tgt_text.3254: These now were his chief opinions.
tgt_text.3255: He affirmed that the soul was immortal and clothed in many bodies successively, and that its first principle was number, and that the first principle of the body was geometry.
tgt_text.3256: And he defined it as an abstract idea of spirit diffused in every direction.
tgt_text.3257: He said also, that it was self-moving and threefold.
tgt_text.3258: For that that part of it which was capable of reasoning was situated in the head, that that portion which was affected by passion was seated around the heart, and that which was appetitive was placed around the navel and the liver.
tgt_text.3259: And that it is placed in the middle of the body, and embraces it at the same time in all its parts, and that it consists of elements ;
tgt_text.3260: and that when it is divided according to harmonic intervals it forms two connected circles ;
tgt_text.3261: of which the inner circle is divided into six portions, and makes in all seven circles ;
tgt_text.3262: and that this is placed on the left hand of the diameter, and situated in the interior.
tgt_text.3263: But the other is on the right hand of the same line ;
tgt_text.3264: on which account, and because it is one only, it is the superior of the two.
tgt_text.3265: For the other is divided internally;
tgt_text.3266: and this too, is the circle of that which is always the same ;
tgt_text.3267: the other, the circle of that which is changeable and different.
tgt_text.3268: And the one he says is the motion of the soul, but the other is the motion of the universe and of the planets.
tgt_text.3269: On the other side, the division of the circles from the centre to the extremities, being harmoniously appropriated to the essence of the soul, the one knows existing things and esta- blishes harmony between them, because it is itself composed of harmonious elements.
tgt_text.3270: The circle of what is changeable, engenders opinion by its regular movements;
tgt_text.3271: but the circle of that which is always the same produces knowledge.
tgt_text.3273: Plato lays down two primary causes or principles of all things, God and matter, which he also calls mind, and the cause.
tgt_text.3274: And he defines matter as something without shape and without limitation, and says that from it all concre- tions arise.
tgt_text.3275: He affirms also that as it was moving about at random, it was brought by God into one settled place, as God thought order better than disorder;
tgt_text.3276: and that this nature is divided into four elements, fire, water, air, and earth, of which the world itself and everything in it was made.
tgt_text.3277: But he says that the earth is the only thing that is unchangeable, as he considers the cause to be the difference of the figures of which it is composed;
tgt_text.3278: for he says that the figures of the others are homogeneous ;
tgt_text.3279: for that they are all composed equally of scalene triangles.
tgt_text.3280: The figure of the earth, however, is peculiar to itself;
tgt_text.3281: for the element of fire is a pyramid ;
tgt_text.3284: and of the earth, a cube;
tgt_text.3285: owing to which these things cannot be changed into earth, nor earth into them.
tgt_text.3286: He teaches also that these elements are not separated so as to occupy each a peculiar and distinct place;
tgt_text.3287: for the spherical motion collects and compresses all the small things towards the centre, and the small things separate the great ones, on which ac- count the species, as they change, do also change their positions.
tgt_text.3288: Moreover he asserts that the world is one, and has been pro- duced, since it has been made by God, in such a manner as to be an object of sensation.
tgt_text.3289: And he considers it endowed with life, because that which is so endowed, is superior to that which is not, and it must be the production of the most excellent pro- ducer.
tgt_text.3290: It is also one, and illimitable;
tgt_text.3291: because the model after which it was made was one ;
tgt_text.3292: and it is spherical, because its creator was of that form;
tgt_text.3293: for it also contains all other animals, and God who made it comprises all forms.
tgt_text.3294: And it is smooth, and has no instruments whatever all round it, because it has no need of any.
tgt_text.3295: But the whole world remains imperishable, because it cannot be resolved into God ;
tgt_text.3296: and God is the cause of universal production, because it is the nature of the good to be productive of good;
tgt_text.3297: and the best is the cause of the production of the heaven;
tgt_text.3298: for the best of all productions can have no other cause than the best of all intelligible existences.
tgt_text.3299: And since God is of that character, and since heaven resembles the best, inasmuch as it is at least the most beautiful of all things, it cannot be like anything else that is produced, except God.
tgt_text.3300: He also teaches that the world consists of fire, water, air, and earth ;
tgt_text.3301: of fire, in order that it may be visible;
tgt_text.3302: of earth, in order that it may be firm ;
tgt_text.3303: of water and air, that it may not be destitute of proportion;
tgt_text.3304: for two middle terms are indispensable to keep the solid bodies in clue proportion to one another, and to realize the unity of the whole.
tgt_text.3305: In short, the world is formed of all the elements together, in order that it may be perfect and imperishable.
tgt_text.3306: Again, time is the image of eternity;
tgt_text.3308: but the motion of the heaven is time;
tgt_text.3309: for day, and night, and the months, and all such divisions, are parts of time, on which account there could be no such thing as time apart from the nature of the world ;
tgt_text.3310: for time existed contempo- raucously and simultaneously with the world.
tgt_text.3311: And it was with reference to time that the sun, and the moon, and the planets were made ;
tgt_text.3312: and it was in order that the number of the seasons might be manifest, and that the animals might partake of num- ber, that God kindled the light of the sun;
tgt_text.3313: and that the moon was above the circle of the earth, and that the sun was next to it, and in the still higher circles were the planets.
tgt_text.3314: And that the universe was animated, because it was altogether bound up in animated motion, and that the race of all other animals was produced in order that the world might be made perfect, and re- sembling an animal such as could be comprehended by intellect.
tgt_text.3315: Since then God had life, the heaven also must have life;
tgt_text.3316: and the Gods are to a great extent composed of fire.
tgt_text.3317: And there are three other races of animals, those which fly in the air;
tgt_text.3318: those which lives in the water;
tgt_text.3319: those which walk in the earth.
tgt_text.3320: The oldest of all the deities in heaven is the Earth;
tgt_text.3321: she was formed in order to be the dispenser of night and day;
tgt_text.3322: and as she is placed in the centre, she is constantly in motion around the .centre.
tgt_text.3323: And since there are two efficient causes, some things must, he says, be affirmed to exist in consequence of intellect, and some from some necessary cause.
tgt_text.3324: Now necessary causes are the air, fire, earth, and water, these not being real elements, but rather receptacles;
tgt_text.3325: and they too are formed of triangles in combination, and are resolvable into triangles;
tgt_text.3326: and their elements are the scalene triangle and the isosceles.
tgt_text.3327: These two before mentioned elements are the principles and causes of things, of which the models are God and matter, which last must necessarily be destitute of form, as is the case of other receptacles.
tgt_text.3328: And that the cause of these things was a necessary cause, -which, receiving the ideas, produced the substances;
tgt_text.3329: and was moved by the dissimilarity of its own power, and again by its motion compelled those things which were moved by it to move other things in their turn.
tgt_text.3330: But all these things were formerly moved without any reason or order;
tgt_text.3331: but after they began to form the world by their com- bination, they then received symmetry and regularity from God, according to the principles applicable to them;
tgt_text.3332: for the efficient causes, even before the creation of the heaven, were two in number.
tgt_text.3333: There was also a third, namely production;
tgt_text.3334: but these were not very evident, but rather traces than actual things, and quite devoid of regularity.
tgt_text.3335: But after the world was made, then they too assumed a regular form and arrange- ment ;
tgt_text.3336: but the heaven was made of all existing bodies.
tgt_text.3337: And Plato considers that God is incorporeal just as the soul is, and that it is owing to that that he is not affected by any destruction or external circumstances.
tgt_text.3338: And ideas, as we have said before, he defines as certain causes and principles, owing to which it is that such and such things are by nature what they are.
tgt_text.3340: On the subject of good and evil, these were his sen- timents :
tgt_text.3341: that the end was to become like God ;
tgt_text.3342: and that virtue was sufficient of herself for happiness, but nevertheless required the advantages of the body as instruments to work with;
tgt_text.3343: such as health, strength, the integrity of the senses, and things of that kind ;
tgt_text.3344: and also external advantages, such as riches, and noble birth, and glory.
tgt_text.3345: Still that the wise man would be not the less happy, even if destitute of these auxiliary circumstances;
tgt_text.3346: for he would enjoy the constitution of his country, and would marry, and would not transgress the es- tablished laws, and that he would legislate for his country, as well as he could under existing circumstances, unless he saw affairs in an unmanageable condition, in consequence of the excessive factiousness of the people.
tgt_text.3347: He thinks too that the Gods superintend all the affairs of men, and that there are such beings as daemons.
tgt_text.3348: And he was the first person who defined the notion of the honourable, as that which borders on the praise- worthy, and the logical, and the useful, and the becoming, and the expedient, all which things are combined with that which is suitable to, and in accordance with, nature.
tgt_text.3350: He also discussed in his dialogues the correctness of terms, so that he was the first person who reduced the science of giving correct answers, and putting correct questions to a system, which he himself used to satiety.
tgt_text.3352: In his dialogues he used to speak of justice as a kind of law of God, as being of influence sufficient to excite men to act justly, in order to avoid suffering punishment as malefac- tors after death.
tgt_text.3353: Owing to which he appeared to some people rather fond of mythical stories, as he mingled stories of this kind with his writings, in order by the uncertainty of all the circumstances that affect men after their death, to induce them to abstain from evil actions.
tgt_text.3356: He used too, says Aristotle, to divide things in this manner :
tgt_text.3357: -Of good, some have their place in the mind, some in the body, and some are wholly external.
tgt_text.3358: As, for instance, justice, and prudence, and manly courage, and temperance, and qualities of that sort exist in the soul.
tgt_text.3359: Beauty, and a good constitution, and health, and strength exist in the body.
tgt_text.3360: But friends, and the prosperity of one's country, and wealth, are external goods.
tgt_text.3361: There are then three species of goods, some in the soul, some in the body, and some external to either.
tgt_text.3363: There are also three species of friendship.
tgt_text.3364: For one kind is natural, another that which arises from companionship ;
tgt_text.3365: and the third is that which is produced by ties of hospitality.
tgt_text.3366: We call that natural friendship which parents feel towards their offspring, and relations towards one another;
tgt_text.3367: and this is partaken of by other animals besides men.
tgt_text.3368: We call that the friendship of companionship which arises from a habit of association, and which has no reference to ties of blood, such as the friendship of Pylades for Orestes.
tgt_text.3369: That which arises from ties of hospitality is one which owes its origin to agree ments, and which is carried on by means of letters between strangers.
tgt_text.3370: There is, therefore, natural friendship, and friend- ship between companions, and between strangers.
tgt_text.3371: Some also add a fourth kind, namely, the friendship of love.
tgt_text.3373: Of political constitutions there are five species.
tgt_text.3374: There is one kind which is democratical, a second which is aristocratical, a third is oligarchical, a fourth monarchical, and the fifth is tyrannical.
tgt_text.3375: Now, the democratical form of con- stitution exists in those cities in which the multitude has the chief power, and elects magistrates, and passes laws at its own pleasure.
tgt_text.3376: But an aristocracy is that form in which neither the rich, nor the poor, nor the most illustrious men of the city rule, but the most nobly born have the chief sway.
tgt_text.3377: And oligarchy is that constitution in which the magistracies are distributed according to some sort of rating :
tgt_text.3378: for the rich are fewer in number than the poor.
tgt_text.3379: The monarchical constitution is either dependent on law or on family.
tgt_text.3380: That in Carthage depends on law;
tgt_text.3381: that in Lacædemon and Macedonia on family ;
tgt_text.3382: for they select their sovereign out of some particular family.
tgt_text.3383: But a tyranny is that kind of government in which the people are either cajoled or constrained into being governed by a single individual.
tgt_text.3384: Forms of government then, are divided into democracy, aristocracy, oligarchy, monarchy, and tyranny.
tgt_text.3386: Again, of justice there are three species.
tgt_text.3387: For there is one kind which is conversant with the gods ;
tgt_text.3388: a second which has reference to men ;
tgt_text.3389: and a third, which concerns the dead.
tgt_text.3390: For they who sacrifice according to the laws, and who pay due respect to the temples, are manifestly pious to the gods.
tgt_text.3391: And those who repay what has been lent to them, and restore what has been deposited with them, act justly as to men.
tgt_text.3392: And those who pay due respect to the tombs, clearly are pious towards the dead.
tgt_text.3393: There is, therefore, one justice towards the Gods, a second towards men, and a third towards the dead.
tgt_text.3396: there are also three species of knowledge.
tgt_text.3397: There is one kind which is practical, a second which is productive, a third which is theoretical.
tgt_text.3398: For the science of building houses or ships, is production, For one can see the work which is produced by it.
tgt_text.3399: Political science, and the science of playing the flute, or the harp, or such things as that, is practical;
tgt_text.3400: for one cannot see any visible re- sult which has been produced by them, and yet they are doing something.
tgt_text.3401: For one man plays the flute or plays the harp, and another occupies himself with state affairs.
tgt_text.3402: Again, geo- metrical, and harmonic, and astronomical science are all theoretical, for they do nothing, and produce nothing.
tgt_text.3403: But the geometrician theorizes as to what relation lines bear to one another ;
tgt_text.3404: and the harmonist speculates about sounds, and the astronomer about stars and about the world.
tgt_text.3405: Accordingly, of sciences some are theoretical, others productive, and a third species is practical..L.
tgt_text.3406: Of medical science there are five species :
tgt_text.3409: a third, conversant about the regulation of the manner of life, and the diet;
tgt_text.3410: a fourth, the business of which is to detect diseases;
tgt_text.3411: and the fifth is re- medial.
tgt_text.3412: The pharmaceutical relieves infirmities by means of medicines ;
tgt_text.3413: the manual heals men by cutting and cauterizing;
tgt_text.3414: the one which attends to the diet, gets rid of diseases by altering and regulating the diet;
tgt_text.3415: the fourth produces its effects by a thorough comprehension of the nature of the disease;
tgt_text.3416: and the last relieves men from suffering by bringing prompt as- sistance at the moment.
tgt_text.3417: Medical science, then, is divided into the pharmaceutical, the manual, the dietetic, the diagnos- tic, and the remedial.
tgt_text.3419: Of law there are two divisions.
tgt_text.3420: For there is a written and an unwritten law.
tgt_text.3421: The one by which we regulate our 'constitutions in our cities, is the written law;
tgt_text.3422: that which arises from custom, is the unwritten law.
tgt_text.3423: As, for instance, for a man to come naked into the market place, or to wear woman's clothes, are actions which are not prohibited by any law, and yet we never do them because they are forbidden by the unwritten law.
tgt_text.3424: Law, therefore, is divided into the written and the unwritten law.
tgt_text.3426: Discourse is divided into five heads;
tgt_text.3427: one of which heads is that which statesmen employ when they speak in the public assemblies;
tgt_text.3429: Another division is that which orators use in their written harangues, and bring forward for the sake of display in panegyrics or reproaches, or impeachments.
tgt_text.3430: And such a description of discourse as this is the rhetorical.
tgt_text.3431: A third class is that which private individuals use when conversing with one another.
tgt_text.3433: Another kind is that which is employed when men converse by means of putting short questions and giving brief answers to those who question them.
tgt_text.3434: This is called the dialectic kind of discourse.
tgt_text.3435: The fifth division is that which artists adopt when conversing on their own particular art, and this is called professional dis- course.
tgt_text.3436: Thus discourse, then, is divided into political, rhetorical, private, dialectic, and professional.
tgt_text.3438: Music again is divided into three species.
tgt_text.3439: For there is the music of the mouth alone, such as song;
tgt_text.3440: se- condly, there is the music which is performed by the hands and mouth together, such as singing to the harp;
tgt_text.3441: thirdly, there is that which is executed by the hands alone, such as harp playing.
tgt_text.3442: Music, therefore, is divided into music of the mouth, music of the mouth and hands, and music of the hands.
tgt_text.3444: Nobleness of birth is divided into four species ;
tgt_text.3445: the first is when one's ancestors are noble, and valiant, and just;
tgt_text.3446: in which case they say that their posterity are nobly born.
tgt_text.3447: The second kind is when one's ancestors have been princes and rulers of nations, and their posterity also we call noble.
tgt_text.3448: Another kind is when one's ancestors have been distinguished for personal renown, such, for instance, as is gained by generalship or by victory at the games.
tgt_text.3449: For their offspring also we address as nobly born.
tgt_text.3450: And the last kind is when a man is himself noble in his spirit, and magnanimous.
tgt_text.3451: For that man also we call noble, and this is the last kind of nobility.
tgt_text.3452: There is, therefore, nobility arising from virtuous ancestors, from royal ancestors, from illustrious ancestors, and from one's own excellent qualities.
tgt_text.3454: Beauty also is divided into three kinds.
tgt_text.3455: For there is one kind which is praiseworthy, as that of a beautiful face.
tgt_text.3456: Another which is useful, as an instrument or a house, and things of that kind which are beautiful, with reference to our use of them.
tgt_text.3457: There is also a beauty with reference to laws, and habits, and things of that kind, which is likewise beautiful, because of its utility.
tgt_text.3458: So that beauty again is looked at in three ways, with reference to its praise, its utility, and to our use of it.
tgt_text.3460: The soul is divided into three parts;
tgt_text.3461: for one part of it is capable of reason, another is influenced by appetite, the third part is liable to passion.
tgt_text.3462: Of these the reasoning part is the cause of deliberating, and reasoning, and understanding, and everything of that kind.
tgt_text.3463: The appetite part is that portion of the soul which is the cause of desiring to eat, and to em- brace, and things of that kind.
tgt_text.3464: The passionate part is the cause of men feeling confidence and delight, and grief and anger.
tgt_text.3465: The soul therefore is divided into the reasoning part, the appetitive part, and the passionate part.
tgt_text.3467: Of perfect virtue there are four species.
tgt_text.3468: One is prudence, one is justice, the third is manly gallantry, and the fourth is temperance.
tgt_text.3469: Of these, prudence is the cause of a man acting rightly in affairs;
tgt_text.3470: justice is the cause of his acting justly in partnerships and bargains ;
tgt_text.3471: manly gallantry is the cause of a man's not being alarmed amid dangers and for- midable circumstances, but standing firm ;
tgt_text.3472: and temperance is the cause of his subduing his appetites, and being enslaved by no pleasure, but living decorously.
tgt_text.3473: So that virtue is divided into prudence, justice, manly gallantry, and temperance.
tgt_text.3475: Rule is divided into five parts.
tgt_text.3476: One is rule ac- cording to law;
tgt_text.3477: another is rule according to nature;
tgt_text.3478: a third kind is rule according to custom;
tgt_text.3479: a fourth division is rule with reference to family;
tgt_text.3480: the fifth is rule by force.
tgt_text.3481: Now when the rulers in cities are elected by the citizens, then they rule according to law;
tgt_text.3482: those who rule according to nature are the males, not only among men, but also among all other animals;
tgt_text.3483: for everywhere we shall find it as a general rule that the male rules the female;
tgt_text.3484: the rule of him who rules according to custom is such as this, when schoolmasters rule their pupils, and teachers their disciples.
tgt_text.3485: Rule according to family is that which prevails in places like Lacedæmon, where hereditary sovereigns reign.
tgt_text.3486: For the kingdom there belongs to a certain family;
tgt_text.3487: and in Macedonia they rule on the same principle.
tgt_text.3488: For there, too, the kingdom depends on family.
tgt_text.3489: But those who rule by force, only cajoling the citizens, rule in spite of ;
tgt_text.3491: and such a sway is called rule by force.
tgt_text.3492: So that there s rule by law, and by nature, and by custom, and by family, and by force.
tgt_text.3494: Of rhetoric he speaks of six species.
tgt_text.3495: For when )rators exhort the people to make war upon or to form alliances against any one, this species of oratory is called exhortation.
tgt_text.3496: When they persuade the people not to make war, or to form fiances, but to keep quiet, this kind of rhetoric is called lissuasion.
tgt_text.3497: The third species of rhetoric, is when any one ays that he has been injured by some one else, and impeaches hat person as guilty of many crimes ;
tgt_text.3498: for this species is ailed accusation.
tgt_text.3499: The fourth kind of rhetoric is called defence, when a man shows that he has done no wrong, and hat he is not guilty of anything out of the way.
tgt_text.3500: Such a kind of peech they call a defence.
tgt_text.3501: The fifth species of rhetoric, is when any one speaks well of another, and shows him to be irtuous and honourable;
tgt_text.3502: and this kind is called encomium.
tgt_text.3503: 'he sixth species, is when any one shows that another person is worthless ;
tgt_text.3504: and this kind is called blame.
tgt_text.3505: So that rhetoric is divided into encomium and blame, exhortation and dis- suasion, accusation and defence.
tgt_text.3506: Speaking correctly is divided under four" heads.
tgt_text.3507: One, the saying what is right;
tgt_text.3508: one, the saying as much as is right;
tgt_text.3509: thirdly, the saying it to the proper people;
tgt_text.3510: and fourthly, the saying it at the proper time.
tgt_text.3511: Now as to the saying what is right, that is the saying what will be advantageous both to the speaker and to the hearer.
tgt_text.3512: The saying as much as is right, is saying neither more nor less than what is sufficient.
tgt_text.3513: The saying it to the proper people, is supposing one is speaking tc one's elders who are mistaken in any point, the using expres- sions proper to be addressed to those older than one's self;
tgt_text.3514: or on the other hand, if one is addressing those younger, then the using language such as is suitable to young people.
tgt_text.3515: ThE saying it at the proper time, is speaking neither too soon no:
tgt_text.3517: for if one does, one will err and speak improperly.
tgt_text.3518: LX. Beneficence is divided under four heads.
tgt_text.3519: For it may be exerted either in money, or by personal exertion, or b;
tgt_text.3521: In money when any one assist those who are in want, so as to put them at ease with respec to money.
tgt_text.3522: And men benefit one another by personal ex ertion when they come upon those who are being beaten an< assist them.
tgt_text.3523: Again, those who instruct, or heal, or who teacl any good thing, benefit others by their knowledge ;
tgt_text.3524: and whei one person comes down to the court of justice as an advocat for another, and delivers some speech full of sense and goos feeling in his behalf, that man assists his friend by words
tgt_text.3525: So that there is one beneficence which is displayed in money another in personal exertion, a third by means of knowledge and the fourth kind by words.
tgt_text.3527: Again, Plato divides the end of all affairs into fou species.
tgt_text.3528: An affair has one end in accordance with law, whe a decree is passed, and when the law establishes it:
tgt_text.3529: it ha an end in accordance with nature, when it is such a thing as day, or a year, or the seasons.
tgt_text.3530: It has an end according to ar when it is architecture for instance, for a man builds a house or when it is ship-building, for it makes a ship.
tgt_text.3531: And affair also come to an end by chance, when they turn out differentl from what any one expected.
tgt_text.3532: So that an end of an affair i regulated either by law, or by nature, or by art, or by chanceLXII.
tgt_text.3533: Power again is divided into four species.
tgt_text.3534: There is one power which we possess by our ability to reason and form conceptions by means of our intellect.
tgt_text.3535: There is another power which we owe to the body, such as the power of walking, or giving, or taking, and such like.
tgt_text.3536: There is a third which we possess through the multitude of soldiers or riches, on which account a king is said to have great power.
tgt_text.3537: And the fourth division of power consists in the being well or ill treated, and treating others well or ill;
tgt_text.3538: as, for instance, we may be sick, or we may be taught, or we may be in vigorous health, and many more cases of that sort.
tgt_text.3539: So that one kind of power dwells in the intellect, another in the body, another in an army and riches, and another in our capacity as agents or patients.
tgt_text.3541: Of philanthropy there are three sorts.
tgt_text.3542: One which is displayed in addressing people, when some persons address every one whom they meet, and give them their right hand, and greet them heartily;
tgt_text.3543: another species is when one is disposed to assist every one who is unfortunate.
tgt_text.3544: The last kind is that sort of philanthropy which makes men pleasant boon com- panions.
tgt_text.3545: So that there is one kind of philanthropy dis- played in addressing people, another in benefiting them, and a third in feasting and making merry with them.
tgt_text.3547: Happiness is divided into five parts.
tgt_text.3548: For one part of it is wisdom in counsel;
tgt_text.3549: another is a healthy condition of the sensations and general health of body;
tgt_text.3550: a third is good fortune in one's affairs;
tgt_text.3551: a fourth kind is good reputation among men ;
tgt_text.3552: a fifth is abundance of riches and of all those things which are useful in life.
tgt_text.3553: Now wisdom in counsel arises from good instruction, and from a person's having experience of many things.
tgt_text.3554: A healthy condition of the sensations de- pends on the limbs of the body ;
tgt_text.3555: as, for instance, when one sees with one's eyes, and hears with one's ears, and smells with one's nose, and feels with one's body, just what one ought to see, and hear, and smell, and feel.
tgt_text.3556: Such a condition as this is a healthy condition.
tgt_text.3557: And good fortune is when a man does rightly and successfully what a good and energetic man ought to do.
tgt_text.3558: And good reputation is when a man is well spoken of.
tgt_text.3559: And abundance of riches is when a man has such a sufficiency of everything which relates to the uses of life, that he is able to benefit his friends, and to discharge all public obligations in a splendid and liberal manner.
tgt_text.3560: And the man who has all these different parts of happiness, is a per- fectly happy man.
tgt_text.3561: So that happiness is made up of wisdom in counsel, a good condition of the sensations and health of body, good fortune, good reputation, and riches.
tgt_text.3563: The arts are divided into three kinds.
tgt_text.3564: The first, the second, and the third.
tgt_text.3565: The first are those of working mines and cutting wood, for these are preparatory arts.
tgt_text.3566: The second are such as working metals and carpentry, for they are alterative arts.
tgt_text.3567: For working in metals makes arms out of iron;
tgt_text.3568: and carpentry makes flutes and lyres out of wood.
tgt_text.3569: The third is the art which makes use of instruments;
tgt_text.3570: such as horsemanship, which uses bridles;
tgt_text.3571: the military art, which uses arms ;
tgt_text.3572: music, which uses flutes and lyres.
tgt_text.3573: So that there are three species of art;
tgt_text.3574: one of which is the first, another the second, and another the third.
tgt_text.3576: Good is divided into four kinds.
tgt_text.3577: One of which we mean when we speak of a man endowed with private virtue, as good;
tgt_text.3578: another kind is that which we indicate, when we call virtue and justice, good.
tgt_text.3579: A third kind is that which we attribute to suitable food, and exercise, and medicine.
tgt_text.3580: The fourth good, is that which we mean, when we speak of good flute playing, good acting, and things of that sort.
tgt_text.3581: There are therefore four kinds of good.
tgt_text.3584: a third, useful food and exercise ;
tgt_text.3585: and fourthly, we call skill in flute playing and acting, good.
tgt_text.3587: Of things existing, some are bad, some good, and some neither one thing nor the other.
tgt_text.3588: Of these, we call those things bad, which are invariably capable of doing injury, such as intemperance, folly, injustice, and things of that sort.
tgt_text.3589: And the opposites to these qualities are good.
tgt_text.3590: But those things, which may at times be beneficial, and at times injurious, such as walking, sitting down, and eating;
tgt_text.3591: or which have absolutely no power in any case to benefit or injure any one ;
tgt_text.3592: these are neither bad nor good.
tgt_text.3593: Of things existing then, there are some bad, and some good, and some of a neutral character, neither bad nor good.
tgt_text.3595: A good state of affairs with reference to the laws, is divided under three heads.
tgt_text.3596: One when the laws are good, for that is a good state of affairs;
tgt_text.3597: so too is it, when the citizens abide by the existing laws ;
tgt_text.3598: and the third case is, when al- though there are no positive laws, still men are good citizens in deference to custom and to established institutions;
tgt_text.3599: and this is also called a good state of affairs.
tgt_text.3600: So that of these three heads, one depends on the laws being good, another on obedience to existing laws, and the third on men yielding to good customs and institutions.
tgt_text.3601: So again, lawlessness is divided into three heads.
tgt_text.3602: One of which is, when the laws are bad, both as concerns strangers, and the citizens;
tgt_text.3603: another, when the citizens do not obey the laws that are established;
tgt_text.3604: and the third is when there is actually no law at all.
tgt_text.3605: So that one kind of lawlessness arises from bad laws, another from disobedience to existing laws, and the third from the absence of laws.
tgt_text.3608: for instance, we say that good is contrary to evil, as justice to injustice, wisdom to folly, and so on.
tgt_text.3609: Again, some evils are contrary to others, as extravagance is to stinginess, and the being tortured with justice to the being tortured with injustice.
tgt_text.3610: And such evils as these are the contraries of other evils.
tgt_text.3611: Again, the heavy is contrary to the light, the swift to the slow, the black to the white ;
tgt_text.3612: so that some things which are of a neutral character, neither good nor evil, are contrary to other things of a neu- tral character.
tgt_text.3613: Of contraries then, there are some which are so, as what is good is contrary to what is evil;
tgt_text.3614: others, as one evil is contrary to another;
tgt_text.3615: and others again, as neutral things are contrary to other things of a neutral character.
tgt_text.3617: Of good things there are three kinds;
tgt_text.3618: for there are some which can be possessed;
tgt_text.3620: others, which one realizes in one's self.
tgt_text.3621: Those which can be possessed, are those which it is possible for a person to have, such as justice, or good health ;
tgt_text.3622: those can be shared, which it is not possible for a person to have entirely to himself, but which he may participate in ;
tgt_text.3623: as for instance, a person cannot be the sole possessor of abstract good, but he may participate in it.
tgt_text.3624: Those again a person realizes in himself, when they are such, that he cannot possess them himself, or share them with others, and yet they ought to exist;
tgt_text.3625: as for instance, it is good to be virtuous and just, but yet a man does not pos- sess the being virtuous, or participate in it;
tgt_text.3626: but the being virtuous and just ought to exist in him.
tgt_text.3628: therefore, there are those which are possessed, those which are shared, and those which ought to exist in a man.
tgt_text.3630: In the same manner, good counsel is divisible into three kinds.
tgt_text.3631: For there is one kind which is derived from past time, another from the future, another from the present.
tgt_text.3632: That which is derived from past time is made up of instances, as for instance what the Lacedaemonians suffered by trusting to such and such people.
tgt_text.3633: That which relates to the present, is when what is wanted, is to show that the fortifications are weak, the men cowardly, or the provisions scanty.
tgt_text.3634: That which concerns the future, is when the speaker urges that no injury ought to be offered to ambassadors, in order that Greece may not get an evil reputation;
tgt_text.3635: and supports his argument by instances.
tgt_text.3636: So that good counsel has reference, firstly to what is past, secondly to what is present, and thirdly to the future.
tgt_text.3638: Voice is divided into two parts, one of which is animated, and the other inanimate.
tgt_text.3639: That is animated, which proceeds from living animals, while sounds and echoes are inanimate.
tgt_text.3640: Again, animated voice may be divided into that which can be indicated by letters, and that which cannot;
tgt_text.3641: that which can be so indicated being the voice of men, and that which cannot being the voice of animals;
tgt_text.3642: so that one kind of voice is animated, the other inanimate.
tgt_text.3644: Of existing things, some are divisible and some indivisible.
tgt_text.3645: Again, those which are divisible, consist either of similar or of dissimilar parts.
tgt_text.3646: Those which are indivisible are such as have no separate parts, and are not formed by any combination, such as unity, a point, or a sound.
tgt_text.3647: But those are divisible which are formed by some combination;
tgt_text.3648: as, for instance, syllables, and symphonies, and animals, and water, and gold.
tgt_text.3649: These too consist of similar parts, which are made up of particles resembling one another, and of which the whole does not differ from any part, except in number.
tgt_text.3650: As for instance, water and gold, and everything which is fusible, and so on.
tgt_text.3651: And these consist of dissimilar parts, which are made up of various things not resembling one another;
tgt_text.3652: as for instance, a house, and things of that sort;
tgt_text.3653: so that of existing things, some are divisible and others indi- visible.
tgt_text.3654: And of those which are divisible, some consist of similar and others of dissimilar parts.
tgt_text.3656: Again, of existing things, some are spoken of as having an independent, and some only a relative existence.
tgt_text.3657: Those which are spoken of as having an independent exist- ence, are those which require nothing else to be added to them, when we are explaining their nature ;
tgt_text.3658: as man, a horse, and the other animals;
tgt_text.3659: for these have no need of any additional explanation.
tgt_text.3660: But those things are said to have a relative existence which do require some additional explana- tion.
tgt_text.3661: As for instance, that which is greater than something else, or less, or swifter, or more beautiful, and so on.
tgt_text.3662: For that which is greater, is greater than something which is less;
tgt_text.3663: and that which is swifter, is swifter than something else.
tgt_text.3664: So that, of existing things, some are spoken of as independently, and others relatively.
tgt_text.3665: And thus he divided them at first, according to Aristotle.
tgt_text.3667: There was also another man of the name of Plato, a philosopher of Rhodes, a disciple of Panætius, as Seleucus, the grammarian says in the first book of his treatise on Philo- sophy ;
tgt_text.3668: and another was a Peripatetic, a pupil of Aristotle;
tgt_text.3669: and there was a third, a pupil of Praxiphanes ;
tgt_text.3670: and there was besides all these, the poet of the Old Comedy.
tgt_text.3671: I. THE long account which I have given of Plato was compiled to the best of my power, and in it I collected with great zeal and industry all that was reported of the man.
tgt_text.3673: And he was succeeded by Speusippus, the son of Eurymedon, and a citizen of Athens, of the Myrrhinusian burgh, and he was the son of Plato's sister Potone.
tgt_text.3675: He presided over his school for eight years, beginning to do so in the hundred and eighth olympiad.
tgt_text.3676: And he set up images of the Graces in the temple of the Muses, which had been built in the Academy by Plato.
tgt_text.3678: And he always adhered to the doctrines which had been adopted by Plato, though he was not of the same dis- position as he.
tgt_text.3679: For he was a passionate man, and a slave to pleasure.
tgt_text.3680: Accordingly, they say that he once in a rage threw a puppy into a well;
tgt_text.3681: and that for the sake of amusement, he went all the way to Macedonia to the marriage of Cassander.V.
tgt_text.3682: The female pupils of Plato, Lasthenea of Mantinea, and Axiothea of Phlius, are said to have become disciples of Speusippus also.
tgt_text.3683: And Dionysius, writing to him in a petulant manner, says, " And one may learn philosophy too from your female disciple from Arcadia;
tgt_text.3684: moreover, Plato used to take his pupils without exacting any fee from them ;
tgt_text.3685: but you collect tribute from yours, whether willing or unwilling.”
tgt_text.3687: He was the first man, as Diodorus relates in the first book of his Commentaries, who investigated in his school what was common to the several sciences;
tgt_text.3688: and who endeavoured, as far as possible, to maintain their connection with each other.
tgt_text.3689: He was also the first who published those things which Isocrates called secrets, as Cæneus tells us.
tgt_text.3690: And the first too who found out how to make light baskets of bundles of twigs.
tgt_text.3692: But he became afflicted with paralysis, aud sent to Xenocrates inviting him to come to him, and to become his successor in his school.
tgt_text.3694: And they say that once, when he was being borne in a carriage into the Academy, he met Diogenes, and said, " Hail;
tgt_text.3695: " and Diogenes replied, " I will not say hail to you, who, though in such a state as you are, endure to live."
tgt_text.3697: And at last in despair he put an end to his life, being a man of a great age.
tgt_text.3698: And we have written this epigram on him :
tgt_text.3700: Had I not known Speusippus thus had died, No one would have persuaded me that he Was e'er akin to Plato ;
tgt_text.3701: who would never Have died desponding for so slight a grief.
tgt_text.3702: But Plutarch, in his Life of Lysander, and again in his Life of Sylla, says that he was kept in a state of constant inflammation by lice.
tgt_text.3703: For he was of a weak habit of body, as Timotheus relates in his treatise on Lives.X. Speusippus said to a rich man who was in love with an ugly woman, " What do you want with her?
tgt_text.3704: I will find you a much prettier woman for ten talents."XI.
tgt_text.3705: He left behind him a great number of commentaries, and many dialogues;
tgt_text.3706: among which was one on Aristippus;
tgt_text.3721: one called the Test of Art.
tgt_text.3722: There were also Commentaries by way of dialogues;
tgt_text.3724: and ten about those things which are alike in their treatment.

tgt_text.3726: Essays on the Genera and Species of Examples ;
tgt_text.3729: Letters to Dion, and Dionysius, and Philip;
tgt_text.3736: There are in all, forty-three thousand four hundred and seventy-five lines.
tgt_text.3737: Simonides dedicated to him the Histories, in which he had related the actions of Dion and Bion.
tgt_text.3738: And in the second book of his Commentaries, Pharorinus states that Aristotle purchased his books for three talents.
tgt_text.3740: There was also another person of the name of Speu- sippus, a physician of the school of Herophilus,* a native of Alexandria.
tgt_text.3741: I. XENOCRATES was the son of Agathenor, and a native of Chalcedon.
tgt_text.3742: From his early youth he was a pupil of Plato, and also accompanied him in his voyages to Sicily.
tgt_text.3744: He was by nature of a lazy disposition, so that they say that Plato said once, when comparing him to Aristotle,- " The one requires the spur, and the other the bridle."
tgt_text.3745: And on another occasion, he said, " What a horse and what an ass am I dressing opposite to one another!
tgt_text.3747: In other respects Xenocrates was always of a solemn and grave character, so that Plato was continually saying to him,—“ Xenocrates, sacrifice to the Graces."
tgt_text.3748: And he spent the greater part of his time in the Academy, and whenever he was about to go into the city, they say all the turbulent and quarrelsome rabble in the city used to make way for him to pass by.
tgt_text.3749: And once, Phryne the courtesan wished to try him and pretending that she was pursued by some people, she fled and took refuge in his house;
tgt_text.3750: and he admitted her indeed, because of what was due to humanity ;
tgt_text.3751: and as there was but one bed in the room, he, at her entreaty, allowed her to share it with him;
tgt_text.3752: but at last, in spite of all her entreaties, she got up and went away, without having been able to succeed in her purpose ;
tgt_text.3753: and told those who asked her, that she had quitted a statue and not a man.
tgt_text.3754: But some say that the real story is, that his pupils put Lais into his bed, and that he was so con- tinent, that he submitted to some severe operations of excision and cautery.
tgt_text.3756: And he was a very trustworthy man ;
tgt_text.3757: so that, though it was not lawful for men to give evidence except on oath, the Athenians made an exception in his favour alone.
tgt_text.3759: He was also a man of the most contented disposition ;
tgt_text.3760: accordingly they say that when Alexander sent him a large sum of money, he took three thousand Attic drachmas, and sent back the rest, saying, that Alexander wanted most, as he had the greatest number of mouths to feed.
tgt_text.3761: And when some was sent him by Antipater, he would not accept any of it, as Myornianus tells us in his Similitudes.
tgt_text.3762: And once, when he gained a golden crown, in a contest as to who could drink most, which was offered in the yearly festival of the Choes by Dionysius, he went out and placed the crown at the feet of the statue of Mercury, which was at the gate, where he was also accustomed to deposit his garlands of flowers.
tgt_text.3763: It is said also, that he was once sent with some colleagues as an ambas- sador to Philip;
tgt_text.3764: and that they were won over by gifts, and went to his banquets and conversed with Philip ;
tgt_text.3765: but that he would do none of these things, nor could Philip propitiate him by these means ;
tgt_text.3766: on which account, when the other am- bassadors arrived in Athens, they said that Xenocrates had gone with them to no purpose ;
tgt_text.3767: and the people were ready to punish him;
tgt_text.3768: but when they had learnt from him that they had now more need than ever to look to the welfare of their city, for that Philip had already bribed all their counsellors, but that he had been unable to win him over by any means, then they say that the people honoured him with redoubled honour.
tgt_text.3769: They add also, that Philip said afterwards, that Xenocrates was the only one of those who had come to him who was in- corruptible.
tgt_text.3770: And when he went as ambassador to Antipater on the subject of the Athenian captives at the time of the Samian war, and was invited by him to a banquet, he addressed him in the following lines :
tgt_text.3771: — I answer, Goddess human, is thy breast By justice sway'd, by tender pity prest ?
tgt_text.3772: Ill fits it me, whose friends are sunk to beasts, To quaff thy bowls, or riot in thy feasts :
tgt_text.3773: Me would'st thou please, for them thy cares employ, And them to me restore, and me to joy ?
tgt_text.3774: *And Antipater, admiring the appropriateness of the quotation, immediately released them.
tgt_text.3776: On one occasion, when a sparrow was pursued by a hawk, and flew into his bosom, he caressed it, and let it go again, saying that we ought not to betray a suppliant.
tgt_text.3777: And being ridiculed by Bion, he said that he would not answer him, for that tragedy, when ridiculed by comedy, did not con- descend to make a reply.
tgt_text.3778: To one who had never learnt music, or geometry, or astronomy, but who wished to become his dis- ciple, he said, 11 Be gone, for you have not yet the handles of philosophy."
tgt_text.3779: But some say that he said, " Be gone, for I do not card wool here."
tgt_text.3780: And when Dionysius said to Plato that some one would cut off his head, he, being present, showed his own, and said, " Not before they have cut off mine."
tgt_text.3782: They say too that once, when Antipater had come to Athens and saluted him, he would not make him any reply before he had finished quietly the discourse which he was delivering.
tgt_text.3784: Being exceedingly devoid of every kind of pride, he often used to meditate with himself several times a day ;
tgt_text.3785: and always allotted one hour of each day, it is said, to silence.
tgt_text.3787: And he left behind him a great number of writings, and books of recommendation, and verses, which are these,- six books on Natural Philosophy;
tgt_text.3808: one on the Power of Law;
tgt_text.3811: one to show that Virtue may be transmitted;
tgt_text.3833: one on the School of Parme- nides;
tgt_text.3834: one the Archidemus, or an essay on Justice ;
tgt_text.3836: eight of those things which concern the Intellect;
tgt_text.3837: ten essays in solution of the difficulties which occur respecting Orations;
tgt_text.3838: six books on the study of Natural Philosophy ;
tgt_text.3840: one treatise on Genus and Species;
tgt_text.3841: one on the doctrines of the Pythagoreans;
tgt_text.3845: several also about the method of conducting Discussions.

tgt_text.3847: nine more which treat of Ratiocination ;
tgt_text.3849: two more books on subjects connected with the Intel- lect ;
tgt_text.3854: one on the Contem- plation of Numbers;
tgt_text.3857: four of elementary suggestions to Alexander, on the subject of Royal Power;
tgt_text.3862: But the Athenians, though he was such a great man, once sold him, because he was unable to pay the tax to which the metics were liable.
tgt_text.3863: And Demetrius Phalereus purchased him, and so assisted both parties, Xenocrates by giving him his freedom, and the Athenians in respect of the tax upon metics.
tgt_text.3864: This circumstance is mentioned by Myronianus of Amastra, in the first book of his chapters of Historical Coincidences.
tgt_text.3866: He succeeded Spuesippus, and presided over the school for twenty-five years, beginning at the archonship of Lysi- machides, in the second year of the hundred and tenth olympiad.
tgt_text.3868: And he died in consequence of stumbling by night against a dish, being more than eighty-two years of age.
tgt_text.3869: And in one of our epigrams we speak thus of him:
tgt_text.3871: He struck against a brazen pot, And cut his forehead deep, And crying cruel is my lot, In death he fell asleep.
tgt_text.3872: So thus Xenocrates did fall, The universal friend of all.
tgt_text.3874: And there were five other people of the name of Xenocrates.

tgt_text.3876: and there is extant an oration of his which is scribed, On Arsinoe, and which was written on the death of Arsinoe.

tgt_text.3878: and that is not strange, for when poets take to writing in prose, they succeed pretty well ;
tgt_text.3879: but when prose writers try their hand at poetry, they fail;
tgt_text.3880: from which it is plain, that the one is a gift of nature, and the other a work of art.

tgt_text.3883: I. POLEMO was the son of Philostratus, an Athenian, of the burgh of Æa.
tgt_text.3884: And when he was young, he was so very in- temperate and profligate, that he used always to carry money about with him, to procure the instant gratification of his passions ;
tgt_text.3885: and he used also to hide money in the narrow alleys, for this purpose.
tgt_text.3886: And once there was found in the Academy a piece of three obols, hidden against one of the columns, which he had put there for some purpose like that which I have indi- cated ;
tgt_text.3887: and on one occasion he arranged beforehand with some young men, and rushed, adorned with a garland, and drunk, into the school of Xenocrates.
tgt_text.3888: But he took no notice of him, and continued his discourse as he had begun it, and it was in praise of temperance;
tgt_text.3889: and the young man, hearing it, was gradually charmed, and became so industrious, that he sur- passed all the rest of the disciples, and himself became the successor of Xenocrates, in his school beginning in the hundred and sixteenth olympiad.
tgt_text.3891: And Antigonus, of Carystus, says in his Lives, that his father had been the chief man of the city, and had kept chariots for the Olympic games.
tgt_text.3893: He also asserts that Polemo was prosecuted by his wife, on the charge of ill-treatment, because he indulged in illicit pleasures, and despised her.
tgt_text.3895: But that when he began to devote himself to philo- sophy, he adopted such a rigorous system of morals, that he for the future always continued the same in appearance, and never even changed his voice, on which account Crantor was charmed by him.
tgt_text.3896: Accordingly, on one occasion, when a dog was mad and had bitten his leg, he was the only person who did not turn pale;
tgt_text.3897: and once, when there was a great confusion in the city, he, having heard the cause, remained where he was without fleeing.
tgt_text.3898: In the theatres too he was quite immoveable ;
tgt_text.3899: accord- ingly, when Nicostratus the poet, who was surnamed Clytæm- nestra, was once reading something to him and Crates, the latter was excited to sympathy, he behaved as though he heard nothing.
tgt_text.3900: And altogether, he was such as Melanthius, the painter, describes in his treatise on Painting ;
tgt_text.3901: for he says that some kind of obstinacy and harshness ought to exist in works of art as in morals.
tgt_text.3902: And Polemo used to say that a man ought to exercise him- self in action, and not in dialectic speculations, as if one had drunk in and dwelt upon a harmonious kind of system of art, so as to be admired for one's shrewdness, in putting questions;
tgt_text.3903: but to be inconsistent with one's self in character.
tgt_text.3904: He was, then, a well-bred and high-spirited man, avoiding what Aristophanes says of Euripides, speeches of vinegar and assafœtida, such as he says himself:
tgt_text.3906: Are base delights compared with better things ?V.
tgt_text.3907: And he did not use to lecture on the propositions before him while sitting down;
tgt_text.3908: but he would walk about, it is said, and so discuss them.
tgt_text.3909: And he was much honoured in the city because of his noble sentiments;
tgt_text.3910: and after he had been walking about, he would rest in his garden;
tgt_text.3911: and his pupils erected little cabins near it, and dwelt near his school and corridor.
tgt_text.3913: And as it seems, Polemo imitated Xenocrates in every- thing ;
tgt_text.3914: and Aristippus, in the fourth book of his treatise on Ancient Luxury, says that Xenocrates loved him;
tgt_text.3915: at all events, Polemo used to be always speaking of him, and praising his guileless nature, and his rigorous virtues, and his chaste severity, like that of a Doric building.
tgt_text.3917: He wasalso very fond of Sophocles, and especially of those passages where, according to one of the comic poets, he seemed to have had a Molossian hound for his colleague in composing his poems;
tgt_text.3918: and when there was, to use the expression of Phrynichus:
tgt_text.3920: No sweet or washy liquor, but purest Pramnian wine.
tgt_text.3921: And he used to say that Homer was an epic Sophocles, and Sophocles a tragic Homer.
tgt_text.3923: And he died when he was very old, of decline, having left behind him a great number of writings.
tgt_text.3924: And there is this epigram of ours upon him:
tgt_text.3926: Do you not hear, we've buried Polemo, Whom sickness, worst affliction of mankind Attacked, and bore off to the shades below;
tgt_text.3927: Yet Polemo lies not here, but Polemo's body, And that he did himself place here on earth, Prepared in soul to mount up to the skies.
tgt_text.3928: I. CRATES was the son of Antigenes, and of the Thriasian burgh, and a pupil and attached friend of Polemo.
tgt_text.3929: He was also his successor as president of his school.
tgt_text.3931: And they benefited one another so much, that not only did they delight while alive in the same pursuits, but almost to their latest breath did they resemble one another, and even after they were both dead they shared the same tomb.
tgt_text.3932: In reference to which circumstance Antagoras has written an epigram on the pair, in which he expresses himself thus :
tgt_text.3933: — Stranger, who passest by, relate that here The God-like Crates lies, and Polemo;
tgt_text.3934: Two men of kindred nobleness of mind ;
tgt_text.3935: Out of whose holy mouths pure wisdom flowed, And they with upright lives did well display, The strength of all their principles and teaching.
tgt_text.3936: And they say too that it was in reference to this that Arcesi- laus, when he came over to them from Theophrastus, said that they were some gods, or else a remnant of the golden race ;
tgt_text.3937: for they were not very fond of courting the people, but had a disposition in accordance with the saying of Dionysodorus the flute player, who is reported to have said, with great exulta- tion and pride, that no one had ever heard his music in a trireme or at a fountain as they had heard Ismenius.
tgt_text.3939: Antigonus relates that he used to be a messmate of Crantor, and that these philosophers and Arcesilaus lived to- gether ;

tgt_text.3941: and he says that Crates was, as I have already mentioned, greatly attached to Polemo, and so was Arcesilaus to Crantor.
tgt_text.3943: But when Crates died, as Apollodorus relates in the third book of his Chronicles, he left behind him compositions, some on philosophical subjects and some on comedy, and some which were speeches addressed to assemblies of the people, or delivered on the occasion of embassies.
tgt_text.3945: He also left behind him some eminent disciples, among whom were Arcesilaus, about whom we shall speak presently, for he too was a pupil of his, and Bion of the Borysthenes, who was afterwards called a Theodorean.
tgt_text.3946: from the sect which he espoused, and we shall speak of him immediately after Arcesilaus.

tgt_text.3949: The first was a poet of the old comedy;
tgt_text.3950: the second was an orator of Tralles, a pupil of Isocrates ;
tgt_text.3951: the third was an engineer who served under Alexander;
tgt_text.3952: the fourth a Cynic, whom we shall mention hereafter;
tgt_text.3954: the sixth the Academic philosopher, of whom we are speaking;
tgt_text.3955: the seventh a grammarian of Males ;
tgt_text.3956: the eighth a writer in geo- metry ;
tgt_text.3958: the tenth was an Academic philosopher, a native of Tarsus.
tgt_text.3959: I. CRANTOR, a native of Soli, being admired very greatly in his own country, came to Athens and became a pupil of Xeno- crates at the same time with Polemo.
tgt_text.3961: And he left behind him memorials, in the shape of writings, to the number of 30,000 lines, some of which, how- ever, are by some writers attributed to Arcesilaus.
tgt_text.3963: They say of him that when he was asked what it was that he was so charmed with in Polemo, he replied, " That he had never heard him speak in too high or too low a key."
tgt_text.3965: When he was ill he retired to the temple of Æscula- pius, and there walked about, and people came to him from all quarters, thinkng that he had gone thither, not on account of any disease, but because he wished to establish a school there.
tgt_text.3967: And among those who came to him was Arcesilaus, wish- ing to be recommended by him to Polemo, although he was much attached to him, as we shall mention in the life of Arce- silaus.
tgt_text.3968: But when he got well he became a pupil of Polemo, and was excessively admired on that account.
tgt_text.3969: It is said, also, that he left his property to Arcesilaus, to the amount of twelve talents ;
tgt_text.3970: and that, being asked by him where he would like to be buried, he said :
tgt_text.3972: It is a happy fate to lie entombed
tgt_text.3973: In the recesses of a well-Iov'd land.

tgt_text.3976: and Meætetus the poet wrote thus about him:
tgt_text.3978: but greater pleasure still He to the Muses gave, ere he aged grew.
tgt_text.3979: Earth, tenderly embrace the holy man,
tgt_text.3980: And let him lie in quiet undisturb'd.

tgt_text.3982: saying that the hardest thing possible was to write tra- gically and in a manner to excite sympathy, without departing from nature ;

tgt_text.3988: Have only borne the usual fate of man.

tgt_text.3996: Or shall I bid you hail, As son of proudest Venus ?
