tgt_text.4013: I. ARCESILAUS was the son of Seuthesor Scythes, as Apollo- dorus states in the third book of his Chronicles, and a native of Pitane in Æolia.
tgt_text.4015: He was the original founder of the Middle Academy, and the first man who professed to suspend the declaration of his judgment, because of the contrarieties of the reasons alleged on either side.
tgt_text.4016: He was likewise the first who attempted to argue on both sides of a question, and who also made the method of discussion, which had been handed down by Plato, by means of question and answer, more contentious than before.
tgt_text.4018: He met with Crantor in the following manner.
tgt_text.4019: He was one of four brothers, two by the same father and two by the same mother.
tgt_text.4020: Of those who were by the same mother the eldest was Pylades, and of those by the same father the eldest was Mæreas, who was his guardian;
tgt_text.4021: and at first he was a pupil of Autolycus the mathematician, who happened to be a fellow citizen of his before he went to Athens ;
tgt_text.4022: and with Autolycus he travelled as far as Sardis.
tgt_text.4023: After that he became a pupil of Xanthus the musician, and after that attended the lectures of Theophrastus, and subsequently came over to the Academy to Grantor.
tgt_text.4024: For Mæreas his brother, whom I have mentioned before, urged him to apply himself to rhetoric;
tgt_text.4025: but he himself had a preference for philosophy, and when he became much attached to him Crantor asked him, quoting a line out of the Andromeda of Euripides:
tgt_text.4026: — 0 virgin, if I save you, will you thank me ?
tgt_text.4027: And he replied by quoting the next line to it:
tgt_text.4028: — 0 take me to you, stranger, as your slave, Or wife, or what you please.
tgt_text.4029: And ever after that they became very intimate, so that they say Theophrastus was much annoyed, and said, " That a most ingenious and well-disposed young man had deserted his school."
tgt_text.4031: For he was not only very impressive in his discourse, and displayed a great deal of learning in it, but he also tried his hand at poetry, and there is extant an epigram which is attributed to him, addressed to Attalus, which is as follows :
tgt_text.4033: Pergamus is not famed for arms alone, But often hears its praise resound For its fine horses, at the holy Pisa.
tgt_text.4034: Yet, if a mortal may declare, Its fate as hidden in the breast of Jove, It will be famous for its woes.
tgt_text.4035: There is another addressed to Menodorus the son of Euda- mus, who was attached to one of his fellow pupils :
tgt_text.4037: Phrygia is a distant land, and so Is sacred Thyatira, and Cadanade, Your country Menodorus.
tgt_text.4038: But from all, As the unvaried song of bards relates, An equal road does lie - to Acheron, That dark unmentioned river;
tgt_text.4039: so you lie Here far from home;
tgt_text.4041: This tomb above your bones, for he did love you, Though you were poor, with an undying love.
tgt_text.4042: But he admired Homer above all poets, and always used to read a portion of his works before going to sleep ;
tgt_text.4043: and in the morning he would say that he was going to the object of his love, when he was going to read him.
tgt_text.4044: He said, too, that Pindar was a wonderful man for filling the voice, and pouring forth an abundant variety of words and expressions.
tgt_text.4045: He also, when he was a young man, wrote a criticism on Ion.V.
tgt_text.4046: And he was a pupil likewise of Hipponicus, the geome- trican, whom he used to ridicule on other points as being lazy and gaping;
tgt_text.4047: but he admitted that in his own profession he was clear sighted enough, and said that geometry had flown into his mouth while he was yawning.
tgt_text.4048: And when he went out of his mind, he took him to his own house, and took care of him till he recovered his senses.
tgt_text.4050: And when Crates died, he succeeded him in the presi- dency of his schools, a man of the name of Socrates willingly yielding to him.
tgt_text.4052: And as he suspended his judgment on every point, he never, as it is said, wrote one single book.
tgt_text.4053: But others say that he was once detected correcting some passages in a work of his;
tgt_text.4054: and some assert that he published it, while others deny it, and affirm that he threw it into the fire.
tgt_text.4056: He seems to have been a great admirer of Plato, and he possessed all his writings.
tgt_text.4057: He also, according to some authorities, had a very high opinion of Pyrrho.
tgt_text.4059: He also studied dialectics, and the discussions of the Eretrian school;
tgt_text.4060: on which account Ariston said of him :
tgt_text.4061: — First Plato comes, and Pyrrho last, And in the middle Diodorus.
tgt_text.4062: And Timon speaks thus of him :
tgt_text.4064: For having on this side the heavy load Of Menedemus plac'd beneath his breast, He'll to stout Pyrrho run, or Diodorus.
tgt_text.4065: And presently afterwards he represents him as saying:
tgt_text.4066: - I'll swim to Pyrrho, or that crooked sophist Called Diodorus.X.
tgt_text.4067: He was exceedingly fond of employing axioms, very concise in his diction, and when speaking he laid an emphasis on each separate word.
tgt_text.4069: He was also very fond of attacking others, and very free spoken, on which account Timon in another passage speaks of him thus :
tgt_text.4071: You'll not escape all notice while you thus Attack the young man with your biting sarcasm.
tgt_text.4072: Once, when a young man was arguing against him with more boldness than usual, he said, " Will no one stop his mouth with the knout ?"*
tgt_text.4073: And to a man who lay under the general imputation of low debauchery, and who argued with him that one thing was not greater than another, he asked him whether a cup holding two pints was not larger than one which held only one.
tgt_text.4074: There was a certain Chian named Hemon, ex- ceedingly ugly, but who fancied himself good looking, and always went about in fine clothes;
tgt_text.4075: this man asked him one day, “ If be thought that a wise man could feel attachment to him;
tgt_text.4076: ” " Why should he not," said he, " when they love even those who are less handsome than you, and not so well-dressed either?" and when the man, though one of the vilest charac- ters possible, said to Arcesilaus as if he were addressing a very rigid man :
tgt_text.4077: — 0, noble man, may I a question put, Or must I hold my tongue ?
tgt_text.4079: — 0 wretched woman, why do you thus roughen Your voice, not speaking in your usual manner?
tgt_text.4080: And once, when he was plagued by a chattering fellow of low extraction, he said :
tgt_text.4082: The sons of slaves are always talking vilely.
tgt_text.4083: tAnother time, when a talkative mail was giving utterance to a great deal of nonsense, he said, that " He had not had a nurse who was severe enough."
tgt_text.4084: And to some people he never gave any answer at all.
tgt_text.4085: On one occasion a usurer, who made pretence to some learning, said in his hearing that he did not know something or other, on which he rejoined :
tgt_text.4087: For often times the passing winds do fill
tgt_text.4088: The female bird, except when big with young.
tgt_text.4089: JAnd the lines come out of the Ænomaus of Sophocles.
tgt_text.4090: He once reminded a certain dialectician, a pupil of Aleximes, who was unable to explain correctly some saying of his master, of what had been done by Philoxenus to some brick-makers.
tgt_text.4091: For when they were singing some of his songs very badly he came upon them, and trampled their bricks under foot, saying, " As you spoil my works so will I spoil yours.
tgt_text.4093: And he used to be very indignant with those who neglected proper opportunities of applying themselves to learn- ing ;
tgt_text.4094: and he had a peculiar habit, while conversing, of using the expression, " I think," and " So and so," naming the per- son, " will not agree to this."
tgt_text.4095: And this was imitated by several of his pupils, who copied also his style of expression and every- thing about him.
tgt_text.4096: He was a man very ready at inventing new words, and very quick at meeting objections, and at bringing round the conversation to the subject before him, and at adapt- ing it to every occasion, and he was the most convincing speaker that could be found, on which account numbers of people flocked to his school, in spite of being somewhat alarmed at his severity, which however they bore with complacency, for he was a very kind man, and one who inspired his hearers with abundant hope, and in his manner of life he was very affable and liberal, always ready to do any one a service with- out any parade, and shrinking from any expression of gratitude on the part of those whom he had obliged.
tgt_text.4098: when he had gone to visit Ctesibius who was ill, seeing him in great distress from want, he secretly slipped his purse under his pillow ;
tgt_text.4099: and when Ctesibius found it, " This," said he, " is the amusement of Arcesilaus."
tgt_text.4100: And at another time he sent him a thousand drachmas.
tgt_text.4101: He it was also who introduced Archias the Arcadian to Eumenes, and who procured him many favours from him.
tgt_text.4103: And being a very liberal man and utterly regardless of money, he made the most splendid display of silver plate, and in his exhibition of gold plate he vied with that of Arche- crates and Callecrates ;
tgt_text.4104: and he was constantly assisting and contributing to the wants of others with money;
tgt_text.4105: and once, when some one had borrowed from him some articles cf silver plate to help him entertain his friends, and did not offer to re- turn them, he never asked for them back or reclaimed them;
tgt_text.4106: but some say that he lent them with the purpose that they should be kept, and that when the man returned them, he made him a present of them as he was a poor man.
tgt_text.4107: He had also property in Pitana, the revenues from which were trans- mitted to him by his brother Pylades.XIV.
tgt_text.4108: Moreover, Eumenes, the son of Philetærus, supplied him with many things, on which account he was the only king to whom he addressed any of his discourses.
tgt_text.4109: And when many philosophers paid court to Antigonus and went out to meet him when he arrived, he himself kept quiet, not wishing to make his acquaintance.
tgt_text.4110: But he was a great friend of Hierocles, the governor of the harbours of Munychia and the Piræus;
tgt_text.4111: and at festivals he always paid him a visit.
tgt_text.4112: And when he constantly endeavoured to persuade him to pay his respects to Antigonus, he would not;
tgt_text.4113: but though he accom- panied him as far as his gates, he turned back himself.
tgt_text.4114: And after the sea-fight of Antigonus, when many people went to him and wrote him letters to comfort him for his defeat, he neither went nor wrote ;
tgt_text.4115: but still in the service of his country, he went to Demetrias as ambassador to Anti- gonus, and succeeded in the object of his mission.
tgt_text.4117: And he spent all his time in the Academy, and avoided meddling with public affairs, but at times he would spend some days in the Piraeus of Athens, discoursing on philo- sophical subjects, from his friendship for Hierocles, which conduct of his gave rise to unfavourable reports being raised against him by some people.
tgt_text.4119: Being a man of very expensive habits, for he was in this respect a sort of second Aristippus, he often went to dine with his friends.
tgt_text.4120: He also lived openly with Theodote and Philæte, two courtesans of Elis ;
tgt_text.4121: and to those who reproached him for this conduct, he used to quote the opinions of Aris- tippus.
tgt_text.4122: He was also very fond of the society of young men, and of a very affectionate disposition, on which account Aristi, the Chian, a Stoic philosopher, used to accuse him of being a corrupter of the youth of the city, and a profligate man.
tgt_text.4123: He is said also to have been greatly attached to Demetrius, who sailed to Cyrene, and to Cleochares of Mydea, of whom he said to his messmates, that he wished to open the door to him, but that he prevented him.
tgt_text.4125: Demochares the son of Laches, and Pythocles the son of Bugelus, were also among his friends, and he said that he humoured them in all their wishes because of his great patience.
tgt_text.4126: And, on this account, those people to whom I have before alluded, used to attack him and ridicule him as a popularity hunter and vain-glorious man.
tgt_text.4127: And they set upon him very violently at an entertainment given by Hieronymus, the Peripatetic, when he invited his friends on the birthday of Alcymeus, the son of Antigonus, on which occasion Anti- gonus sent him a large sum of money to promote the con- viviality.
tgt_text.4128: On this occasion, as he avoided all discussion during the continuance of the banquet, when Aridelus pro- posed to him a question which required some deliberation, and entreated him to discourse upon it, it is said that he replied, " But this is more especially the business of philosophy, to know the proper time for everything."
tgt_text.4129: With reference to the charge that was brought against him of being a popularity hunter, Timon speaks, among other matters, mentioning it in the following manner :
tgt_text.4131: He spoke and glided quick among the crowd, They gazed on him as finches who behold An owl among them.
tgt_text.4133: Alas, poor fool, 'tis no great matter that ;
tgt_text.4134: Why give yourself such airs for such a trifle ?
tgt_text.4136: However, in all other respects he was so free from vanity, that he used to advise his pupils to become the dis- ciples of other men ;
tgt_text.4137: and once, when a young man from Chios was not satisfied with his school, but preferred that of Hiero- nymus, whom I have mentioned before, he himself took him and introduced him to that philosopher, recommending him to preserve his regularity of conduct.
tgt_text.4138: And there is a very witty saying of his recorded.
tgt_text.4139: For when some one asked him once, why people left other schools to go to the Epicureans, but no one left the Epicureans to join other sects, he replied, " People sometimes make eunuchs of men, but no one can ever make a man out of an eunuch.
tgt_text.4141: At last, when he was near his end, he left all his property to his brother Pylades, because he, without the knowledge of Mæreas, had taken him to Chios and had brought him from thence to Athens.
tgt_text.4142: He never married a wife, and never had any children.
tgt_text.4143: He made three copies of his will, and deposited one in Eretria with Amphicritus, and one at Athens with some of his friends, and the third he sent to his own home to Thaumasias, one of his relations, en- treating him to keep it.
tgt_text.4144: And he also wrote him the following letter :
tgt_text.4146: I have given Diogenes a copy of my will to convey to you.
tgt_text.4147: For, because I am frequently unwell and have got very in- firm, I have thought it right to make a will, that, if anything should happen to me I might not depart with the feelings of having done you any injury, who have been so constantly af- fectionate to me.
tgt_text.4148: And as you have been at all times the most faithful to me of all my friends, I entreat you to preserve this for me out of regard for my old age and your regard for me.
tgt_text.4149: Take care then to behave justly towards me, remembering how much I entrust to your integrity, so that I may appear to have managed my affairs well, as far as depends on you;
tgt_text.4150: and there is another copy of this will at Athens, in the care of some of my friends, and another at Eretria, in the hands of Amphicritus."XX.
tgt_text.4151: He died, as Hermippus relates, after having drunk an excessive quantity of wine, and then became delirious, when he was seventy-five years old ;
tgt_text.4152: and he was more beloved by the Athenians than any one else had ever been.
tgt_text.4153: And we have written the following epigram on him :
tgt_text.4154: — 0 wise Arcesilaus, why didst thou drink
tgt_text.4155: So vast a quantity of unmixed wine, As to lose all your senses, and then die ?
tgt_text.4156: I pity you not so much for your death, As for the insult that you thus did offer The Muses, by your sad excess in wine.
tgt_text.4158: There were also three other persons of the name of Arcesilaus ;
tgt_text.4159: one a poet of the old Comedy ;
tgt_text.4161: the third a sculptor, on whom Simonides wrote the following epigram :
tgt_text.4163: This is a statue of chaste Dian's self
tgt_text.4164: The price two hundred Parian drachmas fine, Stamp'd with the image of the wanton goat.
tgt_text.4165: It is the work of wise Arcesilaus, The son of Aristodicus :
tgt_text.4166: a man, Whose hands Minerva guided in his art.
tgt_text.4167: The philosopher of whom we have been speaking flourished, as Apollodorus tells us in his Chronicles, about the hundred and twentieth olympiad.
tgt_text.4168: I. BION was a native of the country around the Borysthenes;
tgt_text.4169: but as to who his parents were, and to what circumstances it was owing that he applied himself to the study of philosophy, we know no more than what he himself told Antigonus.
tgt_text.4172: from whence, from whom you came,
tgt_text.4175: *He,'knowing that he had been misrepresented to the king, said to him, " My father was a freedman, who used to wipe his mouth with his sleeve," (by which he meant that he used to sell salt fish). "
tgt_text.4176: As to his race, he was a native of the district of the Borysthenes;
tgt_text.4177: having no countenance, but only a brand in his face, a token of the bitter cruelty of his master.
tgt_text.4178: My mother was such a woman as a man of that condition might marry, taken out of a brothel.
tgt_text.4179: Then, my father being in arrears to the tax-gatherers, was sold with all his family, and with me among them;
tgt_text.4180: and as I was young and good looking, a certain orator purchased me, and when he died he left me everything.
tgt_text.4181: And I, having burnt all his books, and torn up all his papers, came to Athens and applied myself to the study of Philo- sophy :
tgt_text.4183: Such was my father, and from him I came, The honoured author of my birth and name.
tgt_text.4184: tThis is all that I can tell you of myself:
tgt_text.4185: so that Persæus and Philonides may give up telling these stories about me :
tgt_text.4186: and you may judge of me on my own merits."
tgt_text.4188: And Bion was truly a man of great versatility, and a very subtle philosopher, and a man who gave all who chose great opportunities of practising philosophy.
tgt_text.4189: In some respects he was of a gentle disposition, and very much inclined to indulge in vanity.
tgt_text.4191: And he left behind him many memorials of himself in the way of writings, and also many apophthegms full of useful sentiments.
tgt_text.4192: As for instance, once when he was reproved for having failed to charm a young man, he replied, " You cannot possibly draw up cheese with a hook before it has got hard."
tgt_text.4193: On another occasion he was asked who was the most miserable of men, and replied, " He who has set his heart on the greatest prosperity."
tgt_text.4194: When he was asked whether it was advisable to marry (for this answer also is attributed to him), he replied, " If you marry an ugly woman you will have a punishment (ποινὴ), and if a handsome woman you will have one who is common" (ϰοινή).
tgt_text.4195: He called old age a port to shelter one from misfortune ;
tgt_text.4196: and accordingly, he said that every one fled to it.
tgt_text.4197: He said that glory was the mother of years ;
tgt_text.4198: that beauty was a good which concerned others rather than one's self;
tgt_text.4199: that riches were the sinews of business.
tgt_text.4200: To a man who had squandered his estate he said, " The earth swallowed up Amphiaraus, but you have swallowed up the earth."
tgt_text.4201: Another saying of his was that it was a great evil not to be able to bear evil.
tgt_text.4202: And he condemned those who burnt the dead as though they felt nothing, and then mocked them as though they did feel.
tgt_text.4203: And he was always saying that it was better to put one's own beauty at the disposal of another, than to covet the beauty of others ;
tgt_text.4204: for that one who did so was injuring both his body and his soul.
tgt_text.4205: And he used to blame Socrates saying, that if he derived no advantage from Alcibiades he was foolish, and if he never derived any advantage from him he then deserved no credit.
tgt_text.4206: He used to say that the way to the shades below was easy;
tgt_text.4207: and accordingly, that people went there with their eyes shut.
tgt_text.4208: He used to blame Alcibiades, saying that while he was a boy he seduced husbands from their wives, and when he had become a young man he seduced the wives from their husbands.
tgt_text.4209: While most of the Athenians at Rhodes practised rhetoric, he himself used to give lectures on philoso- phical subjects;
tgt_text.4210: and to one who blamed him for this he said, " I have bought wheat, and I sell barley.
tgt_text.4211: "It was a saying of his that the inhabitants of the shades below would be more punished if they carried water in buckets that were whole, than in such as were bored.
tgt_text.4212: To a chattering fellow who was soliciting him for aid, he said, " I will do what is sufficient for you, if you will send deputies to me, and forbear to come yourself."
tgt_text.4213: Once when he was at sea in the company of some wicked men, he fell into the hands of pirates;
tgt_text.4214: and when the rest said, " We are undone, if we are known."
tgt_text.4215: " But I," said he, "am undone if we are not known."
tgt_text.4216: He used to say that self-conceit was the enemy of progress.
tgt_text.4217: Of a rich man who was mean and niggardly, he said, " That man does not possess his estate, but his estate possesses him."
tgt_text.4218: He used to say that stingy men took care of their property as if it was their own, but derived no advantage from it as if it belonged to other people.
tgt_text.4219: Another of his sayings was, that young men ought to display courage, but that old men ought to be distinguished for prudence.
tgt_text.4220: And that prudence was as much superior to the other virtues as sight was to the other senses.
tgt_text.4221: And that it was not right to speak of old age, at which every one is desirous to arrive.
tgt_text.4222: To an envious man who was looking gloomy, he said, " I know not whether it is because some misfortune has happened to you, or some good fortune to some one else."
tgt_text.4223: One thing that he used to say was, that a mean extraction was a bad companion to freedom of speech.
tgt_text.4226: It does enslave a man, however bold His speech may be.
tgt_text.4227: *And another was that we ought to keep our friends, what- ever sort of people they may be, so that we may not seem to have been intimate with wicked men, or to have abandoned good men.
tgt_text.4229: Very early in his career he abandoned the school of the Academy, and at the same time became a disciple of Crates.
tgt_text.4230: Then he passed over to the sect of the Cynics, taking their coarse cloak and wallet.
tgt_text.4231: For what else could ever have changed his nature into one of such apathy ?
tgt_text.4232: After that he adopted the Theodorean principles, having become a disciple of Theodorus the Atheist, who was used to employ every kind of reasoning in support of his system of philosophy.
tgt_text.4233: After leaving him, he became a pupil of Theophrastus, the Peripa.
tgt_text.4235: He was very fond of theatrical entertainments, and very skilful in distracting his hearers by exciting a laugh, giving things disparaging names.
tgt_text.4236: And because he used to avail himself of every species of reasoning, they relate that Eretos- thenes said that Bion was the first person who had clothed philosophy in a flowery robe.
tgt_text.4238: He was also very ingenious in parodying passages, and adapting them to circumstances as they arose.
tgt_text.4239: As for instance, I may cite the following :
tgt_text.4240: - Tender Archytas, born of tuneful lyre, Whom thoughts of happy vanity inspire;
tgt_text.4241: Most skilled of mortals in appeasing ire.
tgt_text.4242: *And he jested on every part of music and geometry.
tgt_text.4244: He was a man of very expensive habits, and on this account he used to go from city to city, and at times he would contrive the most amazing devices.
tgt_text.4246: Accordingly, in Rhodes, he persuaded the sailors to put on the habiliments of philosophical students and follow him about;
tgt_text.4247: and then he made himself conspicuous by entering the gymnasium with this train of followers.
tgt_text.4249: He was accustomed also to adopt young men as his sons, in order to derive assistance from them in his pleasures, and to be protected by their affection for him.
tgt_text.4250: But he was a very selfish man, and very fond of quoting the saying, " The property of friends is common ;
tgt_text.4251: ” owing to which it is that no one is spoken of as a disciple of his, though so many men attended his school.
tgt_text.4252: And he made some very shameless ;
tgt_text.4253: accordingly, Betion, one of his intimate acquaintances, is reported to have said once to Menedemus, " So Menedemus constantly spends the evening with Bion, and I see no harm in it."
tgt_text.4254: He used also to talk with great impiety to those who conversed with him, having derived his opinions on this subject from Theodorus.X.
tgt_text.4255: And when at a later period he became afflicted with disease, as the people of Chalets said, for he died there, he was persuaded to wear amulets and charms, and to show his repentance for the insults that he had offered to the Gods.
tgt_text.4256: But he suffered fearfully for want of proper people to attend him, until Antigonus sent him two servants.
tgt_text.4257: And he followed him in a litter, as Pharorinus relates in his Universal History.
tgt_text.4258: And the circumstances of his death we have ourselves spoken of in the following lines :
tgt_text.4260: We hear that Bion the Borysthenite, Whom the ferocious Scythian land brought forth, Used to deny that there were Gods at all.
tgt_text.4261: Now, if he'd persevered in this opinion, One would have said he speaks just as he thinks ;
tgt_text.4262: Though certainly his thoughts are quite mistaken.
tgt_text.4263: But when a lengthened sickness overtook him, And he began to fear lest he should die ;
tgt_text.4264: This man who heretofore denied the Gods, And would not even look upon a temple, And mocked all those who e'er approached the Gods With prayer or sacrifice ;
tgt_text.4265: who ne'er, not even For his own hearth, and home, and household table, Regaled the Gods with savoury fat and incense, Who never once said, “ I have sinned, but spare me."
tgt_text.4266: Then did this atheist shrink, and give his neck
tgt_text.4267: To an old woman to hang charms upon, And bound his arms with magic amulets, With laurel branches blocked his doors and windows, Ready to do and venture anything Rather than die.
tgt_text.4268: Fool that he was, who thought To win the Gods to come into existence, Whenever he might think he wanted them.
tgt_text.4269: So wise too late, when now mere dust and ashes, He put his hand forth, Hail, great Pluto, Hail!
tgt_text.4271: There were ten people of the name of Bion.
tgt_text.4272: First of all, the one who flourished at the same time with Pherecydes of Syros, and who has left two books behind him, which are still extant;
tgt_text.4273: he was a native of Proconnesas.
tgt_text.4274: The second was a Syracusan, the author of a system of rhetoric.
tgt_text.4275: The third was the man of whom we have been speaking.
tgt_text.4276: The fourth was a pupil of Democritus, and a mathematician, a native of Abdera, who wrote in both the Attic and Ionic dialect.
tgt_text.4277: He was the person who first asserted that there were countries where there was night for six months, and day for six months.
tgt_text.4278: The fifth was a native of Soli;
tgt_text.4279: who wrote a history of Æthiopia.
tgt_text.4280: The sixth was a rhetorician, who has left behind him nine books, inscribed with the names of the Muses, which are still extant.
tgt_text.4281: The eighth was a Milesian statuary, who is mentioned by Polemo.
tgt_text.4282: The ninth was a tragic poet of the number of those who are called Tarsicans.
tgt_text.4283: The tenth was a statuary, a native of Clazomenæ or Chios, who is mentioned by Hipponax.
tgt_text.4284: I. LACYDES, the sen of Alexander, was a native of Cvrene.
tgt_text.4285: He it is who was the founder of the New Academy, having succeeded Arcesilaus;
tgt_text.4286: and he was a man of great gravity of character and demeanour, and one who had many imitators.
tgt_text.4288: He was industrious from his very childhood, and poor, but very pleasing and sociable in his manners.
tgt_text.4290: They say that he had a pleasant way of managing his house-keeping affairs.
tgt_text.4291: For when he had taken anything out of his store-chest, he would seal it up again, and throw in his seal through the hole, so that it should be impossible for any- thing of what he had laid up there to be stolen from him, or carried off.
tgt_text.4292: But his servants learning this contrivance of his, broke the seal, and carried off as much as they pleased, and then they put the ring back through the hole in the same manner as before ;
tgt_text.4293: and though they did this repeatedly, they were never detected.
tgt_text.4295: Lacydes now used to hold his school in the Academy in the garden which had been laid out by Attains the king, and it was called, the Lacydeum, after him.
tgt_text.4296: And he was the only man, who, while alive, resigned his school to a successor ;
tgt_text.4297: but he resigned this to Telicles and Evander, of Phocis ;
tgt_text.4298: and Hegesinus, of Pergamus, succeeded Evander;
tgt_text.4299: and he himself was in his turn succeeded by Carneades.V.
tgt_text.4300: There is a witty saying, which is attributed to Lacydes.
tgt_text.4301: For they say that when Attalus sent for him, he answered that statues ought to be seen at a distance.
tgt_text.4302: On another occasion, as it is reported, he was studying geometry very late in life, and some said to him, " Is it then a time for you to be learning now ?" " If it is not, he replied, " when will it be ?"VI.
tgt_text.4303: And he died in the fourth year of the hundred and thirty-fourth Olympiad, when he had presided over his school twenty-six years.
tgt_text.4304: And his death was caused by paralysis, which was brought on by drinking.
tgt_text.4305: And we ourselves have jested upon him in the following language.
tgt_text.4306: 'Tis an odd story that I heard of you— Lacydes, that you went with hasty steps, Spurred on by Bacchus, to the shades below.
tgt_text.4307: How then, if this be true, can it be said, That Bacchus e'er trips up his votaries' feet 'Tis a mistake his being named Lyæus.*I. CARNEADES was the son of Epicomus, or Philocomus, as Alexander states in his Successions ;
tgt_text.4310: He read all the books of the Stoics with great care, and especially those of Chrysippus ;
tgt_text.4311: and then he wrote replies to them, but did it at the same time with such modesty that he used to say, " If Chrysippus had not lived, I should never have existed."
tgt_text.4313: He was a man of as great industry as ever existed :
tgt_text.4314: not, however, very much devoted to the investigation of subjects of natural philosophy, but more fond of the discussion of ethical topics, on which account he used to let his hair and his nails grow, from his entire devotion of all his time to philosophical discussion.
tgt_text.4315: And he was so eminent as a philosopher, that the orators would quit their own schools and come and listen to his lectures.
tgt_text.4317: He was also a man of a very powerful voice, so that the president of the Gymnasium sent to him once, to desire he would not shout so loudly.
tgt_text.4318: And he replied, " Give me then, measure for my voice."
tgt_text.4319: And the gymnasiarch again rejoined with great wit, for he said, "You have a measure in your pupils."V.
tgt_text.4320: He was a very vehement speaker, and one difficult to contend with in the investigation of a point.
tgt_text.4321: And he used to decline all invitations to entertainments, for the reasons I have already mentioned.
tgt_text.4323: On one occasion, when Mentor, the Bithynian, one of his pupils, came to him to attend his school, observing that he was trying to seduce his mistress (as Phavorinus relates in his Universal History), while he was in the middle of his lecture, he made the following parody in allusion to him:
tgt_text.4325: A weak old man comes hither, like in voice, And gait, and figure, to the prudent Mentor I order him to be expelled this school.
tgt_text.4327: - Thus did they speak, and straight the others rose.
tgt_text.4329: He appears to have been beset with fears of death;
tgt_text.4330: as he was continually saying, " Nature, who has put this frame together, will also dissolve it."
tgt_text.4331: And learning that Antipater had died after having taken poison, he felt a desire to imitate the boldness of his departure, and said, " Give me some too."
tgt_text.4332: And when they asked “What?” "Some mead," said he.
tgt_text.4333: And it is said that an eclipse of the moon happened when he died, the most beautiful of all the stars, next to the sun, in- dicating (as any one might say) its sympathy with the philo- sopher.
tgt_text.4334: And Apollodorus, in his Chronicles, says that he died in the fourth year of the hundred and sixty-second olym- piad, being eighty-five years old.
tgt_text.4336: There are some letters extant addressed by him to Ariarathes, the king of the Cappadocians.
tgt_text.4337: All- the other writings which are attributed to him were written by his disciples, for he himself left nothing behind him.
tgt_text.4338: And I have written on him the following lines in logoaedical Arche- bulian metre.
tgt_text.4339: Why now, 0 Muse, do you wish me Carneades to confute ?
tgt_text.4340: He was an ignoramus, as he did not understand
tgt_text.4341: Why he should stand in fear of death :
tgt_text.4342: so once, when he'd a cough, The worst of all diseases that affect the human frame, He cared not for a remedy ;
tgt_text.4343: but when the news did reach him, That brave Antipater had ta'en some poison, and so died, “ Give me, said he, some stuff to drink." " Some what ?”—“ Some lus- cious mead."
tgt_text.4344: Moreover, he'd this saying at all times upon his lips :
tgt_text.4346: Nature did make me, and she does together keep me still;
tgt_text.4347: But soon the time will come when she will pull me all to pieces."
tgt_text.4348: But still at last he yielded up the ghost:
tgt_text.4350: He might have died, and so escaped the evils that befell him.
tgt_text.4352: It is said that at night he was not aware when lights were brought in ;
tgt_text.4353: and that once he ordered his servant to light the candles, and when he had brought them in and told him, " I have brought them;
tgt_text.4354: " "Well then," said he, "read by the light of them."X.
tgt_text.4355: He had a great many other disciples;
tgt_text.4356: but the most eminent of them was Clitomachus, whom we must mention presently.
tgt_text.4358: There was also another man of the name of Carneades, a very indifferent elegiac poet.
tgt_text.4360: He was called Asdrubal, and used to lecture on philosophy in his own country in his native language.
tgt_text.4362: But when he came to Athens, at the age of forty years, he became a pupil of Carneades ;
tgt_text.4363: and, as he was pleased with his industry, he caused him to be instructed in literature, and himself educated the man carefully.
tgt_text.4364: And he carried his diligence to such a degree, that he composed more than four hundred books.
tgt_text.4366: And he succeeded Carneades in his schools;
tgt_text.4367: and he illustrated his principles a great deal by his writings:
tgt_text.4368: as he himself had studied the doctrines of their sects, the Academic, the Peripatetic, and the Stoic.
tgt_text.4369: Timon attacks the whole school- of Academics, as a body, in these lines;
tgt_text.4371: Nor the unprofitable chattering Of all the Academies.
tgt_text.4372: But now that we have gone through the philosophers of Plato's school, let us go to the Peripatetics, who also derived their doctrines from Plato ;
tgt_text.4373: and the founder of their sect was Aristotle.
tgt_text.4374: I. ARISTOTLE was the son of Nicomachus and Phæstias, a citizen of Stagira;
tgt_text.4375: and Nicomachus was descended from Nicomachus, the son of Machaon, the son of Æsculapius, as Hermippus tells us in his treatise on Aristotle ;
tgt_text.4376: and he lived with Amyntas, the king of the Macedonians, as both a physician and a friend.
tgt_text.4378: He was the most eminent of all the pupils of Plato ;
tgt_text.4379: he had a lisping voice, as is asserted by Timotheus the Athenian, in his work on Lives.
tgt_text.4380: He had also very thin legs, they say, and small eyes;
tgt_text.4381: but he used to indulge in very conspicuous.
tgt_text.4382: dress, and rings, and used to dress his hair carefully.
tgt_text.4384: He had also a son named Nicomachus, by Herpyllis his concubine, as we are told by Timotheus.
tgt_text.4386: He seceded from Plato while he was still alive ;
tgt_text.4387: so that they tell a story that he said, " Aristotle has kicked us off just as chickens do their mother after they have been hatched."
tgt_text.4388: But Hermippus says in his Lives, that while he was absent on an embassy to Philip, on behalf of the Athenians, Xenocrates became the president of the school in the Academy ;
tgt_text.4389: and that when he returned and saw the school under the presidency of some one else, he selected a promenade in the Lyceum, in which he used to walk up and down with his disciples, dis- cussing subjects of philosophy till the time for anointing themselves came ;
tgt_text.4390: on which account he was called a Peripa- tetic.*
tgt_text.4391: But others say that he got this name because once when Alexander was walking about after recovering from a sickness, he accompanied him and kept conversing with him.
tgt_text.4392: But when his pupils became numerous, he then gave them seats, saying:
tgt_text.4393: — It would be shame for me to hold my peace, And for Isocrates to keep on talking.
tgt_text.4394: And lie used to accustom his disciples to discuss any question which might be proposed, training them just as an orator might.
tgt_text.4396: After that he went to Hermias the Eunuch, the tyrant of Atarneus, who, as it is said, allowed him all kinds of liberties ;
tgt_text.4397: and some say that he formed a matrimonial connec- tion with him, giving him either his daughter or his niece in marriage, as is recorded by Demetrius of Magnesia,? in his essay on Poets and Prose-writers of the same name.
tgt_text.4398: And the same authority says that Hermias had been the slave of Eubulus, and a Bithynian by descent, and that he slew his master.
tgt_text.4399: But Aristippus, in the first book of his treatise on Ancient Luxury, says that Aristotle was enamoured of the concubine of Hermias, and that, as Hermias gave his consent, he married her;
tgt_text.4400: and was so overjoyed that he sacrificed to her, as the Athenians do to the Eleusinian Ceres.
tgt_text.4401: And he wrote a hymn to Hermias, which is given at length below.
tgt_text.4403: After that he lived in Macedonia, at the court of Philip, and was entrusted by, him with his son Alexander as a pupil;
tgt_text.4404: and he entreated him to restore his native city which had been destroyed by Philip, and had his request granted ;
tgt_text.4405: and he also made laws for the citizens.
tgt_text.4406: And also he used to make laws in his schools, doing this in imitation of Xeno- crates, so that he appointed a president every ten days.
tgt_text.4407: And when he thought that he had spent time enough with Alex- ander, he departed for Athens, having recommended to him his relation Callisthenes, a native of Olynthus ;
tgt_text.4408: but as he spoke too freely to the king, and would not take Aristotle's advice, he reproached him and said:
tgt_text.4410: my child, in life's primeval bloom, Such hasty words will bring thee to thy doom.
tgt_text.4411: *And his prophecy was fulfilled, for as he was believed by Hermolaus to have been privy to the plot against Alexander, he was shut up in an iron cage, covered with lice, and untended ;
tgt_text.4412: and at last he was given to a lion, and so died,VII.
tgt_text.4413: Aristotle then having come to Athens, and having presided over his school there for thirteen years, retired secretly to Chalets, as Eurymedon, the hierophant had im- peached him on an indictment for impiety, though Pharorinus, in his Universal History, says that his prosecutor was Demo- phelus, on the ground of having written the hymn to the beforementioned Hermias, and also the following epigram which was engraven on his statue at Delphi ;
tgt_text.4415: The tyrant of the Persian archer race, Broke through the laws of God to slay this man;
tgt_text.4416: Not by the manly spear in open fight, But by the treachery of a faithless friend.
tgt_text.4417: And after that he died of taking a draught of aconite, as Eumelus says in the fifth book of his Histories, at the age of seventy years.
tgt_text.4418: And the same author says that he was thirty years old when he first became acquainted with Plato.
tgt_text.4419: But this is a mistake of his, for he did only live in reality sixty- three years, and he was seventeen years old when he first attached himself to Plato.
tgt_text.4420: And the hymn in honour of Hermias is as follows :
tgt_text.4421: — 0 Virtue, won by earnest strife, And holding out the noblest prize
tgt_text.4422: That ever gilded earthly life, Or drew it on to seek the skies;
tgt_text.4423: For thee what son of Greece would not Deem it an enviable lot, To live the life, to die the death, That fears no weary hour, shrinks from no fiery breath ?
tgt_text.4424: Such fruit hast thou of heavenly bloom, A lure more rich than golden heap, More tempting than the joys of home, More bland than spell of soft-eyed sleep.
tgt_text.4425: For thee Alcides, son of Jove, And the twin boys of Leda strove, With patient toil and sinewy might, Thy glorious prize to grasp, to reach thy lofty height.
tgt_text.4426: Achilles, Ajax, for thy love Descended to the realms of night;
tgt_text.4428: King thy vision drove, To quit for aye the glad sun-light, Therefore, to memory's daughters dear, His deathless name, his pure career, Live shrined in song, and link'd with awe, The awe of Xenian Jove, and faithful friendship's law.
tgt_text.4429: *There is also an epigram of ours upon him, which runs thus :
tgt_text.4431: Of the mysterious Eleusinian Queen, Was once about t' impeach the Stagirite Of impious guilt.
tgt_text.4433: By mighty draught of friendly aconite, And thus defeated all his wicked arts.
tgt_text.4434: Pharorinus, in his Universal History, says that Aristotle was the first person who ever composed a speech to be delivered in his own defence in a court of justice, and that he did so on the occasion of this prosecution, and said that at Athens :
tgt_text.4438: Apollodorus, in his Chronicles, says that he was born in the first year of the ninety-ninth olympiad, and that he attached himself to Plato, and remained with him for twenty years, having been seventeen years of age when he originally joined him.
tgt_text.4439: And he went to Mitylene in the archonsbip of Eubulus, in the fourth year of the hundred and eighth olympiad.
tgt_text.4440: But as Plato had died in the first year of this same olympiad, in the archonship of Theophilus, he departed for the court of Hermias, and remained there three years.
tgt_text.4441: And in the archon- ship of Pythodotus he went to the court of Philip, in the second year of the hundred and ninth olympiad, when Alexander was fifteen years old ;
tgt_text.4442: and he came to Athens in the second year of the hundred and eleventh olympiad, and presided over his school in the Lyceum for thirteen years:
tgt_text.4443: after that he departed to Chalcis, in the third year of the hundred and fourteenth olympiad, and died, at about the age of sixty-three years, of disease, the same year that Demosthenes died in Calumia, in the archonship of Philocles.
tgt_text.4445: It is said also that he was offended with the king.
tgt_text.4446: because of the result of the conspiracy of Calisthenes against Alexander;
tgt_text.4447: and that the king, for the sake of annoying him, promoted Anaximenes to honour, and sent presents to Xeno- crates.
tgt_text.4448: And Theocritus, of Chios, wrote an epigram upon him to ridicule him, in the following terms, as it is quoted by Ambryon in his account of Theocritus :
tgt_text.4451: This empty tomb to Hermias the Eunuch, The ancient slave of the ill-us'd Eubulus.
tgt_text.4452: [Who, for his monstrous appetite, preferred The Bosphorus to Academia's groves.]
tgt_text.4453: And Timon attacked him too, saying of him :
tgt_text.4455: Nor the sad chattering of the empty Aristotle.
tgt_text.4456: Such was the life of the philosopher.
tgt_text.4458: We have also met with his will, which is couched in the following terms :
tgt_text.4461: but if any thing happens to him, in that case Aristotle has made the following disposition of his affairs.
tgt_text.4462: That Antipater shall be the general and universal executor.
tgt_text.4463: And until Nicanor marries my daughter, I appoint Aristomedes, Timarchus, Hipparchus, Dioteles, and Theophrastus, if he will consent and accept the charge, to be the guardians of my children and of Herpyllis, and the trustees of all the property I leave behind me ;
tgt_text.4464: and I desire them, when my daughter is old enough, to give her in marriage to Nicanor;
tgt_text.4465: but if any thing should happen to the girl, which may God forbid, either before or after she is mar- ried, but before she has any children, then I will that Nicanor shall have the absolute disposal of my son, and of all other things, in the full confidence that he will arrange them in a manner worthy of me and of himself.
tgt_text.4466: Let him also be the guardian of my daughter and son Nicomachus, to act as he pleases with respect to them, as if he were their father or brother.
tgt_text.4467: But if anything should happen to Nicanor, which may God forbid, either before he receives my daughter in marriage, or after he is married to her, or before he has any children by her, then any arrangements which he may make by will shall stand.
tgt_text.4468: But, if Theophrastus, in this case, should choose to take my daughter in marriage, then he is to stand exactly in the same position as Nicanor.
tgt_text.4469: And if not, then I will, that my trustees, consulting with Antipater concerning both the boy and girl, shall arrange everything respecting them as they shall think fit;
tgt_text.4470: and that my trustees and Nicanor, remembering both me and Herpyllis, and how well she has behaved to me, shall take care, if she be inclined to take a husband, that one be found for her who shall not be unworthy of us;
tgt_text.4471: and shall give her, in addition to all that has been already given her, a talent of silver, and three maidservants if she please to accept them, and the handmaid whom she has • now, and the boy Pyrrhæus.
tgt_text.4472: And if she likes to dwell at Chalets, she shall have the house which joins the garden ;
tgt_text.4473: but if she likes to dwell in Stagira, then she shall have my father's house.
tgt_text.4474: And whichever of these houses she elects to take, I will that my executors do furnish it with all necessary furniture, in such manner as shall seem to them and to Herpyllis to be sufficient.
tgt_text.4475: And let Nicanor be the guardian of the child Myrmex, so that he shall be conducted to his friends in a manner worthy of us, with all his property which I received.
tgt_text.4476: I also will that Aubracis shall have her liberty, and that there shall be given to her when her daughter is married, five hundred drachmas, and the handmaid whom she now has.
tgt_text.4477: And I will that there be given to Thales, besides the hand- maiden whom she now has, who was bought for her, a thousand drachmas and another handmaid.
tgt_text.4478: And to Timon, in addition to the money that has been given to him before for another boy, an additional slave, or a sum of money which shall be equivalent.
tgt_text.4479: I also will that Tychon shall have his liberty when his daughter is married, and Philon, and Olympius, and his son.
tgt_text.4480: Moreover, of those boys who wait upon me, I will that none shall be sold, but my executors may use them, and when they are grown up then they shall emancipate them if they deserve it.
tgt_text.4481: I desire too, that my executors will take under their care the statues which it has been entrusted to Gryllion to make, that when they are made they may be erected in their proper places ;
tgt_text.4482: and so too shall the statues of Nicanor, and of Proxenus, which I was intending to give him a commission for, and also that of the mother of Nicanor.
tgt_text.4483: I wish them also to erect in its proper place the statue of Arimnestus which is already made, that it may be a memorial of her, since she has died childless.
tgt_text.4484: I wish them also to dedicate a statue of my mother to Ceres at Nemea, or where- ever else they think fit.
tgt_text.4485: And wherever they bury me, there I desire that they shall also place the bones of Pythias, having taken them up from the place where they now lie, as she herself enjoined.
tgt_text.4486: And I desire that Nicanor, as he has been preserved, will perform the vow which I made on his behalf, and dedicate some figures of animals in stone, four cubits high, to Jupiter the saviour, and Minerva the saviour, in Stagira.
tgt_text.4487: "These are the provisions of his will.X.
tgt_text.4488: And it is said that a great many dishes were found in his house ;
tgt_text.4489: and that Lycon stated that he used to bathe in a bath of warm oil, and afterwards to sell the oil.
tgt_text.4490: But some say that he used to place a leather bag of warm oil on his stomach.
tgt_text.4491: And whenever he went to bed, he used to take a brazen ball in his hand, having arranged a brazen dish below it;
tgt_text.4492: so that, when the ball fell into the dish, he might be awakened by the noise.
tgt_text.4494: The following admirable apophthegms are attributed to him.
tgt_text.4495: He was once asked, what those who tell lies gain by it;
tgt_text.4496: " They gain this," said he, " that when they speak truth they are not believed.
tgt_text.4497: "On one occasion he was blamed for giving alms to a worth- less man, and he replied, " I did not pity the man, but his condition.
tgt_text.4498: "He was accustomed continually to say to his friends and pupils wherever he happened to be, " That sight receives the light from the air which surrounds it, and in like manner the soul receives the light from the science.
tgt_text.4499: "Very often, when he was inveighing against the Athenians, he would say that they had invented both wheat and laws, but that they used only the wheat and neglected the laws.
tgt_text.4500: It was a saying of his that the roots of education were bitter, but the fruit sweet.
tgt_text.4501: Once he was asked what grew old most speedily, and he re- plied, " Gratitude.
tgt_text.4502: "On another occasion the question was put to him, what hope is ?
tgt_text.4503: and his answer was, " The dream of a waking man.
tgt_text.4504: "Diogenes once offered him a dry fig, and as he conjectured that if he did not take it the cynic had a witticism ready pre- pared, he accepted it, and then said that Diogenes had lost his joke and his fig too ;
tgt_text.4505: and another time when he took one from him as he offered it, he held it up as a child does, and said, " 0 great Diogenes ;
tgt_text.4506: " and then he gave it to him back again.
tgt_text.4507: He used to say that there were three things necessary to education ;
tgt_text.4509: Having heard that he was abused by some one, he said, " He may beat me too, if he likes, in my absence." ''
tgt_text.4510: He used to say that beauty is the best of all recommenda- tions, but others say that it was Diogenes who gave this de- scription of it;
tgt_text.4511: and that Aristotle called beauty, " The gift of a fair appearance;
tgt_text.4512: " that Socrates called it "A short-lived tyranny ;
tgt_text.4516: " Car- neades, " A sovereignty which stood in need of no guards.
tgt_text.4517: "On one occasion he was asked how much educated men were superior to those uneducated ;
tgt_text.4519: As much," said he, " as the living are to the dead.
tgt_text.4520: "It was a saying of his that education was an ornament in prosperity, and a refuge in adversity.
tgt_text.4521: And that those parents who gave their children a good education deserved more honour than those who merely beget them:
tgt_text.4522: for that the latter only enabled their children to live, but the former gave them the power of living well.
tgt_text.4523: When a man boasted in his presence that he was a native of an illustrious city, he said, " That is not what one ought to look at, but whether one is worthy of a great city.
tgt_text.4524: "He was once asked what a friend is ;
tgt_text.4525: and is answer was, " One soul abiding in two bodies.
tgt_text.4526: "It was a saying of his that some men were as stingy as if they expected to live for ever, and some as extravagant as if they expected to die immediately.
tgt_text.4527: When he was asked why people like to spend a great deal of their time with 'handsome people, " That," said he, " is a question fit for a blind man to ask.
tgt_text.4528: "The question was once put to him, what he had gained by philosophy ;
tgt_text.4529: and the answer he made was this, " That I do without being commanded, what others do from fear of the laws.
tgt_text.4530: "He was once asked what his disciples ought to do to get on ;
tgt_text.4531: and he replied, " Press on upon those who are in front of them, and not wait for those who are behind to catch them.
tgt_text.4532: "A chattering fellow, who had been abusing him, said to him, " Have not I been jeering you properly ? "
tgt_text.4533: Not that I know of," said he, " for I have not been listening to you.
tgt_text.4534: "A man on one occasion reproached him for having given a contribution to one who was not a good man (for the story which I have mentioned before is also quoted in this way), and his answer was, " I gave not to the man, but to humanity.
tgt_text.4535: "The question was once put to him, how we ought to behave to our friends;
tgt_text.4536: and the answer he gave was, " As we should wish our friends to behave to us.
tgt_text.4537: "He used to define justice as " A virtue of the soul distribu- five of what each person deserved.
tgt_text.4538: "Another of his sayings was, that education was the best viaticum for old age.
tgt_text.4539: Pharorinus, in the second book of his Commentaries, says that he was constantly repeating, " The man who has friends has no friend."
tgt_text.4540: And this sentiment is to be found also in the seventh book of the Ethics.
tgt_text.4541: These apophthegms then are attributed to him.
tgt_text.4543: He also wrote a great number of works ;
tgt_text.4544: and I have thought it worth while to give a list of them, on account of the eminence of their author in every branch of philo- sophy.

tgt_text.4704: These then are the books which were written by him.
tgt_text.4705: And in them he expresses the following opinions :
tgt_text.4706: -that there is in philosophy a two-fold division;
tgt_text.4707: one practical, and the other theoretical.
tgt_text.4708: Again, the practical is divided into ethical and political, under which last head are comprised considerations affecting not only the state, but also the management, of a single house.
tgt_text.4709: The theoretical part, too, is subdivided into physics and logic;
tgt_text.4710: the latter forming not a single division, turning on one special point, but being rather an instrument for every art brought to a high degree of accuracy.
tgt_text.4711: And he has laid down two separate objects as what it is conversant about, the persuasive and the true.
tgt_text.4712: And he has used two means with reference to each end;
tgt_text.4713: dialectics and rhetoric, with reference to persuasion;
tgt_text.4714: analytical examination and philosophy, with reference to truth;
tgt_text.4715: omitting nothing which can bear upon discovery, or judgment, or use.
tgt_text.4716: Accordingly, with re- ference to discovery, he has furnished us with topics and works on method, which form a complete armoury of propo- sitions, from which it is easy to provide one's self with an abundance of probable arguments for every kind of question.
tgt_text.4717: And with reference to judgment, he has given us the former and posterior analytics;
tgt_text.4718: and by means of the former ana- lytics, we may arrive at a critical examination of principles;
tgt_text.4719: by means of the posterior, we may examine the conclusions which are deduced from them.
tgt_text.4720: With reference to the use or application of his rules, he has given us works on discussion, on question, on disputation, on sophistical refutation, on syllogism, and on things of that sort.
tgt_text.4721: He has also furnished us with a double criterion of truth.
tgt_text.4722: One, on the perception of those effects, which are according to imagination ;
tgt_text.4723: the other, the intelligence of those things which are ethical, and which concern politics, and economy, and laws.
tgt_text.4724: The chief good he has defined to be the exercise of virtue in a perfect life.
tgt_text.4725: He used also to say, that happi- ness was a thing made up of three kinds of goods.
tgt_text.4726: First of all, the goods of the soul, which he also calls the principal goods in respect of their power;
tgt_text.4727: secondly, the goods of the body, such as health, strength, beauty, and things of that sort;
tgt_text.4728: thirdly, external goods, such as wealth, nobility of birth, glory, and things like those.
tgt_text.4729: And he taught that virtue was not sufficient of itself to confer happiness;
tgt_text.4730: for that it had need besides of the goods of the body, and of the external goods, for that a wise mail would be miserable if he were surrounded by distress, and poverty, and circumstances of that kind.
tgt_text.4731: But, on the other hand, he said, that vice was sufficient of itself to cause unhappiness, even if the goods of the body and the external goods were present in the greatest possible degree.
tgt_text.4732: He also asserted that the virtues did not reciprocally follow one another, for that it was possible for a prudent, and just, and impartial man, to be incontinent and intemperate ;
tgt_text.4733: and he said, that the wise man was not des- titute of passions, but endowed with moderate passions.
tgt_text.4734: He also used to define friendship as an equality of mutual benevolence.
tgt_text.4735: And he divided it into the friendship of kindred, and of love, and of those connected by ties of hospitality.
tgt_text.4736: And he said, that love was divided into sensual and philo- sophical love.
tgt_text.4737: And that the wise man would feel the influence of love, and would occupy himself in affairs of state, and would marry a wife, and would live with a king.
tgt_text.4738: And as there were three kinds of life, the speculative, the practical, and the voluptuous, he preferred the speculative.
tgt_text.4739: He also considered the acquisition of general knowledge serviceable to the acquisition of virtue.
tgt_text.4740: As a natural philosopher, he was the most ingenious man that ever lived in tracing effects back to, their causes, so that he could explain the principles of the most trifling circumstances ;
tgt_text.4741: on which account he wrote a great many books of commentaries on physical questions.
tgt_text.4742: He used to teach that God was incorporeal, as Plato also asserted, and that his providence extends over all the heavenly bodies;
tgt_text.4743: also, that he is incapable of motion.
tgt_text.4744: And that he governs all things upon earth with reference to their sympathy with the heavenly bodies.
tgt_text.4745: Another of his doctrines was, that besides the four elements there is one other, making the fifth, of which all the heavenly bodies are composed ;
tgt_text.4746: and that this one possesses a motion peculiar to itself, for it is a circular one.
tgt_text.4747: That the soul is incorporeal, being the first έντελἐχεια;
tgt_text.4748: for it is the ἐντελέχεια, of a physical and organic body, having an existence in consequence of a capacity for existence.
tgt_text.4749: And this is, according to him, of a twofold nature.
tgt_text.4750: By the word ἐντελέχεια, he means something which has an incoporeal species, either in capacity, as a figure of Mercury in wax, which has a capacity for assuming any shape;
tgt_text.4752: and so the perfection of the Mercury or of the statue is called ἐντελέχεια, with reference to its habit.
tgt_text.4753: But when he speaks of the έντε- λέχεια* of a natural body, he does so because, of bodies some are wrought by the hands, as for instance, those which are made by artists, for instance, a tower, or a ship ;
tgt_text.4754: and some exist by nature, as the bodies of plants and animals.
tgt_text.4755: He has also used the term with reference to an organic body, that is to say, with reference to something that is made, as the faculty of sight for seeing, or the faculty of hearing for the purpose of hearing.
tgt_text.4756: The capacity of having life must exist in the thing itself.
tgt_text.4757: But the capacity is twofold, either in habit or in operation.
tgt_text.4758: In operation, as a man, when awake, is said to have a soul;
tgt_text.4759: in habit, as the same is said of a man when asleep.
tgt_text.4760: That, therefore, he may come under his definition, he has added the word capacity.
tgt_text.4761: He has also given other definitions on a great many sub- jects, which it would be tedious to enumerate here.
tgt_text.4762: For he was in every thing a man of the greatest industry and inge- nuity, as is plain from all his works which I have lately given a list of;
tgt_text.4763: which are in number nearly four hundred, the genuineness of which is undoubted.
tgt_text.4764: There are, also, a great many other works attributed to him, and a number of apoph- thegms which he never committed to paper.
tgt_text.4766: There were eight persons of the name of Aristotle.
tgt_text.4767: First of all, the philosopher of whom we have been speaking;
tgt_text.4768: the second was an Athenian statesman, some of whose forensic orations, of great elegance, are still extant;
tgt_text.4769: the third was a man who wrote a treatise on the Iliad ;
tgt_text.4770: the fourth, a Siciliot orator, who wrote a reply to the Panegyric of Isocrates;
tgt_text.4771: the fifth was the man who was surnamed Myth, a friend of iEschines, the pupil of Socrates ;
tgt_text.4772: the sixth was a Cyrenean, who wrote a treatise on Poetry;
tgt_text.4773: the seventh was a school- master, who is mentioned by Aristoxenus in his Life of Plato ;
tgt_text.4774: the eighth, was an obscure grammarian, to whom a treatise on Pleonasm is attributed.
tgt_text.4776: And the Stagirite had many friends, the most emi- nent of whom was Theophrastus, whom we must proceed to speak of.
tgt_text.4777: I. THEOPHRASTUS was a native of Eresus, the son of Me. lantas, a fuller, as we are told by Athenodorus in the eighth book of his Philosophical Conversations.
tgt_text.4779: He was originally a pupil of Leucippus, his fellow citizen, in his own country;
tgt_text.4780: and subsequently, after having attended the lectures of Plato, he went over to Aristotle.
tgt_text.4781: And when he withdrew to Chalcis, he succeeded him as president of his school, in the hundred and fourteenth olympiad.
tgt_text.4783: It is also said that a slave of his, by name Pomphylus, was a philosopher, as we are told by Myronianus of Amastra, in the first book of Similar Historical Chapters.
tgt_text.4785: Theophrastus was a mail of great acuteness and in- dustry, and, as Pamphila asserts in the thirty-second book of his Commentaries, he was the tutor of Menandar, the comic poet.
tgt_text.4786: He was also a most benevolent mail, and very affable.
tgt_text.4788: Accordingly, Cassander received him as a friend ;
tgt_text.4789: and Ptolemy sent to invite him to his court.
tgt_text.4790: And he was thought so very highly of at Athens, that when Agonides ventured to impeach him on a charge of impiety, he was very nearly fined for his hardihood.
tgt_text.4791: And there thronged to his school a crowd of disciples to the number of two thousand.
tgt_text.4792: In his letter to Phanias, the Peripatetic, among other subjects he speaks of the court of justice in the following terms :
tgt_text.4794: It is not only out of the question to find an assembly (πανήγυϱις), but it is not easy to find even a company (<rtjvtdg/ov) such as one would like ;
tgt_text.4795: but yet recitations produce corrections of the judgment.
tgt_text.4796: And my age does not allow me to put off everything and to feel indifference on such a subject."
tgt_text.4797: In this letter he speaks of himself as one who devotes his whole leisure to learning.
tgt_text.4798: And though he was of this disposition, he nevertheless went away for a short time, both he and all the rest of the philo- sophers, in consequence of Sophocles, the SOIl of Ampbi- elides, having brought forward and carried a law that no one of the philosophers should preside over a school unless the council and the people had passed a resolution to sanction their doing so, if they did, death was to be the penalty.
tgt_text.4799: But they returned again the next year, when Philion had impeached Sophocles for illegal conduct;
tgt_text.4800: when the Athenians abrogated his law, and fined Sophocles five talents, and voted that the philosophers should have leave to return, that Theophrastus might return and preside over his school as before.
tgt_text.4802: His name had originally been Tyrtanius, but Aristotle changed it to Theophrastus, from the divine character of his eloquence....VII.
tgt_text.4803: He is said also to have been very much attached to Aristotle's son, Nicomachus, although he was his master;
tgt_text.4804: at least, this is stated by Aristippus in the fourth book of his treatise on the Ancient Luxury.
tgt_text.4806: It is also related that Aristotle used the same expression about him and Callisthenes, which Plato, as I have previously mentioned, employed about Xenocrates and Aristotle himself.
tgt_text.4807: For he is reported to have said, since Theophrastus was a mail of extraordinary acuteness, who could both comprehend and explain everything, and as the other was somewhat slow in his natural character, that Theo- phrastus required a bridle, and Callisthenes a spur.
tgt_text.4809: It is said, too, that he had a garden of his own after the death of Aristotle, by the assistance of Demetrius Phale- rius, who was an intimate friend of his.X.
tgt_text.4810: The following very practical apophthegms of his are quoted.
tgt_text.4811: He used to say that it was better to trust to a horse without a bridle than to a discourse without arrangement.
tgt_text.4812: And once, when a man preserved a strict silence during the whole of a banquet, he said to him, " If you are an ignorant man.
tgt_text.4814: but if you have had any education, you are behaving like a fool."
tgt_text.4815: And a very favourite expression of his was, that time was the most valuable thing that a man could spend.
tgt_text.4817: He died when he was of a great age, having lived eighty-five years, when he had only rested from his labours a short time.
tgt_text.4818: And we have composed the following epigram on him:
tgt_text.4820: The proverb then is not completely false, That wisdom's bow unbent is quickly broken ;
tgt_text.4821: While Theophrastus laboured, he kept sound, When he relaxed, he lost his strength and died.
tgt_text.4822: They say that on one occasion, when dying, he was asked by his disciples whether he had any charge to give them ;
tgt_text.4823: and he replied, that he had none but that they should " remember that life holds out many pleasing deceits to us by the vanity of glory;
tgt_text.4824: for that when we are beginning to live, then we are dying.
tgt_text.4825: There is, therefore, nothing more profitless than am- bition.
tgt_text.4826: But may you all be fortunate, and either abandon philosophy (for it is a great labour), or else cling to it dili- gently, for then the credit of it is great;
tgt_text.4827: but the vanities of life exceed the advantage of it.
tgt_text.4828: However, it is not requisite for me now to advise you what you should do;
tgt_text.4829: but do you yourselves consider what line of conduct to adopt."
tgt_text.4830: And when he had said this, as report goes, he expired.
tgt_text.4831: And the Athenians accompanied him to the grave, on foot, with the whole population of the city, as it is related, honouring the man greatly.
tgt_text.4833: But Pharorinus says, that when be was very old he used to go about in a litter ;
tgt_text.4834: and that Hermippus states this, quoting Arcesilaus, the Pitanæan, and the account which he sent to Lacydes of Cyrene.
tgt_text.4836: He also left behind him a very great number of works, of which I have thought it proper to give a list on account of their being full of every sort of excellence.
