tgt_text.5776: And, " That mathematicians kept their eyes fixed on the sun and moon, and overlooked what was under their feet."
tgt_text.5777: "That orators were anxious to speak justly, but not at all about acting so."
tgt_text.5779: but were preposterously fond of it."
tgt_text.5780: He often condemned those who praise the just for being superior to money, but who at the same time are eager themselves for great riches.
tgt_text.5781: He was also very indignant at seeing men sacrifice to the Gods to procure good health, and yet at the sacrifice eating in a manner injurious to health.
tgt_text.5782: He often expressed his surprise at slaves, who, seeing their masters eating in a gluttonous manner, still do not themselves lay hands on any of the eatables.
tgt_text.5783: He would frequently praise those who were about to marry, and yet did not marry ;
tgt_text.5784: or who were about to take a voyage, and yet did not take a voyage;
tgt_text.5785: or who were about to engage in affairs of state, and did not do so;
tgt_text.5786: and those who were about to rear children, yet did not rear any;
tgt_text.5787: and those who were preparing to take up their abode with princes, and yet did not take it up.
tgt_text.5788: One of his sayings was, ' That one ought to hold out one's hand to a friend without closing the fingers.
tgt_text.5789: "Hermippus, in his Sale of Diogenes, says that he was taken prisoner and put up to be sold, and asked what he could do;
tgt_text.5791: And so he bade the crier " give notice that if any one wants to purchase a master, there is one here for him."
tgt_text.5792: When he was ordered not to sit down ;
tgt_text.5794: It makes no difference," said he, " for fish are sold, be where they may."
tgt_text.5795: He used to say, that he wondered at men always ringing a dish or jar before buying it, but being content to judge of a man by his look alone.
tgt_text.5796: When Xeniades bought him, he said to him that he ought to obey him even though he was his slave;
tgt_text.5797: for that a physician or a pilot would find men to obey them even though they might be slaves.
tgt_text.5799: And Eubulus says, in his essay entitled, The Sale of Diogenes, that he taught the children of Xeniades, after their other lessons, to ride, and shoot, and sling, and dart.
tgt_text.5800: And then in the Gymnasium he did not permit the trainer to exer- cise them after the fashion of athletes, but exercised them him- self to just the degree sufficient to give them a good colour and good health.
tgt_text.5801: And the boys retained in their memory many sentences of poets and prose writers, and of Diogenes himself;
tgt_text.5802: and he used to give them a concise statement of everything in order to strengthen their memory;
tgt_text.5803: and at home he used to teach them to wait upon themselves, contenting themselves with plain food, and drinking water.
tgt_text.5804: And he accustomed them to cut their hair close, and to eschew ornament, and to go without tunics or shoes, and to keep silent, looking at nothing except themselves as they walked along.
tgt_text.5805: He used, also to take them out hunting;
tgt_text.5806: and they paid the greatest attention and respect to Diogenes himself, and spoke well of him to their parents.
tgt_text.5808: And the same author affirms, that he grew old in the household of Xeniades, and that when he died he was buried by his sons.
tgt_text.5809: And that while he was living with him.
tgt_text.5810: Xeniades once asked him how he should bury him;
tgt_text.5811: and he said, " On my face and when he was asked why, he said, " Because, in a little while, everything will be turned upside down."
tgt_text.5812: And he said this because the Macedonians were already attaining power, and becoming a mighty people from having been very inconsiderable.
tgt_text.5813: Once, when a man had conducted him into a magnificent house, and had told him that he must not spit, after hawking a little, he spit in his face, saying that he could not find a worse place.
tgt_text.5814: But some tell this story of Aristippus.
tgt_text.5815: Once, he called out, " Holloa, men."
tgt_text.5816: And when some people gathered round him in con- sequence, he drove them away with his stick, saying, " I called men, and not dregs."
tgt_text.5817: This anecdote I have derived -from Hecaton, in the first book of his Apophthegms.
tgt_text.5818: They also relate that Alexander said that if he had not been Alexander, he should have liked to be Diogenes.
tgt_text.5819: He used to call ἀνάπηϱοι (cripples), not those who were dumb and blind, but those who had no wallet (πήϱα).
tgt_text.5820: On one occasion he went half shaved into an entertainment of young men, as Metrocles tells us in his Apophthegms, and so was beaten by them.
tgt_text.5821: And afterwards he wrote the names of all those who had beaten him, on a white tablet, and went about with the tablet round his neck, so as to expose them to insult, as they were generally condemned and reproached for their conduct.
tgt_text.5822: He used to say that he was the hound of those who were praised ;
tgt_text.5823: but that none of those who praised them dared to go out hunting with him.
tgt_text.5824: A man once said to him, " I conquered men at the Pythian games on which he said, " I conquer men, but you only conquer slaves."
tgt_text.5825: When some people said to him, " You are an old man, and should rest for the remainder of your life ;
tgt_text.5826: " " Why so?" replied he, " suppose I had run a long distance, ought I to stop when I was near the end, and not rather press on ? "
tgt_text.5827: Once, when he was in- vited to a banquet, he said that he would not come :
tgt_text.5828: for that the day before no one had thanked him for coming.
tgt_text.5829: He used to go bare foot through the snow, and to do a number of other things which have been already mentioned.
tgt_text.5830: Once he at- tempted to eat raw meat, but he could not digest it.
tgt_text.5831: On one occasion he found Demosthenes, the orator, dining in an inn ;
tgt_text.5832: and as he was slipping away, he said to him, "You will now be ever so much more in an inn."*
tgt_text.5833: Once, when some strangers wished to see Demosthenes, he stretched out his middle finger, and said, " This is the great demagogue of the Athenian people."
tgt_text.5834: When some one had dropped a loaf, and was ashamed to pick it up again, he, wishing to give him a lesson, tied a cord round the neck of a bottle and dragged it all through the Ceramicus.
tgt_text.5835: He used to say, that lie imitated the teachers of choruses, for that they spoke too loud, in order that the rest might catch the proper tone.
tgt_text.5836: Another of his sayings, was that most men were within a finger's breadth of being mad.
tgt_text.5837: If, then, any one were to walk along, stretching out his middle finger, he will seem to be mad ;
tgt_text.5838: but if he puts out his fore finger, he will not be thought so.
tgt_text.5839: Another of his sayings was, that things of great value were often sold for nothing, and vice versâ.
tgt_text.5840: Accordingly, that a statue would fetch three thousand drachmas, and a bushel of meal only two obols;
tgt_text.5841: and when Xeniades had bought him, he said to him, " Come, do what you are ordered to."
tgt_text.5843: The streams of sacred rivers now Run backwards to their source !"" Suppose," rejoined Diogenes, " you had been sick, and had bought a physician, could you refuse to be guided by him, and tell him— "
tgt_text.5844: The streams of sacred rivers now Run backwards to their source ?
tgt_text.5845: "Once a man came to him, and wished to study philosophy as his pupil ;
tgt_text.5846: and he gave him a saperda *and made him follow him.
tgt_text.5847: And as he from shame threw it away and departed, he soon afterwards met him and, laughing, said to him, " A saperda has dissolved your friendship for me."
tgt_text.5848: But Diodes tells this story in the following manner;
tgt_text.5849: that when some one said to him, " Give me a commission, Diogenes," he carried him off, and gave him a halfpenny worth of cheese to* carry.
tgt_text.5850: And as he refused to carry it, " See," said Diogenes. " a halfpenny worth of cheese has broken off our friendship.
tgt_text.5851: "On one occasion he saw a child drinking out of its hands, and so he threw away the cup which belonged to his wallet, saying, " That child has beaten me in simplicity."
tgt_text.5852: He also threw away his spoon, after seeing a boy, when he had broken his vessel, take up his lentils with a crust of bread.
tgt_text.5853: And he used to argue thus,—" Everything belongs to the gods ;
tgt_text.5854: and wise men are the friends of the gods.
tgt_text.5855: All things are in common among friends;
tgt_text.5856: therefore everything belongs to wise men."
tgt_text.5857: Once he saw a woman falling down before the Gods in an unbecoming attitude ;
tgt_text.5858: he, wishing to cure her of her super- stition, as Zoilus of Perga tells us, came up to her, and said, " Are you not afraid, 0 woman, to be in such an indecent atti- tude, when some God may be behind you, for every place is full of him?"
tgt_text.5859: He consecrated a man to AEsculapius, who was to run up and beat all these who prostrated themselves with their faces to the ground ;
tgt_text.5860: and he was in the habit of saying that the tragic curse had come upon him, for that he was-
tgt_text.5861: Houseless and citiless, a piteous exile From his dear native land ;
tgt_text.5862: a wandering beggar, Scraping a pittance poor from day to day.
tgt_text.5863: And another of his sayings was that he opposed confidence to fortune, nature to law, and reason to suffering.
tgt_text.5864: Once, while he was sitting in the sun in the Craneum, Alexander was standing by, and said to him, "Ask any favour you choose of me."
tgt_text.5865: And he replied, " Cease to shade me from the sun."
tgt_text.5866: On one occasion a man was reading some long passages, and when he came to the end of the book and showed that there was nothing more written, " Be of good cheer, my friends," exclaimed Diogenes, " I see land."
tgt_text.5867: A man once proved to him syllogistically that he had horns, so he put his hand to his forehead and said, " I do not see them."
tgt_text.5868: And in a similar manner he replied to one who had been asserting that there was no such thing as motion, by getting up and walking away.
tgt_text.5869: When a man was talking about the heavenly bodies and meteors, " Pray how many days," said he to him, " is it since you came down from heaven ?
tgt_text.5870: "A profligate eunuch had written on his house, " Let no evil thing enter in."
tgt_text.5871: "Where," said Diogenes, "is the master of the house going After having anointed his feet with per- fume, he said that the ointment from his head mounted up to heaven, and that from his feet up to his nose.
tgt_text.5872: When the Athenians entreated him to be initiated in the Eleusinian mysteries, and said that in the shades below the initiated had the best seats ;
tgt_text.5874: It will," he replied, " be an absurd thing if Ægesilaus and Epaminondas are to live in the mud, and some miserable wretches, who have been initiated, are to be in the islands of the blest."
tgt_text.5875: Some mice crept up to his table, and he said, " See, even Diogenes maintains his favourites."
tgt_text.5876: Once, when he was leaving the bath, and a man asked him whether many men were bathing, he said, " No;
tgt_text.5877: " but when a number of people came out, he confessed that there were a great many.
tgt_text.5878: When Plato called him a dog, he said, " Un- doubtedly, for I have come back to those who sold me.
tgt_text.5881: Man is a two-footed, featherless animal," and was much praised for the definition;
tgt_text.5882: so Diogenes plucked a cock and brought it into his school, and said, " This is Plato's man."
tgt_text.5883: On which account this addition was made to the definition, " With broad flat nails."
tgt_text.5884: A man once asked him what was the proper time for supper, and he made answer, "If you are a rich man, whenever you please;
tgt_text.5885: and if you are a poor man, whenever you can."
tgt_text.5886: When he was at Megara he saw some sheep carefully covered over with skins, and the children running about naked;
tgt_text.5887: and so he said, " It is better at Megara to be a man's ram, than his son."
tgt_text.5888: A man once struck him with a beam, and then said, " Take care."
tgt_text.5889: "What," said he, "are you going to strike me again?"
tgt_text.5890: He used to say that the demagogues were the ser- vants of the people;
tgt_text.5891: and garlands the blossoms of glory.
tgt_text.5892: Having lighted a candle in the day time, he said, " I am looking for a man."
tgt_text.5893: On one occasion he stood under a foun.
tgt_text.5894: tain, and as the bystanders were pitying him, Plato, who was present, said to them, " If you wish really to show your pity for him, come away;
tgt_text.5895: " intimating that he was only acting thus out of a desire for notoriety.
tgt_text.5896: Once, when a man had struck him with his fist, he said," " 0 Hercules, what a strange thing that I should be walking about with a helmet on without know- ing it!
tgt_text.5897: "When Midias struck him with his fist and said, " There are three thousand drachmas for you;
tgt_text.5898: " the next day Diogenes took the cestus of a boxer and beat him soundly, and said, " There are three thousand drachmas for you." * When Lysias, the drug-seller, asked him whether he thought that there were any Gods :
tgt_text.5899: " How," said he, " can I help thinking so, when I consider you to be hated by them?" but some attribute this reply to Theodorus.
tgt_text.5900: Once he saw a man purifying himself by washing, and said to him, " Oh, wretched man, do not you know that as you cannot wash away blunders in grammar by purification, so, too, you can no more efface the errors of a life in that same manner ?
tgt_text.5901: "He used to say that men were wrong for complaining of fortune;
tgt_text.5902: for that they ask of the Gods what appear to be good things, not what are really so.
tgt_text.5903: And to those who were alarmed at dreams he said, that they did not regard what they do while they are awake, but make a great fuss about what they fancy they see while they are asleep.
tgt_text.5904: Once, at the Olympic games, when the herald proclaimed, " Dioxippus is the conqueror of men;
tgt_text.5905: " he said, " He is the conqueror of slaves, I am the conqueror of men.
tgt_text.5906: "He was greatly beloved by the Athenians;
tgt_text.5907: accordingly, when a youth had broken his cask they beat him, and gave Diogenes another.
tgt_text.5908: And Dionysius, the Stoic, says that after the battle of Chæronea he was taken prisoner and brought to Philip ;
tgt_text.5909: and being asked who he was, replied, " A spy, to spy upon your insatiability."
tgt_text.5910: And Philip marvelled at him and let him go.
tgt_text.5911: Once, when Alexander had sent a letter to Athens to Antipater, by the hands of a man named Athlias, he, being present, said, " Athlias from Athlius, by means of Athlias to Athlius.*
tgt_text.5912: When Perdiccas threatened that he would put him to death if he did not come to him, he replied, "That is nothing strange, for a scorpion or a tarantula could do as much:
tgt_text.5913: you had better threaten me that, if I kept away, you should be very happy."
tgt_text.5914: He used constantly to repeat with emphasis that an easy life had been given to man by the Gods, but that it had been overlaid by their seeking for honey, cheese-cakes, and unguents, and things of that sort.
tgt_text.5915: On which account he said to a mail, who had his shoes put on by his servant, " You are not thoroughly happy, unless he also wipes your nose for you;
tgt_text.5916: and he will do this, if you are crippled in your hands."
tgt_text.5917: On one occasion, when he had seen the hieromnemones t leading off one of the stewards who had stolen a goblet, he said, " The great thieves are carrying off the little thief."
tgt_text.5918: At another time, seeing a young man throw ing stones at a cross, he said, "Well done, you will be sure to reach the mark."
tgt_text.5919: Once, too, some boys got round him and said, "
tgt_text.5920: We are taking care that you do not bite us but he said, " Be of good cheer, my boys, a dog does not eat beef."
tgt_text.5921: He saw a man giving himself airs because he was clad in a lion's skin, and said to him, " Do not go on disgracing the garb of nature."
tgt_text.5922: When people were speaking of the happiness of Calisthenes, and saying what splendid treatment he received from Alexander, he replied, " The man then is wretched, for he is forced to breakfast and dine whenever Alexander chooses."
tgt_text.5923: When he was in want of money, he said that he reclaimed it from his friends and did not beg for it.
tgt_text.5924: On one occasion he was working with his hands in the market-place, and said, " I wish I could rub my stomach in the same way, and so avoid hunger."
tgt_text.5925: When he saw a young man going with some satraps to supper, he dragged him away and led him off to his relations, and bade them take care of him.
tgt_text.5926: He was once addressed by a youth beautifully adorned, who asked him some question;
tgt_text.5927: and he refused to give him any answer, till he satisfied him whether he was a man or a woman.
tgt_text.5928: And on one occasion, when a youth was playing the cottabus in the bath, he said to him, " The better you do it, the worse you do it."
tgt_text.5929: Once at a banquet, some of the guests threw him bones, as if he had been a dog;
tgt_text.5930: so he, as he went away, put up his leg against them as if he had been a dog in reality.
tgt_text.5931: He used to call the orators, and all those who speak for fame τϱιςάνθϱωποι (thrice men), instead of τϱιςάθλιοι, (thrice misera- ble).
tgt_text.5932: He said that a rich but ignorant man, was like a sheep with a golden fleece.
tgt_text.5933: When he saw a notice on the house of a profligate man, " To be sold." " I knew," said he, " that you who are so incessantly drunk, would soon vomit up your owner."
tgt_text.5934: To a young man, who was complaining of the num- ber of people who sought his acquaintance, he said, " Do not make such a parade of your vanity."
tgt_text.5935: Having been in a very dirty bath, he said, " I wonder where the people, who bathe here, clean themselves."
tgt_text.5936: When all the company was blaming an indifferent harp-player, he alone praised him, and being asked why he did so, he said, " Because, though he is such as he is, he plays the harp and does not steal."
tgt_text.5937: He saluted a harp player who was always left alone by his hearers, with, " Good morning, cock;
tgt_text.5938: " and when the man asked him, "Why so ?" he said, " Because you, when you sing, make every one get up."
tgt_text.5939: When a young man was one day making a display of himself, he, having filled the bosom of his robe with lupins, began to eat them;
tgt_text.5940: and when the multitude looked at him, he said, " that he marvelled at their leaving the young man to look at him."
tgt_text.5941: And when a man, who was very superstitious, said to him, " With one blow I will break your head ;
tgt_text.5943: And I," he replied, " with one sneeze will make you tremble."
tgt_text.5944: When Hegesias en- treated him to lend him one of his books, he said, " You are a silly fellow, Hegesias.
tgt_text.5945: for you will not take painted figs, but real ones;
tgt_text.5946: and yet you overlook the genuine practice of virtue, and seek for what is merely written."
tgt_text.5947: A man once reproached him with his banishment, and his answer was, " You wretched man, that is what made me a philosopher."
tgt_text.5948: And when, on another occasion, some one said to him, " The people of Sinope condemned you to banishment," he replied, " And I condemned them to remain where they were."
tgt_text.5949: Once he saw a man who had been victor at the Olympic games, feeding (νεμοντα) sheep, and he said to him, " You have soon come across my friend from the Olympic games, to the Nemean."
tgt_text.5950: When he was asked why athletes are insensible to pain, he said, " Because they are built up of pork and beef.
tgt_text.5952: and being questioned as to his reason for doing so, he said, " I am practising disappoint- ment,'' Once he was begging of some one (for he did this at first out of actual want), he said, " If you have given to any one else, give also to me ;
tgt_text.5953: and if you have never given to any one, then begin with me."
tgt_text.5954: On one occasion, he was asked by the tyrant, " What sort of brass was the best for a statue?" and he replied, " That of which the statues of Har- modius and Aristogiton are made."
tgt_text.5955: When he was asked how Dionysius treats his friends, he said, " Like bags;
tgt_text.5956: those which are full he hangs up, and those which are empty he throws away."
tgt_text.5957: A man who was lately married put an inscription on his house, " Hercules Callinicus, the son of Jupiter, lives here ;
tgt_text.5959: And so Diogenes wrote in addition, " An alliance is made after the war is over."
tgt_text.5960: He used to say that covetousness was the metropolis of all evils.
tgt_text.5961: Seeing on one occasion a profligate man in an inn eating olives, he said, " If you had dined thus, you would not have supped thus."
tgt_text.5962: One of his apophthegms was, that good men were the images of the Gods ;
tgt_text.5963: another, that love was the business of those who had nothing to do.
tgt_text.5964: When he was asked what was miserable in life, he answered, " An indigent old man."
tgt_text.5965: And when the question was put to him, what beast inflicts the worst bite, he said, " Of wild beasts the sycophant, and of tame animals the flatterer.
tgt_text.5966: "On one occasion he saw two Centaurs very badly painted ;
tgt_text.5967: he said, "Which of the two is the worst?"*
tgt_text.5968: He used to say that a speech, the object of which was solely to please, was a honeyed halter.
tgt_text.5969: He called the belly, the Charybdis of life.
tgt_text.5970: Having heard once that Didymon the adulterer, had been caught in the fact, he said, " He deserves to be hung by his name."†
tgt_text.5971: When the question was put to him, why gold is of a pale colour, he said, " Because it has so many people plotting against it."
tgt_text.5972: When he saw a woman in a litter, he said, " The cage is not suited to the animal."
tgt_text.5973: And seeing a runaway slave sitting on a well, he said, " My boy, take care you do not fall in."
tgt_text.5974: Another time, he saw a little boy who was a stealer of clothes from the baths, and said, " Are you going for unguents, (ἐπ' ἀλειμμάτιον), or for other garments (ἐπ' ἄλλ' ἱμάτιον).
tgt_text.5975: Seeing some women hanging on olive trees, he said, " I wish every tree bore similar fruit."
tgt_text.5976: At another time, he saw a clothes' stealer, and addressed him thus :
tgt_text.5978: What moves thee, say, when sleep has clos'd the sight, To roam the silent fields in dead of night ?
tgt_text.5979: Art thou some wretch by hopes of plunder led, Through heaps of carnage to despoil the dead.
tgt_text.5980: *When he was asked whether he had any girl or boy to wait on him, he said, " No."
tgt_text.5981: And as his questioner asked further, " If then you die, who will bury you?"
tgt_text.5982: He replied, "Who- ever wants my house."
tgt_text.5983: Seeing a handsome youth sleeping without any protection, he nudged him, and said, " Wake up:
tgt_text.5984: Mix'd with the vulgar shall thy fate be found, Pierc'd in the back, a vile dishonest wound.
tgt_text.5985: tAnd he addressed a man who was buying delicacies at a great expense :
tgt_text.5987: Not long, my son, will you on earth remain, If such your dealings.
tgt_text.5988: ‡When Plato was discoursing about his " ideas," and using the nouns " tableness " and " cupness ;
tgt_text.5989: " "I, I, 0 Plato !" inter- rupted Diogenes, " see a table and a cup, but I see no table- ness or cupness."
tgt_text.5990: Plato made answer, " That is natural enough, for you have eyes, by which a cup and a table are contemplated;
tgt_text.5991: but you have not intellect, by which tableness and cupness are seen.
tgt_text.5992: "On one occasion, he was asked by a certain person, " What sort of a man, 0 Diogenes, do you think Socrates ?" and he said, " A madman."
tgt_text.5993: Another time, the question was put to him, when a man ought to marry ?
tgt_text.5994: and his reply was, " Young men ought not to marry yet, and old men never ought to marry at all."
tgt_text.5995: When asked what he would take to let a man give him a blow onthe head?" he replied, " A helmet."
tgt_text.5996: Seeing a youth smartening himself up very care- fully, he said to him, " If you are doing that for men, you are miserable ;
tgt_text.5997: and if for women, you are profligate."
tgt_text.5998: Once he saw a youth blushing, and addressed him, " Courage, my boy, that is the complexion of virtue."
tgt_text.5999: Having once listened to two lawyers, he condemned them both ;
tgt_text.6000: saying.,,, That the one had stolen the thing in question, and that the other had not lost it."
tgt_text.6001: When asked what wine he liked to drink, he said, " That which belongs to another," A man said to him one day, " Many people laugh at you."
tgt_text.6002: " But I," he replied, " am not laughed down."
tgt_text.6003: When a man said to him, that it was a bad thing to live ;
tgt_text.6005: Not to live," said he, “ but to live badly."
tgt_text.6006: When some people were advising him to make search for a slave who had run away," he said, " It would be a very absurd thing for Manes to be able to live without Diogenes, but for Diogenes not to be able to live without Manes."
tgt_text.6007: When he was dining on olives, a cheese-cake was brought in, on which he threw the olive away, saying:
tgt_text.6008: - Keep well aloof, 0 stranger, from all tyrants.
tgt_text.6011: He drove the olive off (μάστίξεν δ’ἐλάαν).
tgt_text.6012: †When he was asked what sort of a dog he was, he replied, "When hungry, I am a dog of Melita;
tgt_text.6014: a sort which most of those who praise, do not like to take out hunting with them, because of the labour of keeping up with them;
tgt_text.6015: and in like manner, you cannot associate with me, from fear of the pain I give you."
tgt_text.6016: The question was put to him, whether wise men ate cheese-cakes, and he replied, " They eat everything, just as the rest of mankind."
tgt_text.6017: When asked why people give to beggars and not to philoso.
tgt_text.6019: Because they think it possible that they themselves may become lame and blind, but they do not expect ever to turn out philosophers."
tgt_text.6020: He once begged of a covetous man, and as he was slow to give, he said, " Man, I am asking you for something to maintain me (εἰς τϱοϕὴνand not to bury me (εἰςταϕὴν).”
tgt_text.6021: When some one reproached him for having tampered with the coinage, he said, "There was a time when I was such a person as you are now ;
tgt_text.6022: but there never was when you were such as I am now, and never will be."
tgt_text.6023: And to another person who reproached him on the same grounds, he said, " There were times when 1 did what I did not wish to, but that is not the case now."
tgt_text.6024: When he went to Myndus, he saw some very large gates, but the city was a small one, and so he said, " Oh men of Myndus, shut your gates, lest your city should steal out."
tgt_text.6025: On one occasion, he saw a man who had been detected stealing purple, and so he said :
tgt_text.6027: A purple death, and mighty fate o'ertook him *When Craterus entreated him to come and visit him, he said, " I would rather lick up salt at Athens, than enjoy a luxurious table with Craterus."
tgt_text.6028: On one occasion, he met Anaximenes, the orator, who was a fat man, and thus accosted him;
tgt_text.6029: " Pray give us, who are poor, some of your belly ;
tgt_text.6030: for by so doing you will be relieved yourself, and yon will assist us."
tgt_text.6031: And once, when he was discussing some point, Diogenes held up a piece of salt fish, and drew off the attention of his hearers ;
tgt_text.6032: and as Anaximenes was indignant at this, he said, " See, one pennyworth of salt fish has put an end to the lecture of Anaximenes."
tgt_text.6033: Being once reproached for eating in the market-place, he made answer, " I did, for it was in the market-place that I was hungry."
tgt_text.6034: Some authors also attri- bute the following repartee to him.
tgt_text.6035: Plato saw him washing vegetables, and so, coming up to him, he quietly accosted him thus, " If you had paid court to Dionysius, you would not have been washing vegetables." " And," he replied, with equal quietness, "if you had washed vegetables, you would never have paid court to Dionysius."
tgt_text.6036: When a mail said to him once, " Most people laugh at you ;
tgt_text.6038: “And very likely," he replied, " the asses laugh at them;
tgt_text.6039: but they do not regard the asses, neither do I regard them."
tgt_text.6040: Once he saw a youth studying philosophy, and said to him, " Well done;
tgt_text.6041: inasmuch as you are leading those who admire your person to contemplate the beauty of your mind.
tgt_text.6042: "A certain person was admiring the offerings in the temple at Samothrace,* and he said to him, " They would have been much more numerous, if those who were lost had offered them instead of those who were saved ;
tgt_text.6043: " but some attribute this speech to Diagoras the Thelian.
tgt_text.6044: Once he saw a handsome youth going to a banquet, and said to him, " You will come back worse (χείϱων);
tgt_text.6045: ”and when he the next day after the banquet said to him, “ I have left the banquet, and was no worse for it;
tgt_text.6046: " he replied, "You were not Chiron, but Eury- tion."f
tgt_text.6047: He was begging once of a very ill-tempered mail, and as he said to him, " If you can persuade me, I will give you something;
tgt_text.6048: " he replied, " If I could persuade you, I would beg you to hang yourself."
tgt_text.6049: He was on one occasion returning from Lacedaemon to Athens ;
tgt_text.6050: and when some one asked him, " Whither are you going, and whence do you come ?" he said,“I am going from the men's apartments to the women's."
tgt_text.6051: Another time he was returning from the Olympic games, and when some one asked him whether there had been a great multitude there, he said, " A great multitude, but very few men."
tgt_text.6052: He used to say that debauched men resembled figs growing on a precipice ;
tgt_text.6053: the fruit of which is not tasted by men, but devoured by crows and vultures.
tgt_text.6054: When Phryne had dedi- cated a golden statue of Venus at Delphi, he wrote upon it, " From the profligacy of the Greeks."Once Alexander the Great came and stood by him, and said, " I am Alexander, the great king." " And I," said he, " am Diogenes the dog."
tgt_text.6055: And when he was asked to what actions of his it was owing that he was called a dog, he said, " Because I fawn upon those who give me anything, and bark at those who give me nothing, and bite the rogues."
tgt_text.6056: On one occasion he was gathering some of the fruit of a fig-tree, and when the man who was guarding it told him a man hung him- self on this tree the other day, " I, then," said he, " will now purify it."
tgt_text.6057: Once he saw a man who had been a conqueror at the Olympic games looking very often at a courtesan ;
tgt_text.6058: " Look," said he, " at that warlike ram, who is taken prisoner by the first girl he meets."
tgt_text.6059: One of his sayings was, that good-look- ing courtesans were like poisoned mead.
tgt_text.6060: On one occasion he was eating his dinner in the market- place, and the bystanders kept constantly calling out " Dog ;
tgt_text.6061: ” but he said, " It is you who are the dogs, who stand around me while I am at dinner."
tgt_text.6062: When two effeminate fellows were getting out of his way, he said, " Do not be afraid, a dog does not eat beetroot."
tgt_text.6063: Being once asked about a debauched boy, as to what country he came from, he said, " He is a Tegean.”*
tgt_text.6064: Seeing an unskilful wrestler professing to heal a man he said, " What are you about, are you in hopes now to overthrow those who formerly conquered you ?"
tgt_text.6065: On one occasion he saw the son of a courtesan throwing a stone at a crowd, and said to him, "Take care, lest you hit your father."
tgt_text.6066: When a boy showed him a sword that he had received from one to whom he had done some discreditable service, he told him, " The sword is a good sword, but the handle is infamous."
tgt_text.6067: And when some people were praising a man who had given him some- thing, he said to them, " And do not you praise me who was worthy to receive it?"
tgt_text.6068: He was asked by some one to give him back his cloak ;
tgt_text.6071: If you gave it me, it is mine ;
tgt_text.6072: and if you only lent it me, I am using it."
tgt_text.6073: A suppo- sititious son (ὑποβολιμα̃ιος of somebody once said to him, that he had gold in his cloak ;
tgt_text.6074: " No doubt," said he, " that is the very reason why I sleep with it under my head η- μένος).
tgt_text.6075: ”When he was asked what advantage he had derived from philosophy, he replied, " If no other, at least this, that I am prepared for every kind of fortune."
tgt_text.6076: The question was put to him what countryman he was, and he replied, " A Citizen of the world."
tgt_text.6077: Some men were sacrificing to the Gods to prevail on them to send them sons, and he said, "And do you not sacri- fice to procure sons of a particular character ?"
tgt_text.6078: Once he was asking the president of a society for a contribution, and said to him:
tgt_text.6079: — , " Spoil all the rest, but keep your hands from Hector.
tgt_text.6080: "He used to say that courtesans were the queens of kings ;
tgt_text.6081: for that they asked them for whatever they chose.
tgt_text.6082: When the Athenians had voted that Alexander was Bacchus, he said to them, " Vote, too, that I am Serapis."
tgt_text.6083: When a man re- proached him for going into unclean places, he said, " The sun too penetrates into privies, but is not polluted by them."
tgt_text.6084: When supping in a temple, as some dirty loaves were set before him, he took them up and threw them away, saying that nothing dirty ought to come into a temple ;
tgt_text.6085: and when some one said to him, " You philosophize without being possessed of any knowledge," he said, " If I only pretend to wisdom, that is philosophizing."
tgt_text.6086: A man once brought him a boy, and said that he was a very clever child, and one of an admirable dis- position." “ What, then," said Diogenes, " does he want of me?
tgt_text.6087: ”He used to say, that those who utter virtuous senti- ments but do not do them, are no better than harps, for that a harp has no hearing or feeling.
tgt_text.6088: Once he was going into a theatre while every one else was coming out of it;
tgt_text.6089: and when asked why he did so, " It is," said he, " what I have been doing all my life."
tgt_text.6090: Once when he saw a young man putting on effeminate airs, he said to him, " Are you not ashamed to have worse plans for yourself than nature had for you ?
tgt_text.6091: for she has made you a man, but you are trying to force yourself to be a woman."
tgt_text.6092: When he saw an ignorant man tuning a psaltery, he said to him, " Are you not ashamed to be arranging proper sounds on a wooden instrument, and not arranging your soul to a proper life ? "
tgt_text.6093: When a man said to him, " I am not calculated for philosophy," he said, "Why then do you live, if you have no desire to live properly ? "
tgt_text.6094: To a man who treated his father with contempt, he said, " Are you not ashamed to despise him to whom you owe it that you have it in your power to give yourself airs at all ?"
tgt_text.6095: Seeing a handsome young man chattering in an unseemly manner, he said, " Are you not ashamed to draw a sword cut of lead out of a scabbard of ivory?"
tgt_text.6096: Being once reproached for drinking in a vintner's shop, he said, " I have my hair cut, too, in a barber's."
tgt_text.6097: At another time, he was attacked for having accepted a cloak from Antipater, but he replied:
tgt_text.6099: The gifts which from the mighty Gods proceed.
tgt_text.6101: *A man once struck him with a broom, and said, “Take care so he struck him in return with his staff, and said, " Take care.
tgt_text.6102: "He once said to a man who was addressing anxious en- treaties to a courtesan, " What can you wish to obtain, you wretched man, that you had not better be disappointed in ? ”
tgt_text.6103: Seeing a man reeking all over with unguents, he said to him, " Have a care, lest the fragrance of your head give a bad odour to your life."
tgt_text.6104: One of his sayings was, that servants serve their masters, and that wicked men are the slaves of their appetites.
tgt_text.6105: Being asked why slaves were called ἀνδϱάποδα,he replied, " Because they have the feet of men (τοὺςπόδαςἀνδϱω̃ν),and a soul such as you who are asking this question."
tgt_text.6106: He once asked a profligate fellow for a mina ;
tgt_text.6107: and when he put the question to him, why he asked others for an obol, and him for a mina, he said, " Because I hope to get something from the others another time, but the Gods alone know whether I shall ever extract anything from you again."
tgt_text.6108: Once he was reproached for asking favours, while Plato never asked for any;
tgt_text.6111: He asks as well as I do, but he does it Bending his head, that no one else may hear.
tgt_text.6112: "One day he saw an unskilful archer shooting ;
tgt_text.6113: so he went and sat down by the target, saying, " Now I shall be out of harm's way."
tgt_text.6114: He used to say, that those who were in love were disappointed in regard of the pleasure they expected.
tgt_text.6115: When he was asked whether death was an evil, he replied, " How can that be an evil which we do not feel when it is present ?"
tgt_text.6116: When Alexander was once standing by him,"and saying, “ Do not you fear me?"
tgt_text.6118: for what are you, a good or an evil ? "
tgt_text.6119: And as he said that he was good, " Who, then," said Diogenes, " fears the good ?"
tgt_text.6120: He used to say, that education was, for the young sobriety, for the old comfort, for the poor riches, and for the rich an ornament."
tgt_text.6121: When Didymus the adulterer was once trying to cure the eye of a young girl (ϰόϱης), he said, " Take care, lest when you are curing the eye of the maiden, you do not hurt the pupil."*
tgt_text.6122: A man once said to him, that his friends laid plots against him ;
tgt_text.6124: What then," said he, " are you to do, if you must look upon both your friends and enemies in the same light ?
tgt_text.6125: "On one occasion he was asked, what was the most excellent thing among men;
tgt_text.6126: and he said, " Freedom of speech."
tgt_text.6127: He went once into a school, and saw many statues of the Muses, but very few pupils, and said, " Gods, and all my good schoolmasters, you have plenty of pupils."
tgt_text.6128: He was in the habit of doing everything in public, whether in respect of Venus or Ceres ;
tgt_text.6129: and he used to put his conclusions in this way to people:
tgt_text.6130: " If there is nothing absurd in dining, then it is not absurd to dine in the market-place.
tgt_text.6131: But it is not absurd to dine, therefore it is not absurd to dine in the market-place."
tgt_text.6132: And as he was continually doing manual work in public, he said one day, " Would that by rubbing my belly I could get rid of hunger."
tgt_text.6133: Other sayings also are attributed to him, which it would take a long time to enumerate, there is such a multiplicity of them.
tgt_text.6134: He used to say, that there were two kinds of exercise:
tgt_text.6135: that, namely, of the mind and that of the body;
tgt_text.6136: and that the latter of these created in the mind such quick and agile phantasies at the time of its performance, as very much facile tated the practice of virtue;
tgt_text.6137: but that one was imperfect without the other, since the health and vigour necessary for the practice of what is good, depend equally on both mind and body.
tgt_text.6138: And he used to allege as proofs of this, and of the ease which practice imparts to acts of virtue, that people could see that in the case of mere common working trades, and other employments of that kind, the artisans arrived at no incon- siderable accuracy by constant practice;
tgt_text.6139: and that any one may see how much one flute player, or one wrestler, is superior to another, by his own continued practice.
tgt_text.6140: And that if these men transferred the same training to their minds they would not labour in a profitless or imperfect manner.
tgt_text.6141: He used to say also, that there was nothing whatever in life which could be brought to perfection without practice, and that that alone was able to overcome every obstacle;
tgt_text.6142: that, therefore, as we ought to repudiate all useless toils, and to apply ourselves to useful labours, and to live happily, we are only unhappy in consequence of most exceeding folly.
tgt_text.6143: For the very contempt of pleasure, if we only inure ourselves to it, is very pleasant;
tgt_text.6144: and just as they who are accustomed to live luxuriously, are brought very unwillingly to adopt the contrary system ;
tgt_text.6145: so they who have been originally inured to that opposite system, feel a sort of pleasure in the contempt of pleasure.
tgt_text.6146: This used to be the language which he held, and he used to show in practice, really altering men's habits, and deferring in all things rather to the principles of nature than to those of law;
tgt_text.6147: saying that he was adopting the same fashion of life as Hercules had, preferring nothing in the world to liberty;
tgt_text.6148: and saying that everything belonged to the wise, and advancing arguments such as I mentioned just above.
tgt_text.6150: every tiling belongs to the Gods;
tgt_text.6151: and the Gods are friends to the wise;
tgt_text.6152: and all the property of friends is held in common ;
tgt_text.6153: therefore everything belong to the wise.
tgt_text.6154: He also argued about the law, that without it there is no possibility of a constitution being maintained;
tgt_text.6155: for without a city there can be nothing orderly, but a city is an orderly thing;
tgt_text.6156: and without a city there can be no law;
tgt_text.6158: And he played in the same manner with the topics of noble birth, and reputation, and all things of that kind, saying that they were all veils, as it were, for wickedness ;
tgt_text.6159: and that that was the only proper constitution which consisted, in order.
tgt_text.6160: An- other of his doctrines was that all women ought to be possessed in common ;
tgt_text.6161: and he said that marriage was a nullity, and that the proper way would be for every man to live with her whom he could persuade to agree with him.
tgt_text.6162: And on the same principle he said, that all people's sons ought to belong to every one in common ;
tgt_text.6163: and there was nothing intolerable in the idea of taking anything out of a temple, or eating any animal whatever, and that there was no impiety in tasting even human flesh ;
tgt_text.6164: as is plain from the habits of foreign nations ;
tgt_text.6165: and he said that this principle might be correctly extended to every case and every people.
tgt_text.6166: For he said that in reality every- thing was a combination of all things.
tgt_text.6167: For that in bread there was meat, and in vegetables there was bread, and so there were some particles of all other bodies in everything, communicating by invisible passages and evaporating.
tgt_text.6169: And he explains this theory of his clearly in the Thyestes, if indeed the tragedies attributed to him are really his composition, and not rather the work of Philistus, of Ægina, his intimate friend, or of Pasiphon, the son of Lucian, who is stated by Phavorinus, in his Universal History, to have written them after Diogenes' death.
tgt_text.6171: Music and geometry, and astronomy, and all things of that kind, he neglected, as useless and unnecessary.
tgt_text.6172: But he was a man very happy in meeting arguments, as is plain from what we have already said.
tgt_text.6174: And he bore being sold with a most magnanimous spirit.
tgt_text.6175: For as he was sailing to Ægina, and was taken prisoner by some pirates, under the command of Scirpalus, he was carried off to Crete and sold;
tgt_text.6176: and when the Circe asked him what art he understood, he said, " That of governing men."
tgt_text.6177: And presently pointing out a Corinthian, very carefully dressed, (the same Xeniades whom we have mentioned before), he said, " Sell me to that man;
tgt_text.6179: Accordingly Xeniades bought him and carried him away to Corinth;
tgt_text.6180: and then he made him tutor of his sons, and com- mitted to him the entire management of his house.
tgt_text.6181: And he behaved himself in every affair in such a manner, that Xeniades, when looking over his property, said, " A good genius has come into my house."
tgt_text.6182: And Cleomenes, in his book which is called the Schoolmaster, says, that he wished to ransom all his relations, but that Diogenes told him that they were all fools ;
tgt_text.6183: for that lions did not become the slaves of those who kept them, but, on the contrary, those who main- tained lions were their slaves.
tgt_text.6184: For that it was the part of a slave to fear, but that wild beasts were formidable to men.X.
tgt_text.6185: And the man bad the gift of persuasion in a wonderful degree;
tgt_text.6186: so that he could easily overcome any one by his argu- ments.
tgt_text.6187: Accordingly, it is said that an Æginetan of the name of Onesicritus, having two sons, sent to Athens one of them, whose name was Androsthenes, and that he, after having heard Diogenes lecture, remained there;
tgt_text.6188: and that after that, he sent the elder, Philiscus, who has been already men- tioned, and that Philiscus was charmed in the same manner.
tgt_text.6189: And last of all, he came himself, and then he too remained, no less than his son, studying philosophy at the feet of Diogenes.
tgt_text.6190: So great a charm was there in the discourses of Diogenes.
tgt_text.6191: Another pupil of his was Phocion, who was sur- named the Good;
tgt_text.6192: and Stilpon, the Megarian, and a great many other men of eminence as statesmen.
tgt_text.6194: He is said to have died when he was nearly ninety years of age, but there are different accounts given of his death.
tgt_text.6195: For some say that he ate an ox's foot raw, and was in consequence seized with a bilious attack, of which he died ;
tgt_text.6196: others, of whom Cercidas, a Megalopolitan or Cretan, is one, say that he died of holding his breath for several days;
tgt_text.6197: and Cercidas speaks thus of him in his Meliambics:
tgt_text.6199: He, that Sinopian who bore the stick, Wore his cloak doubled, and in th' open air Dined without washing, would not bear with life A moment longer :
tgt_text.6200: but he shut his teeth, And held his breath.
tgt_text.6201: He truly was the son Of Jove, and a most heavenly-minded dog, The wise Diogenes,Others say that he, while intending to distribute a polypus to his dogs, was bitten by them through the tendon of his foot, and so died.
tgt_text.6202: But his own greatest friends, as Antisthenes tells us in his Successions, rather sanction the story of his having died from holding his breath.
tgt_text.6203: For he used to live in the Craneum, which was a Gymnasium at the gates of Corinth.
tgt_text.6204: And his friends came according to their custom, and found him with his head covered ;
tgt_text.6205: and as they did not suppose that he was asleep, for he was not a man much subject to the influence of night or sleep, they drew away his cloak from his face, and found him no longer breathing;
tgt_text.6206: and they thought that he had done this on purpose, wishing to escape the remaining portion of his life.
tgt_text.6207: On this there was a quarrel, as they say, between his friends, as to who should bury him, and they even came to blows;
tgt_text.6208: but when the elders and chief men of the city came there, they say that he was buried by them at the gate which leads to the Isthmus, And they placed over him a pillar, and on that a dog in Parian marble.
tgt_text.6209: And at a later period his fellow citizens honoured him with brazen statues, and put this inscription on them :
tgt_text.6211: E'en brass by lapse of time doth old become, But there is no such time as shall efface, Your lasting glory, wise Diogenes ;
tgt_text.6212: Since you alone did teach to men the art Of a contented life :
tgt_text.6213: the surest path To glory and a lasting happiness.
tgt_text.6214: We ourselves have also written an epigram on him in the proceleusmatic metre.
tgt_text.6215: A. Tell me, Diogenes, tell me true, I pray, How did you die;
tgt_text.6216: what fate to Pluto bore you ?
tgt_text.6217: B. The savage bite of an envious dog did kill me.
tgt_text.6218: Some, however, say that when he was dying, he ordered his friends to throw his corpse away without burying it, so that every beast might tear it, or else to throw it into a ditch, and sprinkle a little dust over it.
tgt_text.6219: And others say that his injunctions were, that he should be thrown into the Ilissus;
tgt_text.6220: that so he might be useful to his brethren.
tgt_text.6221: But Demetrius, in his treatise on Men of the Same Name, says that Diogenes died in Corinth the same day that Alexander died in Babylon.
tgt_text.6222: And he was already an old man, as early as the hundred and thirteenth olympiad.
tgt_text.6224: The following books are attributed to him.
tgt_text.6239: seven Tragedies, the Helen, the Thyestes, the Hercules, the Achilles, the Medea, the Chrysip- pus, and the CEdippus,But Sosicrates, in the first book of his Successions, and Satyrus, in the fourth book of his Lives, both assert that none of all these are the genuine composition of Diogenes.
tgt_text.6240: And Satyrus affirms that the tragedies are the work of Philiscus, the Æginetan, a friend of Diogenes.
tgt_text.6241: But Sotion, in his seventh book, says that these are the only genuine works of Diogenes:
tgt_text.6250: and that the Aristarchus, the Sisyphus, the Ganymede, a volume of Apophthegms, and another of Letters, are all the work of Philiscus.
tgt_text.6252: There were five persons of the name of Diogenes.
tgt_text.6253: The first a native of Apollonia, a natural philosopher;
tgt_text.6254: and the beginning of his treatise on Natural Philosophy is as follows:
tgt_text.6255: " It appears to me to be well for every one who commences any kind of philosophical treatise, to lay down some undeniable principle to start with."
tgt_text.6256: The second was a Sicymian, who wrote an account of Peloponnesus.
tgt_text.6257: The third was the man of whom we have been speaking.
tgt_text.6258: The fourth was a Stoic, a native of Seleucia, but usually called a Baby- lonian, from the proximity of Seleucia to Babylon.
tgt_text.6259: The fifth was a native of Tarsus, who wrote on the subject of some questions concerning poetry which he endeavours to solve.
tgt_text.6261: Athenodorus, in the eighth book of his Conversations,, says, that the philosopher always had a shining appearance, from his habit of anointing himself.
tgt_text.6262: I. MONIMUS was a Syracusan, and a pupil of Diogenes, but also a slave of some Corinthian money-changer, as Sosicrates tells us.
tgt_text.6263: Xeniades, who bought Diogenes, used often to come to him, extolling the excellency of Diogenes both in actions and words, till he excited a great affection for the mail in the mind of Monimus.
tgt_text.6264: For he immediately feigned madness, and threw about all the money and all the coins that were on the table, until his master discarded him, and then he straightway went to Diogenes and became his pupil.
tgt_text.6265: He also followed Crates the Cynic a good deal, and devoted himself to the same studies as be did;
tgt_text.6266: and the sight of this conduct of his made his master all the more think him mad.
tgt_text.6268: And he was a very eminent man, so that even Menander, the comic poet, speaks of him;
tgt_text.6269: accordingly, in one of his plays, namely in the Hippocomus, he mentions him thus :
tgt_text.6271: There is a man, 0 Philo, named Monimus, A wise man, though but little known, and one Who bears a wallet at his back, and is not Content with one but three.
tgt_text.6272: He never spoke A single sentence, by great Jove I swear, Like this one, " Know thyself," or any other Of the oft-quoted proverbs :
tgt_text.6274: He scorned, as he did beg his way through dirt;
tgt_text.6275: Teaching that all opinion is but vanity.
tgt_text.6276: But he was a man of such gravity that he despised glory, and sought only for truth.
tgt_text.6278: He wrote some jests mingled with serious treatises, and two essays on the Appetites, and an Exhortation.
tgt_text.6279: I. OSNESICRITUS is called by some authors an Æginetan, but Demetrius the Magnesian affirms that he was a native of Astypalæa.
tgt_text.6280: He also was one of the most eminent of the disciples of Diogenes.
tgt_text.6282: And he appears in some points to resemble Xenophon.
tgt_text.6283: For Xenophon joined in the expedition of Cyrus, and Onesi- critus in that of Alexander;
tgt_text.6284: and Xenophon wrote the Cyropædia, and Onesicritus wrote an account of the education of Alexander.
tgt_text.6285: Xenophon, too, wrote a Panegyric on Cyrus, and Onesicritus one on Alexander.

tgt_text.6410: I. HIPPAKCHIA, the sister of Metrocles, was charmed among others, by the doctrines of this school.
tgt_text.6412: Both she and Metrocles were natives of Maronea.
tgt_text.6413: She fell in love with both the doctrines and manners of Crates, and could not be diverted from her regard for him, by either the wealth, or high birth, or personal beauty, of any of her suitors, but Crates was everything to her;
tgt_text.6414: and she threatened her parents to make away with herself, if she were not given in marriage to him.
tgt_text.6415: Crates accordingly, being entreated by her parents to dissuade her from this resolution, did all be could;
tgt_text.6416: and at last, as he could not persuade her, he rose up, and placing all his furniture before her, he said, " This is the bridegroom whom you are choosing, and this is the whole of his property;
tgt_text.6417: consider these facts, for it will not be possible for you to become his partner, if you do not also apply your- self to the same studies, and conform to the same habits that he does."
tgt_text.6419: and assuming the same dress that he wore, went about with him as her husband, and appeared with him in public everywhere, and went to all entertainments in his company.

tgt_text.6484: These then are the lives of each of the Cynics ;
tgt_text.6485: and we shall also subjoin some of the doctrines which they all held in common, if indeed it is not an abuse of language to call that a sect of philosophy at all, instead of, as some contend it should be termed, a mere system of life.
tgt_text.6486: They wished to abolish the whole system of logic and natural philosophy, like Aristo of Chios, and thought that men should study nothing but ethics;
tgt_text.6487: and what some people assert of Socrates was described by Diodes as a characteristic of Dio- genes, for he said that his doctrine was, that a man ought to investigate-

tgt_text.6490: Accordingly, Antis- thenes said that wise men only applied themselves to litera- ture and learning for the sake of perverting others ;
tgt_text.6491: they also wish to abolish geometry and music, and everything of that kind.

tgt_text.6496: Cities are governed,, so are houses too, By wisdom, not by harp-playing and whistling."
tgt_text.6497: *Their doctrine is, that the chief good of mankind is to live according to virtue, as Antisthenes says in his Hercules, in which they resemble the Stoics.
tgt_text.6498: For those two sects have a good deal in common with one another, on which account they themselves say that cynicism is a short road to virtue ;
tgt_text.6499: and Zeno, the Cittiæan lived in the same manner.
tgt_text.6500: They also teach that men ought to live simply, using only plain food in moderate quantities, wearing nothing but a cloak, and despising riches, and glory, and nobleness of birth;
tgt_text.6501: ac- cordingly some of them feed upon nothing beyond herbs and cold water, living in any shelter that they can find, or in tubs as Diogenes did;
tgt_text.6502: for he used to say that it was the peculiar property of the Gods to want nothing, and that, therefore, when a man wished for nothing he was like the Gods.
tgt_text.6503: Another of their doctrines is, that virtue is a thing which may be taught, as Antisthenes affirms in his Heraclides ;
tgt_text.6504: and that when it has once been attained it can never be lost.
tgt_text.6505: They also say that the wise man deserves to be loved, and cannot commit error, and is a friend to every one who resem- bles him, and that he leaves nothing to fortune.
tgt_text.6506: And every- thing which is unconnected with either virtue or vice they call indifferent, agreeing in this with Aristo, the Chian.
tgt_text.6508: and now we must pass on to the Stoics, of which sect the founder was Zeno, who had been a disciple of Crates.1.
tgt_text.6509: ZENO was the son of Innaseas, or Demeas, and a native of Citium, in Cyprus, which is a Grecian city, partly occupied by a Phœnician colony,II.
tgt_text.6510: He had his head naturally bent on one side, as Timo- thens, the Athenian, tells us, in his work on Lives.
tgt_text.6511: And Apollonius, the Tyrian, says that he was thin, very tall, of a dark complexion;
tgt_text.6512: in reference to which some one once called him an Egyptian Clematis, as Chrysippus relates in the first volume of his Proverbs:
tgt_text.6513: he had fat, flabby, weak legs, on which account Persæus, in his Convivial Reminiscences, says that he used to refuse many invitations to supper;
tgt_text.6514: and he was very fond, as it is said, of figs both fresh and dried in the sun.
tgt_text.6516: He was a pupil, as has been already stated, of Crates.
tgt_text.6517: After that, they say that he became a pupil of Stilpon and of Xenocrates, for ten years, as Timocrates relates in his Life of Dion.
tgt_text.6518: He is also said to have been a pupil of Polemo.
tgt_text.6519: But Hecaton, and Apollonius, of Tyre, in the first book of his essay on Zeno, say that when he consulted the oracle, as to what he ought to do to live in the most excellent manner, the God answered him that he ought to become of the same complexion as the dead, on which he inferred that he ought to apply himself to the reading of the books of the ancients.
tgt_text.6520: Accordingly, he attached himself to Crates in the following manner.
tgt_text.6521: Having purchased a quantity of purple from Phœnicia, he was shipwrecked close to the Piraeus ;
tgt_text.6522: and when he had made his way from the coast as far as Athens, he sat down by a bookseller's stall, being now about thirty years of age.
tgt_text.6523: And as he took up the second book of Xenophon's Memorabilia and began to read it, he was delighted with it, and asked where such men as were described in that book lived;
tgt_text.6524: and as Crates happened very seasonably to pass at the moment, the book- seller pointed him out, and said, " Follow that man."
tgt_text.6525: From that time forth he became a pupil of Crates ;
tgt_text.6526: but though he was in other respects very energetic in his application to philosophy, still he was too modest for the shamelessness of the Cynics.
tgt_text.6527: On which account, Crates, wishing to cure him of this false shame, gave him a jar of lentil porridge to carry through the Ceramicus;
tgt_text.6528: and when he saw that he was ashamed, and that he endeavoured to hide it, he struck the jar with his staff, and broke it;
tgt_text.6529: and, as Zeno fled away, and the lentil porridge ran all down his legs, Crates called after him, “Why do you run away, my little Phoenician, you have done no harm ?"
tgt_text.6530: For some time then he continued a pupil of Crates, and when he wrote his treatise entitled the Republic, some said, jokingly, that he had written it upon the tail of the dog.
tgt_text.6532: And besides his Republic, he was the author also of the following works :
tgt_text.6533: -a treatise on a Life according to Nature ;
tgt_text.6534: one on Appetite, or the Nature of Man ;
tgt_text.6538: one on the usual Edu- cation of the Greeks ;
tgt_text.6542: one on the Doctrines of the Pythagoreans;
tgt_text.6545: five essays on Problems relating to Homer ;
tgt_text.6546: one on the Bearing of the Poets.
tgt_text.6547: There is also an essay on Art by him, and two books of Solutions and Jests, and Reminiscences, and one called the Ethics of Crates.
tgt_text.6548: These are the books of which he was the author.
tgt_text.6550: But at last he left Crates, and became the pupil of the philosophers whom I have mentioned before, and continued with them for twenty years.
tgt_text.6551: So that it is related that he said, “I now find that I made a prosperous voyage when I was wrecked."
tgt_text.6552: But some affirm that he made this speech in reference to Crates.
tgt_text.6553: Others say, that while he was staying at Athens he heard of a shipwreck, and said, " Fortune does well in having driven us on philosophy."
tgt_text.6554: But as some relate the affair, he was not wrecked at all, but sold all his cargo at Athens, and then turned to philosophy.
tgt_text.6556: And he used to walk up and down in the beautiful colonnade which is called the Priscanactium, and which is also called ποιϰίλη,from the paintings of Polygnotus, and there he delivered his discourses, wishing to make that spot tranquil;
tgt_text.6557: for in the time of the thirty, nearly fourteen hundred of the citizens had been murdered there by them.
tgt_text.6559: Accordingly, for the future, men came thither to hear him, and from this his pupils were called Stoics, and so were his successors also, who had been at first called Zenonians, as Epicurus tells us in his Epistles.
tgt_text.6560: And before this time, the poets who frequented this colonnade (στοὰ)had been called Stoics, as we are informed by Eratosthenes, in the eighth book of his treatise on the Old Comedy;
tgt_text.6561: but now Zeno's pupils made the name more notorious.
tgt_text.6562: Now the Athenians had a great respect for Zeno, so that they gave him the keys of their walls, and they also honoured him with a golden crown, and a brazen statue ;
tgt_text.6563: and this was also done by his own countrymen, who thought the statue of such a man an honour to their city.
tgt_text.6564: And the Cittiæans, in the district of Sidon, also claimed him as their countryman.
tgt_text.6566: He was also much respected by Antigonus, who, whenever he came to Athens, used to attend his lectures, and was constantly inviting him to come to him.
tgt_text.6567: But he begged off himself, and sent Persæus, one of his intimate friends, who was the son of Demetrius, and a Cittiæan by birth, and who flourished about the hundred and thirtieth olympiad, when Zeno was an old man.
tgt_text.6568: The letter of Antigonus to Zeno was as follows, and it is reported by Apollonius, the Syrian, in his essay on Zeno."
tgt_text.6569: I think that in good fortune and glory I have the advan- tage of you;
tgt_text.6570: but in reason and education I am inferior to you, and also in that perfect happiness which you have attained to.
tgt_text.6571: On which account I have thought it good to address you, and invite you to come to me, being convinced that you will not refuse what is asked of you.
tgt_text.6572: Endeavour, therefore, by all , means to come to me, considering this fact, that you will not be the instructor of me alone, but of all the Macedonians together.
tgt_text.6573: For he who instructs the ruler of the Macedonians, and who leads him in the path of virtue, evidently marshals all his subjects on the road to happiness.
tgt_text.6574: For as the ruler is, so is it natural that his subjects for the most part should be also.
tgt_text.6575: "And Zeno wrote him back the following answer."
tgt_text.6576: I admire your desire for learning, as being a true object for the wishes of mankind, and one too that tends to their advantage.
tgt_text.6577: And the mail who aims at the study of philosophy has a proper disregard for the popular kind of instruction which tends only to the corruption of the morals.
tgt_text.6578: And you, passing by the pleasure which is so much spoken of, which makes the minds of some young men effeminate, show plainly that you are inclined to noble pursuits, not merely by your nature, but also by your own deliberate choice.
tgt_text.6579: And a noble nature, when it has received even a slight degree of training, and which also meets with those who will teach it abundantly, proceeds without difficulty to a perfect attainment of virtue.
tgt_text.6580: But I now find my bodily health impaired by old age, for I am eighty years old:
tgt_text.6581: on which account I am unable to come to you.
tgt_text.6582: But I send you some of those who have studied with me, who in that learning which has reference to the soul, are in no respect inferior to me, and in their bodily vigour are greatly my superiors.
tgt_text.6583: And if you associate with them you will want nothing that can bear upon perfect happiness.
tgt_text.6584: "So he sent him Persæus and Philonides, the Theban, both of whom are mentioned by Epicurus, in his letter to his brother Aristobulus, as being companions of Antigonus.
tgt_text.6586: And I have thought it worth while also to set down the decree of the Athenians concerning him ;
tgt_text.6587: and it is couched in the following language.
tgt_text.6588: In the archonship of Arrhenides, in the fifth presidency of the tribe Acamantis, on the twenty-first day of the month Maimacterion, on the twenty-third day of the aforesaid presidency, in a duly convened assembly, Hippo, the son of Cratistoteles, of the borough of Xypetion, being one of the presidents, and the rest of the presidents, his colleagues, put the following decree to the vote.
tgt_text.6589: And the decree was pro- posed by Thrason, of Anacæa, the son of Thrason."
tgt_text.6591: Zeno the son of Innaseas, the Cittiæan, has passed many years in the city, in the study of philosophy, being in all other respects a good man, and also exhorting all the young men who have sought his company to the practice of virtue, and encouraging them in the practice of temperance ;
tgt_text.6592: making his own life a model to all men of the greatest excellence, since it has in every respect corresponded to the doctrines which he has taught;
tgt_text.6593: it has been determined by the people (and may the determination be fortunate), to praise Zeno, the son of Innaseas, the Cittiæan, and to present him with a golden crown in accordance with the law, on account of his virtue and temperance, and to build him a tomb in the Ceramicus, at the public expense.
tgt_text.6594: And the people has appointed by its vote five men from among the citizens of Athens, who shall see to the making of the crown and the building of the tomb.
tgt_text.6595: And the scribe of the borough shall enrol the decree and engrave it on two pillars, and he shall be permitted to place one pillar in the Academy, and one in the Lyceum.
tgt_text.6596: And he who is appointed to superintend the work shall divide the expense that the pillars amount to, in such a way that every one may understand that the whole people of Athens honours good men both while they are living and after they are dead.
tgt_text.6597: And Thrason of Anaceea, Philocles of the Piræus, Phædrus of Anaphlystos, Medon of Acharnæs, Mecy- thus of Sypalyttas, and Dion of Pæania, are hereby appointed to superintend the building of the tomb.
tgt_text.6598: "These then are the terms of the decree.
tgt_text.6599: X. But Antigonus, of Carystos, says, that Zeno himself never denied that he was a native of Cittium.
tgt_text.6600: For that when on one occasion, there was a citizen of that town who had contributed to the building of some baths, and was having his name engraved on the pillar, as the countryman of Zeno the philosopher, he bade them add, " Of Cittium."XI.

tgt_text.6602: And they say that he, when he first arrived in Greece, had more than a thousand talents, which he lent out at nautical usury.
tgt_text.6604: And he used to eat little loaves and honey, and to drink a small quantity of sweet smelling wine.
tgt_text.6606: He had very few youthful acquaintances of the male sex, and he did not cultivate them much, lest be should be thought to be a misogynist.
tgt_text.6607: And he dwelt in the same house with Persseus ;
tgt_text.6608: and once, when he brought in a female flute- player to him, he hastened to bring her back to him.
tgt_text.6610: And he was, it is said, of a very accommodating temper;
tgt_text.6611: so much so, that Antigonus, the king, often came to dine with him, and often carried him off to dine with him, at the house of Aristocles the harp-player;
tgt_text.6612: but when he was there, he would presently steal away,XV, It is also said that he avoided a crowd with great care, so that he used to sit at the end of a bench, in order at all events to avoid being incommoded on one side.
tgt_text.6613: And he never used to walk with more than two or three companions.
tgt_text.6614: And he used at times to exact a piece of money from all who came to hear him, with a view of not being distressed by numbers ;
tgt_text.6615: and this story is told by Cleantbes, in his.
tgt_text.6617: And when he was surrounded by any great crowd, he would point to a balustrade of wood at the end of the- colonnade which surrounded an altar, and say, " That was once in the middle of this place, but it was placed apart because it was in people's way ;
tgt_text.6618: and now, if you will only withdraw from the middle here, you too will incommode me much less.
tgt_text.6621: And when Demochares, the son of Laches, embraced him once, and said that he would tell Antigonus, or write to him of everything which he wanted, as he always did every- thing for him, Zeno, when he had heard him say this, avoided his company for the future.
tgt_text.6622: And it is said, that after the death of Zeno, Antigonus said, " What a spectacle have I lost."

tgt_text.6624: And when he was asked why he had such an admiration for him, he replied, " Because, though I gave him a great many important presents, he was never elated, and never humbled.
tgt_text.6627: He was a man of a very investigating spirit, and one who inquired very minutely into everything ;
tgt_text.6628: in reference to which, Timon, in his Silli, speaks thus :
tgt_text.6629: - I saw an aged woman of Phœnicia, Hungry and covetous, in a proud obscurity, Longing for everything.

tgt_text.6633: *He used to study very carefully with Philo, the dialectician, and to argue with him at their mutual leisure;
tgt_text.6634: on which account he excited the wonder of the younger Zeno, no less than Diodorus his master.
tgt_text.6636: There were also a lot of dirty beggars always about him, as Timon tells us, where he says :
tgt_text.6638: Till he collected a vast cloud of beggars, Who were of all men in the world the poorest, And the most worthless citizens of Athens.
tgt_text.6639: And he himself was a man of a morose and bitter countenance, with a constantly frowning expression.
tgt_text.6640: He was very economical, and descended even to the meanness of the barbarians, under the pretence of economy.
tgt_text.6642: If he reproved any one, he did it with brevity and without exaggeration, and as it were, at a distance.
tgt_text.6643: I allude, for instance, to the way in which he spoke of a man who took exceeding pains in setting himself off, for as he was crossing a gutter with great hesitation, be said, " He is right to look down upon the mud, for he cannot see himself in it."
tgt_text.6644: And when some Cynic one day said that he had no oil in his cruise, and asked him for some, he refused to give him any, but bade him go away and consider which of the two was the more im- pudent.
tgt_text.6645: He was very much in love with Chremonides;
tgt_text.6646: and once, when he and Cleanthes were both sitting by him, he got up;
tgt_text.6647: and as Cleanthes wondered at this, he said, " I hear from skilful physicians that the best thing for some tumours is rest."
tgt_text.6648: Once, when two people were sitting above him at table at a banquet, and the one next him kept kicking the other with his foot, he himself kicked him with his knee ;
tgt_text.6649: and when he turned round upon him for doing so, he said, "
tgt_text.6650: Why then do you think that your other neighbour is to be treated in this way by you ?
tgt_text.6651: "On one occasion he said to a man who was very fond of young boys, that " Schoolmasters who were always associating with boys had no more intellect than the boys themselves."
tgt_text.6652: He used also to say that the discourses of those men who were careful to avoid solecisms, and to adhere to the strictest rules of composition, were like Alexandrine money, they were pleas- ing to the eye and well-formed like the coni, but were'nothing the better for that;
tgt_text.6653: but those who were not so particular he likened to the Attic tessedrachmas, which were struck at random and without any great nicety, and so he said that their discourses often outweighed the more polished styles of the others.
tgt_text.6654: And when Ariston, his disciple, had been holding forth a good deal without much wit, but still in some points with a good deal of readiness and confidence, he said to him, " It would be impossible for you to speak thus, if your father had not been drunk when he begat you ;
tgt_text.6655: ”and for the same reason he nicknamed him the chatterer, as he himself was very concise in his speeches.
tgt_text.6656: Once, when he was in company with an epicure who usually left nothing for his messmates, and when a large fish was set before him, he took it all as if he could eat the whole of it;
tgt_text.6657: and when the others looked at him with astonishment, he said, “What then do you think that your companions feel every day, if you cannot bear with my gluttony for one day ?
tgt_text.6658: "On one occasion, when a youth was asking him questions with a pertinacity unsuited to his age, he led him to a looking- glass and bade him look at himself, and then asked him whether such questions appeared suitable to the face he saw there.
tgt_text.6659: And when a man said before him once, that in most points he did not agree with the doctrines of Antisthenes, he quoted to him an apophthegm of Sophocles, and asked him whether he thought there was much sense in that, and when he said that he did not know, “ Are you not then ashamed,” said he, " to pick out and recollect anything bad which may have been said by Antisthenes, but not to regard or remember what- ever is said that is good ? "
tgt_text.6660: A man once said, that the say- ings of the philosophers appeared to him very trivial;
tgt_text.6661: " You say true," replied Zeno, " and their syllables too ought to be short, if that is possible."
tgt_text.6662: When some one spoke to him of Polemo, and said that he proposed one question for discussion and then argued another, he became angry, and said, " At what value did he estimate the subject that had been proposed ? "
tgt_text.6663: And he said that a man who was to discuss a question ought to have a loud voice and great energy, like the actors, but not to open his mouth too wide, which those who speak a great deal but only talk nonsense usually do.
tgt_text.6664: And he used to say that there was no need for those who argued well to leave their hearers room to look about them, as good workmen do who want to have their work seen ;
tgt_text.6665: but that, on the contrary, those who are listening to them ought to be so attentive to all that is said as to have no leisure to take notes.
tgt_text.6666: Once when a young man was talking a great deal, he said, " Your ears have run down into your tongue."
tgt_text.6667: On one occa- sion a very handsome man was saying that a wise man did not appear to him likely to fall in love ;
tgt_text.6669: Then," said he, " I can- not imagine anything that will be more miserable than you good-looking fellows."
tgt_text.6670: He also used often to say that most philosophers were wise in great things, but ignorant of petty subjects and chance details ;
tgt_text.6671: and he used to cite the saying of Caphesius, who, when one of his pupils was labouring hard to be able to blow very powerfully, gave him a slap, and said, that excellence did not depend upon greatness, but greatness on excellence.
tgt_text.6672: Once, when a young man was arguing very confidently, he said, " I should not like to say, 0 youth, all that occurs to me."
tgt_text.6673: And once, when a handsome and wealthy Rhodian, but one who had no other qualification, was pressing him to take him as a pupil, he, as he was not inclined to re- ceive him, first of all made him sit on the dusty seats that he might dirt his cloak, then he put him down in the place of the poor that he might rub against their rags, and at last the young man went away.
tgt_text.6674: One of his sayings used to be, that vanity was the most unbecoming of all things, and especially so in the young.

tgt_text.6786: But Demetrius, the Magnesian, says, in his essay on People of the Same Name, that his father Innaseas often came to Athens, as he was a merchant, and that he used to bring back many of the books of the Socratic philosophers, to, Zeno, while he was still only a boy;
