tgt_text.6791: Some, indeed, among whom is Cassius the Sceptic, attack Zeno on many accounts, saying first of all that he denounced the general system of education in vogue at the time, as useless, which he did in the beginning of his Republic.
tgt_text.6792: And in the second place, that he used to call all who were not virtuous, adversaries, and enemies, and slaves, and unfriendly to one another, parents to their children, brethren to brethren, and kinsmen to kinsmen ;
tgt_text.6793: and again, that in his Republic, he speaks of the virtuous as the only citizens, and friends, and relations, and free men, so that in the doctrine of the Stoic, even parents and their children are enemies;
tgt_text.6795: Also, that he lays down the principle of the com- munity of women both in his Republic and in a poem of two hundred verses, and teaches that neither temples nor courts of Jaw, nor gymnasia, ought to be erected in a city ;
tgt_text.6796: moreover, that he writes thus about money, " That he does not think that men ought to coin money either for purposes of traffic, or of travelling."
tgt_text.6797: Besides all this, he enjoins men and women to wear the same dress, and to leave no part of their person uncovered.
tgt_text.6799: And that this treatise on the Republic is his work we are assured by Chrysippus, in his Republic.

tgt_text.6802: Such are the charges made against him by Cassius, and also by Isidorus, of Pergamus, the orator, who says that all the unbecoming doctrines and assertions of the Stoics were cut out of their books by Athenodorus, the Stoic, who was the curator of the library at Pergamus.
tgt_text.6803: And that subsequently they were replaced, as Athenodorus was detected, and placed in a situation of great danger ;
tgt_text.6804: and this is sufficient to say about those doctrines of his which were impugned.
tgt_text.6806: There were eight different persons of the name of Zeno.
tgt_text.6807: The first was the Eleatic, whom we shall mention hereafter ;
tgt_text.6808: the second was this man of whom we are now speaking;
tgt_text.6809: the third was a Rhodian, who wrote a history of his country in one book ;
tgt_text.6810: the fourth was a historian who wrote an account of the expedition of Pyrrhus into Italy and Sicily;
tgt_text.6811: and also an epitome of the transactions between the Romans and Carthaginians ;
tgt_text.6812: the fifth was a disciple of Chrysippus, who wrote very few books, but who left a great number of disciples ;
tgt_text.6813: the sixth was a physician of Hesophila, a very shrewd man in intellect, but a very indifferent writer;
tgt_text.6814: the seventh was a grammarian, who, besides other writings, has left some epigrams behind him;
tgt_text.6815: the eighth was a Sidonian by descent, a philosopher of the Epicurean school, a deep thinker, and very clear writer.
tgt_text.6817: The disciples of Zeno were very numerous.
tgt_text.6818: The most eminent were, first of all, Persæus, of Cittium, the son of Demetrius, whom some call a friend of his, but others describe him as a servant and one of the amanuenses who were sent to him by Antigonus, to whose son, Halcymeus, he also acted as tutor.
tgt_text.6819: And Antigonus once, wishing to make trial of him, caused some false news to be brought to him that his estate had been ravaged by the enemy ;
tgt_text.6820: and as he began to look gloomy at this news, he said to him, " You see that wealth is not a matter of indifference.

tgt_text.6832: seven treatises, the Laws of Plato.

tgt_text.6834: then Herillus, who called knowledge the chief good;
tgt_text.6835: then Diony- sius, who transferred this description to pleasure:
tgt_text.6836: as, on account of the violent disease which he had in his eyes, he could not yet bring himself to call pain a thing indifferent.

tgt_text.6850: And I have thought it best to give a general account of all the Stoic doctrines in the life of Zeno, because he it was who was the founder of the sect.
tgt_text.6851: He has written a great many books, of which I have already given a list, in which he has spoken as no other of the Stoics has.
tgt_text.6852: And his doctrines in general are these.
tgt_text.6853: But we will enumerate them briefly, as we have been in the habit of doing in the case of the other philosophers.
tgt_text.6855: The Stoics divide reason according to philosophy, into three parts;
tgt_text.6856: and say that one part relates to natural philosophy, one to ethics, and one to logic.
tgt_text.6857: And Zeno, the Cittiæan, was the first who made this division, in his treatise on Reason ;
tgt_text.6858: and he was followed in it by Chrysippus, in the first book of his treatise on Reason, and in the first book of his treatise on Natural Philosophy;
tgt_text.6860: and by Syllus, in the first book of his Introduction to the Doctrines of the Stoics;
tgt_text.6861: and by Eudromus, in his Ethical Elements;
tgt_text.6864: Now these divisions are called topics by Apollodorus, species by Chrysippus and Eudromus, and genera by all the rest.
tgt_text.6865: And they compare philosophy to an animal, likening logic to the bones and sinews, natural philosophy to the fleshy parts, and ethical philosophy to the soul.
tgt_text.6866: Again, they compare it to an egg;
tgt_text.6867: calling logic the shell, and ethics the white, and natural philosophy the yolk.
tgt_text.6869: in which logic is the fence which goes round it, ethics are the fruit, and natural philosophy the soil, or the fruit-trees.
tgt_text.6870: Again, they compare it to a city fortified by walls, and regulated by reason ;
tgt_text.6871: and then, as some of them say, no one part is preferred to another, but they are all combined and united inseparably ;
tgt_text.6872: and so theytreat of them all in combination.
tgt_text.6873: But others class logic first, natural philosophy second, and ethics third;
tgt_text.6874: as Zeno does in his treatise on Reason, and in this he is followed by Chrysippus, and Archidemus, and Eudromus.
tgt_text.6875: For Diogenes of Ptolemais begins with ethics ;
tgt_text.6876: but Apollo- dorus places ethics second;
tgt_text.6877: and Pansetius and Posidonius' begin with natural philosophy, as Phanias, the friend of Posidonius asserts, in the first book of his treatise on the School of Posidonius.
tgt_text.6878: But Cleanthes says, that there are six divisions of reason according to philosophy :
tgt_text.6879: dialectics, rhetoric, ethics, politics, physics, and theology ;
tgt_text.6880: but others assert that these are not divisions of reason, but of philosophy itself;
tgt_text.6881: and this is the opinion advanced by Zeno, of Tarsus, among others.
tgt_text.6883: Some again say, that the logical division is properly subdivided into two sciences, namely, rhetoric and dialectics;
tgt_text.6884: and some divide it also into definitive species, which is coversant with rules and tests;
tgt_text.6885: while others deny the propriety of this last division altogether, and argue that the object of rules and tests is the discovery of the truth ;
tgt_text.6886: for it is in this division that they explain the differences of repre- sentations.
tgt_text.6887: They also argue that, on'the other side, the science of definitions has equally for its object the discovery of truth, since we only know things by the intervention of ideas.
tgt_text.6888: They also call rhetoric a science conversant about speaking well concerning matters which admit of a detailed narrative ;
tgt_text.6889: and dialectics they call the science of arguing correctly in discus- sions which can be carried on by question and answer ;
tgt_text.6890: on which account they define it thus:
tgt_text.6891: a knowledge of what is true, and false, and neither one thing nor the other.
tgt_text.6892: Again, rhetoric itself they divide into three kinds;
tgt_text.6893: for one description they say is concerning about giving advice, another is forensic, and the third encomiastic;
tgt_text.6894: and it is also divided into several parts, one relating to the discovery of arguments, one to style, one to the arrangement of arguments, and the other to the delivery of the speech.
tgt_text.6895: And a rhetorical oration they divide into the exordium, the narration, the reply to the statements of the adverse party, and the peroration.
tgt_text.6897: Dialectics, they say, is divided into two parts ;
tgt_text.6898: one of which has reference to the things signified, the other to the expression.
tgt_text.6899: That which has reference to the things signified or spoken of,they divide again into the topic of things con- ceived in the fancy, and into those of axioms, of perfect determinations, of predicaments, of things alike, whether upright or prostrate, of tropes, of syllogisms, and of sophisms, which are derived either from the voice or from the things.
tgt_text.6900: And these sophisms are of various kinds ;
tgt_text.6901: there is the false one, the one which states facts, the negative, the sorites, and others like these;
tgt_text.6902: the imperfect one, the inexplicable one, the con- clusive one, the veiled one, the horned one, the nobody, and the mower.
tgt_text.6903: In the second part of dialectics, that which has for its object the expression, they treat of written language, of the different parts of a discourse, of solecism and barbarism, of poetical forms of expression, of ambiguity, of a melodious voice, of music ;
tgt_text.6904: and some even add definitions, divisions, and diction.
tgt_text.6905: They say that the most useful of these parts is the con- sideration of syllogisms ;
tgt_text.6906: for that they show us what are the things which are capable of demonstration, and that contributes much to the formation of our judgment, and their arrangement and memory give a scientific character to our knowledge.
tgt_text.6907: They define reasoning to be a system composed of assumptions and conclusions :
tgt_text.6908: and syllogism is a syllogistic argument pro- ceeding on them.
tgt_text.6909: Demonstration they define to be a method by which one proceeds from that which is more known to that which is less.
tgt_text.6910: Perception, again, is an impression produced on the mind, its name being appropriately borrowed from impres- sions on wax made by a seal;
tgt_text.6911: and perception they divide into- comprehensible and incomprehensible:
tgt_text.6912: Comprehensible, which they call the criterion of facts, and which is produced by a real object, and is, therefore, at the same time conformable to that object;
tgt_text.6913: Incomprehensible, which has no relation to any real object, or else, if it has any such relation, does not correspond to it, being but a vague and indistinct representation.
tgt_text.6914: Dialectics itself they pronounce to be a necessary science, and a virtue which comprehends several other virtues under its species.
tgt_text.6915: And the disposition not to take up one side of an argument hastily, they defined to be a knowledge by which we are taught when we ought to agree to a statement, and when we ought to withhold our agreement.
tgt_text.6916: Discretion they consider to be a powerful reason, having reference to what is becoming, so as to prevent our yielding to an irrelevant argu- ment.
tgt_text.6917: Irrefutability they define to be a power in an argument, which prevents one from being drawn from it to its opposite.
tgt_text.6918: Freedom from vanity, according to them, is a habit which refers the perceptions back to right reason.
tgt_text.6919: Again, they define knowledge itself as an assertion or safe comprehension, or habit, which, in the perception of what is seen, never deviates from the truth.
tgt_text.6920: And they say further, that without dialectic speculation, the wise man cannot be free from all error in his reasoning.
tgt_text.6921: For that that is what distinguishes what is true from what is false, and which easily detects those arguments which are only plausible, and those which depend upon an ambiguity of language.
tgt_text.6922: And without dialectics they say it is not possible to ask or answer questions correctly.
tgt_text.6923: They also add, that precipitation in denials extends to those things which are done, so that those who have not properly exercised their perceptions fall into irregularity and thoughtlessness.
tgt_text.6924: Again, without dialectics, the wise man cannot be acute, and ingenious, and wary, and altogether dangerous as an arguer.
tgt_text.6925: For that it belongs to the same man to speak correctly and to reason correctly, and to discuss properly those subjects which are proposed to him, and to answer readily whatever questions are put to him, all which qualities belong to a man who is skilful in dialectics.
tgt_text.6926: This then is a brief summary of their opinions on logic.
tgt_text.6928: And, that we may also enter into some more minute details respecting them, we will subjoin what refers to what they call their introductory science, as it is stated by Diodes, of Magnesia, in his Excursion of Philosophers, where he speaks as follows, and we will give his account word for word.
tgt_text.6929: The Stoics have chosen to treat, in the first place, of percep- tion and sensation, because the criterion by which the truth of facts is ascertained is a kind of perception, and because the judgment which expresses the belief, and the comprehension, and the understanding of a thing, a judgment which precedes all others, cannot exist without perception.
tgt_text.6931: and then thought, finding vent in expressions, explains in words the feelings which it derives from perception.
tgt_text.6932: But there is a difference between ϕαντασίαand ϕάντασμα.a.dfJ.Ct..
tgt_text.6933: For ϕάντασμαιs a conception of the intellect, such as takes place in sleep ;
tgt_text.6934: but ϕαντασίαιs an impression, τύπωσις, pro- duced on the mind, that is to say, an alteration, ἀλλοίωσις,as Chrysippus states in the twelfth book of his treatise on the Soul.
tgt_text.6935: For we must not take this impression to resemble that made by a seal, since it is impossible to conceive that there should be many impressions made at the same time on the same thing.
tgt_text.6936: But ϕαντασίαιs understood to be that which is im- pressed, and formed, and imprinted by a real object, according to a real object, in such a way as it could not be by any other than a real object;
tgt_text.6937: and, according to their ideas of the ϕαντασίαι,some are sensible, and some are not.
tgt_text.6938: Those they call sensible, which are derived by us from some one or more senses;
tgt_text.6939: and those they call not sensible, which emanate directly from the thought, as for instance, those which relate to incorporeal objects, or any others which are embraced by reason.
tgt_text.6940: Again, those which are sensible, are produced by a real object, which imposes itself on the intelligence, and com- pels its acquiescence ;
tgt_text.6941: and there are also some others, which are simply apparent, mere shadows, which resemble those which are produced by real objects.
tgt_text.6942: Again, these ϕαντάσιαιare divided into rational and irra- tional ;
tgt_text.6943: those which are rational belong to animals capable of reason;
tgt_text.6944: those which are irrational to animals destitute of reason.
tgt_text.6945: Those which are rational are thoughts ;
tgt_text.6946: those which are irrational have no name ;
tgt_text.6947: but are again subdivided into artificial and not artificial.
tgt_text.6948: At all events, an image is contem- plated in a different light by a man skilful in art, from that in which it is viewed by a man ignorant of art.
tgt_text.6949: By sensation, the Stoics understand a species of breath which proceeds from the dominant portion of the soul to the senses, whether it be a sensible perception, or an organic dispo sition, which, according to the notions of some of them, is crippled and vicious.
tgt_text.6950: They also call sensation the energy, or active exercise, of the sense.
tgt_text.6951: According to them, it is to sensation that we owe our comprehension of white and black, and rough and smooth :
tgt_text.6952: from reason, that we derive the notions which result from a demonstration, those for instance which have for their object the existence of Gods, and of Divine Providence.
tgt_text.6953: For all our thoughts are formed either by indirect perception, or by similarity, or analogy, or trans- position, or combination, or opposition.
tgt_text.6954: By a direct percep- tion, we perceive those things which are the objects of sense ;
tgt_text.6955: by similarity, those which start from some point present to our senses ;
tgt_text.6956: as, for instance, we form an idea of Socrates from his likeness.
tgt_text.6957: We draw our conclusions by analogy, adopt- ing either an increased idea of the thing, as of Tityus, or the Cyclops;
tgt_text.6958: or a diminished idea, as of a pigmy.
tgt_text.6959: So, too, the idea of the centre of the world was one derived by analogy from what we perceived to be the case of the smaller spheres.
tgt_text.6960: We use transposition when we fancy eyes in a man's breast;
tgt_text.6961: combination, when we take in the idea of a Centaur;
tgt_text.6962: opposition, when we turn our thoughts to death.
tgt_text.6963: Some ideas we also derive from comparison, for instance, from a comparison of words and places.
tgt_text.6965: as by nature we comprehend what is just and good.
tgt_text.6966: And privation, when for instance, we form a notion of a man without hands.
tgt_text.6967: Such are the doctrines -of the Stoics, on the subject of phantasm, and sensation, and thought.
tgt_text.6969: They say that the proper criterion of truth is the comprehension, ϕαντασία;
tgt_text.6970: that is to say, one which is derived from a real object, as Chrysippus asserts in the twelfth book of his Physics ;
tgt_text.6971: and he is followed by Antipater and Apollodorus.
tgt_text.6972: For Boethius leaves a great many criteria, such as intellect, sensation, appetite, and knowledge;
tgt_text.6973: but Chrysippus dissents from his view, and in the first book of his treatise on Reason, says, that sensation and preconcep- tion are the only criteria.
tgt_text.6974: And preconception is, according to him, a comprehensive physical notion of general principles.
tgt_text.6975: But others of the earlier Stoics admit right reason as one criterion of the truth;
tgt_text.6976: for instance, this is the opinion of Posidonius, and is advanced by him in his essay on Criteria.
tgt_text.6978: On the subject of logical speculation, there appears to be a great unanimity among the greater part of the Stoics, in beginning with the topic of the voice.
tgt_text.6979: Now voice is a percussion of the air;
tgt_text.6980: or, as Diogenes the Babylonian, defines it, in his essay on the Voice, a sensation peculiar to the hearing.
tgt_text.6981: The voice of a beast is a mere percussion of the air by some impetus :
tgt_text.6982: but the voice of a man is articulate, and is emitted by intellect, as Diogenes lays it down, and is not brought to perfection in a shorter period than fourteen years.
tgt_text.6983: And the voice is a body according to the Stoics ;
tgt_text.6984: for so it is laid down by Archidemus, in his book on the Voice, and by Diogenes, and Antipater, and also by Chrysippus, in the second volume of his Physics.
tgt_text.6985: For everything which makes anything, is a body;
tgt_text.6986: and the voice makes something when it proceeds to those who hear from those who speak.
tgt_text.6987: A word (λέξις), again, is, according to Diogenes, a voice consisting of letters, as " Day."
tgt_text.6988: A sentence (λόγος) is a significant voice, sent out by the intellect, as for instance, " It is day;
tgt_text.6989: " but dialect is a peculiar style imprinted on the utterance of nations, according to their race;
tgt_text.6990: and causes varieties in the Greek language, being a sort of local habit, as for instance, the Attics say θάλαττα,and the Ionians say ἠμέϱη.
tgt_text.6991: The elements of words are the twenty-four letters ;
tgt_text.6992: and the word letter is used in a triple division of sense, meaning the element itself, the graphical sign of the element, and the name, as Alpha.
tgt_text.6993: There are seven vowels, a, s, η,ι, o, υ,ω ;
tgt_text.6994: six mutes, /3, y, δ, x, π, τ.
tgt_text.6995: But voice is different from a word, because voice is a sound ;
tgt_text.6996: but a word is an articulate sound.
tgt_text.6997: And a word differs from a sentence, because a sen- tence is always significative of something, but a word by itself has no signification, as for instance, βλίτϱι.
tgt_text.6998: But this is not the case with a sentence.
tgt_text.6999: Again, there is a difference between speaking and pronouncing;
tgt_text.7000: the sounds are pronounced, but what are spoken are things which are capable of being spoken of.
tgt_text.7002: Now of sentences there are five parts, as Dio- genes tells us in his treatise on Voice ;
tgt_text.7003: and he is followed by Chrysippus.
tgt_text.7004: There is the noun, the common noun, the verb, the conjunction, and the article.
tgt_text.7005: Antipater adds also quality, in his treatise upon Words and the things expressed by them.
tgt_text.7006: And a common noun (πϱοσηγοϱία) is, according to Diogenes, a part of a sentence signifying a common quality, as for instance, man, horse.
tgt_text.7007: But a noun is a part of a sentence signifying a peculiar quality, such as Diogenes, Socrates.
tgt_text.7008: A verb is a part of a sentence signifying an uncombined categorem, as Diogenes (ὁ Διογένης) or, as others define it, an element of a sentence, devoid of case, signifying something compound in reference to some person or persons, as, " I write," " I say."
tgt_text.7009: A conjunc- tion is a part of a sentence destitute of case, uniting the divi- sions of the sentence.
tgt_text.7010: An article is an element of a sentence, having cases, defining the genders of nouns and their numbers ;
tgt_text.7011: as o, ἡ, τὸ, ὁἰ, αἱ, τὰ.XL.
tgt_text.7012: The excellences of a sentence are five,—good Greek, clearness, conciseness, suitableness, elegance.
tgt_text.7013: Good Greek (' Ελληνιϭμὸς) is a correct style, according to art, keeping aloof from any vulgar form of expression ;
tgt_text.7014: clearness is a style which states that which is conceived in the mind in such a way that it is easily known :
tgt_text.7015: conciseness is a style which embraces all that is necessary to the clear explanation of the subject under discussion;
tgt_text.7016: suitableness is a style suited to the subject;
tgt_text.7017: elegance is a style which avoids all peculiarity of expression.
tgt_text.7018: Of the vices of a sentence, on the other hand, barbarism is a use of words contrary to that in vogue among the well-educated Greeks ;
tgt_text.7019: solecism is a sentence incongruously put together.
tgt_text.7021: A poetical expression is, as Posidonius defines it in his introduction on Style, “ A metrical or rhythmical diction, proceeding in preparation, and avoiding all resemblance to prose."
tgt_text.7022: For instance, " The vast and boundless earth," " Th' expanse of heaven," are rhythmical expressions;
tgt_text.7023: and poetry is a collection of poetical expressions signifying some- thing, containing an imitation of divine and human beings.
tgt_text.7025: A definition is, as Antipater explains it in the first book of his treatise on Definitions, a sentence proceeding by analysis enunciated in such a way as to give a complete idea;
tgt_text.7026: or, as Chrysippus says in his treatise on Definitions, it is the explanation of an idea.
tgt_text.7027: Description is a sentence which, in a figurative manner, brings one to a knowledge of the subject, or it may be called a simpler kind of definition, expressing the power of a definition in plainer language.
tgt_text.7028: Genus is a com- prehending of many ideas indissolubly connected, as animal;
tgt_text.7029: for this one expression comprehends all particular kinds of animals.
tgt_text.7030: An idea is an imagination of the mind which does not express actually anything real, or any quality, but only a quasi reality and a quasi quality ;
tgt_text.7031: such, for instance, is the idea of a horse when a horse is not present.
tgt_text.7032: Species is that which is comprehended under genus, as man is comprehended under animal.
tgt_text.7033: Again, that is the most general genus which, being a genus itself, has no other genus, as the existent.
tgt_text.7034: And that is the' most special species, which being a species has no other species, as, for instance, Socrates.
tgt_text.7036: The division of genus is a dissection of it into the proximate species ;
tgt_text.7037: as, for instance, " Of animals, some are rational, others irrational."
tgt_text.7038: Contrary division is the dissection of genus into species on the principle of the contrary ;
tgt_text.7039: so as to be by a sort of negation ;
tgt_text.7040: as, for instance, " Of existent things, some are good and some not good;
tgt_text.7041: " and, " Of things which are not good, some are bad and some indifferent."
tgt_text.7042: Partition is an arrangement of a genus with reference to place, as Crinis says, for instance, " Of goods, some have reference to the mind and some to the body.
tgt_text.7044: Ambiguity (ἀμϕιβολα) is an expression signifying two or more things having an ordinary or a peculiar meaning, according to the pronunciation, in such a way that more things than one may be understood by the very same expression.
tgt_text.7045: Take, for instance, the words αὐλητϱὶςπέπτωϰε.
tgt_text.7046: For you may understand by them, a house has fallen down three times (αὐλητϱὶςπέπτωϰε), or, a female flute-player has fallen, taking αὐλητϱὶςas synonymous with αὐλητϱία.
tgt_text.7048: Dialectics are, as Posidonius explains them, the science of what is true and false, and neither one or the other, and it is, as Chrysippus explains it, conversant about words that signify and things that are signified ;
tgt_text.7049: these then are the doctrines asserted by the Stoics in their speculations on the subject of the voice.
tgt_text.7051: But in that part of dialectics which concerns things and ideas signified, they treat of propositions, of perfect enun- ciations, of judgments, of syllogisms, of imperfect enuncia- tions, of attributes and deficiences, and of both direct and indirect categorems or predicaments.
tgt_text.7053: And they say that enunciation is the manifestation of the ideal perception ;
tgt_text.7054: and these enunciations the Stoics pro- nounce some to be perfect in themselves, and some to be defec- tive;
tgt_text.7055: now those are defective, which furnish an incomplete sense, as for instance, "He writes."
tgt_text.7056: For then we ask further, "Who writes?"
tgt_text.7057: But those are perfect in themselves, which give a sense entirely complete, as for instance, " Socrates writes."
tgt_text.7058: Accordingly, in the defective enunciations, categorems are applied;
tgt_text.7059: but in those which are perfect in themselves, axioms, and syllogisms, and questions, and interrogations, are brought into play.
tgt_text.7060: Now a categorem is something which is predicated of something else, being either a thing which is added to one or more objects, according to the definition of Apollodorus, or else a defective enunciation added to the nominative case, for the purpose of forming a proposition:
tgt_text.7061: Now of categorems, some are accidents ....* as for in- stance, “ The sailing through a rock." ....
tgt_text.7062: And of cate- gorems, some are direct, some indirect, and some neither one nor the other.
tgt_text.7063: Now those are correct, which are construed with one of the oblique cases, in such a manner as to produce a categorem, as for instance, " He hears, he sees, he con- verses."
tgt_text.7064: And those are indirect, which are construed with the passive voice, as for instance, " I am heard, I am seen."
tgt_text.7065: And those which are neither one nor the other, are those which are construed in a neutral kind of manner, as for instance, " To think, to walk."
tgt_text.7066: And those are reciprocal, which are among the indirect ones, with out being indirect themselves.
tgt_text.7067: Those are effects, ἐνϱγήματα,which are such words as, " He is shaved;
tgt_text.7068: " for then, the man who is shaved, implies himself.
tgt_text.7069: The oblique cases, are the genitive, the dative, and the accusative.
tgt_text.7071: An axiom, is that thing which is true, or false, or perfect in itself, being asserted, or denied positively, as far as depends upon itself;
tgt_text.7072: as Chrysippus explains it in his Dialectic Definitions ;
tgt_text.7073: as for instance, "It is day," " Dion is walking."
tgt_text.7074: And it has received the name of axiom, ἀξίωμα,because it is either maintained, ἀξιου̃ται, or repudiated.
tgt_text.7075: For the man who says, "It is day," appears to maintain the fact of its being day.
tgt_text.7076: If then it is day, the axiom put before one is true;
tgt_text.7077: but if it is not day, the axiom is false.
tgt_text.7078: And an axiom, a question, and an interrogation, differ from one another, and so does an imperative proposition from one which is adjurative, or impre- catory, or hypothetical, or appellative, or false.
tgt_text.7079: For that is an axiom which we utter, when we affirm anything positively, which is either true or false.
tgt_text.7080: And a question is a thing com- plete in itself, as also is an axiom, but which requires an answer, as for instance, " Is it day?"
tgt_text.7081: Now this is neither true nor false ;
tgt_text.7083: It is day " is an axiom;
tgt_text.7084: so is, " Is it day?" a question.
tgt_text.7085: But an interrogation, πύϭμα,is a thing to which it is not possible to make an answer symbolically, as in the case of a question, ἐϱώτημα,saying merely "
tgt_text.7086: Yes," but we must reply, " He does live in this place.
tgt_text.7087: "The imperative proposition is a thing which we utter when we give an order, as for instance this :
tgt_text.7089: Do you now go to the sweet stream of Inachus.
tgt_text.7090: *The appellative proposition is one which is used in the case in which, when a man says anything, be must address somebody, as for instance :
tgt_text.7091: - Atrides, glorious king of men, Most mighty Agamemnon.
tgt_text.7092: tA false judgment is a proposition, which, while it has at the same time the appearance of a real judgment, loses this character by the addition, and under the influence of, some particle, as for instance :
tgt_text.7093: The Parthenon at least is beautiful.
tgt_text.7094: How like the herdsman is to Priam's sons.
tgt_text.7095: There is also the dubitative proposition, which differs from the judgment, inasmuch as it is always uttered in the form of a doubt;
tgt_text.7098: Are not, then, grief and life two kindred states ?
tgt_text.7099: *But questions, and interrogations, and things like these, are neither true nor false, while judgments and propositions are necessarily one or the other.
tgt_text.7100: Now of axioms, some are simple, and others are not simple;
tgt_text.7101: as Chrysippus, and Archedemus, and Athenodorus, and Anti- pater, and Crinis, agree in dividing them.
tgt_text.7102: Those are simple, which consist of an axiom or proposition, which is not am- biguous, (or of several axioms, or propositions of the same character,) as for instance the sentence, "It is day."
tgt_text.7103: And those are not simple, which consist of an axiom or proposition which is ambiguous, or of several axioms or propositions of that character.
tgt_text.7104: Of an axiom, or proposition, which is am- biguous.
tgt_text.7107: " of several axioms, or propositions of that character, as, "If it is day, it is light.
tgt_text.7108: "And simple propositions are divided into the affirmative, the negative, the privative, the categorical, the definite, and the indefinite ;
tgt_text.7109: those which are not simple, are divided into the combined, and the adjunctive, the connected and the dis- junctive, and the causal and the augmentative, and the dimi- nutive.
tgt_text.7110: That is an affirmative proposition, " It is not day."
tgt_text.7111: And the species of this is doubly affirmative.
tgt_text.7112: That again is doubly affirmative, which is affirmative of an affirmative, as for instance, “ It is not not day ;
tgt_text.7113: ” for this amounts to, " It is day."
tgt_text.7114: That is a negative proposition, which consists of a negative particle and a categorem, as for instance, " No one is walking."
tgt_text.7115: That is a privative proposition which consists of a privative particle and an axiom according to power, as "This man is inhuman."
tgt_text.7116: That is a categorical proposition, which consists of a nominative case and a categorem, as for in- stance, " Dion is walking."
tgt_text.7117: That is a definite proposition, which consists of a demonstrative nominative case and a categorem, as for instance, " This man is walking."
tgt_text.7118: That is an indefinite one which consists of an indefinite particle, or of indefinite particles, as for instance, " Somebody is walk- ing," " He is moving.
tgt_text.7119: "Of propositions which are not simple, the combined propo- sition is, as Chrysippus states, in his Dialectics, and Diogenes, too, in his Dialectic Art;
tgt_text.7120: that which is held together by the copulative conjunction " if."
tgt_text.7121: And this conjunction professes that the second member of the sentence follows the first, as for instance, " If it is day, it is light."
tgt_text.7122: That which is adjunc- tive is, as Crinis states in his Dialectic Art, an axiom which is made to depend on the conjunction " since " (ἐπεὶ), beginning with an axiom and ending in an axiom, as for instance, " Since it is day, it is light."
tgt_text.7123: And this conjunction professes both that the second portion of the proposition follows the first, and the first is true.
tgt_text.7124: That is a connected proposition which is connected by some copulative conjunctions, as for instance, " It both is day, and it is light."
tgt_text.7125: That is a disjunctive pro- position which is disconnected by the disjunctive conjunction, "or" (ἤτοι,) as for instance, " It is either day or night."
tgt_text.7126: And this proposition professes that one or other of these proposi- tions is false.
tgt_text.7127: That is a causal proposition which is connected by the word, "because;
tgt_text.7128: " as for instance, " Because it is day, it is light."
tgt_text.7129: For the first is, as it were, the cause of the second.
tgt_text.7130: That is an augmentative proposition, which explains the greater, which is construed with an augmentative particle, and which is placed between the two members of the pro- position, as for instance, "It is rather day than night."
tgt_text.7131: The diminutive proposition is, in every respect, the exact contrary of the preceding one ;
tgt_text.7132: as for instance, " It is less night than day."
tgt_text.7133: Again, at times, axioms or propositions are opposed to one another in respect of their truth and falsehood, when one is an express denial of the other;
tgt_text.7134: as for instance, " It is day," and, " It is not day.
tgt_text.7135: "Again, a conjunctive proposition is correct, when it is such that the opposite of the conclusion is contradictory of the premiss;
tgt_text.7136: as for instance, the proposition, "If it is day, it is light," is true ;
tgt_text.7137: for, " It is not light," which is the opposite to.
tgt_text.7138: the conclusion expressed, is contradictory to the premiss, " It is day."
tgt_text.7139: And a conjunctive proposition is incorrect, when it is such that the opposite of the conclusion is not inconsistent with the premiss, as for instance, " If it is day, Dion is walk- ing."
tgt_text.7140: For the fact that Dion is not walking, is not contra- dictory of the premiss, " It is day.
tgt_text.7141: "An adjunctive proposition is correct, which begins with a true premiss, and ends in a consequence which follows of necessity, as for instance, " Since it is day, the sun is above the earth."
tgt_text.7142: But it is incorrect when it either begins with a false premiss, or ends with a consequence which does not fol- low properly;
tgt_text.7143: as for instance, " Since it is night, Dion is walking," for this may be said in the day-time.
tgt_text.7144: A causal proposition is correct, when it begins with a true premiss, and ends in a consequence which necessarily follows from it, but yet does not have its premiss reciprocally con- sequent upon its conclusion;
tgt_text.7145: as for instance, " Because it is day, it is light."
tgt_text.7146: For the fact of its being light, is a neces- sary consequence of its being day;
tgt_text.7147: but the fact of its being day, is not necessarily a consequence of its being light.
tgt_text.7148: A causal proposition is incorrect, which either begins with a false premiss, or ends with a conclusion that does not follow from it, or which has a premiss which does not correspond to the conclusion ;
tgt_text.7149: as for instance, " Because it is night, Dion is walking.
tgt_text.7150: "A proposition is persuasive, which leads to the assent of the mind, as for instance, “ If she brought him forth, she is his mother."
tgt_text.7151: But still this is a falsehood, for a hen is not the mother of an egg.
tgt_text.7152: Again, there are some propositions which are possible, and some which are impossible ;
tgt_text.7153: and some which are necessary, and some which are not necessary.
tgt_text.7154: That is possible, which is capable of being true, since external cir- cumstances are no hindrance to its being true;
tgt_text.7156: And that is impossible which is not capable of being true;
tgt_text.7157: as for instance, " The earth flies."
tgt_text.7158: That is necessary which, being true, is not capable of being false ;
tgt_text.7159: or perhaps is intrinsically capable of being false, but still has ex- ternal circumstances whioh hinder its being false, as for instance, " Virtue profits a man."
tgt_text.7160: That again, is not neces- sary, which is true, but which has a capacity of being false, though external circumstances offer no hindrance to either alternative ;
tgt_text.7162: "That is a reasonable or probable proposition, which has a great preponderance of opportunities in favour of its being true ;
tgt_text.7163: as for instance, " I shall be alive to-morrow."
tgt_text.7164: And there are other different kinds of propositions and conversions of them, from true to false, and re-conversions again;
tgt_text.7165: con- cerning which we must speak at some length.
tgt_text.7167: An argument, as Crinis says, is that which is com- posed of a lemma or major premiss, an assumption or minor premiss, and a conclusion;
tgt_text.7168: as for instance this, " If it is day, it is light;
tgt_text.7169: " , But it is day, therefore it is light."
tgt_text.7170: For the lemma, or major premiss, is, " If it is day, it is light."
tgt_text.7171: The assumption, or minor premiss, is, "It is day."
tgt_text.7172: The conclusion follows, " Therefore it is light."
tgt_text.7173: The mode of a proposition is, as it were, a figure of an argument, as for instance, such as this, " If it is the first, it is the second ;
tgt_text.7174: but it is the first, therefore it is the second.
tgt_text.7175: "A conditional syllogism is that which is composed of both the preceding arguments ;
tgt_text.7176: as for instance, " If Plato is alive, Plato breathes;
tgt_text.7177: but the first fact is so, therefore so is the second."
tgt_text.7178: And this conditional syllogism has been introduced for the sake, in long and complex sentences, of not being forced to repeat the assumption, as it was a long one, and also the conclusion ;
tgt_text.7179: but of being able, instead, to content one's self with summing it up briefly thus, “ The first case put is true, therefore so is the second.
tgt_text.7180: "Of arguments, some are conclusive, others are inconclusive.
tgt_text.7181: Those are inconclusive which are such, that the opposite of the conclusion drawn in them is not necessarily incompatible with the connection of the premisses.
tgt_text.7182: As for instance, such arguments as these, " If it is day, it is light;
tgt_text.7183: but it is day, therefore, Dion is walking."
tgt_text.7184: But of conclusive arguments, some are called properly by the kindred name conclusions, and some are called syllogistic arguments.
tgt_text.7185: Those then are syllogistic which are either such as do not admit of demonstra- tion, or such as are brought to an indemonstrable conclusion, according to some one or more propositions ;
tgt_text.7186: such for instance as the following:
tgt_text.7187: " If Dion walks, then Dion is in motion."
tgt_text.7188: Those are conclusive, which infer their conclusion specially, and not syl-logistically ;
tgt_text.7189: such for instance, as this, " The proposition it is both day and night is false.
tgt_text.7192: "Those again, are unsyllogistic arguments which have an air of probability about them, and a resemblance to syllogistic ones, but which still do not lead to the deduction of proper conclusions.
tgt_text.7193: As for instance, " If Dion is a horse, Dion is an animal;
tgt_text.7194: but Dion is not a horse, therefore, Dion is not an animal.
tgt_text.7195: "Again, of arguments, some are true, and some are false.
tgt_text.7196: Those are true which deduce a conclusion from true premisses, as, for instance, " If virtue profits, then vice injures."
tgt_text.7197: And those are false which have some falsehood in their premisses, or which are inconclusive ;
tgt_text.7198: as, for instance, " If it is day, it is light;
tgt_text.7199: but it is day, therefore, Dion is alive.
tgt_text.7200: "There are also arguments which are possible, and others which are impossible ;
tgt_text.7201: some likewise which are necessary, and others which are not necessary.
tgt_text.7202: There are too, some which are not demonstrated from their not standing in need of demonstration, and these are laid down differently by different people ;
tgt_text.7203: but Chrysippus enumerates five kinds, which serve as the foundation for every kind of argument;
tgt_text.7204: and which are assumed in conclusive arguments properly so called, and in syllogisms, and in modes.
tgt_text.7205: The first kind that is not demonstrated, is that in which the whole argument consists of a conjunctive and an antecedent;
tgt_text.7206: and in which the first term repeats itself so as to form a sort of conjunctive proposition, and to bring forward as the conclu- sion the last term.
tgt_text.7207: As, for instance, " If the first be true, so is the second ;
tgt_text.7208: but the first is true, therefore, so is the second."
tgt_text.7209: The second kind that is not demonstrated, is that which, by means of the conjunctive and the opposite of the conclusion, has a conclusion opposite to the first premiss.
tgt_text.7210: As, for instance, " If it be day, it is light;
tgt_text.7211: but it is night, therefore it is not day."
tgt_text.7212: For here the assumption arises from the opposite of the conclusion, and the conclusion from the opposite of the first term.
tgt_text.7213: The third kind that is not demonstrative, is that which, by a negative combination, and by one of the terms in the proposition, produces the contradictory of the remainder;
tgt_text.7214: as, for instance, " Plato is not dead and alive at the same time but Plato is dead ;
tgt_text.7216: The fourth kind that is not demonstrative, is that which, by means of a disjunctive, and one of those terms which are in the disjunctive, has a conclusion opposite to what remains;
tgt_text.7217: as, for instance, " It is either the first, or the second :
tgt_text.7219: therefore, it is not the second."
tgt_text.7220: The fifth kind that is not demonstrative, is that in which the whole argument consists of a disjunctive proposition, and the opposite of one of the terms, aud then one makes the conclusion identical with the remainder ;
tgt_text.7221: as, for instance, " It is either day or night ;
tgt_text.7224: "According to the Stoics, truth follows upon truth, as " It is light," follows upon "
tgt_text.7227: as, " If it is false that it is night, it is also false that it is dark."
tgt_text.7228: Sometimes too, truth follows from falsehood ;
tgt_text.7229: for instance, though it is false that " the earth flies,” it is true that " there is the earth."
tgt_text.7230: But falsehood does never follow from truth;
tgt_text.7231: for, from the fact that " there is the earth," it does not follow that the earth flies.
tgt_text.7232: "There are also some arguments which are perplexed, being veiled and escaping notice ;
tgt_text.7233: or such as are called sorites, the horned one, or the nobody.
tgt_text.7234: That is a veiled argument* which resembles the following one ;
tgt_text.7235: “ two are not a few, nor three, nor those, nor four, and so on to ten ;
tgt_text.7237: there- fore, so are ten few.
tgt_text.7238: "The nobody is a conjunctive argument, and one that consists of the indefinite and the definite, and which has a minor pre- miss and a conclusion;
tgt_text.7239: as, for instance, " If any one is here, he is not in Rhodes."L. Such then are the doctrines which the Stoics maintain on the subject of logic, in order as far as possible to establish their point that the logician is the only wise man.
tgt_text.7240: For they assert that all affairs are looked at by means of that speculation which proceeds by argument, including under this assertion' both those that belong to natural and also those which belong to moral philosophy :
tgt_text.7241: for, say they, how else could one deter- mine the exact value of nouns, or how else could one explain what laws are imposed upon such and such actions ?
tgt_text.7242: More- over, as there are two habits both incidental to virtue, the one considers what each existing thing is, and the other inquires what it is called.
tgt_text.7243: These then are the notions of the Stoics on the subject of logic.
tgt_text.7245: The ethical part of philosophy they divide into the topic of inclination, the topic of good and bad, the topic of the passions, the topic of virtue, the topic of the chief good, and of primary estimation, and of actions ;
tgt_text.7246: the topic of what things are becoming, and of exhortation and dissuasion.
tgt_text.7247: And this division is the one laid down by Chrysippus, and Archedemus, and Zeno, of Tarsus, and Apollodorus, and Diogenes, and Antipater, and Posidonius.
tgt_text.7248: For Zeno, of Cittium, and Clean- thes, have, as being more ancient they were likely to, adopted a more simple method of treating these subjects.
tgt_text.7249: But these men divided logical and the natural philosophy.
tgt_text.7251: They say that the first inclination which an animal has is to protect itself, as nature brings herself to take an interest in it from the beginning, as Chrysippus affirms in the first book of his treatise on Ends ;
tgt_text.7252: where he says, that the first and dearest object to every animal is its own existence, and its consciousness of that existence.
tgt_text.7253: For that it is not natural for any animal to be alienated from itself, or even to be brought into such a state as to be indifferent to itself, being neither alienated from nor interested in itself.
tgt_text.7254: It remains, therefore, that we must assert that nature has bound the animal to itself by the greatest unanimity and affection;
tgt_text.7255: for by that means it repels all that is injurious, and attracts all that is akin to it and desirable.
tgt_text.7256: But as for what some people say, that the first inclination of animals is to pleasure, they say what is false.
tgt_text.7257: For they say that pleasure, if there be any such thing at all, is an accessory only, which, nature, having sought it out by itself, as well as those things which are adapted to its constitution, receives incidentally in the same manner as animals are pleased, and plants made to flourish.
tgt_text.7258: Moreover, say they, nature makes no difference between animals and plants, when she regulates them so as to leave them without voluntary motion or sense ;
tgt_text.7259: and some things too take place in ourselves in the same manner as in plants.
tgt_text.7260: But, as inclination in animals tends chiefly to the point of making them pursue what is appropriate to them, we may say that their inclinations are regulated by nature.
tgt_text.7261: And as reason is given to rational animals according to a more perfect principle, it follows, that to live correctly according to reason, is properly predicated of those who live according to nature.
tgt_text.7262: For nature is as it were the artist who produces the inclination.
tgt_text.7264: On which account Zeno was the first writer who, in his treatise on the Nature of Man, said, that the chief good was confessedly to live according to nature;
tgt_text.7265: which is to live ac- cording to virtue, for nature leads us to this point.
tgt_text.7266: And in like manner Cleanthes speaks in his treatise on Pleasure, and so do Posidonius and Hecaton in their essays on Ends as the Chief Good.
tgt_text.7267: And again, to live according to virtue is the same thing as living according to one's experience of those things which happen by nature ;
tgt_text.7268: as Chrysippus explains it in the first book of his treatise on the Chief Good.
tgt_text.7269: For our individual natures are all parts of universal nature ;
tgt_text.7270: on which account the chief good is to live in a manner corresponding to nature, and that means corresponding to one's own nature and to universal nature ;
tgt_text.7271: doing none of those things which the common law of mankind is in the habit of forbidding, and that common law is identical with that right reason which pervades everything, being the same with Jupiter, who is the regulator and chief manager of all existing things.
tgt_text.7272: Again, this very thing is the virtue of the happy man and the perfect happiness of life when everything is done according to a harmony with the genius of each individual with reference to the will of the universal governor and manager of all things.
tgt_text.7273: Diogenes, accordingly, says expressly that the chief good is to act according to sound reason in our selection of things according to our nature.
tgt_text.7274: And Archidemus defines it to be living in the discharge of all becoming duties.
tgt_text.7275: Chrysippus again understands that the nature, in a manner corresponding to which we ought to live, is both the common nature, and also human nature in particular;
tgt_text.7276: but Cleanthes will not admit of any other nature than the common one alone, as that to which people ought to live in a manner corresponding;
tgt_text.7277: and re- pudiates all mention of a particular nature.
tgt_text.7278: And he asserts that virtue is a disposition of the mind always consistent and always harmonious;
tgt_text.7279: that one ought to seek it out for its own sake, without being influenced by fear or hope by any external ' influence.
tgt_text.7280: Moreover, that it is in it that happiness consists, as producing in the soul the harmony of a life always consistent with itself;
tgt_text.7281: and that if a rational animal goes the wrong way, it is because it allows itself to be misled by the deceitful appearances of exterior things, or perhaps by the instigation of those who surround it;
tgt_text.7282: for nature herself never gives us any but good inclinations.
tgt_text.7284: Now virtue is, to speak generally, a perfection in everything, as in the case of a statue ;
tgt_text.7285: whether it is invisible as good health, or speculative as prudence.
tgt_text.7286: For Hecaton says, in the first book of his treatise on Virtues, that the scientific and speculative virtues are those which have a constitution arising from speculation and study, as, for instance, prudence and justice ;
tgt_text.7287: and that those which are not speculative are those which are generally viewed in their extension as a practical result or effect of the former;
tgt_text.7288: such for instance, as health and strength.
tgt_text.7289: Accordingly, temperance is one of the specu- lative virtues, and it happens that good health usually follows it, and is marshalled as it were beside it;
tgt_text.7290: in the same way as strength follows the proper structure of an arch.
tgt_text.7291: -And the unspeculative virtues derive their name from the fact of their not proceeding from any acquiescence reflected by intelli- gence ;
tgt_text.7292: but they are derived from others, are only accessories, and are found even in worthless people, as in the case of good health, or courage.
tgt_text.7293: And Posidonius, in the first book of his treaties on Ethics, says that the great proof of the reality of virtue is that Socrates, and Diogenes, and Antisthenes, made great improvement;
tgt_text.7294: and the great proof of the reality of vice may be found in the fact of its being opposed to virtue.
tgt_text.7295: Again, Chrysippus, in the first book of his treatise on the Chief Good, and Cleanthes, and also Posidonius in his Ex- hortations, and Hecaton, all agree that virtue may be taught.
tgt_text.7296: And that they are right, and that it may be taught, is plain from men becoming good after having been bad.
tgt_text.7297: On this account Pansetius teaches that there are two virtues, one speculative and the other practical;
tgt_text.7298: but others make three kinds, the logical, the natural, and the ethical.
tgt_text.7299: Posidonius divides virtue into four divisions;
tgt_text.7300: and Cleanthes, Chrysippus, and Antipater make the divisions more numerous still;
tgt_text.7301: for Apollophanes asserts that there is but one virtue, namely, prudence.
tgt_text.7302: Among the virtues some are primitive and some are derived.
tgt_text.7303: The primitive ones are prudence, manly courage, justice, and temperance.
tgt_text.7304: And subordinate to these, as a kind of species contained in them, are magnanimity, continence, endurance, presence of mind, wisdom in council.
tgt_text.7305: And the Stoics define prudence as a knowledge of what is good, and bad, and in- different ;
tgt_text.7306: justice as a knowledge of what ought to be chosen, what ought to be avoided, and what is indifferent;
tgt_text.7307: magnanimity as a knowledge of engendering a lofty habit, superior to all such accidents as happen to all men indifferently, whether they be good or bad;
tgt_text.7308: continence they consider a disposition which never abandons right reason, or a habit which never yields to pleasure ;
tgt_text.7309: endurance they call a knowledge or habit by which we understand what we ought to endure, what we ought not, and what is indifferent;
tgt_text.7310: presence of mind they define as a habit which is prompt at finding out what is suitable on a sudden emergency;
tgt_text.7311: and wisdom in counsel they think a knowledge which leads us to judge what we are to do, and how we are to do it, in order to act becomingly.
tgt_text.7312: And analogously, of vices too there are some which are primary, and some which are subordinate ;
tgt_text.7313: as, for instance, folly, and cowardice, and injustice, and intemperance, are among the primary vices ;
tgt_text.7314: incontinence, slowness, and folly in counsel among the subordinate ones.
tgt_text.7315: And the vices are ignorance of those things of which the virtues are the knowledge.
tgt_text.7317: Good, looked at in a general way, is some advantage, with the more particular distinction, being partly what is actually useful, partly what is not contrary to utility.
tgt_text.7318: On which account virtue itself, and the good which partakes of virtue are spoken of in a threefold view of the subject.
tgt_text.7319: First, as to what kind of good it is, and from what it ensues ;
tgt_text.7320: as, for instance, in an action done according to virtue.
tgt_text.7321: Secondly, as to the agent, in the case of a good man who partakes of virtue.
tgt_text.7322: At another time, they define the good in a peculiar manner, as being what is perfect according to the nature of a rational being as rational being.
tgt_text.7323: And, secondly, they say that it is conformity to virtue, so that all actions which partake of virtue, and all good men, are themselves in some sense the good.
tgt_text.7324: And in the third place, they speak of its accessories, joy, and mirth, and things of that kind.
tgt_text.7325: In the same manner they speak of vices, which they divide into folly, cowardice, injustice, and things of that kind.
tgt_text.7326: And they consider that those things which partake of vices, and actions done according to vice, and bad men, are themselves in some sense the evil;
tgt_text.7327: and its accessories are despondency, and melancholy, and other things of that kind.
tgt_text.7329: Again, of goods, some have reference to the mind, and some are external;
tgt_text.7330: and some neither have reference to the mind, nor are external.
tgt_text.7331: The goods having reference to the mind are virtues, and actions according to the virtues.
tgt_text.7332: The external goods are the having a virtuous country, a virtuous friend, and the happiness of one's country and friend.
tgt_text.7333: And those which are not external, and which have no reference to the mind, are such as a man's being virtuous and happy to himself.
tgt_text.7334: And reciprocally, of evils, some have reference to the mind, such as the vices and actions according to them;
tgt_text.7335: some are external, such as having a foolish country, or a foolish friend, or one's country or one's friend being unhappy.
tgt_text.7336: And those evils which are not external, and which have no reference to the mind, are such as a man's being worthless and unhappy to himself.
tgt_text.7338: Again, of goods, some are final, some are efficient, and some are both final and efficient.
tgt_text.7339: For instance, a friend, and the services done by him to one, are efficient goods;
tgt_text.7340: but courage, and prudence, and liberty, and delight, and mirth, and freedom from pain, and all kinds of actions done according to virtue, are final goods.
tgt_text.7341: There are too, as I said before, some goods which are both efficient and final;
tgt_text.7342: for inasmuch as they produce perfect happiness they are efficient, and inasmuch as they complete it by being themselves parts of it, they are final.
tgt_text.7343: And in the same way, of evils, some are final, and some efficient, and some partake of both natures.
tgt_text.7344: For instance, an enemy and the injuries done to one by him, are efficient evils ;
tgt_text.7345: fear, meanness of condition, slavery, want of delight, depression of spirits, excessive grief, and all actions done according to vice, are final evils ;
tgt_text.7346: and some partake of both characters, since, inasmuch as they produce perfect unhappiness, they are efficient;
tgt_text.7347: and inasmuch as they complete it in such a way as to become parts of it, they are final.
tgt_text.7349: Again, of the goods which have reference to the mind, some are habits, some are dispositions, and some are neither habits nor dispositions.
tgt_text.7350: Dispositions are virtues, habits are practices, and those which are neither habits nor dispositions are energies.
tgt_text.7351: And, speaking generally, the following may be called mixed goods:
tgt_text.7352: happiness in one's children, and a happy old age.
tgt_text.7353: But knowledge is a pure good.
tgt_text.7354: And some goods are continually present, such as virtue ;
tgt_text.7355: and some are not always present, as joy, or taking a walk.
tgt_text.7357: But every good is expedient, and necessary, and profitable, and useful, and serviceable, and beautiful, and advantageous, and eligible, and just.
tgt_text.7358: Expedient, inasmuch as it brings us things, which by their happening to us do us good ;
tgt_text.7359: necessary, inasmuch as it assists us in what we have need to be assisted ;
tgt_text.7360: profitable, inasmuch as it repays all the care that is expended on it, and makes a return with interest to our great advantage;
tgt_text.7361: useful, inasmuch as it supplies us with what is of utility ;
tgt_text.7362: serviceable, because it does us service which is much praised;
tgt_text.7363: beautiful, because it is in accurate proportion to the need we have of it, and to the service it does.
tgt_text.7364: Advantageous, inasmuch as it is of such a character as to confer advantage on us ;
tgt_text.7365: eligible, because it is such that we may rationally choose it;
tgt_text.7366: and just, because it is in accordance with law, and is an efficient cause of union.
tgt_text.7367: And they call the honourable the perfect good, because it has naturally all the numbers which are required by nature, and because it discloses a perfect harmony.
tgt_text.7368: Now, the species of this perfect good are four in number:
tgt_text.7369: justice, manly courage, temperance, and knowledge;
tgt_text.7370: for in these goods all beautiful actions have their accomplishment.
tgt_text.7371: And analogously, there are also four species of the disgraceful:
tgt_text.7372: injustice, and cowardice, and intemperance, and folly.
tgt_text.7373: And the honourable is predicated in one sense, as making those who are possessed of it worthy of all praise;
tgt_text.7374: and in a second sense, it is used of what is well adapted by nature for its proper work ;
tgt_text.7375: and in another sense, when it expresses that which adorns a man, as when we say that the wise man alone is good and honourable.
tgt_text.7376: The Stoics also say, that the beautiful is the only good, as Hecaton says, in the third book of his treatise on Goods, and Chrysippus asserts the same principle in his essays on the Beautiful.
tgt_text.7377: And they say that this is virtue, and that which partakes of virtue;
tgt_text.7378: and this assertion is equal to the other, that everything good is beautiful, and that the good is an equivalent term to the beautiful, inasmuch as the one thing is exactly equal to the other.
tgt_text.7379: For since it is good, it is beautiful;
tgt_text.7380: and it is beautiful, therefore, it is good.
tgt_text.7382: But it seems that all goods are equal, and that every good is to be desired in the highest degree, and that it admits of no relaxation, and of no extension.
tgt_text.7383: Moreover, they divide all existing things into good, bad, and indifferent.
tgt_text.7384: The good are the virtues, prudence, justice, manly courage, temperance, and the rest of the like qualities.
tgt_text.7385: The bad are the contraries, folly, injustice, and the like.
tgt_text.7386: Those are indifferent which are neither beneficial nor injurious, such as life, health, pleasure, beauty, strength, riches, a good reputation, nobility of birth ;
tgt_text.7387: and their contraries, death, disease, labour, disgrace, weakness, poverty, a bad reputation, baseness of birth, and the like;
tgt_text.7388: as Hecaton lays it down in the seventh book of his treatise on the Chief Good ;
tgt_text.7389: and he is followed by Apollodorus, in his Ethics, and by Chrysippus.
tgt_text.7390: For they affirm that those things are not good but indifferent, though perhaps a little more near to one species than to the other.
tgt_text.7391: For, as it is the property of the hot to warm and not to chill one, so it is the property of the good to benefit and not to injure one.
tgt_text.7392: Now, wealth and good health cannot be said to benefit any more than to injure any one :
tgt_text.7393: therefore, neither wealth nor good health are, goods.
tgt_text.7394: Again, they say that that thing is not good which it is possible to use both well and ill.
tgt_text.7395: But it is possible to make either a good or a bad use of wealth, or of health;
tgt_text.7396: therefore, wealth and good health are not goods.
tgt_text.7397: Posidonius, however, affirms that these things do come under the head of goods.
tgt_text.7398: But Hecaton, in the nineteenth book of his treatise on Goods, and Chrysippus, in his treatises on Pleasure, both deny that pleasure is a good.
tgt_text.7399: For they say that there are disgraceful pleasures, and that nothing disgrace- ful is good.
tgt_text.7400: And that to benefit a person is to move him or to keep him according to virtue, but to injure him is to move him or to keep him according to vice.
tgt_text.7401: They also assert, that things indifferent are so spoken of in a twofold manner;
tgt_text.7402: firstly, those things are called so, which have no influence in producing either happiness or unhappi- ness ;
tgt_text.7403: such for instance, as riches, glory, health, strength, and the like ;
tgt_text.7404: for it is possible for a man to be happy without any of these things;
tgt_text.7405: and also, it is upon the character of the use that is made of them, that happiness or unhappiness depends.
tgt_text.7406: In another sense, those things are called indifferent, which do not exite any inclination or aversion, as for instance, the fact of a man's having an odd or an even number of hairs on his head, or his putting out or drawing back his finger;
tgt_text.7407: for it is not in this sense that the things previously mentioned are called indifferent, for they do excite inclination or aver- sion.
tgt_text.7408: On which account some of them are chosen, though there is equal reason for preferring or shunning all the others.
tgt_text.7410: Again, of things indifferent, they call some pre- ferred (πϩοηγμένα), and others rejected (ἀποπϩοηγμένα).
tgt_text.7411: Those are preferred, which have some proper value (ἀξιάν), and those are rejected, which have no value at all (ἀπαξιάν ἔχοντα).
tgt_text.7412: And by the term proper value, they mean that quality of things, which causes them to concur in producing a well- regulated life ;
tgt_text.7413: and in this sense, every good has a proper value.
tgt_text.7414: Again, they say that a thing has value, when in some point of view, it has a sort of intermediate power of aiding us to live conformably to nature;
tgt_text.7415: and under this class, we may range riches or good health, if they give any assistance to natural life.
tgt_text.7416: Again, value is predicated of the price which one gives for the attainment of an object, which some one, who has experience of)the object sought, fixes as its fair price ;
tgt_text.7417: as if we were to say, for instance, that as some wheat was to be exchanged for barley, with a mule thrown in to make up the difference.
tgt_text.7418: Those goods then are preferred, which have a value, as in the case of the mental goods, ability, skill, im- provement, and the like;
tgt_text.7419: and in the case of the corporeal goods, life, health, strength, a good constitution, soundness, beauty;
tgt_text.7420: and in the case of external goods, riches, glory, nobility of birth, and the like.
tgt_text.7421: Rejected things are, in the case of qualities of the mind, stupidity, unskilfulness, and the like ;
tgt_text.7422: in the case of circum- stances affecting the body, death, disease, weakness, a bad constitution, mutilation, disgrace, and the like ;
tgt_text.7423: in the case of external circumstances, poverty, want of reputation, ignoble birth, and the like.
tgt_text.7424: But those qualities and circumstances which are indifferent, are neither preferred nor rejected.
tgt_text.7425: Again, of things preferred, some are preferred for their own sakes, some for the sake of other things, and some partly for their own sakes and partly for that of other things.
tgt_text.7426: Those which are preferred for their own sakes, are ability, improve- ment, and the like ;
tgt_text.7427: those which are preferred for the sake of other things, are wealth, nobility of birth, and the like ;
tgt_text.7428: those which are preferred partly for their own sake, and partly for that of something else, are strength, vigour of the senses, universal soundness, and the like;
tgt_text.7429: for they are preferred, for their own sakes, inasmuch as they are in accordance with nature ;
tgt_text.7430: and for the sake of something else, inasmuch as they are productive of no small number of advantages ;
tgt_text.7431: and the same is the case in the inverse ratio, with those things which are rejected.
tgt_text.7433: Again, they say that that is duty, which is preferred, and which contains in itself reasonable arguments why we should prefer it;
tgt_text.7434: as for instance, its corresponding to the nature of life itself;
tgt_text.7435: and this argument extends to plants and animals, for even their nature is subject to the obligation of certain duties.
tgt_text.7436: And duty (τὸ ϰαθη̃ϰον) had this name given to it by Zeno, in the first instance, its appellation being derived from its coming to, or according to some people, ἀπὸ του̃ ϰατά τινας ἥϰειν;
tgt_text.7437: and its effect is something kindred to the prepa- rations made by nature.
tgt_text.7438: Now of the things done according to inclination, some are duties, and some are contrary to duty;
tgt_text.7439: and some are neither duties nor contrary to duty.
tgt_text.7440: Those are duties, which reason selects to do, as for instance, to honour one's parents, one's brothers, one's country, to gratify one's friends.
tgt_text.7441: Those actions are contrary to duty, which reason does not choose;
tgt_text.7442: as for instance, to neglect one's parents, to be indifferent to one's brothers, to shirk assisting one's friends, to be careless about the welfare of one's country, and so on.
tgt_text.7443: Those are neither duties, nor contrary to duty, which reason neither selects to do, nor, on the other hand, repudiates, such actions, for instance, as to pick up straw, to hold a pen, or a comb, or things of that sort.
tgt_text.7444: Again, there are some duties which do not depend on cir- cumstances, and some which do.
tgt_text.7445: These do not depend on circumstances, to take care of one's health, and of the sound state of one's senses, and the like.
tgt_text.7446: Those which do depend on circumstances, are the mutilation of one's members, the sacrificing of one's property, and so on.
tgt_text.7447: And the case of those actions which are contrary to duty, is similar.
tgt_text.7448: Again, of duties, some are always such, and some are not always.
tgt_text.7449: What is always a duty, is to live in accordance with virtue;
tgt_text.7450: but to ask questions, to give answers, to walk, and the like, are not always duties.
tgt_text.7451: And the same statement holds good with respect to acts contrary to duty.
tgt_text.7452: There is also a class of intermediate duties, such as the duty of boys obeying their masters.
tgt_text.7454: The Stoics also say that the mind is divisible into eight parts;
tgt_text.7455: for that the five organs of sensation, and the vocal power, and the intellectual power, which is the mind itself, and the generative power, are all parts of the mind.
tgt_text.7456: But by error, there is produced a perversion which operates on the intellect, from which many perturbations arise, and many causes of inconstancy.
tgt_text.7457: And all perturbation is itself, accord- ing to Zeno, a movement of the mind, or superfluous inclina- tion, which is irrational, and contrary to nature.
tgt_text.7458: Moreover, of the |superior class of perturbations, as Hecaton says, in the second book of his treatise on the Passions, and as Zeno also says in his work on the Passions, there are four kinds, grief, fear, desire, and pleasure.
tgt_text.7459: And they consider that these perturbations are judgments, as Chrysippus contends in his work on the Passions ;
tgt_text.7460: for covetousness is an opinion that money is a beautiful object, and in like manner drunkenness and intemperance, and other things of the sort, are judg- ments.
tgt_text.7461: And grief they define to be an irrational contraction of the mind, and it is divided into the following species, pity, envy, emulation, jealousy, pain, perturbation, sorrow, anguish, confusion.
tgt_text.7462: Pity is a grief over some one, on the ground of his being in undeserved distress.
tgt_text.7463: Envy is a grief, at the good fortune of another.
tgt_text.7464: Emulation is a grief at that belonging to some one else, which one desires one's self.
tgt_text.7465: Jealousy is a grief at another also having what one has one's self.
tgt_text.7466: Pain is a grief which weighs one down.
tgt_text.7467: Perturbation is grief which narrows one, and causes one to feel in a strait.
tgt_text.7468: Sorrow is a grief arising from deliberate thought, which endures for some time, and gradually increases.
tgt_text.7469: Anguish is a grief with acute pain.
tgt_text.7470: Confusion is an irrational grief, which frets one, and prevents one from clearly discerning present circumstances.
tgt_text.7471: But fear is the expectation of evil ;
tgt_text.7472: and the following feelings are all classed under the head of fear:
tgt_text.7473: apprehension, hesita- tion, shame, perplexity, trepidation, and anxiety.
tgt_text.7474: Apprehen- sion is a fear which produces alarm.
tgt_text.7475: Shame is a fear of dis- credit.
tgt_text.7476: Hesitation is a fear of coming activity.
tgt_text.7477: Perplexity is a fear, from the imagination of some unusual thing.
tgt_text.7478: Tre- pidation is a fear accompanied with an oppression of the voice.
tgt_text.7479: Anxiety is a fear of some uncertain event.
tgt_text.7480: Again, desire is an irrational appetite ;
tgt_text.7481: to which head, the following feelings are referrible:
tgt_text.7482: want, hatred, contentiousness, anger, love, enmity, rage.
tgt_text.7483: Want is a desire arising from our not having something or other, and is, as it were, separated from the thing, but is still stretching, and attracted towards it in vain.
tgt_text.7484: And hatred is a desire that it should be ill with some one, accompanied with a certain continual increase and extension.
tgt_text.7485: Contentiousness is a certain desire accompanied with deliberate choice.
tgt_text.7486: Anger is a desire of revenge, on a person who appears to have injured one in an unbecoming way.
tgt_text.7487: Love is a desire not conversant about a virtuous object, for it is an attempt to conciliate affection, because of some beauty which is seen.
tgt_text.7488: Enmity is a certain anger of long duration, and full of hatred, and it is a watchful passion, as is shown in the following lines :
tgt_text.7490: For though we deem the short-liv'd fury past, 'Tis sure the mighty will revenge at last.
tgt_text.7491: *But rage is anger at its commencement.
tgt_text.7492: Again, pleasure is an irrational elation of the mind over something which appears to be desirable;
tgt_text.7493: and its different species are enjoyment, rejoicing at evil, delight, and extrava- gant joy.
tgt_text.7494: Enjoyment now, is a pleasure which charms the mind through the ears.
tgt_text.7495: Rejoicing at evil (ἐπιχαιρεϰαϰιά), is a pleasure which arises at the misfortunes of others.
tgt_text.7496: Delight (τέϩψις,) that is to say turning (τϩέψις), is a certain turning of the soul (προτροπή τις ψυχη̃ς), to softness.
tgt_text.7497: Extravagant joy is the dissolution of virtue.
tgt_text.7498: And as there are said to be some sicknesses (ἀῤῥωστηματα,) in the body, as, for instance, gout and arthritic disorders;
tgt_text.7499: so too are those diseases of the soul, such as a fondness for glory, or for pleasure, and other feelings of that sort.
tgt_text.7500: For an ἀῤῥώστημα is a disease accompanied with weakness ;
tgt_text.7501: and a disease is an opinion of something which appears ex- ceedingly desirable.
tgt_text.7502: And, as in the case of the body, there are illnesses to which people are especially liable, such as colds or diarrhoea;
tgt_text.7503: so also are there propensities which the mind is under the influence of, such as enviousness, pitifulness, quarrelsomeness, and so on.
tgt_text.7504: There are also three good dispositions of the mind;
tgt_text.7506: And joy they say is the opposite of pleasure, since it is a rational elation of the mind;
tgt_text.7507: so caution is the opposite of fear, being a rational avoidance of anything, for the wise man will never be afraid, but he will act with caution;
tgt_text.7508: and will, they define as the opposite of desire, since it is a rational wish.
tgt_text.7509: As therefore some things fall under the class of the first perturbations, in the same manner do some things fall under the class of the first good dispositions.
tgt_text.7510: And accordingly, under the head of will, are classed goodwill, placidity, salutation, affection;
tgt_text.7511: and under the head of caution are ranged reverence and modesty;
tgt_text.7512: under the head of joy, we speak of delight, mirth, and good spirits.
tgt_text.7514: They say also, that the wise man is free from per- turbations, because he has no strong propensities.
tgt_text.7515: But that this freedom from propensities also exists in the bad man, being, however, then quite another thing, inasmuch as it pro- ceeds in him only from the hardness and unimpressibility of his nature.
tgt_text.7516: They also pronounce the wise man free from vanity, since he regards with equal eye what is glorious and what is inglorious.
tgt_text.7517: At the same time, they admit that there is another character devoid of vanity, who, however, is only reckoned one of the rash men, being in fact the bad man.
tgt_text.7518: They also say that all the virtuous men are austere, because they do never, speak with reference to pleasure, nor do they listen to what is said by others with reference to pleasure.
tgt_text.7519: At the same time, they call another man austere too, using the term in nearly the same sense as they do when they speak of austere wine, which is used in compounding medicines, but not for drinking.
tgt_text.7520: They also pronounce the wise to be honest-hearted men, anxiously attending to those matters which may make them better, by means of some principle which conceals what is bad, and brings to light what is good.
tgt_text.7521: Nor is there any hypocrisy about them;
tgt_text.7522: for they cut off all pretence in their voice and appearance.
tgt_text.7523: They also keep aloof from business;
tgt_text.7524: for they guard carefully against doing any thing contrary to their duty.
tgt_text.7525: They drink wine, but they do not get drunk ;
tgt_text.7526: and they never yield to frenzy.
tgt_text.7527: Occasionally, extraordinary imaginations may obtain a momentary power over them, owing to some melancholy or trifling, arising not according to .
tgt_text.7528: the principle of what is desirable, but contrary to nature.
tgt_text.7529: Nor, again, will the wise man feel grief;
tgt_text.7530: because grief is an irrational contraction of the soul, as Apollodorus defines it in his Ethics.
tgt_text.7531: They are also, as they say, godlike ;
tgt_text.7532: for they have something in them which is as it were a God.
tgt_text.7533: But the bad man is an atheist.
tgt_text.7534: Now there are two kinds of atheists;
tgt_text.7535: one who speaks in a spirit of hostility to, and the other, who utterly disregards, the divine nature;
tgt_text.7536: but they admit that all bad men are not atheists in this last sense.
tgt_text.7537: The good, on the contrary, are pious;
