tgt_text.8569: When the great Samian sage his noble problem found, A hundred oxen dyed with their life-blood the ground.
tgt_text.8571: He is also said to have been the first man who trained athletes on meat;
tgt_text.8572: and Eurymenes was the first man, according to the statement of Phavorinus, in the third book of his Commentaries, who ever did submit to this diet, as before that time men used to train themselves on dry figs and moist cheese, and wheaten bread;
tgt_text.8573: as the same Phavorinus informs us in the eighth book of his Universal History.
tgt_text.8574: But some authors state, that a trainer of the name of Pythagoras certainly did train his athletes on this system, but that it was not our philosopher;
tgt_text.8575: for that he even forbade men to kill animals at all, much less would have allowed his disciples to eat then, as having a right to live in common with mankind.
tgt_text.8577: but in reality, he prohibited the eating of animals, because he wished to train and accustom men to simplicity of life, so that all their food should be easily procurable, as it would be, if they ate only such things as required no fire to dress them, and if they drank plain water;
tgt_text.8578: for from this diet they would derive health of body and acuteness of intellect.
tgt_text.8579: The only altar at which he worshipped was that of Apollo the Father, at Delos, which is at the back of the altar of Ceratinus, because wheat, and barley, and cheese-cakes are the only offerings laid upon it, being not dressed by fire;
tgt_text.8580: and no victim is ever slain there, as Aristotle tells us in his Constitution of the Delians.
tgt_text.8581: They say, too, that he was the first person who asserted that the soul went a necessary circle, being changed about and confined at different times in differ- ent bodies.
tgt_text.8583: He was also the first person who introduced mea- sures and weights among the Greeks ;
tgt_text.8584: as Aristoxenus the musician informs us.
tgt_text.8586: Parmenides, too, assures us, that he was the first person who asserted the identity of Hesperus and Lucifer.XV.
tgt_text.8587: And he was so greatly admired, that they used to say that his friends looked on all his sayings as the oracles of God.*
tgt_text.8588: And he himself says in his writings, that he had come among men after having spent two hundred and seven years in the shades below.
tgt_text.8589: Therefore the Lucanians and the Peucetians, and the Messapians, and the Romans, flocked around him, coming with eagerness to hear his discourses ;
tgt_text.8590: but until the time of Philolaus, there were no doctrines of Pythagoras ever divulged;
tgt_text.8591: and he was the first person who published the three celebrated books which Plato wrote to have purchased for him for a hundred minæ.
tgt_text.8592: Nor were the number of his scholars who used to come to him by night fewer than six hundred.
tgt_text.8593: And if any of them had ever been permitted to see him, they wrote of it to their friends, as if they had gained some great advantage.
tgt_text.8594: The people of Metapontum used to call his house the temple of Ceres;
tgt_text.8595: and the street leading to it they called the street of the Muses, as we are told by Phavorinus in his Universal History.
tgt_text.8596: And the rest of the Pythagoreans used to say, according to the account given by Aristoxenus, in the tenth book of his Laws on Education, that his precepts ought not to be divulged to all the -world;
tgt_text.8597: and Xenophilus, the Pythagorean, when he was asked what was the best way for a man to educate his son, said, " That he must first of all take care that he was born in a city which enjoyed good laws.
tgt_text.8598: "Pythagoras, too, formed many excellent men in Italy, by his precepts, and among them Zaleucus,* and Charondas,f the lawgivers.
tgt_text.8600: For he was very eminent for his power of attracting friendships;
tgt_text.8601: and among other things, if ever he heard that any one had any community of symbols with him, he at once made him a companion and a friend.
tgt_text.8603: Now, what he called his symbols were such as these.
tgt_text.8604: " Do not stir the fire with a sword." " Do not sit down on a bushel." " Do not devour your heart." " Do not aid men in discarding a burden, but in increasing one." " Always have your bed packed up." " Do not bear the image of a God on a ring." " Efface the traces of a pot in the ashes." “ Do not wipe a seat with a lamp." “ Do not make water in the sun- shine." " Do not walk in the main street."
tgt_text.8605: " Do not offer your right hand lightly.” " Do not cherish swallows under your roof." " Do not cherish birds with crooked talons." " Do not defile ;
tgt_text.8606: and do not stand upon the parings of your nails, or the cuttings of your hair."
tgt_text.8608: "When you are travelling abroad, look not back at your own borders."
tgt_text.8609: Now the precept not to stir fire with a sword meant, not to provoke the anger or swelling pride of powerful men ;
tgt_text.8610: not to violate the beam of the balance meant, not to transgress fair- ness and justice;
tgt_text.8611: not to sit on a bushel is to have an equal care for the present and for the future, for by the bushel is meant one's daily food.
tgt_text.8612: By not devouring one's heart, he intended to show that we ought not to waste away our souls with grief and sorrow.
tgt_text.8613: In the precept that a man when travelling abroad should not turn his eyes back, he recom- mended those who were departing from life not to be desirous to live, and not to be too much attracted by the pleasures here on earth.
tgt_text.8614: And the other symbols may be explained in a similar manner, that we may not be too prolix here.
tgt_text.8616: And above all things, he used to prohibit the eating of the erythinus, and the melanurus ;
tgt_text.8617: and also, he enjoined his disciples to abstain from the hearts of animals, and from beans.
tgt_text.8618: And Aristotle informs us, that he sometimes used also to add to these prohibitions paunches and mullet.
tgt_text.8619: And some authors assert that he himself used to be contented with honey and honeycomb, and bread, and that he never drank wine in the day time.
tgt_text.8620: And his desert was usually vegetables, either boiled or raw ;
tgt_text.8621: and he very rarely ate fish.
tgt_text.8622: His dress was white, very clean, and his bed-clothes were also white, and woollen, for linen had not yet been introduced into that country.
tgt_text.8623: He was never known to have eaten too much, or to have drunk too much, or to indulge in the pleasures of love.
tgt_text.8624: He abstained wholly from laughter, and from all such indul- gences as jests and idle stories.
tgt_text.8625: And when he was angry, he never chastised any one, whether slave or freeman.
tgt_text.8626: He used to call admonishing, feeding storks.
tgt_text.8627: He used to practise divination, as far 'as auguries and auspices go, but not by means of burnt offerings, except only the burning of frankincense.
tgt_text.8628: And all the sacrifices which he offered consisted of inanimate things.
tgt_text.8629: But some, however, assert that he did sacrifice animals, limiting himself to cocks, and sucking kids, which are called ἁπάλιοι, but that he very rarely offered lambs.
tgt_text.8630: Aristoxenus, however, affirms that he permitted the eating of all other animals, and only abstained from oxen used in agriculture, and from rams.
tgt_text.8632: The same author tells us, as I have already mentioned, that he received his doctrines from Themistoclea, at -Delphi.
tgt_text.8633: And Hieronymus says, that when he descended to the shades below, he saw the soul of Hesiod bound to a brazen pillar, and gnashing its teeth;
tgt_text.8634: and that of Homer suspended from a tree, and snakes around it, as a punishment for the things that they bad said of the Gods.
tgt_text.8635: And that those people also were punished who refrained from commerce with their wives ;
tgt_text.8636: and that on account of this he was greatly honoured by the people of Crotona.
tgt_text.8637: But Aristippus, of Cyrene, in his Account of Natural Philo- sophers, says that Pythagoras derived his name from the fact of his speaking (ἀγοϱεύειν) truth no less than the God at Delphi (του̃ πυθίου).
tgt_text.8638: It is said that he used to admonish his disciples to repeat these lines to themselves whenever they returned home to their houses :
tgt_text.8642: What that I should have done have I omitted ?
tgt_text.8643: And that he used to forbid them to offer victims to the Gods, ordering them to worship only at those altars which were un- stained with blood.
tgt_text.8644: He forbade them also to swear by the Gods;
tgt_text.8645: saying, “ That every man ought so to exercise himself, as to be worthy of belief without an oath."
tgt_text.8646: He also taught men that it behoved them to honour their elders, thinking that which was precedent in point of time more honourable;
tgt_text.8647: just as in the world, the rising of the sun was more so than the setting ;
tgt_text.8648: in life, the beginning more so than the end;
tgt_text.8649: and in animals, production more so than destruction.
tgt_text.8650: Another of his rules was that men should honour the Gods above the dæmones, heroes above men ;
tgt_text.8651: and of all men parents were entitled to the highest degree of reverence.
tgt_text.8652: Another, that people should associate with one another in such a way as not to make their friends enemies, but to render their enemies friends.
tgt_text.8653: Another was that they should think nothing exclu- sively their own.
tgt_text.8654: Another was to assist the law, and to make war upon lawlessness.
tgt_text.8655: Not to destroy or injure a cultivated tree, nor any animal either which does not injure men.
tgt_text.8656: That modesty and decorum consisted in never yielding to laughter, and yet not looking stern.
tgt_text.8657: He taught that men should avoid too much flesh, that they should in travelling let rest and exertion alternate;
tgt_text.8659: that they should never say or do anything in anger ;
tgt_text.8660: that they should not pay respect to every kind of divination;
tgt_text.8661: that they should use songs set to the lyre ;
tgt_text.8662: and by hymns to the Gods and to eminent men, display a reasonable gratitude to them.
tgt_text.8664: He also forbade his disciples to eat beans, because, as they were flatulent, they greatly partook of animal properties [he also said that men kept their stomachs in better order by avoiding them];
tgt_text.8665: and that such abstinence made the visions which appear in one's sleep gentle and free from agitation.
tgt_text.8666: Alexander also says, in his Successions of Philosophers, that he found the following dogmas also set down in the Commen- taries of Pythagoras:
tgt_text.8667: —That the monad was the beginning of everything.
tgt_text.8668: From the monad proceeds an indefinite duad, which is subordinate to the monad as to its cause.
tgt_text.8669: That from the monad and the indefinite duad proceed numbers.
tgt_text.8671: And from these last, lines of which plane figures consist.
tgt_text.8672: And from plane figures are derived solid bodies.
tgt_text.8673: And from solid bodies sensible bodies, of which last there are four elements ;
tgt_text.8675: And that the world, which is endued with life, and intellect, and which is of a spherical figure, having the earth, which is also spherical, and inhabited all over in its centre, results from a combination of these elements, and derives its motion from them ;
tgt_text.8676: and also that there are antipodes,* and that what is below, as respects us, is above in respect of them.
tgt_text.8677: He also taught that light and darkness, and cold and heat, and dryness and moisture, were equally divided in the world;
tgt_text.8678: and that, while heat was predominant it was summer ;
tgt_text.8679: while cold had the mastery it was winter;
tgt_text.8680: when dryness prevailed it was spring;
tgt_text.8682: And while all these qualities were on a level, then was the loveliest season of the year;
tgt_text.8683: of which the flourishing spring was the wholesome period, and the season of autumn the most pernicious one.
tgt_text.8684: Of the day, he said that the flourishing period was the morning, and the fading one the evening;
tgt_text.8685: on which account that also was the least healthy time.
tgt_text.8686: Another of his theories was, that the air around the earth was immoveable, and pregnant with disease, and that every- thing in it was mortal;
tgt_text.8687: but that the upper air was in perpetual motion, and pure and salubrious ;
tgt_text.8688: and that everything in that was immortal, and on that account divine.
tgt_text.8689: And that the sun, and the moon, and the stars, were all Gods;
tgt_text.8690: for in them the warm principle predominates which is the cause of life.
tgt_text.8691: And that the moon derives its light from the sun.
tgt_text.8692: And that there is a relationship between men and the Gods, because men partake of the divine principle;
tgt_text.8693: on which account also, God exercises his providence for our advantage.
tgt_text.8694: Also, that fate is the cause of the arrangement of the world both generally and particularly.
tgt_text.8695: Moreover, that a ray from the sun penetrated both the cold æther and the dense sether;
tgt_text.8696: and they call the air (ἀὴϱ), the cold æther (ψυχϱὸν αἰθέϱα), and the sea and moisture they call the dense æther (παχὺν αἰθϱα).
tgt_text.8697: And this ray descends into the depths, and in this way vivifies every- thing.
tgt_text.8698: And everything which partakes of the principle of heat lives, on which account also plants are animated beings ;
tgt_text.8699: but that all living things have not necessarily souls.
tgt_text.8700: And that the soul is a something torn off from the æther, both warm and cold, from its partaking of the cold æther.
tgt_text.8701: And that the soul is something different from life.
tgt_text.8702: Also, that it is immortal, because that from which it has been detached is immortal.
tgt_text.8703: Also, that animals are born from one another by seeds, and that it is impossible for there to be any spontaneous production by the earth.
tgt_text.8704: And that seed is a drop from the brain which contains in itself a warm vapour;
tgt_text.8705: and that when this is applied to the womb, it transmits virtue, and moisture, and blood from the brain, from which flesh, and sinews, and bones, and hair, and the whole body are produced.
tgt_text.8706: And from the vapour is produced the soul, and also sensation.
tgt_text.8707: And that the infant first becomes a solid body at the end of forty days;
tgt_text.8708: but, according to the principles of harmony, it is not perfect till seven, or perhaps nine, or at most ten months, and then it is brought forth.
tgt_text.8709: And that it contains in itself all the principles of life, which are all connected together, and by their union and combination form a harmonious whole, each of them developing itself at the appointed time.
tgt_text.8710: The senses in general, and especially the sight, are a vapour of excessive warmth, and on this account a man is said to see through air, and through water.
tgt_text.8711: For the hot principle is opposed by the cold one ;
tgt_text.8712: since, if the vapour in the eyes were cold, it would have the same temperature as the air, and so would be dissipated.
tgt_text.8713: As it is, in some passages he calls the eyes the gates of the sun.
tgt_text.8714: And he speaks in a similar manner of hearing, and of the other senses.
tgt_text.8715: He also says that the soul of man is divided into three parts ;
tgt_text.8716: into intuition (νου̃ς), and reason (ϕϱὴν), and mind (θυμὸς), and that the first and last divisions are found also in other animals, but that the middle one, reason, is only found in man.
tgt_text.8717: And that the chief abode of the soul is in those parts of the body which are between the heart and the brain.
tgt_text.8718: And, that that portion of it which is in the heart is the mind (θυμός);
tgt_text.8719: but that deliberation (νοὺς), and reason reside in the brain.
tgt_text.8720: *Moreover, that the senses are drops from them;
tgt_text.8721: and that the reasoning sense is immortal, but the others are mortal.
tgt_text.8722: And that the soul is nourished by the blood ;
tgt_text.8723: and that reasons are the winds of the soul.
tgt_text.8724: That it is invisible, and so are its reasons, since the æther itself is invisible.
tgt_text.8725: That the links of the soul are the veins, and the arteries, and the nerves.
tgt_text.8726: But that when it is vigorous, and is by itself in a quiescent state, then its links are words and actions.
tgt_text.8727: That when it is cast forth upon the earth it wanders about, resembling the body.
tgt_text.8728: Moreover, that Mercury is the steward of the souls, and that on this account he has the name of Conductor, and Commercial, and Infernal, since it is he who conducts the souls from their bodies, and from earth, and sea;
tgt_text.8729: and that he conducts the pure souls to the highest region, and that he does not allow the impure ones to approach them, nor to come near one another;
tgt_text.8730: but commits them to be bound in indissoluble fetters by the Furies.
tgt_text.8731: The Pythagoreans also assert, that the whole air is full of souls, and that these are those which are accounted dæmones, and heroes.
tgt_text.8732: Also, that it is by them that dreams are sent among men, and also the tokens of disease and health ;
tgt_text.8733: these last too, being sent not only to men, but to sheep also, and other cattle.
tgt_text.8734: Also, that it is they who are concerned with purifications, and expiations, and all kinds of divination, and oracular predictions, and things of that kind.
tgt_text.8735: They also say, that the most important privilege in man is, the being able to persuade his soul to either good or bad.
tgt_text.8736: And that men are happy when they have a good soul;
tgt_text.8737: yet, that they are never quiet, and that they never retain the same mind long.
tgt_text.8738: Also, that an oath is justice ;
tgt_text.8739: and that on that account, Jupiter is called Jupiter of Oaths (“Οϱϰιος).
tgt_text.8740: Also, that virtue is harmony, and health, and universal good, and God ;
tgt_text.8741: on which account everything owes its existence and consistency to har- mony.
tgt_text.8742: Also, that friendship is a harmonious equality.
tgt_text.8743: Again, they teach that one ought not to pay equal honours to Gods and to heroes ;
tgt_text.8744: but that one ought to honour the Gods at all times, extolling them with praises, clothed in white garments, and keeping one's body chaste ;
tgt_text.8745: but that one ought not to pay such honour to the heroes till after midday.
tgt_text.8746: Also, that a state of purity is brought about by purifications, and washings, and sprinklings, and by a man's purifying himself from all funerals, or concubinage, or pollution of every kind, and by abstaining from all flesh that has either been killed or died of itself, and from mullets, and from melanuri, and from eggs, and from such animals as lay eggs, and from beans, and from other things which are prohibited by those who have the charge of the mysteries in the temples.
tgt_text.8747: And Aristotle says, in his treatise on Beans, that Pythagoras enjoined his disciples to abstain from beans, either because they resemble some part of the human body, or because they are like the gates of hell (for they are the only plants without parts);
tgt_text.8748: or because they dry up other plants, or because they are representatives of universal nature, or because they are used in elections in oligarchical governments.
tgt_text.8749: He also forbade his disciples to pick up what fell from the table, for the sake of accustoming them not to eat immoderately, or else because such things belong to the dead.
tgt_text.8750: But Aristophanes says, that what falls belongs to the heroes;
tgt_text.8753: Never taste the things which fall From the table on the floor.
tgt_text.8754: He also forbade his disciples to eat white poultry, because a cock of that colour was sacred to Month, and was also a suppliant.
tgt_text.8755: He was also accounted a good animal;
tgt_text.8756: * and he was sacred to the God Month, for he indicates the time.
tgt_text.8757: The Pythagoreans were also forbidden to eat of all fish that were sacred ;
tgt_text.8758: on the ground that the same animals ought not to be served up before both Gods and men, just as the same things do not belong to freemen and to slaves.
tgt_text.8759: Now, white is an indication of a good nature, and black of a bad one.
tgt_text.8760: Another of the precepts of Pythagoras was, that men ought not to break bread ;
tgt_text.8761: because in ancient times friends used to assemble around one loaf, as they even now do among the barbarians.
tgt_text.8762: Nor would he allow men to divide bread which unites them.
tgt_text.8763: Some think that he laid down this rule in refer- ence to the judgment which takes place in hell;
tgt_text.8764: some because this practice engenders timidity in war.
tgt_text.8765: According to others, what is alluded to is the Union, which presides over the government of the universe.
tgt_text.8766: Another of his doctrines was, that of all solid figures the sphere was the most beautiful;
tgt_text.8767: and of all plane figures, the circle.
tgt_text.8768: That old age and all diminution were similar, and also increase and youth were identical.
tgt_text.8769: That health was the permanence of form, and disease the destruction of it.
tgt_text.8770: Of salt his opinion was, that it ought to be set before people as a reminder of justice ;
tgt_text.8771: for salt preserves everything which it touches, and it is composed of the purest particles of water and sea.
tgt_text.8772: These are the doctrines which Alexander asserts that he discovered in the Pythagorean treatises ;
tgt_text.8773: and Aristotle gives a similar account of them.
tgt_text.8774: XV. Timon, in his Silli, has not left unnoticed the dignified appearance of Pythagoras, when he attacks him on other points.
tgt_text.8777: Pythagoras, who often teaches Precepts of magic, and with speeches
tgt_text.8778: Of long high-sounding diction draws, From gaping crowds, a vain applause.
tgt_text.8779: And respecting his having been different people at different times, Xenophanes adds his evidence in an elegiac poem which commences thus :
tgt_text.8781: Now I will on another subject touch, And lead the way.
tgt_text.8782: And the passage in which he mentions Pythagoras is as follows:
tgt_text.8784: They say that once, as passing by he saw A dog severely beaten, he did pity him, And spoke as follows to the man who beat him :
tgt_text.8786: Stop now, and beat him not;
tgt_text.8787: since in his body, Abides the soul of a dear friend of mine, Whose voice I recognized as he was crying.
tgt_text.8789: Cratinus also ridiculed him in his Pythagorean Woman ;
tgt_text.8790: but in his Tarentines, he speaks thus :
tgt_text.8792: They are accustomed, if by chance they see A private individual abroad, To try what powers of argument he has, How he can speak and reason :
tgt_text.8793: and they bother him With strange antithesis and forced conclusions, Errors, comparisons, and magnitudes, Till they have filled and quite perplex'd his mind.
tgt_text.8794: And Innesimachus says in his Alcmæon:
tgt_text.8796: As we do sacrifice to the Phœbus whom Pythagoras worships, never eating aught
tgt_text.8797: Which has the breath of life.
tgt_text.8800: He said that when he did descend below Among the shades in Hell, he there beheld All men who e'er had died;
tgt_text.8801: and there he saw, That the Pythagoreans differ'd much From all the rest;
tgt_text.8802: for that with them alone Did Pluto deign to eat, much honouring Their pious habits.
tgt_text.8803: B. He's a civil God, If he likes eating with such dirty fellows.
tgt_text.8804: And again, in the same play he says :
tgt_text.8806: They eat Nothing but herbs and vegetables, and drink Pure water only.
tgt_text.8807: But their lice are such, Their cloaks so dirty, and their unwash'd scent
tgt_text.8808: So rank, that no one of our younger men Will for a moment bear them.
tgt_text.8811: When he was sitting with some of his companions in Milo's house, some one of those whom he did not think worthy of admission into it, was excited by envy to set fire to it.
tgt_text.8812: But some say that the people of Crotona themselves did this, being afraid lest he might aspire to the tyranny.
tgt_text.8813: And that Pythagoras was caught as he was trying to escape ;
tgt_text.8814: and coming to a place full of beans, he stopped there, saying that it was better to be caught than to trample on the beans, and better to be slain than to speak ;
tgt_text.8815: and so he was murdered by those who were pursuing him.
tgt_text.8816: And in this way, also, most of his companions were slain;
tgt_text.8818: but that a very few did escape, among whom were Archippus, of Tarentum, and Lysis, whom I have mentioned before.
tgt_text.8819: But Dicæarchus relates that Pythagoras died afterwards, having escaped as far as the temple of the Muses, at Meta- pontum, and that he died there of starvation, having abstained from food for forty days.
tgt_text.8820: And Heraclides says, in his abridgment of the life of Satyrus, that after he had buried Pherecydes in Delos, he returned to Italy, and finding there a superb ban- quet prepared at the house of Milo, of Cortona, he left Cro- tona, and went to Metapontum, and there put an end to his life by starvation, not wishing to live any longer.
tgt_text.8821: But Her- mippus says, that when there was war between the people of Agrigentum and the Syracusans, Pythagoras went out with his usual companions, and took the part of the Agrigentines ;
tgt_text.8822: and as they were put to flight, he ran all round a field of beans, instead of crossing it, and so was slain by the Syracu- sans ;
tgt_text.8823: and that the rest, being about five-and-thirty in num- ber, were burnt at Tarentum, when they were trying to excite a sedition in the state against the principal magistrates.
tgt_text.8824: Hermippus also relates another story about Pythagoras.
tgt_text.8825: For he says that when he was in Italy, he made a subterra- neous apartment, and charged his mother to write an account of everything that took place, marking the time of each on a tablet, and then to send them down to him, until he came up again ;
tgt_text.8826: and that his mother did so ;
tgt_text.8827: and that Pythagoras came up again after a certain time, lean, and reduced to a skeleton ;
tgt_text.8828: and that he came into the public assembly, and said that he had arrived from the shades below, and then he recited to them all that had happened during his absence.
tgt_text.8829: And they, being charmed by what he told them, wept and lamented, and believed that Pythagoras was a divine being;
tgt_text.8830: so that they even entrusted their wives to him, as likely to learn some good from him ;
tgt_text.8831: and that they too were called Pythagoreans.
tgt_text.8832: And this is the story of Hermippus.
tgt_text.8834: And Pythagoras had a wife, whose name was Theano;
tgt_text.8835: the daughter of Brontinus, of Crotona.
tgt_text.8836: But some say that she was the wife of Brontinus, and only a pupil of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.8837: And he had a daughter named Damo, as Lysis mentions in his letter to Hipparchus;
tgt_text.8838: where he speaks thus of Pythagoras:
tgt_text.8839: "And many say that you philosophize in public, as Pythagoras also used to do;
tgt_text.8840: who, when he had entrusted his Commentaries to Damo, his daughter, charged her to divulge them to no person out of the house.

tgt_text.8842: and that too, though she was a woman.

tgt_text.8855: And we have written a sportive epigram on him, which is couched in the following terms :

tgt_text.8858: And who, I'd like to know did ever taste Food while alive, most sage Pythagoras ?,
tgt_text.8859: When meat is boil'd, or roasted well and salted, I don't think it can well be called living.
tgt_text.8860: Which, therefore, without scruple then we eat it, And call it no more living flesh, but meat.

tgt_text.8878: and his system lasted for nine or ten generations.
tgt_text.8879: And the last of the Pythagoreans, whom Aristoxenus knew, were Xenophilus, the Chalcidean, from Thrace;
tgt_text.8880: and Phanton, the Phliasian, and Echurates, and Diodes, and Polymnestus, who were also Phliasians, and they were disciples of Philolaus and Eurytus, of Tarentum.
tgt_text.8882: And there were four men of the name of Pytha- goras, about the same time, at no great distance from one another.
tgt_text.8883: One was a native of Crotona, a man who attained tyrannical power;
tgt_text.8884: the second was a Phliasian, a trainer of wrestlers, as some say ;
tgt_text.8885: the third was a native of Zacynthus ;
tgt_text.8886: the fourth was this our philosopher, to whom they say the mysteries of philosophy belong, in whose time that proverbial phrase, " Ipse dixit," was introduced into ordinary life.
tgt_text.8887: Some also affirm, that there was another man of the name of Pythagoras, a statuary of Rhodes ;
tgt_text.8888: who is believed to have been the first discoverer of rhythm and proportion;
tgt_text.8889: and another was a Samian statuary;
tgt_text.8890: and another an orator, of no reputation;
tgt_text.8891: and another was a physician, who wrote a treatise on Squills ;
tgt_text.8892: and also some essays on Homer;
tgt_text.8893: and another was a man, who wrote a history of the affairs of the Dorians, as we are told by Dionysius.

tgt_text.8895: and that he was rejected from the competition among boys, and being ridiculed for his application, he immediately entered among the men, and came off victorious.

tgt_text.8912: But now the reputation of your father keeps you back, which perhaps would have restrained me too, if I had been like Anaximenes.

tgt_text.8916: But since we have now finished our account of Pythagoras, we must also speak of the most eminent of the Pythagoreans.
tgt_text.8917: After whom, we must mention those who are spoken of more promiscuously in connection with no particular school;
tgt_text.8918: and then we will connect the whole series of philosophers worth speaking of, till we arrive at Epicurus, as we have already promised.
tgt_text.8919: Now Jelanges and Theano we have mentioned;
tgt_text.8920: and we must now speak of Empedocles, in the first place, for, accord- .ing to some accounts, he was a pupil of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.8921: I. EMPEDOCLES, as Hippobotus relates, was the son of Meton, the son of Empedocles, and a citizen of Agrigentum.
tgt_text.8922: And Timæus, in the fifteenth book of his Histories, gives the same account, adding that Empedocles, the grandfather of the poet, was also a most eminent man.
tgt_text.8923: And Hermippus tells the same story as Timæus;
tgt_text.8924: and in the same spirit Heraclides, in his treatise on Diseases, relates that he was of an illus- trious family, since his father bred a fine stud of horses.
tgt_text.8925: Erastothenes, in his List of the Conquerors at the Olympic Games, says, that the father of Meton gained the victory in the seventy-first olympiad, quoting Aristotle as his authority for the assertion.
tgt_text.8926: But Apollodorus, the grammarian, in his Chronicles, says that he was the son of Meton;
tgt_text.8927: and Glaucus says that he came to Thurii when the city was only just completed.
tgt_text.8928: And then proceeding a little further, he adds :
tgt_text.8930: And some relate that he did flee from thence, And came to Syracuse, and on their side Did fight in horrid war against th' Athenians ;
tgt_text.8931: But those men seem to me completely wrong-
tgt_text.8932: For by this time he must have been deceased, Or very old, which is not much believed;
tgt_text.8933: For Aristotle, and Heraclides too, Say that he died at sixty years of age.
tgt_text.8934: But certainly the person who got the victory with a single horse in the seventy-first olympiad was a namesake of this man, and that it is which deceived Apollodorus as to the age of this philosopher.
tgt_text.8935: But Satyrus, in his Lives, asserts, that Empedocles was the son of Exænetus, and that he also left a son who was named Exænetus, And that in the same Olympiad, he himself gained the victory with the single horse;
tgt_text.8936: and his son, in wrestling, or, as Heraclides says in his Abridgment, in running.
tgt_text.8937: But I have found in the Commentaries of Phavo- rinus, that Empedocles sacrificed, and gave as a feast to the spectators of the games, an ox made of honey and flour, and that he had a brother named Callicratidas.
tgt_text.8938: But Jelanges, the son of Pythagoras, in his letters to Philolaus, says that Empedocles was the son of Archinomus ;

tgt_text.8943: Timæus, in his ninth book, relates that he was a pupil of Pythagoras, saying that he was afterwards convicted of having divulged his doctrines, in the same way as Plato was, and therefore that he was forbidden from thenceforth to attend his school.
tgt_text.8944: And they say that Pythagoras himself mentions him when he says :
tgt_text.8946: And in that band there was a learned man, Of wondrous wisdom;
tgt_text.8947: one, who of all men Had the profoundest wealth of intellect.
tgt_text.8948: But some say that when the philosopher says this, he is referring to Parmenides.
tgt_text.8949: Neanthes relates, that till the time of Philolaus and Empe- docles, the Pythagoreans used to admit all persons indis- criminately into their school;
tgt_text.8950: but when Empedocles made their doctrines public by means of his poems, then they made a law to admit no Epic poet.
tgt_text.8951: And they say that the same thing happened to Plato ;
tgt_text.8952: for that he too was excluded from the school.
tgt_text.8953: But who was the teacher of the Pythagorean school that Empedocles was a pupil of, they do not say ;
tgt_text.8954: for, as for the letter of Jelanges, in which he is stated to have been a pupil of Hippasus and Brontinus, that is not worthy of belief.
tgt_text.8955: But Theophrastus says that he was an imitator and a rival of Parmenides, in his poems, for that he too had delivered his opinions on natural philosophy in epic verse.
tgt_text.8956: Hermippus, however, says that he was an imitator, not of Parmenides, but of Xenophanes with whom he lived;
tgt_text.8957: and that he imitated his epic style, and that it was at a later period that he fell in with the Pythagoreans.
tgt_text.8958: But Alcidamas, in his Natural Philosophy, says, that Zeno and Empedocles were pupils of Parmenides, about the same time;
tgt_text.8959: and that they subsequently seceded from him;
tgt_text.8960: and that Zeno adopted a philosophical system peculiar to himself;
tgt_text.8961: but that Empedo- cles became a pupil of Anaxagoras and Pythagoras, and that he imitated the pompous demeanour, and way of life, and gestures of the one, and the system of Natural Philosophy of the other.
tgt_text.8963: And Aristotle, in his Sophist, says that Empedocles was the first person who invented rhetoric, and Zeno the first person who invented dialectics.
tgt_text.8964: And in his book on Poetry, he says, that Empedocles was a man of Homeric genius, and endowed with great power of language, and a great master of metaphor, and a man who employed all the successful artifices of poetry, and also that when he had written several poems, and among them one on the passage of the Hellespont, by Xerxes, and also the proœmium of a hymn to Apollo, his daughter subsequently burnt them, or, as Hieronymus says, his sister, burning the proœmium unintentionally, but the Persian poem on purpose, because it was incomplete.
tgt_text.8965: And speaking generally, he says that he wrote tragedies and political treatises.
tgt_text.8966: But Heraclides, the son of Sarapion, says that the tragedies were the work of some other Empedocles;
tgt_text.8967: and Hieronymus says that he had met with forty-three.
tgt_text.8968: Neanthes, too, affirms that when he was a young man, he wrote tragedies, and that he himself had subsequently met with them;
tgt_text.8969: and Satyrus, in his Lives, states that he was a physician, and also a most excellent orator.
tgt_text.8970: And accordingly, that Gorgias, of Leontini, was his pupil, a man of the greatest eminence as a rhetorician, and one who left behind him a treatise containing a complete system of the art;
tgt_text.8971: and who, as we are told by Apollodorus, in his Chronicles, lived to the age of a hundred and nine years.

tgt_text.8989: And so, when the wind ceased, he was called wind-forbidder (ϰωλυσανέμας).

tgt_text.8994: He also wrote an epigram upon him:

tgt_text.9012: on which account Empedocles, seeing the people immersed in luxury, said, " The men of Agrigentum devote themselves wholly to luxury as if they were to die to-morrow, but they furnish their houses as if they were to live for ever."

tgt_text.9017: And Aristotle says, that he was a most liberal man, and far removed from anything like a domineering spirit;
tgt_text.9018: since he constantly'refused the sovereign power when it was offered to him, as Xanthus assures us in his account of him, showing plainly that he preferred a simple style of living.
tgt_text.9019: And Timæus tells the same story, giving at the same time the reason why he was so very popular.
tgt_text.9020: For he says that when on one occa- sion, he was invited to a banquet by one of the magistrates, the wine was carried about, but the supper was not served up.
tgt_text.9021: And as every one else kept silence, he, disapproving of what he saw, bade the servants bring in the supper;
tgt_text.9022: but the person who had invited him said that he was waiting for the secretary of the council.
tgt_text.9023: And when he came he was appointed master of the feast, at the instigation of the giver of it, and then he gave a plain intimation of his tyrannical inclinations, for he ordered all the guests to drink, and those who did not drink were to have the wine poured over their heads.
tgt_text.9024: Empedocles said nothing at the moment, but the next day he summoned them before the court, and procured the execution of both the entertainer and the master of the feast.
tgt_text.9025: And this was the beginning of his political career.
tgt_text.9026: And at another time, when Acron, the physician, asked of the council a place where he might erect a monument to his father, on account of his eminence as a physician, Empedocles came forward and opposed any such grant, adducing many argu- ments on the ground of equality, and also putting the following question :
tgt_text.9028: And what elegy shall we inscribe upon it ?

tgt_text.9033: the magistrates were to hold office for three years, on such a footing that it should consist not only of rich men, but of those who were favourers of the interests of the people.

tgt_text.9046: And then Empedocles, the honeyed speaker Of soft forensic speeches;
tgt_text.9047: he did take As many offices as he was able, Creating magistrates who wanted helpers.
tgt_text.9048: But there are two accounts of the manner of his death.
tgt_text.9050: For Heraclides, relating the story about the dead woman, how Empedocles got great glory from sending away a dead woman restored to life, says that he celebrated a sacrifice in the field of Pisianax, and that some of his friends were invited, among whom was Pausanias.
tgt_text.9051: And then, after the banquet, they lay down, some going a little way off, and some lying under the trees close by in the field, and some wherever they happened to choose.
tgt_text.9052: But Empedocles himself remained in the place where he had been sitting.
tgt_text.9053: But when day broke, and they arose, he alone was not found.
tgt_text.9054: And when he was sought for, and the servants were examined and said that they did not know, one of them said, that at midnight he had heard a loud voice calling Empedocles ;
tgt_text.9055: and that then he himself rose up and saw a great light from heaven, but nothing else.
tgt_text.9056: And as they were all amazed at what had taken place, Pau- sanias descended and sent some people to look for him ;
tgt_text.9057: but afterwards he was commanded not to busy himself about the matter, as he was informed that what had happened was de- serving of thankfulness, and that they behoved to sacrifice to Empedocles as to one who had become a God.
tgt_text.9058: Hermippus says also, that a woman of the name of Panthea, a native of Agrigentum, who had been given over by the physi- cians, was cured by him, and that it was on this account that he celebrated a sacrifice ;
tgt_text.9059: and that the guests invited were about eighty in number.
tgt_text.9060: But Hippobotus says that he rose up and went away as if he were going to mount Ætna;
tgt_text.9061: and that when he arrived at the crater of fire he leaped in, and disappeared, wishing to establish a belief that he had become a God.
tgt_text.9062: But afterwards the truth was detected by one of his slippers having been dropped.
tgt_text.9063: For he used to wear slippers with brazen soles.
tgt_text.9065: *But Diodorus, of Ephesus, writing about Anaximander, says that Empedocles imitated him;
tgt_text.9066: indulging in a tragic sort of pride, and wearing magnificent apparel.
tgt_text.9067: And when a pestilence attacked the people of Selinus, by reason of the bad smells arising from the adjacent river, so that the men died and the women bore dead children, Empedocles contrived a plan, and brought into the same channel two other rivers at his own expense ;
tgt_text.9068: and so, by mixing their waters with that of the other river, he sweetened the stream.
tgt_text.9069: And as the pestilence was removed in this way, when the people of Selinus were on one occasion holding a festival on the bank of the river, Empedo- cles appeared among them;
tgt_text.9070: and they rising up, offered him adoration, and prayed to him as to a God.
tgt_text.9071: And he, wishing to confirm this idea which they had adopted of him, leaped into the fire.
tgt_text.9072: But Timæus contradicts all these stories ;
tgt_text.9073: saying expressly, that he departed into Peloponnesus, and never returned at all, on which account the manner of his death is uncertain.
tgt_text.9074: And he especially denies the tale of Heraclides in his fourth book;
tgt_text.9075: for he says that Pisianax was a Syracnsan, and had no field in the district of Agrigentum ;
tgt_text.9076: but that Pausanias erected a monument in honour of his friend, since such a report had got about concerning him ;
tgt_text.9077: and, as he was a rich man, made it a statue and little chapel, as one might erect to a God. "
tgt_text.9078: How then," adds Timæus, " could he have leaped into a crater, of which, though they were in the neighbourhood, he had never made any mention ?
tgt_text.9080: and there is nothing extraordinary in there being no tomb of his to be seen ;
tgt_text.9081: for there are many other men who have no tomb visible."
tgt_text.9082: These are the words of Timaeus ;
tgt_text.9083: and he adds further, " But Heraclides is altogether a man fond of strange stories, and one who would assert that a man had fallen from the moon.
tgt_text.9084: "Hippobotus says, that there was a clothed statue of Empe docles which lay formerly in Agrigentum, but which was afterwards placed in front of the Senate House of the Romans divested of its clothing, as the Romans had carried it off and erected it there.
tgt_text.9085: And there are traces of some inscriptions or reliefs still discernible on it.
tgt_text.9086: Neanthes, of Cyzicus, who also wrote about the Pythago- reans, says, that when Meton was dead, the seeds of tyrannical power began to appear;
tgt_text.9087: and that then Empedocles persuaded the Agrigentines to desist from their factious disputes, and to establish political equality.
tgt_text.9088: And besides, as there were many of the female citizens destitute of dowry, he portioned them out of his own private fortune.
tgt_text.9089: And relying on these actions of his, he assumed a purple robe and wore a golden circlet on his hand, as Phavorinus relates in the first book of his Com- mentaries.
tgt_text.9090: He also wore slippers with brazen soles, and a Delphian garland.
tgt_text.9091: His hair was let grow very long, and he had boys to follow him ;
tgt_text.9092: and he himself always preserved a solemn countenance, and a uniformly grave deportment.
tgt_text.9093: And he marched about in such style, that he seemed to all the citizens, who met him and who admired his deportment, to exhibit a sort of likeness to kingly power.
tgt_text.9094: And afterwards, it happened that as on the occasion of some festival he was going -in a chariot to Messene, he was upset and broke his thigh ;
tgt_text.9095: and he was taken ill in consequence, and so died, at the age of seventy-seven.
tgt_text.9096: And his tomb is in Megara.
tgt_text.9097: But as to his age, Aristotle differs from this account of Neanthes ;
tgt_text.9098: for he asserts that he died at sixty years of age ;
tgt_text.9099: others again say, that lie was a hundred and nine when he died.
tgt_text.9100: He flourished about the eighty-fourth olympiad.
tgt_text.9101: Deme- trius, of Træzen, in his book against the Sophists, reports that, as the lines of Homer say :
tgt_text.9103: He now, self-murdered, from a beam depends, And his mad soul to blackest hell descends.
tgt_text.9104: *But in the letter of Telauges, which has been mentioned before, it is said that he slipped down through old age, and fell into the sea, and so died.
tgt_text.9105: And this is enough to say about his death.
tgt_text.9106: There is also a jesting epigram of ours upon him, in our collection of Poems in all Metres, which runs thus:
tgt_text.9107: - You too, Empedocles, essayed to purge Your body in the rapid flames, and drank
tgt_text.9108: The liquid fire from the restless crater;
tgt_text.9109: I say not that you threw yourself at once Into the stream of Ætna's fiery flood.
tgt_text.9110: But seeking to conceal yourself you fell, And so you met with unintended death.
tgt_text.9113: 'Tis said the wise Empedocles did fall Out of his chariot, and so broke his thigh:
tgt_text.9114: But if he leapt into the flames of Ætna, How could his tomb be shown in Megara ?XII.
tgt_text.9115: The following were some of his doctrines.
tgt_text.9116: He used to assert that there were four elements, fire, water, earth, and air.
tgt_text.9117: And that that is friendship by which they are united, and discord by which they are separated.
tgt_text.9118: And he speaks thus on this subject:
tgt_text.9119: - Bright Jove, life-giving Juno, Pluto dark, And Nestis, who fills mortal eyes with tears.
tgt_text.9120: Meaning by Jove fire, by Juno the earth, by Pluto the air, and by Nestis water.
tgt_text.9121: And these things, says he, never cease alternating with one another;
tgt_text.9122: inasmuch as this arrangement is perpetual.
tgt_text.9124: — Sometimes in friendship bound they coalesce, Sometimes they're parted by fell discord's hate.
tgt_text.9125: And he asserts that the sun is a vast assemblage of fire, and that it is larger than the moon.
tgt_text.9127: and that the heaven itself is like crystal ;
tgt_text.9128: and that the soul inhabits every kind of form of animals and plants.
tgt_text.9129: Accord- ingly, he thus expresses himself.
tgt_text.9130: For once I was a boy, and once a girl.
tgt_text.9131: A bush, a bird, a fish who swims the sea,XIII.
tgt_text.9132: His writings on Natural Philosophy and his Purifi- cations extend to five thousand verses ;
tgt_text.9133: and his Medical Poem to six hundred ;
tgt_text.9134: and his Tragedies we have spoken of previously.
tgt_text.9135: I. EPICHARMUS was a native of Cos, the son of Helothales;
tgt_text.9137: he also was a pupil of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.9138: When he was three months old he was brought to Megara, in Sicily, and from thence he came to Syracuse, as he himself tells us in his writings.
tgt_text.9139: And on his statue there is the following inscription.
tgt_text.9140: As the bright sun excels the other stars,
tgt_text.9141: As the sea far exceeds the river streams :
tgt_text.9142: So does sage Epicharmus men surpass, Whom hospitable Syracuse has crowned.
tgt_text.9144: He has left behind him Commentaries in which he treats of natural philosophy, and delivers apophthegms, and discusses medicine.
tgt_text.9145: He has also added brief notes to many of his commentaries, in which he declares plainly that he is the author of the works.
tgt_text.9147: He died at the age of ninety years.
tgt_text.9148: I. ARCHYTAS was a native of Tarentum, and the son of Innesagoras ;
tgt_text.9149: or, as Aristoxenus relates, of Histiæus.
tgt_text.9152: and he it was who saved Plato's life by means of a letter, when he was in danger of being put to death by Dionysius.
tgt_text.9154: He was a man held in very general esteem on account of his universal virtue;
tgt_text.9155: and he was seven times appointed general of his countrymen, when no one else had ever held the office for more than one year, as the law forbade it to be held for a longer period.
tgt_text.9157: Plato wrote his letters to him;
tgt_text.9158: as he had begun the correspondence by writing himself to Plato, which he did in the following manner :
tgt_text.9160: I am very glad that you have recovered from your delicate state of health;
tgt_text.9161: for you yourself have sent me word of your recovery, and Lamiscus gives the same account.
tgt_text.9162: I have been much occupied with some commentaries, and have been among the Lucanians, and have met with the descendants of Orellus.
tgt_text.9163: I have now in my possession, and I send to you the treatises on Law, and Kingly Power, and Piety, and the Creation of the Universe.
tgt_text.9164: As for the rest, I have not been able to- find them, but whenever I do find any, I will send them to you.
tgt_text.9166: And Plato sent him an answer in the following terms :
tgt_text.9168: I was exceedingly glad to receive the Commentaries which came from you, and I have admired their author in the greatest possible degree;
tgt_text.9169: and he seems to us to be a man worthy of his ancient ancestors.
tgt_text.9170: For they are said to have been originally natives of Myra ;
tgt_text.9171: and to have been among the Trojans, whom Laomedon took with him, gallant men, as the story handed down by tradition attests.
tgt_text.9172: As for my Commentaries which you ask me for, they are not yet completed, but, such as they are I send them to you.
tgt_text.9173: And on the propriety of taking care of such things we are both agreed, so that I have no need to impress anything on you on that head.
tgt_text.9175: "These then are the letters which these philososophers wrote to one another.
tgt_text.9177: There were four people of the name of Archytas.
tgt_text.9178: The first, this man of whom we are speaking.
tgt_text.9179: The second was a Mytilenean, a musician.
tgt_text.9180: The third wrote a treatise on Agri- culture.
tgt_text.9181: The fourth was an epigrammatic poet.
tgt_text.9182: Some writers also make mention of a fifth, who was an architect;
tgt_text.9183: and there is a book on mechanics extant which is attributed to him ;
tgt_text.9186: This is what I heard from Teucer, the Carthaginian.
tgt_text.9187: "And concerning the musician, the following story is told :
tgt_text.9188: That once he was reproached for not making himself heard, and he replied, “My organ contends on my behalf, and speaks."VI. Aristoxenus says, that this Pythagorean was never once defeated while acting as general.
tgt_text.9189: But that as he was attacked by envy, he once gave up his command, and his army was immediately taken prisoner.
tgt_text.9191: He was the first person who applied mathematical principles to mechanics, and reduced them to a system;
tgt_text.9192: and the first also who gave a methodical impulse to descriptive geometry in seeking, in the sections of a demicylinder for a proportional mean, which should enable him to find the double of a given cube.
tgt_text.9193: He was also the first person who ever gave the geometrical measure of a cube, as Plato mentions in his Republic.
tgt_text.9194: I. ALCMÆON was a citizen of Crotona ;
tgt_text.9195: he also was a pupil of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.9196: And the chief part of his writings are on medical subjects ;
tgt_text.9197: but he also at times discusses points of natural philosophy, and asserts that the greater part of human affairs have two sides.
tgt_text.9198: He appears to have been the first person who wrote a treatise on Natural Philosophy, as Phavo- rinus affirms, in his Universal History;
tgt_text.9199: and he used to argue that the moon had the same nature for ever which she had at that moment.
tgt_text.9201: He was the son of Pirithus, as he himself states at the beginning of his treatise, where he says, " Alcmaeon, of Cro- tona, the son of Pirithus, says this to Brontinus, and Leon, and Bathyllus.
tgt_text.9202: About things invisible, and things mortal, the Gods alone have a certain knowledge ;
tgt_text.9205: He used also to say that the soul was immortal, and that it was In a state of perpetual motion in the same way as the sun.1.
tgt_text.9206: HIPPASUS was a citizen of Metapontum, and a pupil of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.9208: He used to say that the time of the changes of the world was definite, and that the universe also was finite, and in a state of perpetual motion.
tgt_text.9210: Demetrius, in his treatise on People of the same Name, says that he left no writings behind him.
tgt_text.9212: There were two people of the name of Hippasus ;
tgt_text.9213: this man, and another who wrote an account of the Constitution of the Lacedæmonians, in five books.
tgt_text.9214: And he was himself a Lacedæmonian.
tgt_text.9215: I. PHILOLAUS was a native of Crotona, and a pupil of Pythagoras, it was from him that Plato wrote to Dion to take care and purchase the books of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.9217: And he died under suspicion of having designed to seize on the tyranny;
tgt_text.9218: and we have written an epigram on him:
tgt_text.9219: — I say that all men ought above all things
tgt_text.9221: For, though innocent, Still if you are suspected, you're unfortunate.
tgt_text.9222: And thus his native city of Crotona Slew Philolaus;
tgt_text.9224: Thought that his house betrayed a tyrant's purpose.
tgt_text.9226: His theory was, that everything was produced by harmony and necessity.
tgt_text.9227: And he was the first person who affirmed that the earth moved in a circle;
tgt_text.9228: though some attribute the assertion of this principle to Icetas of Syracuse.
tgt_text.9230: He wrote one book, which Hermippus reports, on the authority of some unknown writer, that Plato the philosopher purchased when he was in Sicily (having come thither to the court of Dionysius), of the relations of Philolaus, for forty Alexandrian minæ of silver;
tgt_text.9231: and that from this book he copied his Timæus.
tgt_text.9232: But others say that Plato received it as a present, after having obtained his liberty for a young man, one of the disciples of Philolaus, who had been arrested by Dionysius.
tgt_text.9233: Demetrius, in his treatise on people of the same name, says that he was the first of the Pythagoreans who wrote a treatise on Natural Philosophy;
tgt_text.9236: But nature in the world has been composed of bodies infinite and finite, and so is the whole world and all that is in it.
tgt_text.9237: "I. EUDOXUS was the son of Æschines, and a native of Cnidos.
tgt_text.9238: He was an astronomer, a geometrician, a physician, and a lawgiver.
tgt_text.9239: In geometry he was a pupil of Archytas, and in medicine of Philistion, the Sicilian, as Callimachus relates in his Tablets ;
tgt_text.9240: and Sotion, in his Successions, asserts that he was likewise a pupil of Plato ;
tgt_text.9241: for that, when he was twenty-three years of age, and in very narrow circumstances, he came to Athens with Theomedon the physician, by whom he was chiefly supported, being attracted by the reputation of the Socratic school.
tgt_text.9242: Some say that his attachment to Theo- medon was cemented by nearer ties.
tgt_text.9243: And when he had arrived at Piræus, he went up to the city every day, and when he had heard the Sophists lecture he returned.
tgt_text.9244: And having spent two , months there, he returned home again ;
tgt_text.9245: and being again aided by the contributions of his friends, he set sail for Egypt, with Chrysippus the physician, bearing letters of introduction from Agesilaus to Nectanabis, and that he recommended him to the priests.
tgt_text.9247: And having remained there a year and four months, he shaved his eyebrows after the manner of the Egyptian priests, and composed, as it is said, the treatise called the Octacteris.
tgt_text.9248: From thence he went to Cyzicus, and to the Propontis, in both of which places he lived as a Sophist;
tgt_text.9249: he also went to the court of Mansolus.
tgt_text.9250: And then, in this manner, he returned again to Athens, having a great many disciples with him, for the sake, as some say, of annoying Plato, because he had originally discarded him from his school.
tgt_text.9251: Some say, that when Plato gave an entertainment on one occasion, Eudoxus, as the guests were very numerous, introduced the fashion of sitting in a semicircle.
tgt_text.9252: Nichomachus, the son of Aristotle, affirms that he used to say, that pleasure was the good.
tgt_text.9254: He was received in his own country with great honours, as the decree that was passed respecting him shows.
tgt_text.9255: He was also accounted very illustrious among the Greeks, having given laws to his own fellow citizens, as Hermippus tells us in the fourth book of his account of the Seven Wise Men;
tgt_text.9256: and having also written treatises on Astronomy and Geometry, and several other considerable works.
tgt_text.9257: He had three daughters, Actis, Philtis, and Delphis.
tgt_text.9258: And Eratosthenes asserts, in his books addressed to Baton, that he also composed dialogues entitled Dialogues of Dogs;
tgt_text.9259: others say that these were written by some Egyptians, in their own language, and that Eudoxus translated them, and published them in Greece.
tgt_text.9260: One of his pupils was Chrysippus, of Cnidos, son of Erineus, who learnt of him all that he knew about the Gods, and the world, and the heavenly bodies;
tgt_text.9261: and who learnt medicine from Philistion the Sicilian.
tgt_text.9262: He also left some very admirable Reminiscences.IV.
tgt_text.9263: He had a son of the name of Aristagoras, who was the teacher of Chrysippus, the son of Aëthlius;
tgt_text.9264: be was the author of a work on Remedies for the Eyes, as speculations on natural philosophy had come very much under his notice.
tgt_text.9266: There were three people of the name of Eudoxus.
tgt_text.9267: The first, this man of whom we are speaking ;
tgt_text.9268: the second, a Rhodian, who wrote histories;
tgt_text.9269: the third, a Sicilist, a son of Agathocles, a comic poet, who gained three victories at the Dionysia in the city, and five at the Lenæa,* as Apollodorus tells us in his Chronicles.
tgt_text.9270: We also find another, who was a phy- sician of Cnidos, who is mentioned by this Eudoxus, in his Circuit of the World, where he says that he used to warn peo- ple to keep constantly exercising their limbs in every kind of exercise, and their senses too.
tgt_text.9272: The same author says, that the Cnidean Eudoxus flourished about the hundred and third olympiad;
tgt_text.9273: and that be was the inventor of the theory of crooked lines.
tgt_text.9274: And he died in his fifty-third year.
tgt_text.9275: But when he was in Egypt with Conu- pliis, of Heliopolis, Apis licked his garment;
tgt_text.9276: and so the priests said that he would be short-lived, but very illustrious, as it is reported by Phavorinus in his Commentaries.
tgt_text.9277: And we have written an epigram on him, that runs thus :
tgt_text.9279: 'Tis said, that while at Memphis wise Eudoxus Learnt his own fate from th' holy fair-horned bull;
tgt_text.9280: He said indeed no word, bulls do not speak;
tgt_text.9281: Nor had kind nature e'er calf Apis gifted With an articulately speaking mouth.
tgt_text.9282: But standing on one side he lick'd his cloak, Slowing by this most plainly-in brief time
tgt_text.9283: You shall put off your life.

tgt_text.9288: And since we have gone through the illustrious Pythagoreans, we must now speak of the Promiscuous philosophers, as they call them.
tgt_text.9289: And we will first of all speak of Heraclitus.1.
tgt_text.9290: HERACLITUS was the son of Blyson, or, as some say, of Heraceon, and a citizen of Ephesus.
tgt_text.9291: He flourished about the sixty-ninth olympiad.
tgt_text.9293: He was above all men of a lofty and arrogant spirit, as is plain from his writings, in which he says, " Abundant learning does not form the mind;
tgt_text.9294: for if it did, it would have instructed Hesiod, and Pythagoras, and likewise Xenophanes, and Hecatæus.
tgt_text.9295: For the only piece of real wisdom is to know that idea, which by itself will govern everything on every occasion.
tgt_text.9296: He used to say, too, that Homer deserved to be expelled from the games and beaten, and Archilochus likewise.
tgt_text.9297: He used also to say, " It is more necessary to extin- guish insolence, than to put out a fire."
tgt_text.9298: Another of his say- ings was, " The people ought to fight for the law, as for their city."
tgt_text.9299: He also attacks the Ephesians for having banished his companion Hermodorus, when he says, " The Ephesians deserve to have all their youth put to death, and all those who are younger still banished from their city, inasmuch as they have banished Hermodorus, the best man among them, saying, “ Let no one of us be pre-eminently good ;
tgt_text.9300: and if there be any such person, let him go to another city and another people.
tgt_text.9301: "And when he was requested to make laws for them, he refused, because the city was already immersed in a thoroughly bad constitution.
tgt_text.9302: And having retired to the temple of Diana with his children, he began to play at dice;
tgt_text.9303: and when all the Ephesians flocked round him, he said, " You wretches, what are you wondering at ?
tgt_text.9304: is it not better to do this, than to meddle with public affairs in your company?"
tgt_text.9306: And at last, becoming a complete misanthrope, he used to live, spending his time in walking about the mountains ;
tgt_text.9307: feeding on grasses and plants, and in consequence of these habits, he was attacked by the dropsy, and so then he returned to the city, and asked the physicians, in a riddle, whether they were able to produce a drought after wet weather.
tgt_text.9308: And as they did not understand him, he shut himself up in a stable for oxen, and covered himself with cow-dung, hoping to cause the wet to evaporate from him, by the warmth that this pro- duced.
tgt_text.9309: And as he did himself no go good in this way, he died, having lived seventy years;
tgt_text.9310: and we have written an epigram upon him which runs thus :
tgt_text.9311: — I've often wondered much at Heraclitus, That he should chose to live so miserably, And die by such a miserable fate.
tgt_text.9312: For fell disease did master all his body, With water quenching all the light of his eyes, And bringing darkness o'er his mind and body.
tgt_text.9313: But Hermippus states, that what he asked the physicians was this, whether any one could draw off the water by de- pressing his intestines ?
tgt_text.9314: and when they answered that they could not, he placed himself in the sun, and ordered his servants to plaster him over with cow-dung;
tgt_text.9315: and being stretched out in that way, on the second day he died, and was buried in the market-place.
tgt_text.9316: But Neanthes, of Cyzicus says, that as he could not tear off the cow-dung, he remained there, and on account of the alteration in his appearance, he was not discovered, and so was devoured by the dogs.
tgt_text.9318: And he was a wonderful person, from his boyhood, since, while he was young, he used to say that he knew nothing but when he had grown up, he then used to affirm that he knew everything.
tgt_text.9319: And he was no one's pupil, but he used to say, that he himself had investigated every thing, and had learned everything of himself.
tgt_text.9320: But Sotion relates, that some people affirmed that he had been a pupil of Xenophanes.
tgt_text.9321: And that Ariston, stated in his account of Heraclitus, that he was cured of the dropsy, and died of some other disease.
tgt_text.9322: And Hippobotus gives the same account.Y.
tgt_text.9323: There is a book of his extant, which is about nature generally, and it is divided into three discourses;
tgt_text.9327: And he leposited this book in the temple of Diana, as some authors eport, having written it intentionally in an obscure style, in order that only those who were able men might comprehend it, and that it might not he exposed to ridicule at the hands of the common people.

tgt_text.9329: — Among them came that cuckoo Heraclitus

tgt_text.9333: and Antisthenes, in his Succes sions, adduces as a proof of his lofty spirit, the fact, that h< yielded to his brother the title and privileges of royalty.*
tgt_text.9334: And his book had so high a reputation, that a sect arose ii consequence of it, who were called after his own name Heracliteans,VI.
tgt_text.9335: The following may be set down in a general manner as his main principles:
tgt_text.9336: that everything is created from fire and is dissolved into fire;
tgt_text.9337: that everything happens accord ing to destiny, and that all existing things are harmonized and made to agree together by opposite tendencies ;
tgt_text.9338: and thai all things are full of souls and dæmones.
tgt_text.9339: He also discussec all the passions which exist in the world, and used also tc contend that the sun was of that precise magnitude of which he appears to be.
tgt_text.9340: One of his sayings too was, that no one, by whatever road he might travel, could ever possibly find out the boundaries of the soul, so deeply hidden are the prin- ciples which regulate it.
tgt_text.9341: He used also to call opinion the sacred disease ;
tgt_text.9342: and to say that eye-sight was often deceived Sometimes, in his writings, he expresses himself with great brilliancy and clearness;
tgt_text.9343: so that even the most stupid man may easily understand him, and receive an elevation of soul from him.
tgt_text.9344: And his conciseness, and the dignity of his style are incomparable.
tgt_text.9345: In particulars, his doctrines are of this kind.
tgt_text.9346: That fire is an element, and that it is by the changes of fire that all things exist;
tgt_text.9347: being engendered sometimes by rarity, some- times by density.
tgt_text.9349: He also says, that everything is produced by contrariety, and that everything flows on like a river;
tgt_text.9350: that the universe is finite, and that there is one world, and that that is produced from ire, and that the whole world is in its turn again con- ,umed by fire at certain periods, and that all this happens Lccording to fate.
tgt_text.9351: That of the contraries, that which leads to production is called war and contest, and that which leads to he conflagration is called harmony and peace ;
tgt_text.9352: that change is he road leading upward, and the road leading downward;
tgt_text.9353: and that the whole world exists according to it.
tgt_text.9354: For that fire, when densified becomes liquid, and.
tgt_text.9356: again, that the water when con- rete is turned to earth, and that this is the road down;
tgt_text.9357: again, hat the earth itself becomes fused, from which water is pro- luced, and from that everything else is produced ;
tgt_text.9358: and then te refers almost everything to the evaporation which takes )lace from the sea;
tgt_text.9359: and this is the road which leads upwards.
tgt_text.9360: Also, that there are evaporations, both from earth and sea, some of which are bright and clear, and some are dark;
tgt_text.9361: .nd that the fire is increased by the dark ones, and the mois- ure by the others.
tgt_text.9362: But what the space which surrounds us s, he does not explain.
tgt_text.9363: He states, however, that there are essels in it, turned with their hollow part towards us;
tgt_text.9364: in vhich all the bright evaporations are collected, and form lames, which are the stars;
tgt_text.9365: and that the brightest of these lames, and the hottest, is the light of the sun;
tgt_text.9366: for that all he other stars are farther off from the earth;
tgt_text.9367: and that on his account, they give less light and warmth;
tgt_text.9368: and that the noon is nearer the earth, but does not move through a pure pace;
tgt_text.9369: the sun, on the other hand, is situated in a transparent pace, and one free from all admixture, preserving a well )roportioned distance from us, on which account it gives us nore light and more heat.
tgt_text.9370: And that the sun and moon are eclipsed, when the before-mentioned vessels are turned up- wards.
tgt_text.9371: And that the different phases of the moon take place very month, as its vessel keeps gradually turning round.
tgt_text.9372: Moreover, that day and night, and months and years, and ains and winds, and things of that kind, all exist according o, and are caused by, the different evaporations.
tgt_text.9373: For that the bright evaporation catching fire in the circle )f the sun causes day, and the predominance of the opposite ne causes night;
tgt_text.9374: and again, from the bright one the heat is ncreased so as to produce summer, and from the dark one the cold gains strength and produces winter;
tgt_text.9375: and he also explains the causes of the other phenomena in a correspond- ing manner.
tgt_text.9376: But with respect to the earth, he does not explain at all of what character it is, nor does he do so in the case of the vessels ;
tgt_text.9377: and these were his main doctrines.
tgt_text.9379: Now, what his opinion about Socrates was, and what expressions he used when he met with a treatise of his which Euripides brought him, according to the story told by Ariston, we have detailed in our account of Socrates.

tgt_text.9381: and that he said that he wanted some Delian diver who would not be drowned in it.
tgt_text.9382: And the book is described under several titles;
tgt_text.9383: some calling it the Muses, some a treatise on Nature;
tgt_text.9385: A well compacted helm to lead a man Straight through the path of life.

tgt_text.9399: but with me you shall have every kind of distinc- on and honour, and you shall enjoy every day honourable .d worthy conversation, and your pupils' life shall become rtuous, in accordance with your precepts.""
tgt_text.9400: All the men that exist in the world, are far removed from nth and just dealings ;
tgt_text.9401: but they are full of evil foolishness, rich leads them to insatiable covetousness and vain-glorious abition.
tgt_text.9402: I, however, forgetting all their worthlessness, and unning satiety, and who wish to avoid all envy on the part my countrymen, and all appearance of arrogance, will never me to Persia, since I am quite contented with a little, and re as best suits my own inclination."X.
tgt_text.9403: This was the way in which the man behaved even to the ng.
tgt_text.9404: And Demetrius, in his treatise on People of the same ame, says that he also despised the Athenians, among whom had a very high reputation.
tgt_text.9405: And that though he was him- elf despised by the Ephesians, he nevertheless preferred his vn home.
tgt_text.9406: Demetrius Phaleruus also mentions him in his efence of Socrates.
tgt_text.9408: There were many people who undertook.
tgt_text.9410: For Antisthenes and Heraclides, Ponticus, and leanthes, and Sphærus the Stoic;
tgt_text.9411: and besides them Pau- mias, who was surnamed Heraclitistes, and Nicomedes, and dionysius, all did so.

tgt_text.9413: and he says that the subject of the 3ok is not natural philosophy:
tgt_text.9415: and that all that said in it about natural philosophy, is only by way of illus- ation.
tgt_text.9416: And Hieronymus tells us, that a man of the name of cythenus, an iambic poet, attempted to render the book into erse.
tgt_text.9418: There are many epigrams extant which were written pon him, and this is one of them :
tgt_text.9419: — I who lie here am Heraclitus, spare me Ye rude unlettered men :
tgt_text.9420: 'Twas not for you That I did labour, but for wiser people.
tgt_text.9421: One man may be to me a countless host, And an unnumbered multitude be no one ;
tgt_text.9422: And this I still say in the shades below.
tgt_text.9423: And there is another expressed thus :
tgt_text.9425: Be not too hasty, skimming o'er the book Of Heraclitus ;
tgt_text.9426: 'tis a difficult road, For mist is there, and darkness hard to pierce.
tgt_text.9427: But if you have a guide who knows his system, Then everything is clearer than the sun.
tgt_text.9429: There were five people of the name of Heraclitus
tgt_text.9430: The first was this philosopher of ours.
tgt_text.9431: The second a lyri poet, who wrote a panegyrical hymn on the Twelve Gods
tgt_text.9432: The third was an Elegiac poet, of Halicarnassus;
tgt_text.9433: on whor Callimachus wrote the following epigram :
tgt_text.9434: — I heard, 0 Heraclitus, of your death, And the news filled my eyes with mournful tears, When I remembered all the happy hours
tgt_text.9435: When we with talk beguiled the setting sun.
tgt_text.9438: Of your sweet converse cloth and will survive;
tgt_text.9439: Nor can fell death, which all things else destroys, Lay upon that his ruthless conquering grasp.
tgt_text.9440: The fourth was a Lesbian, who wrote a history of Macedonia
tgt_text.9441: The fifth was a man who blended jest with earnest ;
tgt_text.9442: and wil having been a harp-player, abandoned that profession for serio-comic style of writing.
tgt_text.9443: I. XENOPHANES was the son of Dexius, or, as Apollodoru says, of Orthomenes.
tgt_text.9444: He was a citizen of Colophon ;
tgt_text.9447: — Xenophanes, not much a slave to vanity, The wise reprover of the tricks of Homer.
tgt_text.9448: He, having been banished from his own country, lived Zande, in Sicily, and at Cataua.
tgt_text.9450: And, according to the statements made by some people, he was a pupil of no one ;
tgt_text.9451: but, as others say, he was a pupil of Boton the Athenian;
tgt_text.9452: or, as another account again affirms, of Archelaus.
tgt_text.9453: He was, if we may believe Sotion, a contemporary of Anaxemander.
tgt_text.9455: He wrote poems in hexameter and in elegiac verse and also he wrote iambics against Hesiod and Homer, attacking the things said in their poems about the Gods'.
tgt_text.9456: He also used to recite his own poems.
tgt_text.9457: It is said likewise, that he argued against the opinions of Thales and Pythagoras, and that he also attacked Epimenides.
tgt_text.9458: He lived to an extreme old age ;
tgt_text.9460: - Threescore and seven long years are fully passed, Since first my doctrines spread abroad through Greece :
tgt_text.9461: And 'twixt that time and my first view of light Six lustres more must added be to them :
tgt_text.9462: If I am right at all about my age, Lacking but eight years of a century.
tgt_text.9463: His doctrine was, that there were four elements of existing things ;
tgt_text.9464: and an infinite number of worlds, which were all unchangeable.
tgt_text.9465: He thought that the clouds were produced by the vapour which was borne upwards from the sun, and which lifted them up into the circumambient space.
tgt_text.9466: That the essence of God was of a spherical form, in no respect resembling man ;
tgt_text.9467: that the universe could see, and that the universe could hear, but could not breathe ;
tgt_text.9468: and that it was in all its parts intellect, and wisdom, and eternity.
tgt_text.9469: He was the first person who asserted that everything which is produced is perishable, and that the soul is a spirit.
tgt_text.9470: He used also to say that the many was inferior to unity.
tgt_text.9471: Also, that we ought to associate with tyrants either as little as possible, or else as pleasantly as possible.
tgt_text.9472: When Empedocles said to him that the wise man was andiscoverable, he replied, " Very likely;
tgt_text.9473: for it takes a wise man to discover a wise man."
tgt_text.9474: And Sotion says, that he was the first person who asserted that everything is incomprehen- sible.
tgt_text.9475: But he is mistaken in this.
tgt_text.9476: Xenophanes wrote a poem on the Founding of Colophon ;
tgt_text.9477: and also, on the Colonisation of Elea, in Italy, consisting of two thousand verses.
tgt_text.9478: And he flourished about the sixtieth olympiad.
tgt_text.9480: Demetrius Phalereus, in his treatise on Old Age, and Phenætius the Stoic, in his essay on Cheerfulness, relate that he buried his sons with his own hands, as Anaxagoras had also done.
tgt_text.9481: And he seems to have been detested * by the Pythago- reans, Parmeniscus, and Orestades, as Phavorinus relates in the first book of his Commentaries.V.
tgt_text.9482: There was also another Xenophanes, a native of Lesbos, and an iambic poet.
tgt_text.9483: These are the Promiscuous or unattached philosophers.
tgt_text.9484: I. PARMENIDES, the son of Pyres, and a citizen of Velia was a pupil of Xenophanes.
tgt_text.9485: And Theophrastus, in his Abridgment, says that he was also a pupil of Anaximander However, though he was a pupil of Xenophanes, he was not afterwards a follower of his;
tgt_text.9486: but he attached himself to Aminias, and Diochartes the Pythagorean, as Sotion relates which last was a poor but honourable and virtuous man.
tgt_text.9487: Anc he it was whose follower he became, and after he was dead hE erected a shrine, or ήρῳ̑ον, in his honour.
tgt_text.9488: And so Parmenides who was of a noble family and possessed of considerable wealth, was induced, not by Xenophanes but by Aminias, t( embrace the tranquil life of a philosopher.
tgt_text.9490: He was the first person who asserted that the earth waf of a spherical form ;
tgt_text.9491: and that it was situated in the centre o the universe.
tgt_text.9492: He also taught that there were two elements fire and earth ;
tgt_text.9493: and that one of them occupies the place of thE maker, the other that of the matter.
tgt_text.9494: He also used to teacl that man was originally made out of clay ;
tgt_text.9495: and that they wer< composed of two parts, the hot and the cold ;
tgt_text.9496: of which, in fact everything consists.
tgt_text.9497: Another of his doctrines was, that th< mind and the soul were the same thing, as we are informe( by Theophrastus,' in his Natural Philosophy, when he enu- merates the theories of nearly all the different philosophers.
tgt_text.9498: He also used to say that philosophy was of a twofold character;
tgt_text.9499: one kind resting on certain truth, the other on opinion.
tgt_text.9500: On which account he says some wheie :
