tgt_text.10381: But with respect to those things as to which the dogmatic philosophers make positive assertions, saying that they are comprehended, we suspend our judgment on the ground of their being uncertain ;
tgt_text.10382: and we know nothing but the passions ;
tgt_text.10383: for we confess that we see, and we are aware that" we comprehend that such a thing is the fact;
tgt_text.10384: but we do not know how we see, or how we com- prehend.
tgt_text.10385: Also, we state in the way of narrative, that this appears white, without asserting possitively that it really is so.
tgt_text.10386: And with respect to the assertion, " We define nothing," and other sentences of that sort, we do not pronounce them as dogmas.
tgt_text.10387: For to say that is a different kind of statement from saying that the world is spherical;
tgt_text.10388: for the one fact is not evident, while the other statements are mere admissions.
tgt_text.10389: While, therefore, we say that we define nothing, we do not even say that as a definition.
tgt_text.10390: Again, the dogmatic philosophers say that the Sceptics over- throw all life, when they deny everything of which life consists.
tgt_text.10391: But the Sceptics say that they are mistaken ;
tgt_text.10392: for they do not deny that they see, but that they do not know how it is that they see.
tgt_text.10393: For, say they, we assert what is actually the fact, but we do not describe its character.
tgt_text.10394: Again, we feel that fire burns, but we suspend our judgment as to whether it has a burning nature.
tgt_text.10395: Also, we see whether a person moves, and that a man dies ;
tgt_text.10396: but how these things happen we know not.
tgt_text.10397: Therefore, say they, we only resist the uncertain deductions which are put by the side of evident facts.
tgt_text.10398: For when we say that an image has projections, we only state plainly what is evident;
tgt_text.10399: but when we say that it has not projections, we no longer say what appears evident, but something else.
tgt_text.10400: On which account Timon, in his Python, says that Pyrrho does not destroy the authority of custom.
tgt_text.10401: And in his Images he speaks thus :
tgt_text.10403: But what is evidently seen prevails, Wherever it may be.
tgt_text.10404: And in his treatise on the Senses, he says, " The reason why a thing is sweet I do not declare, but I confess that the fact of sweetness is evident."
tgt_text.10405: So too, Ænesidemus, in the first book of his Pyrrhonean Discourses, says that Pyrrho defines nothing dogmatically, on account of the possibility of contradiction, but that he is guided by what is evident.
tgt_text.10406: And he says the same thing in his book against Wisdom, and in his treatise on Investigation.
tgt_text.10407: In like manner, Zeuxis, a friend of Ænesidemus, in his treatise on Twofold Arguments, and Antiochus, of Laodicea, and Apellas, in his Agrippa, all declare nothing beyond what is evident.
tgt_text.10408: The criterion therefore, among the Sceptics, is that which is evident;
tgt_text.10410: and Epicurus says the same thing.
tgt_text.10411: But Democritus says, that there is no test whatever of appearances, and also that they are not criteria of truth.
tgt_text.10412: More- over, the dogmatic philosophers attack the criterion derived from appearances, and say that the same objects present at times different appearances;
tgt_text.10413: so that a town presents at one time a square, and at another a round appearance ;
tgt_text.10414: and that consequently, if the Sceptic does not discriminate between different appearances, he does nothing at all.
tgt_text.10415: If, on the contrary, he determines in favour of either, then, say they, he no longer attaches equal value to all appearances.
tgt_text.10416: The Sceptics reply to this, that in the presence of different appearances, they content themselves with saying that there are many appearances, and that it is precisely because things present themselves under different characters, that they affirm the existence of appearances.
tgt_text.10417: Lastly, the Sceptics say, that the chief good is the suspen- sion of the judgment which tranquillity of mind follows, like its shadow, as Timon and Ænesidemus say;
tgt_text.10418: for that we need not choose these things, or avoid those, which- all depend on ourselves:
tgt_text.10419: but as to those things which do not depend upon us, but upon necessity, such as hunger, thirst, and pain, those we cannot avoid;
tgt_text.10420: for it is not possible to put an end to them by reason.
tgt_text.10421: But when the dogmatic philosophers object that the Sceptic, on his principles, will not refuse to kill his own father, if he is ordered to do so ;
tgt_text.10422: so that they answer, that they can live very well without disquieting themselves about the specula- tions of the dogmatic philosophers;
tgt_text.10423: but, suspending their judgment in all matters which do not refer to living and the preservation of life.
tgt_text.10424: Accordingly, say they, we avoid some things, and we seek others, following custom in that;
tgt_text.10426: Some authors have asserted, that the chief good of the Stoics is impassibility;
tgt_text.10427: others say that it is mildness and tranquillity.
tgt_text.10429: APOLLONIDES, of Nicæa, a philosopher of our school, in the first book of his Commentaries on the Silli, which he dedicated to Tiberius Cæsar, says that Timon was the son of Timarchus, and a Phliasian by birth.
tgt_text.10430: And then, when he was young, he studied dancing, and afterwards he renounced that study, and went to Megara to Stilpo.
tgt_text.10431: And having spent some time there, he returned home again and married.
tgt_text.10432: Then he came with his wife to Elis, to see Pyrrho, and there he remained while his children were born;
tgt_text.10433: the elder of whom, he called Xanthus, and taught him medicine, and left him his successor in his sect of philosophy.
tgt_text.10434: And he was a man of considerable eminence, as Sotion tells us in his eleventh book.
tgt_text.10435: Afterwards, being in difficulty as to his means, he departed to the Hellespont and the Propontis;
tgt_text.10436: and living at Chalcedon as a Sophist, he earned a very high reputation and great popularity;
tgt_text.10437: from thence he departed, after having made a con- siderable fortune, and went to Athens, and remained there till his death, going across once for a short time to Thebes.
tgt_text.10438: He was also acquainted with king Antigonus, and with Ptolemy Philadelphus, as he himself testifies in his Iambics.
tgt_text.10440: He was, says Antigonus, fond of drinking, and he at times occupied himself with works quite inconsistent with philosophy;
tgt_text.10441: for he wrote lyric and epic poems, and tragedies and satiric dramas, and thirty comedies, and sixty tragedies and Silli, and amatory poems.
tgt_text.10442: There are works of his also enumerated in a regular catalogue, extending to twenty thousand verses, which are mentioned by Antigonus, of Carystos, who also wrote his life.
tgt_text.10443: Of the Silli, there are three volumes ;
tgt_text.10444: in which he attacks every one as if he were a Sceptic, and especially he lampoons the dogmatic philosophers under the form of parodies.
tgt_text.10445: The first volume of these Silli contain a long uninterrupted nar- ration ;
tgt_text.10446: but the second and third are in the form of dialogues.
tgt_text.10447: He is represented in them, as interrogating Xenophanes, the Colophonian, about every thing, and he utters a long con- tinued discourse;
tgt_text.10448: in his second book he speaks of the more ancient philosophers;
tgt_text.10449: and in his third of the more modern ones ;
tgt_text.10450: on which account some people have given the last book the name of the epilogue.
tgt_text.10451: But the first book contains the same subjects, with this dif- ference, that in that it is all confined to one single person ;
tgt_text.10452: and its first line begins thus :
tgt_text.10454: Come hither, all you over-busy Sophists.
tgt_text.10456: He died when he was nearly ninety years old, as Antigonus tells us;
tgt_text.10457: and Sotion, in his eleventh book;
tgt_text.10459: I have heard it said that he had only one eye, and, indeed, he used to call himself Cyclops.
tgt_text.10461: There was also another Timon, the misanthrope.
tgt_text.10463: Now this philosopher was very fond of a garden, and also of solitude, as we are told by Antigonus.
tgt_text.10464: Accordingly it is reported, that Hieronymus, the Peripatetic, said of him, as among the Scythians, both they who fly, and they who pursue shoot with the bow, so in the case of the philosophers, those who pursue and those who fly both hunt for pupils, as Timon for instance.
tgt_text.10466: He was a man of very acute perceptions, and very quick at seeing the ridiculous side of any question :
tgt_text.10467: he was also very fond of learning, and a very clever man at devising plots for poets, and at composing dramas.
tgt_text.10468: And he used to associate with himself, in the composition of his tragedies, two other poets, named Alexander and Homer ;
tgt_text.10469: and whenever he was disturbed by his maid-servants or by the dogs, he paid no attention to them, studying above all things to live in tran- quillity.
tgt_text.10470: They tell a story, that Aratus asked him how he could procure an entire and correct copy of Homer's poetry, and he answered, " If he could fall in with an old manuscript which had never been corrected."
tgt_text.10471: And all his works used to lie about at random, and at times half eaten by mice;
tgt_text.10472: so that once when he was reading them to Zopyrus, the orator, and unrolling a volume, he read whatever passages came first, and when he got to the middle of the book he found a great gap, which he had not previously perceived, so very indifferent was he about such matters.
tgt_text.10473: His constitution was so vigorous, that he could easily go without his dinner.
tgt_text.10474: And they say, that once when he saw Arcesilaus passing through the forum of the Cercipes, he said, "What are you doing here, where we freemen are?"
tgt_text.10475: And he used constantly to quote to those who invoked the testi- mony of their intellects to judge of the senses :
tgt_text.10477: *And this jesting manner was habitual with him.
tgt_text.10478: Accord- ingly he once said to a man, who was surprised at everything, " Why do you not wonder that we three men have only four eyes between us ? " for he himself had only one eye, no more had Dioscorides, his pupil;
tgt_text.10479: but the man to whom he was speaking had his sight unimpaired.
tgt_text.10480: On another occasion, he was asked by Arcesilaus, why he had come from Thebes, and he said, " To laugh at you all when I see you face to face."
tgt_text.10481: But though he attacked Arcesilaus in his Silli, he has praised him in the book entitled the Funeral Banquet of Arcesilaus.
tgt_text.10483: He had no successor, as Menodotus tells us;
tgt_text.10484: but his school ceased, till Ptolemy the Cyrenean re-established it.
tgt_text.10485: .According to the account given to us by Hippobotus and Sotion, he had as pupils, Dioscorides of Cyprus, and Nilolo- chus of Rhodes, and Euphranor of Seleucia, and Pracylus of the Troas, who was a mail of such constancy of mind that, as Phylarchus relates in his History, he allowed himself to be punished as a traitor wholly undeservedly, not uttering one word of complaint against his fellow citizens ;
tgt_text.10486: and Euphranor had for his pupil, Eubulus, of Alexandria, who was the master of Ptolemy, who was the master of Sarpedon and Heraclides.
tgt_text.10487: And Heraclides was the master of Ænesidemus, of Cnossus, who wrote eight books of Pyrrhonean discourses;
tgt_text.10488: he was also the master of Xeuxippus Polites, who was the master of Zeuxis Gonicpus, who was the master of Antiochus, of Laodicea, in Lycia.
tgt_text.10489: Antiochus again, was the master of Menodotus, of Nicomedia, a skilful physician, and of Theodos, of Laodicea;
tgt_text.10490: and Menodotus was the master of Herodotus, of Tarsus, the son of Arieus ;
tgt_text.10491: Herodotus was the master of Sex- tus Empiricus, who left ten books of Sceptic Maxims, and other excellent works;
tgt_text.10492: and Sextus was the master of Saturninus Cythenas, who was also an empiric.
tgt_text.10493: I. EPICURUS was an Athenian, and the son of Neocles and Chærestrate, of the burgh of Gargettus, and of the family of the Philaidæ, as Metrodorus tells us in his treatise on Nobility of Birth.
tgt_text.10494: Some writers, and among them Heraclides, in his Abridgment of Sotion, say, that as the Athenians had Colonis and Samos, he was brought up there, and came to Athens in his eighteenth year, while Xenocrates was president of the Academy, and Aristotle at Chalcis.
tgt_text.10495: But after the death of Alexander, the Macedonian, when the Athenians were driven out of Samos by Perdiccas, Epicurus went to Colophon to his father.
tgt_text.10497: And when he had spent some time there, and collected some disciples, he again returned to Athens, in the time of Anaxicrates, and for some time studied philosophy, mingling with the rest of the philosophers;
tgt_text.10498: but subsequently, he some how or other established the school which was called after his name;
tgt_text.10499: and he used to say, that he began to study philosophy, when he was fourteen years of age ;
tgt_text.10500: but Apollodorus, the Epicurean, in the first book of his account of the life of Epicurus, says, that he came to the study of philosophy, having conceived a great contempt for the grammarians, because they could not explain to him the statements in Hesiod respecting Chaos.
tgt_text.10501: But Hermippus tells us, that he himself was a teacher of grammar, and that afterwards, having met with the books of Democritus, he applied himself with zeal to philosophy, o.. which account Timon says of him.—
tgt_text.10502: The last of all the natural philosophers, And the most shameless too, did come from Samos, A grammar teacher, and the most ill-bred And most unmanageable of mankind.
tgt_text.10503: And he had for his companions in his philosophical studies, his three brothers, Neocles, Chæredemus, and Aristobulus, who were excited by his exhortations, as Philodemus, the Epicurean, relates in the tenth book of the Classification of Philosophers.
tgt_text.10504: He had also a slave, whose name was Inus, as Myronianus tells us in his Similar Historical Chapters.
tgt_text.10506: But Diotimus, the Stoic, was very hostile to him, and calumniated him in a most bitter manner, publishing fifty obscene letters, and attributing them to Epicurus, and also giving him the credit of the letters, which generally go under the name of Chrysippus.
tgt_text.10507: And Posidonius, the Stoic, and Nicolaus, and Sotion, in the twelfth of these books, which are entitled the Refutations of Diodes, of which there are altogether twenty-four volumes, and Dionysius, of Halicar- nassus, have also attacked him with great severity;
tgt_text.10508: for they say that he used to accompany his mother when she went about the small cottages, performing purifications, and that he used to read the formula, and that he used also to keep a school with his father at very low terms.
tgt_text.10509: Also, that he, as well as as one of his brothers, was a most profligate man in his morals, and that he used to live with Leontium, the courtesan.
tgt_text.10510: Moreover, that he claimed the books of Demo- critus on Atoms, and that of Aristippus on Pleasure, as his own;
tgt_text.10511: and that he was not a legitimate citizen;
tgt_text.10512: and this last fact is asserted also by Timocrates, and by Herodotus, in his treatise on the Youth of Epicurus.
tgt_text.10513: They also say that he used to flatter Mithras, the steward of Lysimachus, in a disgraceful manner, calling him in his letters Paean, and King;
tgt_text.10514: and also that he flattered Idomeneus, and Herodotus, and Timocrates who had revealed all his secret practices, and that he flattered them on this very account.
tgt_text.10515: And in his letters to Leontium, he says, " 0 king Apollo, my dear Leontium, what transports of joy did I feel when I read your charming letter."
tgt_text.10516: And to Themista, the wife of Leontius, he writes, " I am ready and prepared, if you do not come to me, to roll myself to wherever you and Themista invite me."
tgt_text.10517: And he addresses Pythocles, a beautiful youth, thus, " I will sit quiet," says he, " awaiting your longed for and god-like approach."
tgt_text.10518: And at another time, writing to Themista, he says, " That he had determined to make his way with her," as Theodorus tells us in the fourth book of his treatises against Epicurus.
tgt_text.10519: He also wrote to many other courtesans, and especially tc Leontium, with whom Metrodorus also was in love.
tgt_text.10520: And ic his treatise on the Chief Good, he writes thus, " For I do not know what I can consider good, if I put out of sight thE pleasures which arise from favours, and those which are derived from amatory pleasures, and from music, and from the contemplation of beauty."
tgt_text.10521: And in his letter to Pythocles, he writes, " And, my dear boy, avoid all sorts of education.
tgt_text.10523: Epictetus also attacks him as a most debauched man, and reproaches him most vehemently, and so does Timocrates, the brother of Metrodorus, in his treatise entitled the Merry Guests, and this Timocrates had been a disciple in his school, though he afterwards abandoned it;
tgt_text.10524: and he says that he used to vomit twice a day, in consequence of his intemperance ;
tgt_text.10525: and that he himself had great difficulty in escaping from this noc- turnal philosophy, and that mystic kind of re-union.
tgt_text.10526: He also accuses Epicurus of shameful ignorance in his reasoning, and still more especially in all matters relating to the conduct of life.
tgt_text.10527: And says that he was in a pitiable state of health, so that he could not for many years rise up from his sofa;
tgt_text.10528: and that he used to spend a minae a day on his eating, as he himself states in his letter to Leontium, and in that to the philosophers at Mitylene.
tgt_text.10529: He also says that many courtesans used to live with him and Metrodorus ;
tgt_text.10530: and among them Marmaricem, and Hedea, and Erotium, and Nicidium.
tgt_text.10532: And in the thirty-seven books which he wrote about natural philosophy, they say that he says a great many things of the same kind over and over again, and that in them he writes in contradiction of other philosophers, and especially of Nausiphanes, and speaks as follows, word for word :
tgt_text.10534: But if any one else ever was afflicted in such a manner, then certainly this mail had a continual labour, striving to bring forth the sophistical boastfulness of his mouth, like many other slaves."
tgt_text.10535: And Epicurus also speaks of Nausiphanes in his letters, in the following terms :
tgt_text.10537: These things led him on to such arrogance of mind, that he abused me and called me a schoolmaster."
tgt_text.10538: He used also to call him Lungs, and Blockhead, and Humbug, and Fornicator.
tgt_text.10539: And he used to call Plato's followers Flat.
tgt_text.10540: terers of Dionysius, but Plato himself he called Golden.
tgt_text.10541: Aristotle he called a debauchee and a glutton, saying that he joined the army after he had squandered his patrimony, and sold drugs.
tgt_text.10542: He used also to call Protagoras a porter, and the secretary of Democritus, and to say that he taught boys their etters in the streets.
tgt_text.10546: t rhe Cynics he called enemies of Greece ;
tgt_text.10547: and the Dialecticians ne charged with being eaten up with envy.
tgt_text.10548: Pyrrho, he said, vas ignorant and unlearned.
tgt_text.10550: But these men who say this are all wrong, for there are lenty of witnesses of the unsurpassable kindness of the man o every body ;
tgt_text.10551: both his own country which honoured him with razen statues, and his friend who were so numerous that they ould not be contained in whole cities;
tgt_text.10552: and all his acquaint- nces who were bound to him by nothing but the charms of his octrine, none of whom ever deserted him, except Metrodo- us, the soil of Stratoniceus, who went over to Carneades, robably because he was not able to bear with equanimity the napproachable excellence of Epicurus.
tgt_text.10553: Also, the perpetual accession of his school, which, when every other school decayed, ontinued without any falling off, and produced a countless umber of philosophers, succeeding one another without any iterruption.
tgt_text.10554: We may also speak here of his gratitude towards is parents, and his beneficence to his brothers, and his entleness to his servants (as is plain from his will, and from ne fact too, that they united with him in his philosophical ;
tgt_text.10555: udies, and the most eminent of them was the one whom I ave mentioned already, named Inus);
tgt_text.10556: and his universal hilanthropy towards all men.
tgt_text.10557: His piety towards the Gods, and his affection for his country as quite unspeakable ;
tgt_text.10558: though, from an excess of modesty, he voided affairs of state.
tgt_text.10559: And though he lived when very ifficult times oppressed Greece, he still remained in his wn country, only going two or three times across to Ionia > see his friends, who used to throng to him from all quarters, nd to live with him in his garden, as we are told by Apol- dorus.
tgt_text.10560: (This garden he bought for eighty minæ.)
tgt_text.10562: And Diodes, in the third book of his Excursion, says that they all lived in the most simple and economical manner "
tgt_text.10563: They were content," says he, " with a small cup of ligh wine, and all the rest of their drink was water."
tgt_text.10564: He alsi tells us that Epicurus would not allow his followers to throv their property into a common stock, as Pythagoras did, wh( said that the possessions of friends were held in common
tgt_text.10565: For he said that such a doctrine as that was suited rathe] for those who distrusted one another;
tgt_text.10566: and that those wh< distrusted one another were not friends.
tgt_text.10567: But he himsel in his letters, says that he is content with water and plair bread, and adds, "Send me some Cytherean cheese, that if ] wish to have a feast, I may have the means."
tgt_text.10568: This was th( real character of the man who laid down the doctrine that pleasure was the chief good ;
tgt_text.10569: whom Athenæus thus mentions in an epigram:
tgt_text.10570: - 0 men, you labour for pernicious ends;
tgt_text.10571: And out of eager avarice, begin Quarrels and wars.
tgt_text.10572: And yet the wealth of nature Fixes a narrow limit for desires, Though empty judgment is insatiable.
tgt_text.10573: This lesson the wise child of Neocles Had learnt by heart, instructed by the Muses, Or at the sacred shrine of Delphi's God.
tgt_text.10574: And as we advance further, we shall learn this fact from his dogmas, and his apophthegms.
tgt_text.10576: Of all the ancient philosophers he was, as we are told by Diodes, most attached to Anaxagoras k'although in some points he argued against him) ;
tgt_text.10577: and to Archelaus, the master of Socrates.
tgt_text.10578: And he used, Diodes adds, to accustom his pupils to preserve his writings in their memory.
tgt_text.10579: Apollodorus, in his Chronicles, asserts that he was a pupil of Nausiphanes, and Praxiphanes ;
tgt_text.10580: but he himself does not mention this ;
tgt_text.10581: but says in his letter to Euridicus, that he had been his own instructor.
tgt_text.10582: He also agreed with Hermarchus in not admitting that Leucippus deserved to be called a philosopher;
tgt_text.10583: though some authors, among whom his Apollodorus, speak of him as the master of Democritus.
tgt_text.10584: Demetrius, the Magnesian, says that he was a pupil of Xenocrates also.
tgt_text.10586: He uses in his works plain language with respect to anything he is speaking of, for which Aristophanes, the gram- marian, blames him, on the ground of that style being vulgar.
tgt_text.10587: But he was such an admirer of perspicuity, that even in his treatise on Rhetoric, he aims at and recommends nothing but clearness of expression.
tgt_text.10588: And in his letters, instead of the usual civil expressions, " Greeting," " Farewell," and so on, he substitutes, " May you act well," "May you live virtuously," and expressions of that sort.
tgt_text.10589: Some of his biographers assert that it was he who composed the treatise entitled the Canon, in imitation of the Tripod of Nausiphanes, whose pupil they say that he was, and add that he was also a pupil of Pamphilus, the Platonist, at Samoa.
tgt_text.10591: They further tell us that he began to study philosophy at twelve years of age, and that he presided over his school thirty-two years.
tgt_text.10592: And he was born as we are told by Apollo- dorus, in his Chronicles, in the third year of the hundred and ninth olympiad, in the archonship of Sosigenes, on the seventh day of the month Gamelion, seven years after the death of Plato.
tgt_text.10593: And when he was thirty-two years of age, he first set up his school at Mitylene, and after that at Lampsacus;
tgt_text.10594: and when he had spent five years in these two cities, he came to Athens ;
tgt_text.10595: and he died there in the second year of the hundred and twenty-seventh olympiad, in the archonship of Pytharatus, when he had lived seventy-two years.
tgt_text.10596: And Hermarchus, the son of Agemarchus, and a citizen of Mitylene, succeeded him in his school.
tgt_text.10597: He died of the stone, as Hermarchus mentions in his letters, after having been ill a fortnight;
tgt_text.10598: and at the end of the fort- night, Hermippus says that he went into a brazen bath, properly tempered with warm water, aud asked for a cup of pure wine and drank it;
tgt_text.10599: and having recommended his friends to remember his doctrines, he expired.
tgt_text.10600: And there is an epigram of ours on him, couched in the following language :
tgt_text.10602: Now, fare-ye-well, remember all my words;
tgt_text.10603: This was the dying charge of Epicurus :
tgt_text.10604: Then to the bath he went, and drank some wine, And sank beneath the cold embrace of Pluto.
tgt_text.10605: Such was the life of the man, and such was his death.X.
tgt_text.10606: And he made his will in the following terms :
tgt_text.10608: "According to this my will, I give all my possessions to Amynomachus, of Bate, the son of Philocrates, and to Timo- crates, of Potamos, the son of Demetrius;
tgt_text.10609: according to the deed of gift to each, which is deposited in the temple < Cybele;
tgt_text.10610: on condition that they make over my garden and a that is attached to it to Hermarchus, of Mitylene, the son < Agemarchus ;
tgt_text.10611: and to those who study philosophy with hin and to whomsoever Hermarchus leaves as his successors in hi school, that they may abide and dwell in it, in the study an practice of philosophy;
tgt_text.10612: and I give it also to all those wh philosophize according to my doctrines, that they may, to th best of their ability, maintain my school which exists in m garden, in concert with Amynomachus and Timocrates ;
tgt_text.10614: I enjoin their heirs to do the same in the most perfect an secure manner that they can ;
tgt_text.10615: so that they also may maintain my garden, as those also shall to whom my immediatesuces sors hand it down.
tgt_text.10616: As for the house in Melita, that Amyno machus and Timocrates shall allow Hermarchus that he may live in it during his life, together with all his companions in philosophy."
tgt_text.10617: Out of the income which is derived from that property which is here bequeathed by me to Amynomachus and Timo crates, I will that they, consulting with Hermarchus, shall arrange in the best manner possible the offerings to the manes in honour of the memory of my father, and mother, and brothers, and myself, and that my birth-day may be kept as it has been in the habit of being kept, on the tenth day of the month Gamelion ;
tgt_text.10618: and that the re-union of all the philosophers of our school, established in honour of Metrodorus and myself, may take place on the twentieth day of every month.
tgt_text.10619: They shall also celebrate, as I have been in the habit of doing myself, the day consecrated to my brothers, in the month Poseideon;
tgt_text.10620: and the day consecrated to the memory of Polyænus, in the month Metageitnion.
tgt_text.10621: "Amynomachus and Timocrates, shall be the guardians of Epicurus, the son of Metrodorus, and of the son of Polyænus, as long as they study philosophy under, and live with, Hermar- elms.
tgt_text.10622: In the same way also, they shall be the guardians of the daughter of Metrodorus, and when she is of marriageable age, they shall give her to whomsoever Hermarchus shall select of his companions in philosophy, provided she is well behaved and obedient to Hermarchus.
tgt_text.10623: And Amynomachus and Timo- crates shall, out of my income, give them such a sum for their support as shall appear sufficient year by year, after due consultation with Hermarchus.
tgt_text.10624: And they shall associate Hermarchus with themselves in the management of my revenues, in order that everything may be done with the approval of that man who has grown old with me in the study of philosophy, and who is now left as the president of all those who have studied philosophy with us.
tgt_text.10625: And as for the dowry for the girl when she is come to marriageable age, let Amyno- machus and Timocrates arrange that, taking for the purpose such a sum from my property as shall seem to them, in con- junction with Hermarchus, to be reasonable.
tgt_text.10626: And let them also take care of Nicanor, as we ourselves have done ;
tgt_text.10627: in order that all those who have studied philosophy with us, and who have assisted us with their means, and who have shown great friendship for us, and who have chosen to grow old with us in the study of philosophy, may never be in want of anything as far as our power to prevent it may extend."
tgt_text.10628: I further enjoin them to give all my books to Hermarchus;
tgt_text.10629: and, if anything should happen to Hermarchus before the children of Metrodorus are grown up, then I desire that Amynomachus and Timocrates, shall take care that, provided they are well behaved, they shall have everything that is necessary for them, as far as the estate which I leave behind me shall allow such things to be furnished to them.
tgt_text.10630: And the same men shall also take care of everything else that I have enjoined ;
tgt_text.10631: so that it may all be fulfilled, as far as the case may permit."
tgt_text.10632: Of my slaves, I hereby emancipate Inns, and Nicias, and Lycon :
tgt_text.10633: I also give Phædrium her freedom.
tgt_text.10634: "And when he was at the point of death, he wrote the following letter to Idomeneus :
tgt_text.10636: We have written this letter to you on a happy day to us, which is also the last day of our life.
tgt_text.10637: For strangury has attacked me, and also a dysentery, so violent that nothing can be added to the violence of my sufferings.
tgt_text.10638: But the cheerfulness of my mind, which arises from the recollection of all my philosophical contemplations, counterbalances all these afflictions.
tgt_text.10639: And I beg you to take care of the children of (Metrodorus, in a manner worthy of the devotion shown by the youth to me, and to philosophy.
tgt_text.10640: "Such then as I have given it, was his will.
tgt_text.10642: He had a great number of pupils, of whom the most eminent were Metrodorus, the Athenian, and Timocrates, and Sandes, of Lampsacus ;
tgt_text.10643: who, from the time that he first became acquainted with him, never left him, except once when he weni home for six months ;
tgt_text.10644: after which he returned to him.
tgt_text.10645: And he was a virtuous man in every respect, as Epicurus tells us ii his Fundamental Principles.
tgt_text.10646: And he also bears witness tc his virtue in the third book of his Timocrates.
tgt_text.10647: And being man of this character, he gave his sister Bates in marriage to Idomeneus ;
tgt_text.10648: and he himself had Leontium, the Attic courtesan, for his concubine.
tgt_text.10649: He was very unmoved at all disturbances, and even at death;
tgt_text.10650: as Epicurus tells us, in the first book of his Metrodorus.
tgt_text.10651: He is said to have died seven years before Epicurus himself, in the fifty-third year of his age.
tgt_text.10652: And Epicurus himself, in the will which I have given above, gives!
tgt_text.10653: many charges about the guardianship of his children, showing by this that he had been dead some time.
tgt_text.10654: He also had a brother whom I have mentioned before, of the name of Timo- crates, a trifling, silly man.
tgt_text.10655: The writings of Metrodorus are these.
tgt_text.10656: Three books addressed to the Physicians ;
tgt_text.10660: one on the Illness of Epicurus ;
tgt_text.10663: one on the Road to Wisdom;
tgt_text.10669: Likewise Polyænus, of Lampsacus, the son of Atheno- dorus, was a man of mild and friendly manners, as Philodemus particularly assures us.
tgt_text.10671: And his successor was Hermarchus, of Mitylene, the son of Agemarchus, a poor man ;
tgt_text.10672: and his favourite pursuit was rhetoric.
tgt_text.10673: And the following excellent works of his are extant.
tgt_text.10674: Twenty-two books of letters about Empedocles;
tgt_text.10678: And he died of paralysis, being a most eminent man.
tgt_text.10680: There was also Leontius, of Lampsacus, and his wife Themista, to whom Epicurus wrote.
tgt_text.10682: There were also Colotes and Idomeneus;
tgt_text.10683: and these also were natives of Lampsacus.
tgt_text.10684: And among the most eminent philosophers of the school of Epicurus, were Polystratus, who succeeded Hermarchus, and Dionysius who succeeded him, and Basilides who succeeded him.
tgt_text.10685: Likewise Apollodorus, who was nicknamed the tyrant of the gardens (ϰηποτύϱαννος), was a very eminent man, and wrote more than four hundred books.
tgt_text.10686: And there were the two Ptolemies of Alexandria, Ptolemy the Black, and Ptolemy the Fair.
tgt_text.10687: And Zeno, of Sidon, a pupil of Apollodorus, a very voluminous author;
tgt_text.10688: and Demetrius, who was surnamed the Lacedæmonian;
tgt_text.10689: and Diogenes, of Tarsus, who wrote the Select Dialogues;
tgt_text.10690: and Orion, and others whom the genuine Epicureans call Sophists.
tgt_text.10692: There were also three other persons of the name of Epicurus;
tgt_text.10693: first, the son of Leonteus and Themista ;
tgt_text.10697: And Epicurus was a most voluminous author.
tgt_text.10698: exceeding all men in the number of his books ;
tgt_text.10699: for there are more than three hundred volumes of them :
tgt_text.10700: and in the whole of them there is not one citation from other sources, but they are filled wholly with the sentiments of Epicurus himself.
tgt_text.10701: In the quantity of his writings he was rivalled by Chrysippus, as Carneades asserts, who calls him a parasite of the books of Epicurus ;
tgt_text.10702: for if ever this latter wrote anything, Chrysippus immediately set his heart on writing a book of equal size ;
tgt_text.10703: and in this way he often wrote the same thing over again;
tgt_text.10704: putting down whatever came into his head ;
tgt_text.10705: and he published it all without any corrections, by reason of his haste.
tgt_text.10706: And he quotes such numbers of testimonies from other authors, that his books are entirely filled with them alone;
tgt_text.10707: as one may find also in the works of Aristotle and Zeno.
tgt_text.10708: Such then, and so numerous are the works of Epicurus;
tgt_text.10709: the chief of which are the following.
tgt_text.10711: one on Atoms, and the Vacuum;
tgt_text.10713: an abridgment of the Arguments employed against the Natural Philosophers;
tgt_text.10714: Doubts in Contradiction of the Doctrines of the Megarians;
tgt_text.10716: a treatise on Choice and Avoidance;
tgt_text.10718: another on the Criterion, called also the Canon;
tgt_text.10719: the Chæridemus, a treatise on the Gods;
tgt_text.10730: one on the Angle in an Atom;
tgt_text.10741: one on Justice and the other Virtues ;
tgt_text.10744: the Timocrates, a treatise in three books;
tgt_text.10754: And I will endeavour to give an abridgment of the doctrines contained in these works, as it may be agreeable, quoting three letters of his, in which he has made a sort of epitome of all his philosophy.
tgt_text.10755: I will also give his fundamental and peculiar opinions, and any apophthegms which he uttered which appear worthy of being selected.
tgt_text.10756: So that you may be thoroughly acquainted with the man, and may also judge that I understand him.
tgt_text.10757: Now the first letter is one that he wrote to Herodotus, on the subject of Natural Philosophy;
tgt_text.10758: the second is one that he wrote to Pythocles, which is about the Heavenly Bodies ;
tgt_text.10759: the third is addressed to Menæceus, and in that there are contained the discussions about lives.
tgt_text.10760: We must now begin with the first, after having said a little by way of preface concerning the divisions of philosophy which he adopted.
tgt_text.10762: Now he divides philosophy into three parts.
tgt_text.10763: The canonical, the physical, and the ethical.
tgt_text.10764: The canonical, which serves as an introduction to science, is contained in the single treatise which is called the Canon.
tgt_text.10765: The physical embraces the whole range of speculation on subjects of natural philoso- phy, and is contained in the thirty-seven books on nature, and in the letters again it is discussed in an elementary manner.
tgt_text.10766: The ethical contains the discussions on Choice and Avoidance ;
tgt_text.10767: and is comprised in the books about lives, and in some of the Letters, and in the treatise on the Chief Good.
tgt_text.10768: Accordingly, most people are in the habit of combining the canonical divi- sion with the physical;
tgt_text.10769: and then they designate the whole under the names of the criterion of the truth, and a discussion on principles, and elements.
tgt_text.10770: And they say that the physical division is conversant about production, and destruction, and nature;
tgt_text.10771: and that the ethical division has reference to the objects of choice and avoidance, and lives, and the chief good of mankind.
tgt_text.10773: Dialectics they wholly reject as superfluous.
tgt_text.10774: For they say that the correspondence of words with things is sufficient for the natural philosopher, so as to enable him to advance with certainty in the study of nature.
tgt_text.10775: Now, in the Canon, Epicurus says that the criteria of truth are the senses, and the preconceptions, and the passions.
tgt_text.10776: But the Epicureans, in general, add also the perceptive impressions of the intellect.
tgt_text.10777: And he says the same thing in his Abridg- ment, which he addresses to Herodotus, and also in his Funda- mental Principles.
tgt_text.10778: For, says he, the senses are devoid of reason, nor are they capable of receiving any impressions of memory.
tgt_text.10779: For they are not by themselves the cause of any motion, and when they have received any impression from any external cause, then they can add nothing to it, nor can they subtract anything from it.
tgt_text.10780: Moreover, they are out of the reach of any control ;
tgt_text.10781: for one sensation cannot judge of another which resembles itself;
tgt_text.10782: for they have all an equal value.
tgt_text.10783: Nor can one judge of another which is different from itself;
tgt_text.10784: since their objects are not identical.
tgt_text.10785: In a word, one sensation cannot control another, since the effects of all of them influence us equally.
tgt_text.10786: Again, the reason cannot pronounce on the senses ;
tgt_text.10787: for we have already said that all reasoning has the senses for its foundation.
tgt_text.10788: Reality and the evidence of sensation establish the certainty of the senses ;
tgt_text.10789: for the impressions of sight and hearing are just as real, just as evident, as pain.
tgt_text.10790: It follows from these considerations that we ought to judge of things which are obscure by their analogy to those which we perceive directly.
tgt_text.10791: In fact, every notion proceeds from the senses, either directly, or in consequence of some analogy, or proportion, or combination.
tgt_text.10792: Reasoning having always a share in these last operations.
tgt_text.10793: The visions of insanity and of sleep have a real object, for they act upon us;
tgt_text.10794: and that which has no reality can produce no action.
tgt_text.10796: By preconception, the Epicureans mean a sort of comprehension as it were, or right opinion, or notion, or general idea which exists in us;
tgt_text.10797: or, in other words, the recollection of an external object often perceived anteriorly.
tgt_text.10798: Such for instance, is this idea:
tgt_text.10799: " Man is a being of such and such a nature."
tgt_text.10800: At the same moment that we utter the word man, we conceive the figure of a man, in virtue of a preconception which we owe to the preceding operations of the senses.
tgt_text.10801: Therefore, the first notion which each word awakens in us is a correct one;
tgt_text.10802: in fact, we could not seek for anything if we had not previously some notion of it.
tgt_text.10803: To enable us to affirm that what we see at a distance is a horse or an ox, we must have some preconception in our minds which makes us ac- quainted with the form of a horse and an ox.
tgt_text.10804: We could not give names to things, if we had not a preliminary notion of what the things were.
tgt_text.10806: These preconceptions then furnish us with certainty.
tgt_text.10807: And with respect to judgments, their certainty depends on our referring them to some previous notion, of itself certain, in virtue of which we affirm such and such a judgment;
tgt_text.10808: for instance, " How do we know whether this thing is a man?
tgt_text.10810: And say that it is at times true, and at times false;
tgt_text.10811: for that, if it is supported by testimony, and not contradicted by testi- mony, then it is true ;
tgt_text.10812: but if it is not supported by testimony, and is contradicted by testimony, then it is false.
tgt_text.10813: On which account they have introduced the expression of " waiting," as if, before pronouncing that a thing seen is a tower, we must wait till we come near, and learn what it looks like when we are near it.
tgt_text.10815: They say that there are two passions, pleasure and pain, which affect everything alive.
tgt_text.10816: And that the one is natural, and the other foreign to our nature ;
tgt_text.10817: with reference to which all objects of choice and avoidance are judged of.
tgt_text.10818: They say also, that there are two kinds of investigation ;
tgt_text.10819: the one about facts, the other about mere words.
tgt_text.10820: And this is as far as an elementary sketch can go-their doctrine about division, and about the criterion.
tgt_text.10822: Let us now go to the letter:
tgt_text.10824: For those, 0 Herodotus, who are not able accurately to comprehend all the things which I have written about nature, nor to investigate those larger books which I have composed on the subject, I have made an abridgment of the whole discus- sion on this question, as far as I thought sufficient to enable them to recollect accurately the most fundamental points ;
tgt_text.10825: that so, on all grave occasions, they might be able to assist themselves on the most important and undeniable principles ;
tgt_text.10826: in proportion as they devoted themselves to speculations on natural philosophy.
tgt_text.10827: And here it is necessary for those who have made sufficient progress in their view of the general question, to recollect the principles laid down as elements of the whole discussion ;
tgt_text.10828: for we have still greater need of a correct notion of the whole, than we have even of an accurate under standing of the details.
tgt_text.10829: We must, therefore, give preference to the former knowledge, and lay up in our memory those principles on which we may rest, in order to arrive at an exact perception of things, and at a certain knowledge of particular objects."
tgt_text.10830: Now one has arrived at that point when one has thoroughly embraced the conceptions, and, if I may so express myself, the most essential forms, and when one has impressed them adequately on one's senses.
tgt_text.10831: For this clear and precise know- ledge of the whole, taken together, necessarily facilitates one's particular perceptions, when one has brought one's ideas back to the elements and simple terms.
tgt_text.10832: In short, a veritable synthesis, comprising the entire circle of the phenomena of the universe, ought to be able to resume in itself, and in a few words, all the particular facts which have been previously studied.
tgt_text.10833: This method being useful even to those who are already familiarised with the laws of the universe, I recom- mend them, while still pursuing without intermission the study of nature, which contributes more than anything else to the tranquillity and happiness of life, to make a concise state- ment or summary of their opinions."
tgt_text.10834: First of all, then, Herodotus, one must determine with exactness the notion comprehended under each separate word, in order to be able to refer to it, as to a certain criterion, the conceptions which emanate from ourselves, the ulterior re- searches and the difficulties;
tgt_text.10835: otherwise the judgment has no foundation.
tgt_text.10836: One goes on from demonstration to demonstration ad infinitum ;
tgt_text.10837: or else one gains nothing beyond mere words.
tgt_text.10838: In fact, it is absolutely necessary that in every word we should perceive directly, and without the assistance of any demonstra- tion, the fundamental notion which it expresses, if we wish to have any foundation to which we may refer our researches, our difficulties, and our personal judgments, whatever in other respects may be the criterion which we adopt, whether we take as our standard the impressions produced on our senses, or the actual impression in general;
tgt_text.10839: or whether we cling to the idea by itself, or to any other criterion.
tgt_text.10840: "We must also note carefully the impressions which we receive in the presence of objects, in order to bring ourselves back to that point in the circumstances in which it is ne- cessary to suspend the judgment, or even when the question is about things, the evidence of which is not immediately per- ceived."
tgt_text.10841: When these foundations are once laid we may pass to the study of those things, the evidence of which is not immediate.
tgt_text.10842: And, first of all, we must admit that nothing can come of that which does not exist;
tgt_text.10843: for, were the fact otherwise, then every thing would be produced from everything, and there would be no need of any seed.
tgt_text.10844: And if that which disappeared were so absolutely destroyed as to become non-existent, then every thing would soon perish, as the things with which they would be dissolved would have no existence.
tgt_text.10845: But, in truth, the universal whole always was such as it now is, and always will be such.
tgt_text.10846: For there is nothing into which it can change ;
tgt_text.10847: for there is nothing beyond this universal whole which can penetrate into it, and produce any change in it.
tgt_text.10849: (And Epicurus establishes the same principles at the beginning of the great Abridgment;
tgt_text.10850: and in the first book of his treatise on Nature.)* “ Now the universal whole is a body;
tgt_text.10851: for our senses bear us witness in every case that bodies have a real existence ;
tgt_text.10852: and the evidence of the senses, as I have said before, -ought to be the rule of our reasonings about everything which is not directly perceived.
tgt_text.10853: Otherwise, if that which we call the vacuum, or space, or intangible nature, had not a real existence, there would be nothing on which the bodies could be contained, or across which they could move, as we see that they really do move.
tgt_text.10854: Let us add to this reflection that one cannot conceive, either in virtue of perception, or of any analogy founded on perception, Any general quality pe- culiar to all beings which is not either an attribute, or an accident of the body, or of the vacuum.
tgt_text.10856: (The same principles are laid down in the first, and four- teenth, and fifteenth book of the treatise on Nature ;
tgt_text.10857: and also in the Great Abridgment.)"
tgt_text.10858: Now, of bodies, some are combinations, and some the elements out of which these combinations are formed.
tgt_text.10859: These last are indivisible, and protected from every kind of trans- formation ;
tgt_text.10860: otherwise everything would be resolved into non- existence.
tgt_text.10861: They exist by their own force, in the midst of the dissolution of the combined bodies, being absolutely full, and as such offering no handle for destruction to take hold of.
tgt_text.10862: It follows, therefore, as a matter of absolute necessity, that the principles of things must be corporeal, indivisible elements."
tgt_text.10864: For that which is finite has an extreme, and that which has an extreme is looked at in relation to something else.
tgt_text.10865: Consequently, that which has not an extreme, has no boundary;
tgt_text.10866: and if it has no boundary, it must be infinite, and not terminated by any limit.
tgt_text.10867: The universe then is infinite, both with reference to the quantity of bodies of which it is made up, and to the magnitude of the vacuum ;
tgt_text.10868: for if the vacuum were infinite, the bodies being finite, then, the bodies would not be able to rest in any place ;
tgt_text.10869: they would be transported about, scattered across the infinite vacuum for want of any power to steady themselves, or to keep one another in their places by mutual repulsion.
tgt_text.10870: If, on the other hand, the vacuum were finite, the bodies being infinite, then the bodies clearly could never be contained in the vacuum.
tgt_text.10872: the atoms which form the bodies, these full elements from which the combined bodies come, and into which they resolve themselves, assume an incalculable variety of forms, for the numerous differences which the bodies present cannot possibly result from an aggregate of the same forms.
tgt_text.10873: Each variety of forms contains an infinity of atoms, but there is not for that reason an infinity of atoms;
tgt_text.10874: it is only the number of them which is beyond all calculation.
tgt_text.10876: (Epicurus adds, a little lower down, that divisibility, ad in- finitum, is impossible;
tgt_text.10877: for, says he, the only things which change are the qualities;
tgt_text.10878: unless, indeed, one wishes to pro- ceed from division to division, till one arrives absolutely at infinite littleness.)"
tgt_text.10879: The atoms are in a continual state of motion.
tgt_text.10881: (He says, farther on, that they move with an equal rapidity from all eternity, since the vacuum offers no more resistance to the lightest than it does to the heaviest.)
tgt_text.10882: "Among the atoms, some are separated by great distances, others come very near to one another in the formation of com- bined bodies, or at times are enveloped by others which are combining;
tgt_text.10883: but in this latter case they, nevertheless, preserve their own peculiar motion, thanks to the nature of the vacuum, which separates the one from the other, and yet offers them no resistance.
tgt_text.10884: The solidity which they possess causes them, while knocking against one another, to re-act the one upon the other;
tgt_text.10885: till at last the repeated shocks bring on the disso- lution of the combined body;
tgt_text.10886: and for all this there is no external cause, the atoms and the vacuum being the only causes.
tgt_text.10888: (He says, further on, that the atoms have no peculiar quality of their own, except from magnitude and weight.
tgt_text.10889: As to colour, he says in the twelfth book of his Principia, that it varies according to the position of the atoms.
tgt_text.10890: Moreover, he does not attribute to the atoms any kind of dimensions ;
tgt_text.10891: and, accordingly, no atom has ever been perceived by the senses;
tgt_text.10892: but this expression, if people only recollect what is here said, will by itself offer to the thoughts a sufficient image of the nature of things.)"
tgt_text.10893: But, again, the worlds also are infinite, whether they re- semble this one of ours or whether they are different from it.
tgt_text.10894: For, as the atoms are, as to their number, infinite, as I have proved above, they necessarily move about at immense dis- tances ;
tgt_text.10895: for besides, this infinite multitude of atoms, of which the world is formed, or by which it is produced, could not be entirely absorbed by one single world, nor even by any worlds, the number of which was limited, whether we suppose them like this world of ours, or different from it.
tgt_text.10896: There is, there- fore, no fact inconsistent with an infinity of worlds."
tgt_text.10897: Moreover, there are images resembling, as far as their form goes, the solid bodies which we see, but which differ materially from them in the thinness of their substance.
tgt_text.10898: In fact it is not impossible but that there may be in space some secretions of this kind, and an aptitude to form surfaces without depth, and of an extreme thinness;
tgt_text.10899: or else that from the solids there may emanate some particles which preserve the connection, the disposition, and the motion which they had in the body.
tgt_text.10900: I give the name of images to these representations;
tgt_text.10901: and, indeed, their movement through the vacuum taking place, without meeting any obstacle or hindrance, perfects all imaginable extent in an inconceivable moment of time;
tgt_text.10902: for it is the meeting of obstacles, or the absence of obstacles, which pro- duces the rapidity or the slowness of their motion.
tgt_text.10903: At all events, a body in motion does not find itself, at any moment imaginable, in two places at the same time;
tgt_text.10905: From whatever point of infinity it arrives at some appreciable moment, and whatever may be the spot in its course in which we perceive its motion, it has evidently quitted that spot at the moment of our thought;
tgt_text.10906: for this motion which, as we have admitted up to this point, encounters no obstacle to its rapidity, is wholly in the same condition as that the rapidity of which is diminished by the shock of some resistance.
tgt_text.10907: "It is useful, also, to retain this principle, and to know that the images have an incomparable thinness;
tgt_text.10908: which fact indeed is in no respect contradicted by sensible appearances.
tgt_text.10909: From which it follows that their rapidity also is incomparable ;
tgt_text.10910: for they find everywhere an easy passage, and besides, their infinite smallness causes them to experience no shock, or at all events to experience but a very slight one, while an infinite multitude of elements very soon encounter some resistance."
tgt_text.10911: One must not forget that the production of images is simul- taneous with the thought;
tgt_text.10912: for from the surface of the bodies images of this kind are continually flowing off in an insen- 3ible manner indeed, because they are immediately replaced.
tgt_text.10913: They preserve for a long time the same disposition, and the same arrangement that the atoms do in the solid body, although, notwithstanding, their form may be sometimes altered.
tgt_text.10914: The direct production of images in space is equally instantaneous, because these images are only light substances lestitute of depth."
tgt_text.10915: But there are other manners in which natures of this kind ire produced;
tgt_text.10916: for there is nothing in all this which at all contradicts the senses, if one only considers in what way the senses are exercised, and if one is inclined to explain the -elation which is established between external objects and ourselves.
tgt_text.10917: Also, one must admit that something passes from external objects into us in order to produce in us sight and the knowledge of forms;
tgt_text.10918: for it is difficult to conceive that external objects can affect us through the medium of the air which is between us and them, or by means of rays, whatever emissions proceed from us to them, so as to give us an im- pression of their form and colour.
tgt_text.10919: This phenomenon, on the contrary, is perfectly explained, if we admit that certain images of the same colour, of the same shape, and of a proportionate magnitude pass from these objects to us, and so arrive at being seen and comprehended.
tgt_text.10921: by an exceeding rapidity, and, as on the other side, the send object forming a compact mass, and comprising a vast quantity of atoms, emits always the same quantity of particles, the vision is continued, and only produces in us one single per- ception which preserves always the same relation to the object.
tgt_text.10922: Every conception, every sensible perception which bears upon the form or the other attributes of these images, is only the same form of the solid perceived directly, either in virtue of a sort of actual and continued condensation of the image, or in consequence of the traces which it has left in us.
tgt_text.10923: Error and false judgments always depend upon the suppo- sition that a preconceived idea will be confirmed, or at all events will not be overturned, by evidence.
tgt_text.10924: Then, when it is not confirmed, we form our judgment in virtue of a sort of initiation of the thoughts connected, it is true with the per- ception, and with a direct representation ;
tgt_text.10925: but still connected also with a conception peculiar to ourselves, which is the parent of error.
tgt_text.10926: In fact the representations which intelligence reflects like a mirror, whether one perceives them in a dream, or by any other conceptions of the intellect, or of any other of the criteria, can never resemble the objects that one calls real and true, unless there were objects of this kind perceived directly.
tgt_text.10927: And, on the other side, error could not be possible, if we did not receive some other motion also, a sort of initiative of intelligence connected;
tgt_text.10928: it is true with direct representa- tion, but going beyond that representative.
tgt_text.10929: These con- ceptions being connected with the direct perception which produces the representation, but going beyond it, in consequence of a motion peculiar to the individual thought, produces error when it is not confirmed by evidence, or when it is con- tradicted by evidence:
tgt_text.10930: but when it is confirmed, or when it is not contradicted by evidence, then it produces truth.
tgt_text.10931: "We must carefully preserve these principles in order not to reject the authority of the faculties which perceive truth directly;
tgt_text.10932: and not, on the other hand, to allow what is false to be established with equal firmness, so as to throw everything into confusion."
tgt_text.10933: Moreover, hearing is produced by some sort of current pro- ceeding from something that speaks, or sounds, or roars, or in any manner causes any sort of audible circumstance.
tgt_text.10934: And thin current is diffused into small bodies resembling one another in their parts ;
tgt_text.10935: which, preserving not only some kind of rela- tion between one another, but even a sort of particular identity with the object from which they emanate, puts
tgt_text.10936: Is, very fre- quently, into a communication of sentiments with this object, or at least causes us to become aware of the existence of some external circumstance.
tgt_text.10937: If these currents did not carry with them some sort of sympathy, then there would be no such per- ception.
tgt_text.10938: We must not therefore think that it is the air which receives a certain form, under the action of the voice or of some other sound.
tgt_text.10939: For it is utterly impossible that the voice should act in this manner on the air.
tgt_text.10940: But the per cussion produced in us when we, by the utterance of a voice, cause a disengagement of certain particles, constitutes a current resembling a light whisper, and prepares an acoustic feeling for us.“
tgt_text.10941: We must admit that the case of smelling is the same as that of hearing.
tgt_text.10942: There would be no sense of smell if there did not emanate from most objects certain particles capable of producing an impression on the smell.
tgt_text.10943: One class being ill-suited to the organ, and consequently producing a disordered state of it, the other being suited to it, and causing it no distress.“
tgt_text.10944: One must also allow, that the atoms possess no one of the qualities of sensible objects, except form, weight, magnitude, and anything else is unavoidably inherent in form ;
tgt_text.10945: in fact, every quality is changeable, but the atoms are necessarily unchangeable;
tgt_text.10946: for it is impossible but that in the dissolution of combined bodies, there must be something which continues solid and indestructible, of such a kind, that it will not change either into what does riot exist, or out of what does not exist;
tgt_text.10947: but that it results either from a simple displace ment of parts, which is the most usual case, or from the addition or subtraction of certain particles.
tgt_text.10948: It follows from that, that that which does not admit of any change in itself, is imperishable, participates in no respect in the nature oi changeable things, and in a word, has its dimensions and forms immutably determined.
tgt_text.10949: And this is proved plainly enough, because even in the transformations which take place under our eyes, in consequence of the retrenchment of certain parts, we can still recognise the form of these constituent parts;
tgt_text.10950: while those qualities, which are not constituent parts, do not remain like the form, but perish in the dissolution of the combination.
tgt_text.10951: The attributes which we have indicated, suffice to explain all the differences of combined bodies;
tgt_text.10952: for we must inevitably leave something indestructible, lest every- thing should resolve itself into non-existence.
tgt_text.10953: "However, one must not believe that every kind of magni- tude exists in atoms, lest we find ourselves contradicted by phenomena.
tgt_text.10954: But we must admit that there are atoms of different magnitude, because, as that is the case, it is then more easy to explain the impressions and sensations ;
tgt_text.10955: at all events, I repeat, it is not necessary for the purpose of explain- ing the differences of the qualities, to attribute to atoms every kind of magnitude.“
tgt_text.10956: We must not suppose either, that an atom can become visible to us ;
tgt_text.10957: for, first of all, one does not see that that is the case, and besides, one cannot even conceive, how an atom is to become visible;
tgt_text.10958: besides, we must not believe, that in a finite body there are particles of every sort, infinite in num- ber ;
tgt_text.10959: consequently, one must not only reject the doctrine of in- finite divisibility in parcels smaller and smaller, lest we should be reducing everything to nothing, and find ourselves forced to admit, that in a mass composed of a crowd of elements, exist- ence can reduce itself to non-existence.
tgt_text.10960: But one cannot even suppose that a finite object can be susceptible of transforma- tions ad infinitum, or even of transformation into smaller objects than itself;
tgt_text.10961: for when once one has said that there are in an object particles of every kind, infinite in number, there is absolutely no means whatever of imagining that this object can have only a finite magnitude;
tgt_text.10962: in fact, it is evident that these particles, infinite in number, have some kind of dimen- sion or other, and whatever this dimension may be in other respects, the objects which are composed of it will have an infinite magnitude;
tgt_text.10963: in presenting forms which are deter- mined, and limits which are perceived by the senses, one con- ceives, easily, without its being necessary to study this last question directly, that this would be the consequence of the contrary supposition, and that consequently, one must come to look at every object as infinite."
tgt_text.10964: One must also admit, that the most minute particle per- ceptible to the sense, is neither absolutely like the objects which are susceptible of transformation, nor absolutely differ- ent from them.
tgt_text.10965: It has some characteristics in common with the object which admit of transformation, but it also differs from them, inasmuch as it does not allow any distinct parts to be discerned in it.
tgt_text.10966: When then, in virtue of these common characteristics, and of this resemblance, we wish to form an idea of the smallest particle perceptible by the senses, in taking the objects which change for our terms of comparison, it is necessary that we should seize on some characteristic common to these different objects.
tgt_text.10967: In this way, we examine them successively, from the first to the last, not by themselves, nor as composed of parts in juxtaposition, but only in their extent;
tgt_text.10968: in other words, we consider the magnitudes by them- selves, and in an abstract manner, inasmuch as they measure, the greater a greater extent, and the smaller a smaller extent.
tgt_text.10969: This analogy applies to the atom, as far as we consider it as having the smallest dimensions possible.
tgt_text.10970: Evidently by its minuteness, it differs from all sensible objects, still this analogy is applicable to it;
tgt_text.10971: in a word, we establish by this comparison, that the atom really has some extent, but we exclude all considerable dimensions, for the sake of only investing it with the smallest proportions.*
tgt_text.10972: “ We must also admit, in taking for our guide, the reasoning which discourses to us things which are invisible to the senses, that the most minute magnitudes, those which are not com- pound magnitudes, and which from the limit of sensible extent, are the first measure of the other magnitudes which are only called greater or less in their relation to the others.
tgt_text.10973: For these relations which they maintain with these particles, which are not subject to transformation, suffice to give them this characteristic of first measure.
tgt_text.10974: But they cannot, like atoms, combine themselves, and form compound bodies in virtue of any motion belonging to themselves."
tgt_text.10975: Moreover, we must not say (while speaking of the infinite), that such or such a point is the highest point of it, or the lowest.
tgt_text.10976: For height and lowness must not be predicated of the infinite.
tgt_text.10977: We know, in reality, that if, wishing to determine the infinite, we conceive a point above our head, this point, whatever it may be, will never appear to us to have the cha- racter in question:
tgt_text.10978: otherwise, that which would be situated above the point so conceived as the limit of the infinite, would be at the same moment, and by virtue of its relation to the same point, both high and low;
tgt_text.10979: and this is impossible to imagine."
tgt_text.10980: It follows that thought can only conceive that one single movement of transference, from low to high, ad infinitum;
tgt_text.10981: and one single movement from high to low.
tgt_text.10982: From low to high, when even the object in motion, going from us to the places situated above our heads, meets ten thousand times with the feet of those who are above us;
tgt_text.10983: and from high to low, when in the same way it advances towards the heads of those who are below us.
tgt_text.10984: For these two movements, looked at by themselves and in their whole, are conceived as really opposed the one to the other, in their progress towards the infinite."
tgt_text.10985: Moreover, all the atoms are necessarily animated by the same rapidity, when they move across the vacuum, or when no obstacle thwarts them.
tgt_text.10986: For why should heavy atoms have a more rapid movement than those which are small and light, since in no quarter do they encounter any obstacle ?
tgt_text.10987: Why, on e other hand, should the small atoms have a rapidity superior that of the large ones, since both the one and the other nd everywhere an easy passage, from the very moment that o obstacle intervenes to thwart their movements ?
tgt_text.10988: Move- lent from low to high, horizontal movement to and fro, in irtue of the reciprocal percussion of the atoms, movement ownwards, in virtue of their weight, will be all equal, for in hatever sense the atom moves, it must have a movement as ipid as the thought, till the moment when it is repelled, in irtue of some external cause, or of its own proper weight, by he shock of some object which resists it."
tgt_text.10989: Again, even in the compound bodies, one atom does not love more rapidly than another.
tgt_text.10990: In fact, if one only looks t the continued movement of an atom which takes place in a indivisible moment of time, the briefest possible, they all ave a movement equally rapid.
tgt_text.10991: At the same time, an atom as not, in any moment perceptible to the intelligence, a con- inued movement in the same direction;
tgt_text.10992: but rather a series f oscillating movements from which there results, in the last nalysis, a continued movement perceptible to the senses.
tgt_text.10993: f then, one were to suppose, in virtue of a reasoning on hings invisible, that, in the intervals of time accessible to bought, the atoms have a continued movement one would eceive one's self, for that which is conceived by the thought is rue as well as that which is directly perceived."
tgt_text.10994: Let us now return to the study of the affections, and of the ensations;
tgt_text.10995: for this will be the best method of proving that he soul is a bodily substance composed of slight particles, iffused over all the members of the body, and presenting a reat analogy to a sort of spirit, having an admixture of heat, esembling at one time one, and at another time the other of hose two principles.
tgt_text.10996: There exists in it a special part, endowed rith an extreme mobility, in consequence of the exceeding lightness of the elements which compose it, and also in eference to its more immediate sympathy with the rest of the ody.
tgt_text.10997: That it is which the faculties of the soul sufficiently rove, and the passions, and the mobility of its nature, and he thoughts, and, in a word, everything, the privation of which s death.
tgt_text.10998: We must admit that it is in the soul most especially hat the principle of sensation resides.
tgt_text.10999: At the same time, it ould not possess this power if it were not enveloped by the rest of the body which communicates it to it, and in its turn receives it from it;
tgt_text.11000: but only in a certain measure;
tgt_text.11001: for there are certain affections of the soul of which it is not capable.“
tgt_text.11002: It is on that account that, when the soul departs, the body is no longer possessed of sensation ;
tgt_text.11003: for it has not this power, (that of sensation namely) in itself;
tgt_text.11004: but, on the other hand, this power can only manifest itself in the soul through the medium of the body.
tgt_text.11005: The soul, reflecting the manifestations which are accomplished in the substance which environs it, realises in itself, in a virtue or power which belongs to it, the sensible affections, and immediately communicates them to the body in virtue of the reciprocal bonds of sympathy which unite it to the body ;
tgt_text.11006: that is the reason why the destruction of a part of the body does not draw after it a cessation of all feeling in the soul while it resides in the body, provided that the senses still preserve some energy ;
tgt_text.11007: although, nevertheless, the disso- lution of the corporeal covering, or even of any one of its portions, may sometimes bring on with it the destruction of the soul."
tgt_text.11008: The rest of the body, on the other hand, even when it remains, either as a whole, or in any part, loses all feeling by the dispersion of that aggregate of atoms, whatever it may be, that forms the soul.
tgt_text.11009: When the entire combination of the body is dissolved, then the soul too is dissolved, and ceases to retain those faculties which were previously inherent in it, and espe- dally the power of motion ;
tgt_text.11010: so that sensation perishes equally as far as the soul is concerned ;
tgt_text.11011: for it is impossible to imagine j that it still feels, from the moment when it is no longer in the1 same conditions of existence, and no longer possesses the same movements of existence in reference to the same organic system;
tgt_text.11012: from the moment, in short, when the things which cover and surround it are no longer such, that it retains in them the same movements as before.
tgt_text.11013: (Epicurus expresses the same ideas in other works, and adds that the soul is composed of atoms of the most perfect light- ness and roundness ;
tgt_text.11014: atoms wholly different from those of fire.
tgt_text.11015: He distinguishes in it the irrational part which is diffused over the whole body, from the rational part which has its seat in the chest, as is proved by the emotions of fear and joy.
tgt_text.11016: He adds that sleep is produced when the parts of the soul diffused over the whole of the body concentre themselves, or when they disperse and escape by the pores of the body;
tgt_text.11017: for particles emanate from all bodies.)"
tgt_text.11018: It must also be observed, that I use the word incorporeal (ἀσώματος) in the usual acceptation of the word, to express that which is in itself conceived as such.
tgt_text.11019: Now, nothing can- be conceived in itself as incorporeal except the vacuum;
tgt_text.11020: but the vacuum cannot be either passive or active;
tgt_text.11021: it is only the condition and the place of movement.
tgt_text.11022: Accordingly, they who pretend that the soul is incorporeal, utter words destitute of sense;
tgt_text.11023: for, if it had this character, it would not be able either to do or to suffer anything ;
tgt_text.11024: but, as it is, we see plainly enough that it is liable to both these circumstances."
tgt_text.11025: Let us then apply all these reasonings to the affections and sensations, recollecting the ideas which we laid down at the beginning, and then we shall see clearly that these general principles contain an exact solution of all the particular cases."
tgt_text.11026: As to forms, and hues, and magnitudes, and weight, and the other qualities which one looks upon as attributes, whether it be of every body, or of those bodies only which are visible and perceived by the senses, this is the point of view under which they ought to be considered :
tgt_text.11027: they are not particular sub- stances, having a peculiar existence of their own, for that cannot be conceived ;
tgt_text.11028: nor can one say any more that they have no reality at all.
tgt_text.11029: They are not incorporeal substances inherent in the body, nor are they parts of the body.
tgt_text.11030: But they consti- tute by their union the eternal substance and the essence of the entire body.
tgt_text.11031: We must not fancy, however, that the body is composed of them, as an aggregate is formed of particles of the smallest dimensions of atoms or magnitudes, whatever they may be, smaller than the compound body itself;
tgt_text.11032: they only constitute by their union, I repeat, the eternal substance of the body.
tgt_text.11033: Each of these attributes has ideas and particular perceptions which correspond to it;
tgt_text.11034: but they cannot be per- ceived independently of the whole subject taken entirely;
tgt_text.11035: the union of all these perceptions forms the idea of the body.
tgt_text.11036: Bodies often possess other attributes which are not eternally inherent in them, but which, nevertheless, cannot be ranged among the incorporeal and invisible things.
tgt_text.11037: Accordingly, it is sufficient to express the general idea of the movement of transference to enable us to conceive in a moment certain Distinct qualities, and those combined beings, which, being taken in their totality, receive the name of bodies;
tgt_text.11038: and the necessary and eternal attributes without which the body cannot i be conceived."
tgt_text.11039: There are certain conceptions corresponding to these attri- butes ;
tgt_text.11040: but, nevertheless, they cannot be known abstractedly, and independently of some subjects ;
tgt_text.11041: and further, inasmuch as they are not attributes necessarily inherent in the idea of a body, one can only conceive them in the moment in which they are visible ;
tgt_text.11043: and one must not refuse them being an existence merely because they have neither the characteristic of the compound beings to which we give the name of bodies, nor that of the eternal attributes.
tgt_text.11044: We should be equally deceived if we were to suppose that they have a separate and independent existence ;
tgt_text.11045: for that is true neither of them nor of the eternal attributes.
tgt_text.11046: They are, as one sees plainly, accidents of the body ;
tgt_text.11047: accidents which do not of necessity make any part of its nature;
tgt_text.11048: which cannot be considered as independent substances, but still to each of which sensation gives the peculiar character under which it appears to us."
tgt_text.11049: Another important question is that of time.
tgt_text.11050: Here we cannot apply any more the method of examination to which we submit other objects, which we study with reference to a given subject;
tgt_text.11051: and which we refer to the preconceptions which exist in ourselves.
tgt_text.11052: We must seize, by analogy, and going round the whole circle of things comprised under this general, denomination of time—we must seize, I say-that essential character which causes us to say that a time is long or short.
tgt_text.11053: It is not necessary for that purpose to seek for any new forms of expression as preferable to those which are in common use ;
tgt_text.11054: we may content ourselves with those by which time is usually indicated.
tgt_text.11055: Nor need we, as certain philosophers do.
tgt_text.11056: affirm any particular attribute of time, for that would be to suppose that its essence is the same as that of this attribute.
